A. Whenever in this code or in any ordinance of the city any act is prohibited or is made or declared to be
unlawful or an offense, or whenever in this code or any ordinance the doing of any act is required or the
failure to do any act is declared to be unlawful, where no specific penalty is provided therefor, the violation of
any such provision of this code or any ordinance shall be punishable by a fine of not less than fifty dollars
6/5/2019 Sterling Codifiers, Inc.
https://www.sterlingcodifiers.com/codebook/index.php?book_id=502 41/767
($50.00) nor more than seven hundred fifty dollars ($750.00)1. Each day that a violation is permitted to exist
shall constitute a separate offense.
B. Notwithstanding the provisions of subsection A of this section, upon any prosecution for any violation of any
section of this code, the court may, in lieu of or in addition to any other penalty or finding, impose
"supervision", being a disposition of conditional and revocable release without probationary supervision, but
under such conditions and reporting requirements as may be imposed by the court.
1. In the event conditions and/or reporting requirements of supervision shall be required by the court, such
conditions and reporting requirements shall be entered by the court by order deferring future proceedings
in the case and specifying any or all of the following:
a. The period of supervision (reasonable under all circumstances of the case):
(1) Up to two (2) years from the date of entry of the order; and/or
(2) Requirement that the defendant:
(A) Make a report to and appear in person before or participate with the court or such courts, person
or social service agency as directed by the court in the order of supervision;
(B) Pay a fine and costs;
(C) Work or pursue a course of study or vocational training;
(D) Undergo medical or psychiatric treatment or treatment for drug addiction or alcoholism;
(E) Attend or reside in a facility established for the instruction or residence of defendants on
probation;
(F) Support his dependents;
(G) Refrain from possessing a firearm or other dangerous weapon;
(H) And in addition, if a minor:
(i) Reside with his parents or in a foster home;
(ii) Attend school;
(iii) Attend a nonresidential program for youth; and
(iv) Contribute to his own support.
(I) Make restitution or reparation in an amount not to exceed actual loss or damage to property and
pecuniary loss. The court shall determine the amount and conditions of payment; and/or
6/5/2019 Sterling Codifiers, Inc.
https://www.sterlingcodifiers.com/codebook/index.php?book_id=502 42/767
(J) Perform some reasonable public service work such as, but not limited to, the picking up of litter in
public parks or along public highways or the maintenance of public facilities.
2. In the event the court enters an order of supervision, if the court thereafter determines that the defendant
has successfully complied with all of the conditions of supervision, the court shall discharge the defendant
and enter a judgment dismissing the charge. Discharge and dismissal upon a successful conclusion of a
disposition of supervision shall be deemed without adjudication of guilt and shall not be termed a
conviction for purposes of disqualification or disabilities imposed by law upon conviction of a
misdemeanor.
3. No person assigned to a public service employment program shall be considered an employee for any
purpose, nor shall the mayor or city council be obliged to provide any compensation to such person.
4. A disposition of supervision is a final order for the purpose of appeal.
C. For purposes of this section, "court" means any court of competent jurisdiction and the system of
administrative adjudication of the city of Countryside created by chapter 12 of this title. (Ord. 12-10-0, 2-25-
2012)
1-4-2: APPLICATION OF PROVISIONS:
The penalty provided in this chapter shall be applicable to every section of this code the same as though it were
a part of each and every separate section. Any person convicted of a violation of any section of this code where
any duty is prescribed or obligation imposed, or where any action which is of a continuing nature is forbidden or
is declared to be unlawful, shall be deemed guilty of a misdemeanor. A separate offense shall be deemed
committed upon each day such duty or obligation remains unperformed or such act continues, unless otherwise
specifically provided in this code.
In all cases where the same offense is made punishable or is created by different clauses or sections of this
code, the prosecuting officer may elect under which to proceed; but not more than one recovery shall be had
against the same person for the same offense; provided, that the revocation of a license or permit shall not be
considered a recovery or penalty so as to bar any other penalty being enforced.
Whenever the doing of any act or the omission to do any act constitutes a breach of any section or provision of
this code and there shall be no fine or penalty specifically declared for such breach, the provisions of this
chapter shall apply. (1986 Code)
1-4-3: LIABILITY OF OFFICERS:
No provision of this code designating the duties of any officer or employee shall be so construed as to make
such officer or employee liable for any fine or penalty provided for a failure to perform such duty, unless the
intention of the city council to impose such fine or penalty on such officer or employee is specifically and clearly
expressed in the section creating the duty. (1986 Code)
1-4-4: ABATEMENT OF CODE VIOLATIONS:
A. In addition to any fine or other penalty, the city may, in all appropriate cases, seek and obtain an order of
court directing the abatement of any violation of this code by the person which has created, continued or
allowed such violation to exist; the city may also seek and obtain an order of court permitting it to abate such
violation upon failure of such person to do so, for any other reason deemed appropriate by the court.
6/5/2019 Sterling Codifiers, Inc.
https://www.sterlingcodifiers.com/codebook/index.php?book_id=502 43/767
B. The expense of any such abatement on the part of the city shall be paid by and collected from, any person
which has created, continued or allowed such violation to exist. (Ord. 90-44-0, 10-24-1990)
1-4-5: ENFORCEMENT OF FINES:
A. Whenever a fine assessed against any person, firm or corporation shall remain unpaid for more than thirty
(30) days from the date said person, firm or corporation was notified of the assessment of said fine, the
following shall occur: The office of the city clerk or the city police department, as the case may be, shall so
notify the city attorney who shall then proceed to enforce such fine by such legal means, including legal
action, as he shall determine most appropriate. This enactment shall constitute continuing authority for the
city attorney to so act with regard to any such matter referred to him until such time as this authority is
specifically revoked by legislative act of the city council.
B. For the purposes of this section, notification of the assessment of a fine may be given by personal delivery or
by mailing the same to the person, firm or corporation against whom such fine is assessed by regular United
States mail addressed to the last known address of such person, firm or corporation, postage prepaid.
When notification is by mail, the date of deposit in the United States mail shall be considered the date of
notification. (Ord. 04-30-0, 7-28-2004)
C. That prior to the issuance of any license, certificate and/or permit required pursuant to the laws and
ordinances of the city of Countryside, the city clerk, or his/her duly designated agent, shall ascertain that
there are no unpaid charges for water service, other municipal services or any other municipal fees, fines,
judgments, levies or debts then due and unpaid. No such license, certificate or permit shall be approved or
issued until such time as the applicant presents to the appropriate department a certificate of the city clerk,
or his/her duly designated agent, indicating that all charges, fees, assessments, fines, judgments, levies or
debts, owed to the city have been paid in full. (Ord. 11-59-0, 9-28-2011)
Chapter 5
MAYOR AND CITY COUNCIL
ARTICLE A. MAYOR
1-5A-1: ELECTION AND TERM OF OFFICE:
The mayor shall be elected and hold office for four (4) years and until his successor is elected and has
qualified, as provided by statute1. He shall be the chief executive officer of the city. (1970 Code §2-3.01)
1-5A-2: BOND AND OATH:
Before entering upon the duties of his office, the mayor shall give a bond as provided in section 1-6-3 of this
title and he shall take the oath of office as prescribed by section 1-6-2 of this title. (1970 Code §2-3.10)
1-5A-3: COMPENSATION:
The mayor shall receive the sum of nine thousand six hundred dollars ($9,600.00) per annum as compensation
for his or her office, and in addition, he or she shall receive the sum of one thousand dollars ($1,000.00) a year
as liquor commissioner. (Ord. 96-39-0, 8-28-1996)
6/5/2019 Sterling Codifiers, Inc.
https://www.sterlingcodifiers.com/codebook/index.php?book_id=502 44/767
1-5A-4: POWERS AND DUTIES:
A. Message To Council: The mayor shall perform all the duties which are prescribed by law, including the city
ordinances, and shall take care that the laws and ordinances are faithfully executed. He may, from time to
time, and annually shall give the city council information relative to the affairs of the city, and may
recommend for their consideration such measures as he believes expedient. (1970 Code §2-3.02)
B. Presiding Officer: He shall preside at all meetings of the city council. (1970 Code §2-3.03)
C. Appointment Or Removal Of Officers:
1. He shall appoint, by and with the advice and consent of the city council, all officers of the city whose
appointment is not otherwise provided for by the laws of this state or the provisions of this code.
Whenever a vacancy shall occur in any office which by law he is empowered to fill, the mayor shall, within
thirty (30) days after the occurrence of such vacancy, communicate to the city council the name of his
appointee to such office.
2. He may remove any officer appointed by him, under this code, on any formal charges, whenever he is of
the opinion that the interests of the city demand removal, but such removal shall be as authorized by law.
3. In order to prevent a stoppage of public business, to meet extraordinary exigencies, or to prevent material
impairment to the city, the mayor may make temporary appointments of officers, to remain in force until
regular appointments may be made under the provisions of this code, but no such temporary appointment
shall exceed sixty (60) days. No temporary appointment of any one person shall be made more than twice
in any calendar year. (Ord. 12-34-0, 4-25-2012)
D. Examination Of Records: He may, at all times, examine and inspect the books, records and papers of any
agent, employee or officer of the city. (1970 Code §2-3.05)
E. Release Of Prisoners: He may release any person imprisoned for violation of any city ordinance, and shall
report the release, with reasons therefor, to the council at its first session thereafter. (1970 Code §2-3.06)
F. Ordinance Enforcement: In addition to the duties, powers and functions vested in him by statute as the chief
executive officer of the city and those specifically vested in him by the provisions of this code, he shall have
authority to act, or to designate the officer who shall act, in the enforcement of any ordinance of the city in all
cases where an ordinance fails to specify the officer who shall be charged with the duty of enforcement.
(1970 Code §2-3.09)
1-5A-5: SIGNATURE REQUIRED:
The mayor's signature shall appear on all licenses and permits granted by the authority of the city council
except as otherwise provided by law or provisions of this code. The mayor may designate another to affix the
signature of the mayor to any written instrument, which is required to be signed by the mayor in the manner
provided by law. (1970 Code §2-3.08)
1-5A-6: CONTINUITY OF GOVERNMENT:
In the event that the city mayor is unavailable in an emergency, the powers of the office shall be exercised and
duties shall be discharged by his designated emergency interim successors in the order specified. The
emergency interim successor shall exercise the powers and discharge the duties of the office to which
6/5/2019 Sterling Codifiers, Inc.
https://www.sterlingcodifiers.com/codebook/index.php?book_id=502 45/767
designated until such time as a vacancy which may exist shall be filled in accordance with the constitution or
statutes; or until the officer, or his deputy or a preceding emergency interim successor, again becomes
available to exercise the powers and discharge the duties of his office. The line of succession for the executive
branch of government will be:
Mayor
City administrator
Chief of police
ESDA coordinator
(Ord. 05-04-0, 1-26-2005)
ARTICLE B. ALDERMEN
1-5B-1: ELECTION AND FUNCTIONS:
The City Council shall consist of six (6) Aldermen who shall be elected to office for a four (4) year term
according to the method provided by statute1. The Aldermen shall perform such duties and have such powers
as may be delegated to them by statute. (1970 Code §2-4.01)
1-5B-2: WARDS:
Two (2) Aldermen shall be elected to represent each of the three (3) wards of the City, which are described as
follows:
A. First Ward: All that part of the City lying east of the center line of LaGrange Road.
B. Second Ward: All that part of the City lying south of the center line of Joliet Road.
C. Third Ward: All that part of the City lying west of the center line of LaGrange Road and north of the center
line of Joliet Road.
A detailed land description of the three (3) wards and a map showing the same shall be and remain on file in
the office of the City Clerk. (1970 Code §2-4.01, as amended)
1-5B-3: OATH:
Before entering upon their duties as Aldermen, each Alderman shall take and subscribe the oath prescribed by
Section 1-6-2 of this Title. (1970 Code §2-4.02)
1-5B-4: COMPENSATION:
Each Alderman whose term of office commences after the consolidated election of April 1, 1997, shall receive
an annual salary of seven thousand two hundred dollars ($7,200.00). Each Alderman whose term of office
commenced prior to said election shall receive an annual salary of six thousand dollars ($6,000.00). (Ord. 96-
39-0, 8-28-1996)
6/5/2019 Sterling Codifiers, Inc.
https://www.sterlingcodifiers.com/codebook/index.php?book_id=502 46/767
ARTICLE C. COUNCIL MEETINGS
1-5C-1: COMPOSITION AND GENERAL REQUIREMENTS:
The city council shall consist of the mayor and aldermen. It shall sit with open doors, and shall keep minutes of
its meetings. It shall keep a journal of its own proceedings. (1970 Code §2-2.01; amd. 1986 Code)
1-5C-2: REGULAR AND SPECIAL MEETINGS:
A. Regular Meetings: Regular meetings of the city council shall be held on the second and fourth Wednesdays
of each month at seven thirty o'clock (7:30) P.M. at the city hall, 5550 East Avenue, unless otherwise
ordered at a regular meeting. (Ord. 88-37-0, 9-28-1988)
B. Special Meetings: Special meetings of the city council may be held at any time on call of the mayor or any
three (3) aldermen. Written notice shall be issued at least twenty four (24) hours previous by the clerk, in
accordance with subsection 1-6B-3D of this title, stating the time and place of holding such special meeting,
and the purpose for which it is called, and stating the names of the members requesting such call. The clerk
shall cause such notice to be served by any police officer of the city, or other authorized person, by
delivering to and leaving with each of them personally at their place of residence, abode or business
address, a correct copy of same; provided, that such special meeting may be called at any previous regular
meeting, by a majority vote of the council, without further notice; and further provided that if all members are
present at a special meeting, no notice of such meeting is necessary. (1970 Code §2-2.03)
1-5C-3: NOTICE OF MEETINGS:
In addition to any notice requirement prescribed by the city council, public notice of meetings shall be given as
prescribed by statute1. (1970 Code §2-2.04)
1-5C-4: QUORUM:
Three (3) aldermen and the mayor or four (4) aldermen shall constitute a quorum to do business. A smaller
number of the council, however, may adjourn from time to time and may compel the attendance of absentees.
(1970 Code §2-2.05)
1-5C-5: COMPELLING ATTENDANCE:
Should less than a quorum of the council be present at any regular or special meeting, at the time and place
appointed, such minority may instruct the city clerk to send immediate notice to any absent alderman that can
be found, commanding him to appear immediately at such meeting, and any alderman receiving such notice
and not obeying the same, without reasonable excuse, shall be subject to a fine of not less than twenty five
dollars ($25.00) nor more than fifty dollars ($50.00), for each and every offense. (1970 Code §2-2.06; amd.
1986 Code)
1-5C-6: RULES AND PROCEDURES:
6/5/2019 Sterling Codifiers, Inc.
https://www.sterlingcodifiers.com/codebook/index.php?book_id=502 47/767
A. Adoption Of Robert's Rules Of Order Newly Revised: The city council hereby adopts "Robert's Rules Of
Order Newly Revised", 10th edition, as its rules and procedures and to govern the conduct of all meetings of
the city council and committees thereof. Notwithstanding the foregoing, the more specific rules contained in
the remaining subsections of this section shall govern where applicable. In all cases where the rules set
forth below in the remaining subsections of this section are in conflict with the aforesaid "Robert's Rules Of
Order Newly Revised", the rules contained in the remaining subsections of this section shall govern and
control.
B. Order Of Business:
1. The agenda at regular meetings of the city council shall be substantially as follows:
a. Roll call of members.
b. Adoption of omnibus agenda, including the approval minutes of preceding meetings and the approval of
bills presented for payment. (Note: Any member may ask that an item appearing on the omnibus
agenda be removed therefrom and taken up separately as shall be the case whenever there is a
question regarding minutes or to correct them and whenever there is any question concerning a bill.
Unless otherwise directed in specific instances, all bills shall be approved by the city council, before
being paid.)
c. Petitions, communications, questions and comments from the audience.
d. Mayor's report.
e. Reports of officers, including, but not limited to:
(1) City clerk.
(2) City treasurer.
f. Committee reports, if any:
(1) Economic development.
(2) Finances.
(3) Human resources.
(4) Infrastructure.
(5) Licenses.
(6) Police.
(7) Recreation.
(8) Water.
g. Attorney/legal report.
h. Administrator's report.
i. Staff reports.
j. Old or unfinished business.
k. New business.
l. Adjournment.
6/5/2019 Sterling Codifiers, Inc.
https://www.sterlingcodifiers.com/codebook/index.php?book_id=502 48/767
2. Committee chairs shall have the unilateral right to have added to or removed from the agenda certain
items discussed during their committee meetings. In addition, items may be added to the agenda of a
future city council meeting upon motion duly made, seconded and passed during any city council meeting.
3. The mayor shall have the unilateral right to have added to or removed from the agenda certain items to
be listed under or removed from the mayor's report.
4. Notwithstanding the foregoing, no member of the city council or other person shall seek to have any item
added to an agenda and no item shall be removed from any agenda unless at least forty eight (48) hours
remain before the time set for the meeting to commence.
5. The council, upon motion carried during any meeting, may remove any item or table any item on the
agenda of that meeting.
C. Ordinances: No ordinance, including an ordinance amending an existing ordinance, shall be voted on by the
city council unless such ordinance has been listed by title on the agenda of the meeting wherein it is to be
considered.
D. Voting: All voting shall be by casting a "yes" or "no". Any provision in this code or in any other ordinance,
resolution or state statute, requiring a vote of the city council in a manner contrary to the requirements of
this subsection are without force or effect.
1. The passage of all ordinances, for whatever purpose, shall require the affirmative vote of a majority of the
city council.
2. The passage of any resolution or motion shall require the affirmative vote of a majority of the council
members present.
3. When called upon to a vote, no member of the city council may refuse to vote, unless such member has a
conflict of interest. Accordingly:
a. When called upon to vote, the vote of any member of the city council who abstains from voting or who
votes "present" or otherwise refuses to vote shall be tallied with the prevailing side in any vote.
b. When called upon to vote, a member who has a conflict of interest in connection with any question
before the city council for vote shall announce the specific conflict and shall thereafter abstain from
voting. In such case, such abstention shall not be tallied but shall be recorded as an abstention.
E. Mayor Presiding Officer:
1. The mayor shall preside at all meetings of the city council.
2. The mayor shall not be called upon to vote except: a) when the vote of the aldermen has resulted in a tie;
or b) when one-half (1/2) of the aldermen have voted in favor of an ordinance, resolution or motion
whether or not there is a tie vote; or c) when all of the aldermen present have voted in favor of an
ordinance, resolution or motion.
a. In the instance of a tie vote, the mayor shall vote; and in all other instances, the mayor may vote.
b. Nothing in this subsection shall deprive a mayor pro tem from voting in the capacity as alderman, but
shall not be entitled to an additional vote in the capacity as acting mayor or mayor pro tem.
F. Questions Of Order: All questions relating to the priority of business shall be decided by the chair without
debate, subject to appeal.
6/5/2019 Sterling Codifiers, Inc.
https://www.sterlingcodifiers.com/codebook/index.php?book_id=502 49/767
G. Civility/Expulsion: Upon motion duly made, seconded and passed during any city council meeting, any
member of the city council may be censured or expelled by the city council for the remainder of such city
council meeting for having been out of order during such city council meeting by acting in a manner
unbecoming a member of the city council.
H. Addressing The Council: No person not a member of the city council shall address the council without first
being recognized by the chair.
I. Suspension Of Rules: These rules of the city council may be suspended or waived at any time by motion
adopted by the city council. However:
1. No requirement or procedure imposed by any state law which is a limitation on municipal home rule units
may be suspended or waived; and
2. No suspension or waiver of the rules of procedure shall extend beyond the meeting during which the
motion to suspend or waive the rules is made.
J. Executive Sessions: At any time during any meeting thereof, the city council may move to adjourn to a closed
meeting after a motion duly made in accordance with the open meetings act2, seconded and approved by a
call of the roll. In such case, the city council shall adhere to following procedure:
1. As soon as all members of the city council who were present for the open session of the meeting out of
which the executive session arose are assembled in the room wherein the executive session is to be held,
the city clerk will commence making an audio recording and immediately thereafter the chair of such
meeting shall call the executive session to order.
2. The city clerk will call the roll and the chair will declare a quorum of the city council present, unless there
is no quorum; and in cases where there is no quorum, there shall be no executive session, even though
there may be a majority of a quorum.
3. The city attorney will then read into the audio record: a) the names of all others present, including the
name of the city clerk; b) a restatement of the purpose(s) for adjourning the open session of the meeting
into the executive session, as was contained in the original motion to adjourn to executive session made
during open session, seconded and adopted; and c) announce that such original motion had been
adopted by way of a call of the roll during the open session.
4. If a purpose of the executive session is to discuss probable or imminent litigation, the chair shall next
entertain a motion that the city council finds that litigation is probable or imminent and expressing the
basis for the finding, which motion, second and roll call vote thereon shall be recorded and entered into
the minutes of the closed meeting. If the motion fails to carry, no discussion may be had concerning the
subject matter of the failed motion and the executive session shall be adjourned, unless other purpose(s)
for adjourning the open session of the meeting was (were) contained in the motion made and carried
during open session.
5. The chair of the executive session shall then conduct the closed session, being certain that all discussion
and nonfinal actions are directly related to the purpose(s) for which the executive session was called to
order.
6. No final action on any matter may be taken during an executive session and upon concluding the
discussions for which the executive session was called, the city council shall adjourn the executive
session. (Ord. 11-57-0, 9-14-2011)
1-5C-7: MAYOR PRO TEM:
A. Election: The city council shall elect one of its members to act as mayor pro tem.
6/5/2019 Sterling Codifiers, Inc.
https://www.sterlingcodifiers.com/codebook/index.php?book_id=502 50/767
B. Duties:
1. The mayor pro tem shall perform all of the duties of the mayor during an absence or disability of the
mayor. Absence of the mayor shall occur whenever the exercise of mayoral duties and/or powers requires
the physical presence of the mayor and the mayor is not able to be physically present: a) at a previously
scheduled event; or b) within an hour following notice given by the city administrator or city clerk.
2. In the event the mayor fails to attend a meeting of the city council or a portion thereof, the mayor pro tem
shall chair the meeting; and while so serving as chairman, shall have the right to vote only in the capacity
as alderman. In the absence of both the mayor and mayor pro tem from a meeting of the city council, the
city council shall elect one of its members to act as a temporary chairman.
C. Term: The alderman serving as mayor pro tem shall serve until:
1. Such alderman resigns as mayor pro tem; or
2. Such alderman is no longer a city alderman. (Ord. 12-54-0, 9-12-2012)
1-5C-8: COMMITTEES:
A. Standing Committees: The following shall be the standing committees of the city council, the members of
which together with their respective chairmen shall be appointed by the mayor with the consent of the city
council. Unless otherwise provided, each committee shall consist of three (3) aldermen including the
committee chairman; and the mayor shall be an ex officio nonvoting member of each committee.
1. Committee on economic development: This committee shall review and make recommendations to the
full city council regarding all aspects of economic and community development, including, but not limited
to: economic development planning, marketing, business attraction and retention, incentive programs,
special districts, housing development plans, and development agreements.
2. Committee on finances: This committee shall review and make recommendations to the full city council
regarding all aspects of city finances and financial planning and policy, including, but not limited to:
purchasing, budgeting, investing, auditing, accounts payable, accounts receivable, insurance, risk
management, utility billing, payroll and borrowing. In addition to the mayor, the city treasurer shall be an
ex officio nonvoting member of this committee.
3. Committee on human resources: This committee shall review and make recommendations to the full city
council regarding, but not limited to: all personnel matters involving employees and officers of the city and
to perform other such duties as may be requested by the mayor or city council.
4. Committee on infrastructure: This committee shall review and make recommendations to the full city
council regarding public improvements and infrastructure, including, but not limited to:
a. Maintenance and associated operations of street lighting, the storm sewer system, nonregulatory signs,
city owned buildings/property, infrastructure related interlocal agreements and capital improvement
planning; and
b. Proposed amendments, from time to time, of the following titles of this code: title 7, chapters 1 through
4 and 8 through 11 concerning public ways and property; title 8, building regulations; title 9,
subdivisions; and title 10, zoning and the comprehensive plan.
5. Committee on licenses: This committee shall review and make recommendations to the full city council
regarding, but not limited to, proposed amendments, from time to time, of the following titles of this code:
title 3, business regulations; and title 6, health and sanitation.
6/5/2019 Sterling Codifiers, Inc.
https://www.sterlingcodifiers.com/codebook/index.php?book_id=502 51/767
6. Committee on police: This committee shall review and make recommendations to the full city council
regarding, but not limited to, police operations, capital planning and related intergovernmental
agreements, and proposed amendments of the following titles of this code: title 4, police regulations; and
title 5, motor vehicles and traffic.
7. Committee on recreation: This committee shall review and make recommendations to the full city council
regarding, but not limited to: capital planning for the city's park system, recreation programming,
recreation program fees and park permits; city festivals; park and recreation intergovernmental
agreements, culture and history; and proposed amendments of the open space master plan and the
following chapter of this code: title 7, chapter 5, city parks and the Flagg Creek golf course.
8. Committee on water: This committee shall review and make recommendations to the full city council
regarding, but not limited to: water and sanitary sewer systems operations and maintenance; planning of
capital improvements, and establishing fees and charges associated with the water and sanitary sewer
systems, water purchase and water sales agreements, water system intergovernmental agreements; and
proposed amendments, from time to time, of the following chapters of this code: title 7, chapter 6,
waterworks system; and title 7, chapter 7, sewerage system.
B. Ad Hoc Committees: The mayor shall appoint all special committees, unless the city council determines
otherwise in specific instances, in which case they shall be appointed by the city council. (Ord. 11-57-0, 9-
14-2011)
1-5C-9: PROCEDURES FOR THE RECORDING OF CLOSED SESSIONS:
A. Recording Closed Sessions: The city of Countryside shall keep a verbatim record of all closed or executive
session meetings of the corporate authorities of the city or any subsidiary "public body" as defined by the
Illinois open meetings act, 5 Illinois Compiled Statutes 120/1. The verbatim record shall be in the form of an
audio or video recording as determined by the corporate authorities.
B. Responsibility For Recording Closed Sessions And Maintaining Records: The city clerk or her designee shall
be responsible for arranging for the recording of such closed or executive sessions. In the absence of the
city clerk or her designee, the meeting chair will arrange for the audio or video recording of the closed or
executive session of the city council. Each subsidiary public body of the city shall designate an individual
who will be responsible for the recording of any and all closed or executive sessions of the subsidiary body
and for providing the city clerk with a copy of such recording. The city clerk, or her designee, shall securely
maintain the verbatim recordings of all closed sessions of the corporate authorities of the city and all
subsidiary public bodies of the city.
C. Closed Session Minutes: In addition to the recordings of the closed and executive session as addressed in
this section, the city will keep minutes of all closed meetings in accordance with the requirements of the
open meetings act, 5 Illinois Compiled Statutes 120/2.06.
D. Procedure For Recording: At the beginning of each closed session, those present shall identify themselves
by voice for the audio recording. If the meeting is videotaped, those present shall individually appear on
camera and identify themselves by voice at the beginning of the closed session. The meeting chair shall
also announce the times the closed session commences and ends at the appropriate points of the
recording.
E. Backup Equipment/Procedure For Equipment Malfunction: The city will maintain sufficient tapes, batteries
and equipment for the city to comply with this section. The city clerk or her designee will periodically check
the equipment to confirm that it is functioning. In the event that anyone present at a closed session
determines that the equipment is not functioning properly, the closed session will be temporarily suspended
to attempt to correct any malfunction. In the event that an equipment malfunction cannot be corrected
6/5/2019 Sterling Codifiers, Inc.
https://www.sterlingcodifiers.com/codebook/index.php?book_id=502 52/767
immediately, the closed session will terminate until such time as the closed session may proceed with a
functioning recording device.
F. Procedure For Review Of Closed Session Minutes And Recordings: At one meeting at least every six (6)
months, the agenda shall include the item: "Review of the minutes and recordings of all closed sessions that
have not yet been released for public review, and determination of which minutes, if any, may be released".
Minutes shall be reviewed in closed session and shall not be released unless the corporate authorities of the
city find that it is no longer necessary to protect the public interest or the privacy of an individual by keeping
them confidential. As to any minutes not released, the corporate authorities shall find that the "need for
confidentiality still exists" as to those minutes. Minutes of the closed sessions shall be kept indefinitely.
G. Maintenance And Public Release Of Recordings And Access To Tapes: The audio or video tape recordings
of closed sessions shall be maintained for eighteen (18) months after the closed session and shall not be
released to the public unless such release is required by a court order or specifically authorized for release
by a vote of the city council. Members of the corporate authorities may listen to the closed session
recordings in the presence of the city clerk or her designee. Copies of such tapes will not be made or
provided to anyone unless specifically authorized by vote of the city council.
H. Procedure For Destruction Of Recordings: The city clerk or her designee is hereby authorized to destroy the
audio and video recordings of those closed sessions for which:
1. The corporate authorities of the city have approved the minutes of the closed sessions as to accurate
content, regardless of whether the minutes have been released for public review;
2. More than eighteen (18) months have elapsed since the date of the closed session;
3. There is no court order requiring the preservation of such recording; and
4. The corporate authorities of the city have not passed a motion requiring the preservation of the verbatim
recording of that meeting. (Ord. 06-49-0, 11-8-2006)
Chapter 6
CITY OFFICERS AND EMPLOYEES
1-6-1: APPOINTMENTS, HIRINGS AND REMOVALS:
A. Appointment: All officers, other than elective officers, and policemen under the jurisdiction of the fire and
police commissioners, shall be appointed by the mayor by and with the advice and consent of the city
council as provided by statute; however, no employees shall, in the absence of any provisions to the
contrary, be appointed or selected by the mayor, but shall be hired by the city council.
B. Removal: The mayor may remove any officer appointed by him, under this chapter, in the manner prescribed
by the Illinois municipal code1, and the city council may remove any employee hired by them in a manner
not inconsistent with law. (Ord. 95-01-0, 1-11-1995)
1-6-2: OATH OF OFFICE:
Before entering upon the duties of their respective offices, all officers of the city, whether elected or appointed,
shall take and subscribe the following oath:
6/5/2019 Sterling Codifiers, Inc.
https://www.sterlingcodifiers.com/codebook/index.php?book_id=502 53/767
I do solemnly swear that I will support the Constitution of the United States, and the Constitution of the State
of Illinois, and that I will faithfully discharge the duties of the office of according to the best of my ability.
This oath, so subscribed, shall be filed in the office of the city clerk. (1970 Code §2-1.02)
1-6-3: BOND REQUIREMENTS:
Before entering upon the duties of their respective offices, certain city officers and employees must have a
minimum mandatory bond as required under relevant sections of the Illinois Compiled Statutes.
A. Mayor's Bond: In no case shall the mayor's bond be less than the mandated amount specified under the
Illinois Compiled Statutes.
B. Clerk's Bond: In no case shall the clerk's bond be less than the mandated amount specified under the Illinois
Compiled Statutes.
C. Treasurer's Bond: In no case shall the treasurer's bond be less than the mandated amount specified under
the Illinois Compiled Statutes.
D. Cost: The cost for any mandated bonds shall be paid in its entirety by the city. (Ord. 14-34-0, 9-10-2014)
1-6-4: MONIES RECEIVED; SIGNATORIES ON CITY ACCOUNTS:
A. Monies Received: Any money coming into the hands of any officer or employee of the city for the city shall
be paid over to the city treasurer daily.
B. Signatories On City Accounts: Subject to the requirements of subsection C of this section, the following city
officials are hereby authorized to sign checks or other orders withdrawing funds from city accounts: the
mayor, the city treasurer, the city administrator, the city finance director. Any bank or other institution holding
city funds is authorized and directed to honor, pay, and charge to the account of the city all checks and
orders for the payment of money so drawn when signed by any such authorized official, without inquiry as to
the circumstances of their issue or the disposition of their proceeds. Each such official shall be bonded for
an amount not less than the minimum required by law and as approved by the city council.
C. Orders For Withdrawals From Certain Accounts: Orders for withdrawal from the pending forfeiture funds
account, the state forfeiture funds account and the federal forfeiture funds account, each maintained by the
city of Countryside police department, shall be made only upon checks or other orders signed by at least
two (2) of the following: the chief of police, the deputy chief of police, the mayor, the city treasurer, the city
administrator, the city finance director. (Ord. 05-39-0, 10-12-2005)
1-6-5: SALARIES:
The city council shall fix the salaries of all city officers, except those who are elected for a definite term, and all
employees, and provide for the same in the annual appropriation ordinance. They shall fix the salary of all
officers who are elected for a definite term in an ordinance, other than the appropriation ordinance, within the
time required by law. (Ord. 95-01-0, 1-11-1995)
6/5/2019 Sterling Codifiers, Inc.
https://www.sterlingcodifiers.com/codebook/index.php?book_id=502 54/767
1-6-6: ELECTED CITY OFFICERS:
A. Duty To Attend Regular Meetings: It shall be the duty of each elected officer of the city to attend all regularly
scheduled meetings of the city, except that absences shall be permitted as hereinafter provided by
subsection B of this section. (1970 Code §2-1.07, as amended)
B. Permitted Absences:
1. Each elected city officer shall be permitted four (4) absences from regularly scheduled city council
meetings in any one fiscal year for which meetings he shall receive compensation. Such permitted
absences may not be accumulated and carried over from one year to another. Further, each such elected
officer may be permitted additional absences, with compensation, if such absences are shown to be for
good cause. Good cause shall include, but not be limited to, illness of the officer or serious illness or
death of a member of the officer's immediate family.
2. When an officer's absences exceed the permitted number of four (4), it will be presumed that good cause
does not exist. However, the city council, which will be the sole judge of determining whether good cause
exists, may find to the contrary, by affirmative vote, and determine that such absences are permitted,
thereby entitling the officer to receive his regular compensation for the meeting missed.
3. The city council will not make a determination as to whether due cause exists unless specifically
requested to do so by the officer whose absence is in question, or a member of his immediate family.
Further, the city council may, by affirmative vote, determine that due cause will continue to exist in any
particular case for a specified period of time, but not to exceed six (6) months. At the end of such
specified period, it will be presumed that good cause no longer exists, unless the city council again finds
to the contrary.
4. This subsection shall be applicable only to elected officers whose terms of office commence after the city
election of April 3, 1979. (1970 Code §2-1.08, as amended)
C. Nonpermitted Absences: When an elected officer is absent from a regularly scheduled meeting, and such
absence is not permitted under subsection B of this section, the following will occur:
1. In the case of any elected officer, except an alderman, one-three hundred sixty five hundredths (1/365) of
his salary will be deducted from his next succeeding paycheck for each nonpermitted absence.
2. In the case of an alderman, he will be subject to a fine, as provided for by section 1-5C-5 of this title, for
the meeting missed.
This subsection shall apply only to elected officers whose terms of office commence after the city election
of April 3, 1979. (1970 Code §2-1.09, as amended)
D. Officers Appointed To Fill Vacancies Included: The term "elected officer", as used herein, shall include any
person appointed to fill the unexpired term of a person elected to office. (1970 Code §2-1.10, as amended)
ARTICLE A. PERSONNEL POLICIES
1-6A-1: DEFINITION OF EMPLOYEE:
For purposes of this Article, a full-time employee is any individual employed by the City, except sworn peace
officers, whose employment is for two thousand eighty (2080) hours of service per year which may include one
hour for meals in each eight (8) hour workday. All such employees shall be entitled to receive the benefits
6/5/2019 Sterling Codifiers, Inc.
https://www.sterlingcodifiers.com/codebook/index.php?book_id=502 55/767
hereinafter stated.
Individuals appointed or hired to positions of less than two thousand eighty (2080) hours of service per year
shall be entitled only to those benefits offered by the IMRF (Illinois Municipal Retirement Fund) where such
individuals qualify under the guidelines of IMRF, or such other benefits as may be agreed upon between the
employees and the City. (1986 Code)
1-6A-2: VACATIONS:
A. All full-time City employees shall be entitled to a paid vacation leave of ten (10) working days after
completion of the first full year of employment, and each full year of employment thereafter, through the sixth
year of employment; fifteen (15) working days after the completion of the sixth full year of employment, and
each full year of employment thereafter, through the tenth year; twenty (20) working days after completion of
the tenth full year of employment, and each full year of employment thereafter, through the nineteenth year;
twenty five (25) working days after completion of the nineteenth full year of employment and each full year
of employment thereafter. For the purpose of this Section, all time periods shall be measured by anniversary
dates of employment and not in terms of calendar or fiscal years. (Ord. 90-04-0, 3-14-90)
B. Paid vacation leave must be earned prior to its use; however, full-time employees during their first year of
employment may be allowed five (5) working days of paid leave after completion of six (6) months of
service. However, although the five (5) working days of paid leave taken after the first six (6) months of
employment shall not be considered as earned vacation for the purposes of this Section, it shall be counted
against the ten (10) working days of paid vacation leave allowed after one year of employment, and if any
part thereof is taken before the end of the first year of employment, the employee shall be entitled only to
ten (10) working days of paid vacation leave, less the number of unearned paid leave days taken, until the
second anniversary of his or her employment.
C. Prior to the completion of an anniversary year, an employee is permitted to take the unearned paid leave
referred to in subsection B hereof; and, if the employee terminates his/her employment during that period,
the unearned paid vacation leave will be deducted from his/her final paycheck. Unused vacation time may
not be carried over from one anniversary year to another. (Ord. 90-36-0, 9-12-90)
1-6A-3: HOLIDAYS:
A. Full-time employees shall be entitled to nine (9) paid holidays per calendar year, to wit: New Year's Day,
Easter, Memorial Day, Fourth of July, Labor Day, Thanksgiving, the Friday following Thanksgiving, the work
day next preceding Christmas Day and Christmas Day.
B. In addition to the nine (9) paid holidays set forth in paragraph A above, full-time employees shall receive
three (3) personal days per calendar year.
C. Neither holidays nor personal days shall be accumulated nor payable at the time of termination or
resignation. (Ord. 91-01-0, 1-9-91)
1-6A-4: SICK LEAVE BENEFITS:
A. Allowance of Sick Leave: Sick leave benefits for each individual City employee, except police officers who
are covered under Title 4, Chapter 1 of this Code, will become effective for an employee of the City on the
first day of his employment as a City employee. The department head to oversee these benefits will be the
supervisor to whom the employee reports. All final decisions will be made by the City Council.
6/5/2019 Sterling Codifiers, Inc.
https://www.sterlingcodifiers.com/codebook/index.php?book_id=502 56/767
Sick leave benefits are payable to an employee under the following conditions:
1. The allowance period will begin as of the date the employee gives oral or written notification of disability
to his department head or supervisor, or, in the event of inability to reach a department head or
supervisor, to the desk officer on duty at the Police Department1. No sick leave will be granted unless the
employee reports to the department head or supervisor, or leaves such notification with the Police
Department, not less than one hour prior to his scheduled starting time. The employee, in making this
report, must do so in person or through another person, stating the reason for his being unable to work
and the amount of time he will expect to be absent.
2. Any employee who is disabled for three (3) consecutive days or more will, upon request, furnish his
department head or supervisor with written evidence from a physician stating:
a. That the employee is disabled;
b. Nature of illness or injury; and
c. When the employee will be capable of returning to work.
3. Pay for any employee during the sick leave allowance period shall be at his regular salary rate.
4. When an employee on sick leave is within seven (7) days of exhausting his accumulated sick leave credit,
notification will be sent to the Mayor and Aldermen. The department head may, in unusual meritorious
cases and with prior approval of the City Council, grant additional days of sick leave even if sick leave
credit is not available.
5. Violations of the regulations for use of sick leave or request of sick leave for an improper purpose is an
act of dishonesty and can result in disciplinary action or discharge.
6. It is the employee's responsibility to:
a. Promptly notify the department head, or supervisor, or the desk officer on duty at the Police
Department, of illness or injury;
b. Obtain adequate medical treatment to speed recovery; and
c. Provide satisfactory proof of disability and submit such medical return-to-work clearance as required by
this policy.
B. Time of Eligibility: If employee is absent without pay for any reason, he can become eligible for sick leave
benefits only after returning to work.
C. Disqualification for Benefits: Employees shall be disqualified for sick leave benefits for any of the following
reasons:
1. Medical Treatment: Failure to take adequate steps to expedite his recovery; refusal to submit to medical
examination as may be required by the department head or supervisor, or refusal to authorize disclosure
of information by any physician to the department head or supervisor pertaining to his condition.
2. Avoidable Disability: Disability resulting from an unlawful act, negligence or violation of the rules and
regulations governing the City.
3. Other Employment: Disability arising while the employee is engaged in personal activities for profit or
while working for another employer. (1970 Code §2-18.01)
D. Maternity Leave Of Absence: In case of pregnancy, the only question as to return to work would be the state
of health of the employee. The employee may leave duty upon written advice of her physician and will, at
6/5/2019 Sterling Codifiers, Inc.
https://www.sterlingcodifiers.com/codebook/index.php?book_id=502 57/767
the time, become entitled to sick leave benefits, vacation benefits and disability application, and will be
expected to return to duty status six (6) weeks after the birth of the child.
If an employee fails to report back to duty status when released by her physician, it shall be equivalent to a
resignation and/or a dismissal will be sought from the City Council. (1970 Code §2-18.02)
E. Accumulation Of Sick Leave: Sick leave will be credited on the employee's personnel reports at the rate of
one day of sick leave credit accumulated each month, which will total twelve (12) working days of sick leave
credit each year. This sick leave can accumulate to a maximum of two hundred thirty six (236) working days
of sick leave credit. Sick leave credit will not accumulate beyond this two hundred thirty six (236) working
days limit.
At retirement, with a minimum of ten (10) years of service, at age fifty five (55) or older, full-time employees
will receive thirty five percent (35%) of unused sick leave time credit at regular pay. (Ord. 97-11-0, 5-14-
1997)
1-6A-5: HEALTH INSURANCE BENEFITS:
A. Full-Time Employees: Full-time employees shall be entitled to those health, hospitalization, life and dental
insurance coverages as may be, from time to time, in effect through contracts established and approved by
the Mayor and City Council.
B. Retired Employees, Prior To January 1, 1991: For all full-time employees who have retired prior to January 1,
1991, and who maintain accident, health, and/or hospitalization insurance, either through the City or on their
own, the City will pay up to one-half (1/2) the monthly premium, not to exceed one hundred dollars ($100.00)
per month. Such payments will terminate upon the death of the retired employee, cessation of such
insurance coverage, or at the request of the retired employee.
C. Retired Employees, After January 1, 1991: For all full-time employees who retire after January 1, 1991, and
who are eligible under section 367i of the Illinois Insurance Code as amended (P.A. 86-1444), to continue
the group accident and health insurance provided by the City at the time of their retirement, and who elect to
do so, or who elect to secure and maintain such coverage on their own, the City will pay up to one-half (1/2)
of the monthly premium, not to exceed one hundred dollars ($100.00) per month, so long as such retired
employee is eligible to continue such coverage and elects to do so.
D. Retroactive: Insofar as applicable, the benefits provided for in this Section shall be retroactive to September
1, 1990. (Ord. 91-04-0, 2-13-1991)
1-6A-6: PERSONAL LEAVE:
In cases where there is an emergency situation and/or illness of a serious nature at the home of an employee,
that certain employee may be excused from work for up to a total of twenty four (24) normal working hours
(including lunch hours) per calendar year by his supervisor or by the Mayor. Such time shall be personal leave
time and is not accumulative. Such time will not be deducted from the employee's sick leave time.
In event of a death of a member of the employee's immediate family, three (3) days will be allowed for leave,
which will not be deducted from the employee's sick leave time. Immediate family shall include husband, wife,
children, mother, or father. One day will be allowed for grandparents, grandchildren, brothers, sisters, motherin-
law or father-in-law. Request for such leave may be made through the supervisor or Mayor. (1970 Code §2-
18.03)
6/5/2019 Sterling Codifiers, Inc.
https://www.sterlingcodifiers.com/codebook/index.php?book_id=502 58/767
1-6A-7: EMPLOYEE GRIEVANCE PROCEDURES:
A. Purpose: Section 504 Regulations of the Office of Revenue Sharing (31 C.F.R. 51.55 (d)(2)) requires that
each recipient of revenue sharing funds adopt a grievance procedure which may be utilized by persons who
believe that such recipient, by its policies or inaccessibility of facilities or programs, discriminates against
individuals because of handicapped status. Section 504 states, in part, that "no otherwise qualified
handicapped individual . . . shall, solely by reason of his handicap, be excluded from the participation in, be
denied the benefits of, or be subjected to discrimination under any program or activity receiving federal
financial assistance . . .". Therefore, the City adopts the following internal grievance procedure providing for
prompt and equitable resolution of complaints alleging any action prohibited by the Office of Revenue
Sharing's (ORS) regulations (31 C.F.R. 51.55 (d)(2)) implementing section 504 of the Rehabilitation Act of
1973, as amended (29 U.S.C. 794). (1970 Code §2-19.01, as amended)
B. Procedure:
1. Complaints should be addressed to: Mayor of the City of Countryside, 5550 East Avenue, Countryside,
Illinois 60525, who has been designated to coordinate section 504 compliance efforts.
2. A complaint may be filed in writing or verbally, should contain the name and address of the person filing it,
and briefly describe the alleged violation of the regulations.
3. A complaint should be filed within thirty (30) days after the complainant becomes aware of the alleged
violation. (Processing of allegations of discrimination occurring before this grievance procedure was
adopted will be considered on a case-by-case basis.)
4. An investigation, as may be appropriate, shall follow filing of a complaint. All such investigations will be
conducted by the Mayor. These rules contemplate informal but thorough investigations, affording all
interested persons and their representatives, if any, an opportunity to submit evidence relevant to a
complaint. Under 31 C.F.R. 51.55 (d)(2), the City need not process complaints from applicants for
employment.
5. A written determination as to the validity of the complaint and description of resolution, if any, shall be
issued by the Mayor and a copy forwarded to the complainant no later than ninety (90) days after initial
filing of the complaint.
6. The section 504 coordinator shall maintain the files and records of the City relating to the complaints filed.
7. The complainant can request a reconsideration of the case in instances where he is dissatisfied with the
resolution. The request for reconsideration should be made within thirty (30) days to the Mayor.
8. The right of a person to a prompt and equitable resolution of the complaint filed hereunder shall not be
impaired by the person's pursuit of other remedies such as the filing of a section 504 complaint with the
Office of Revenue Sharing, U.S. Department of the Treasury. Utilization of this grievance procedure is not
a prerequisite to the pursuit of other remedies. (1970 Code §2-19.02, as amended)
C. Construction Of Rules: These rules shall be construed to protect the substantive rights of interested persons,
to meet appropriate due process standards and to assure that the City complies with section 504 and the
ORS regulations. (1970 Code §2-19.03, as amended)
1-6A-8: VACATION TIME FOR PART-TIME REGULAR EMPLOYEES:
A. Definitions:
PART-TIME REGULAR EMPLOYEE: A person regularly employed by the City but whose total base hours of
work are less than two thousand eighty (2,080) hours per year.
6/5/2019 Sterling Codifiers, Inc.
https://www.sterlingcodifiers.com/codebook/index.php?book_id=502 59/767
REGULARLY EMPLOYED: Employment for which the employee is expected to report to work on a regular
basis and which, regardless of the length of time between periods of work, shall not require that the
employee go through any reemployment procedures or be rehired.
B. Computation Of Vacation Time: Each part-time regular employee shall be entitled to paid vacation based
upon the ratio his or her annual base hours of work bears to the number of the minimum annual base work
hours of a full-time employee, two thousand eighty (2,080), multiplied by the number of vacation days to
which a full-time employee with the same number of years worked would be entitled. Where such product
results in a fraction of five-tenths (0.5) or more, the employee shall receive one additional day of paid
vacation. (i.e., where a part-time regular employee has an annual base of 1,560 work hours, the ratio his or
her base bears to that of a full-time employee is 0.75. If that part-time regular employee has completed 6
years of employment, he or she shall receive 75 percent of the 15 days of paid vacation to which a full-time
employee with 6 years of service is entitled. Because the product of multiplying 10 work days by 0.75 equals
7.5, the employee would be entitled to 8 days of paid vacation time.) (Ord. 93-09-0, 1-27-1993)
ARTICLE B. CITY CLERK
1-6B-1: ELECTION AND TERM:
The City Clerk shall be elected and serve for a 4-year term and until his or her successor is elected and
qualified as provided by statute1. (1970 Code §2-5.01; amd. Ord. 90-50-0, 12-19-1990)
1-6B-2: BOND, OATH AND COMPENSATION:
Before entering upon the duties of his or her office, the City Clerk shall give a bond as required by Section 1-6-3
of this Chapter. The Clerk shall take the oath of office as prescribed in Section 1-6-2 of this Chapter. The Clerk
shall receive the sum of eight thousand four hundred dollars ($8,400.00) per annum as compensation for his or
her office. (Ord. 96-39-0, 8-28-1996)
1-6B-3: DUTIES:
The City Clerk shall, in addition to other duties imposed upon him or her by law, perform the following:
A. The Clerk shall record in a book to be kept for that purpose, and before the next regular meeting after their
passage, all ordinances and resolutions passed by the City Council, and if any ordinance requires
publication, the Clerk shall cause the same to be duly published, and shall note at the foot of the record of
each ordinance, a memorandum of the date of its passage, the date of its approval, if approved by the
Mayor, and, if published, the date of publication thereof, and shall procure and file in his or her office all
certificates of publication of ordinances which are published in a newspaper in this City. The Clerk shall also,
within the time required by law in each year, publish the Treasurer's annual report filed in his or her office.
B. The Clerk shall, except where otherwise provided by ordinance, issue and attest under the Corporate Seal of
the City, all licenses granted by the Mayor and City Council, and shall keep a record of all licenses granted,
transferred or revoked by the Mayor and City Council or under their authority, with the date, the name
thereof, and the name and residence of the applicants in a book to be kept by him or her for that purpose.
6/5/2019 Sterling Codifiers, Inc.
https://www.sterlingcodifiers.com/codebook/index.php?book_id=502 60/767
C. The Clerk shall issue notices to the members of the City Council when directed to do so by that body, also to
the members of the different committees and to all persons whose attendance is required before any
committee, when directed or requested to do so by the chairman of such committee.
D. The Clerk shall, upon the filing of a call for any special meeting, prepare notices of such meeting and cause
them to be served on the members of the City Council not later than the calendar day next preceding the
day set for such special meeting. Notices of special meetings shall specify in brief the objects and purposes
for which they shall have been called2.
E. The Clerk shall keep the Corporate Seal and affix the same to all documents and papers that are required to
bear the official Seal of the City3.
F. The Clerk shall be the custodian of all documents belonging to the City which are not assigned to the custody
of some other officer, and keep a record showing all of the officers and regular employees of the City. (1970
Code §2-5.02; amd. Ord. 90-50-0, 12-19-1990)
G. The City Clerk shall hold the office of City Collector, shall perform the duties thereof, and may be referred to
as "Clerk, ex officio Collector". (Ord. 90-50-0, 12-19-1990)
1-6B-4: COLLECTOR:
A. Office Created, Powers and Duties: There is hereby created the office of City Collector, whose duty it shall
be to receive all City revenue from sources other than taxes, and to transfer all such funds to the City
Treasurer, not less frequently than weekly, and to obtain therefor a receipt, in duplicate, and to file one such
receipt forthwith in the office of the City Clerk.
When required to do so by the City Council, the Collector shall also prepare written reports of all money
collected, the account whereon collected or any other matter connected with the Collector's office.
Between April 1 and April 10 of each year, the Collector shall file in the office of the City Clerk a statement of
all money collected by him or her during the year, the particular warrant, special assessment, or account on
which collected, the balance of money uncollected on all warrants in the Collector's possession, and the
balance remaining uncollected at the time of the return of all warrants which the Collector returned to the
City Clerk during the preceding fiscal year. Such statement shall be published by the Clerk at least once
within ten (10) days in one or more newspapers published or with a general circulation within the City.
The Collector shall report all delinquent special assessment accounts to the County, on or before August 1
in each year, as required by chapter 24, section 9-2-82 of the Illinois Municipal Code.
The Collector shall perform all such other duties and assume all such other responsibilities that are
reasonably required in the conduct of the Collector's office or as may be, from time to time, directed by the
City Council.
B. Appointment of Deputy Collector: There is hereby created the office of the Deputy Collector, and the City
Collector is authorized to appoint a Deputy Collector who shall have the power and duty to execute all
documents and do all things required by law or ordinance to be executed or done by the City Collector. The
office of Deputy Collector may be held by the same person who concurrently holds the office of Deputy
Clerk, in which case the Deputy Clerk shall be the ex officio Deputy Collector.
When signing any document, the Deputy Collector shall sign the name of the City Collector, followed by the
words "By _________ ______________, Deputy Collector" or when applicable, "Deputy Clerk, ex officio
Deputy Collector". (Ord. 90-50-0, 12-19-90)
6/5/2019 Sterling Codifiers, Inc.
https://www.sterlingcodifiers.com/codebook/index.php?book_id=502 61/767
1-6B-5: AMENDMENTS TO CODE:
It is the duty of the City Clerk to keep at least two (2) copies of the City Code which shall be preserved by said
Clerk in a book or binder in loose leaf form. All amendments thereto and all general ordinances may be inserted
in their appropriate places in such volumes, and all sections of the City Code or ordinances repealed from time
to time may be extracted therefrom for the purpose of maintaining said two (2) copies in such condition that
they will show the general ordinances passed up to date at any time in such manner that ready reference may
be had thereto4. (1970 Code §2-5.03)
1-6B-6: DEPUTY CITY CLERK:
A. Office Created, Powers: There is hereby created the office of Deputy Clerk. The City Clerk is authorized to
appoint not more than two (2) Deputy Clerks. A Deputy Clerk shall have the power and duty to execute all
documents required by law or ordinance to be executed by the City Clerk and affix the Seal of the City
thereto whenever required.
B. Signature: When signing any documents, the Deputy Clerk shall sign the name of the City Clerk followed by
the words "by Deputy Clerk".
C. Exercise of Duties: The powers and duties herein described shall be exercised only in the name of the Clerk
from the place where the Clerk's office is maintained, and only when either written direction has been given
by the Clerk to such Deputy to exercise such power, or when the corporate authorities have determined by
resolution that the City Clerk is temporarily or permanently incapacitated to perform such function.
When duly authorized, as herein provided, the signature affixed by any such Deputy Clerk in the manner
herein prescribed on any document, including, but not limited to, contracts, bonds or other obligations of the
Municipality, such document shall have the same effect as if the documents so executed had been signed
by the City Clerk in person.
D. Authority and Power: A Deputy Clerk shall have the authority and power herein described and such further
power and authority as may be provided by statute5.
E. Any person appointed Deputy Clerk after September 1, 1992, shall have four (4) years from the date of his or
her appointment to such position in which to become certified as a Certified Municipal Clerk by the
International Institute of Municipal Clerks. The City shall pay all necessary costs incurred for obtaining such
certification, including tuition, lodging, travel and materials. Failure to become so certified within that time
shall constitute ground for termination of appointment as Deputy Clerk. (Ord. 92-27-0, 9-9-92)
ARTICLE C. CITY TREASURER
1-6C-1: ELECTION AND TERM:
The city treasurer shall be elected and serve for a four (4) year term and until his successor is elected and
qualified as provided by statute1. (1970 Code §2-6.01)
1-6C-2: BOND, OATH AND COMPENSATION:
6/5/2019 Sterling Codifiers, Inc.
https://www.sterlingcodifiers.com/codebook/index.php?book_id=502 62/767
Before entering upon the duties of his or her office, the city treasurer shall give a bond as required by section 1-
6-3 of this chapter. The treasurer shall take the oath of office as prescribed in section 1-6-2 of this chapter. The
treasurer shall receive the sum of eight thousand four hundred dollars ($8,400.00) per annum as compensation
for his or her office. (Ord. 96-39-0, 8-28-1996)
1-6C-3: POWERS AND DUTIES:
A. Receipt Of Funds; Payments: The city treasurer shall receive all money belonging to the city, and shall keep
his books and accounts in the manner prescribed by ordinance. These books and accounts shall always be
subject to the inspection of any member of the city council or the mayor. He shall keep a separate account
of each fund or appropriation, and the debits and credits belonging thereto. The city treasurer shall give
every person paying money into the treasury receipt therefor, specifying the date of payment, and upon
what account paid. He shall file copies of these receipts with the clerk, with his monthly reports. If he has in
his possession money properly appropriated to the payment of any warrant lawfully drawn upon him, he
shall pay the money specified in this warrant to the person designated by the warrant. (1970 Code §2-6.03)
B. Monthly Statements; Register Of Warrants: At the end of every month, and more often if required by the city
council, the treasurer shall render an account under oath to the city council, or to such officer as may be
designated by ordinance, showing the state of the treasury at the date of the account, and the balance of
money in the treasury. He shall accompany the account with a statement of all money received into the
treasury, and on what account, together with all warrants redeemed and paid by him. On the day he renders
an account, these warrants, with all vouchers held by him, shall be delivered to the city clerk and filed,
together with the account, in the clerk's office. He shall return all warrants paid by him marked "paid". He
shall keep a register of all warrants, which shall describe each warrant, showing its date, amount, and
number, the fund from which paid, the name of the person to whom paid, and when paid. (1970 Code §2-
6.04)
C. Deposit Of Funds: He shall keep all funds and money in his custody belonging to the city in such places of
deposit as may be designated by the city council and as provided by law. (1970 Code §2-6.05)
D. Personal Use Of Funds: He shall keep all money belonging to the city in his custody separate and distinct
from his own money, and he shall not use, either directly or indirectly, the city's money or warrants in his
custody for his own use and benefit, or that of any other person. (1970 Code §2-6.06)
E. Report: He shall report to the city council, as often as they require, a full and detailed account of all receipts
and expenditures of the city, as shown by his books, up to the time of the report. (1970 Code §2-6.07)
F. Annual Account:
1. Prior to September 1 of each year, the treasurer shall prepare and file with the city clerk an account of all
monies received and expenditures incurred during the preceding fiscal year in the manner prescribed by
law. (1970 Code §2-6.08)
2. Prior to September 1 of each year, he shall file with the county collector, a copy of the annual account
together with an affidavit of the city clerk stating that such copy is a true and correct copy of such annual
account filed with him and that it was published. (1970 Code §2-6.09)
1-6C-4: SPECIAL ASSESSMENT FUNDS:
All money received on any special assessment shall be held by the treasurer as a special fund, to be applied to
6/5/2019 Sterling Codifiers, Inc.
https://www.sterlingcodifiers.com/codebook/index.php?book_id=502 63/767
the payment of the improvement for which the assessment was made, and the money shall be used for no
other purpose, except to reimburse the city for money expended for such improvement. (1970 Code §2-6.10)
ARTICLE D. OTHER CITY OFFICERS
1-6D-1: BUILDING INSPECTOR:
A. Appointment: The building inspector shall be appointed by the mayor by and with the advice and consent of
the city council. He shall be ex officio building commissioner and whenever in this code powers, rights or
duties are delegated to the building commissioner, such shall be performed by the building inspector. (1970
Code §2-7.01)
B. Bond: Before entering upon the duties of his or her office, the building inspector shall qualify and have the
minimum mandated bond required for his or her position pursuant to the Illinois Compiled Statutes. The cost
of such bond shall be paid in its entirety by the city. (Ord. 14-34-0, 9-10-2014)
C. Oath And Compensation: The building inspector shall take the oath of office as prescribed by section 1-6-2
of this chapter. He shall receive such compensation as may be set from time to time by the city council.
(1970 Code §2-7.03)
D. Powers And Duties:
1. Generally: It shall be the duty of the building inspector to see to the enforcement of all ordinance
provisions relating to buildings1 or zoning2 and to inspect all buildings or structures being constructed,
repaired or altered, as frequently as may be necessary to ensure compliance with city ordinances. (1970
Code §2-7.04)
2. Entry Powers: He shall make or cause to be made a legally authorized entry into any building or premises
where work of altering, repairing or construction of any building or structure is going on for the purpose of
making inspections at any reasonable hour. This right of entry shall also extend to any inspection made
for the purpose of enforcing all of the ordinances of the city where such an inspection is deemed
necessary. (1970 Code §2-7.08)
3. Stop Order: He shall have the power to order all work stopped on construction, alteration or repair of
buildings in the city when such work is being done in violation of any provision of any ordinance relating
thereto or in violation of the zoning ordinance. Work shall not be resumed after the issuance of such an
order except on the written permission of the building inspector; provided, however, that if the stop order
is an oral one, it shall be followed by a written stop order within twenty four (24) hours. Such stop order
may be served by any police officer.
And any person who shall continue work in violation of a stop order of the building inspector shall be fined
not less than fifty dollars ($50.00) nor more than five hundred dollars ($500.00) for each day on which any
work in violation of such stop order is done. (1970 Code §2-7.09; amd. 1986 Code)
E. Serve Other Offices:
1. Ex Officio Electrical Inspector: The building inspector shall act as ex officio electrical inspector and shall
have the powers and perform all duties connected with that office. He shall have the authority to inspect
and test electrical equipment, and to enforce all ordinance provisions relating to electrical wiring and
equipment. He shall have the power to cause the current in any wire or conduit to be turned off whenever
this is necessary in an emergency for the protection of life and property. (1970 Code §2-7.05)
6/5/2019 Sterling Codifiers, Inc.
https://www.sterlingcodifiers.com/codebook/index.php?book_id=502 64/767
2. Ex Officio Plumbing Inspector: He shall act as ex officio plumbing inspector and shall have the powers
and perform all the duties connected with that office. He shall make all inspections necessary to see that
the ordinances of this city relating to plumbing are enforced; and no pipe or water mains shall be covered
until they have been inspected and approved. (1970 Code §2-7.06)
3. Ex Officio Fire Inspector: He shall act as ex officio fire inspector and shall have the powers and perform
all duties connected with that office. He shall have the authority to inspect all buildings, structures and
premises, and to enforce all ordinance provisions relating to fire prevention. (1970 Code §2-7.07)
1-6D-2: CITY PROSECUTOR:
A. Appointment: There is hereby created the office of city prosecutor. The city prosecutor shall be appointed by
the mayor by and with the advice and consent of the city council. (1970 Code §2-8.01)
B. Oath And Compensation: Before entering upon the duties of his office, the city prosecutor shall take the oath
of office as prescribed by section 1-6-2 of this chapter. He shall receive compensation as may be set from
time to time by the city council. (1970 Code §§2-8.02, 2-8.03; amd. 1986 Code)
C. Duties: The city prosecutor shall prosecute all ordinance violations and appeals thereof to which the city may
be a party, or in which the city may be interested, after the same have been referred to him by the
appropriate city official. He shall also perform such other and further legal services as the corporate
authorities may from time to time direct. (1970 Code §2-8.04; amd. 1986 Code)
1-6D-3: HEALTH OFFICER:
A. Appointment: The health officer shall be appointed by the mayor by and with the advice and consent of the
city council. (1970 Code §2-9.01)
B. Bond, Oath And Compensation: Before entering upon the duties of his office, the health officer shall furnish a
bond as provided in section 1-6-3 of this chapter. He shall take the oath of office as prescribed by section 1-
6-2 of this chapter, and shall receive such compensation as may be set from time to time by the city council.
(1970 Code §§2-9.02, 2-9.03)
C. Powers And Duties3:
1. It shall be the duty of the health officer to enforce all ordinances containing provisions for the protection of
public health; he shall make inspections of foodstuffs and of the premises used for storing or selling of
provisions as may be provided by ordinance, and he shall perform such other duties and functions as may
be required by statute and ordinance.
2. He shall have and exercise a general supervision over the sanitary condition of the city, and shall cause
all nuisances affecting the health of the public to be abated with all reasonable promptness.
3. For the purpose of carrying out the requirements of this code, the health officer shall, in accordance with
all applicable laws:
a. Enter into any house, store, stable or other building, and cause the floors to be raised if he shall deem it
necessary, in order to make a thorough examination of cellars, vaults, sinks or drains.
b. Cause all dead animals or other unwholesome things or substances to be buried, removed or disposed
of as he may direct. (1970 Code §2-9.04)
6/5/2019 Sterling Codifiers, Inc.
https://www.sterlingcodifiers.com/codebook/index.php?book_id=502 65/767
4. He shall make such reports to the city council as may be required, and shall also make recommendations
for rulings, orders or ordinances respecting the public health whenever he is requested to do so, or
whenever he deems it advisable or necessary. (1970 Code §2-9.05; amd. 1986 Code)
ARTICLE E. CITY ADMINISTRATOR
1-6E-1: CREATION OF POSITION, EMPLOYMENT:
There is hereby created the position of the City Administrator, an administrative position of the City.
A. Selection and Term of Service: The City Administrator shall be selected by and serve at the pleasure of the
