City Council and under such terms and conditions as the City Council shall determine and as are permitted
by law.
B. Qualifications: The City Administrator shall be chosen on the basis of executive, administrative and
academic qualifications with special reference to actual experience in and knowledge of accepted practices
in respect to the duties of that position as hereinafter set forth. The following factors and personal traits have
been identified by the City Council as ideal attributes for the City Administrator to possess:
Achievement of a bachelors degree in public or business administration or related field is highly desirable;
possess sufficient municipal administrative experience to direct and relate with all aspects of Countryside
City Administrator Municipal government responsibilities; have municipal experience in a metropolitan
setting involving interaction in regional and intergovernmental affairs; possess sound financial management
abilities, including budget preparation and administration; be knowledgeable about local land use planning
and zoning administration; have sufficient municipal experience and judgment to evaluate the adequacy of
Municipal organizations structure, staffing levels, and personal performance and productivity, toward
meeting current and future Municipal/community needs in a cost-effective manner; have an orientation
toward continuing education and professional development in self, staff, and employees - keeping up to date
and abreast of modern, innovative methods; possess and exemplify high moral standards and personal
ethics with a background of complete integrity; have a professional style which will establish early credibility
with City officials, Council, staff, and the community at large; possess an open style, dealing with all in a
forthright, straightforward, thoughtful, and responsive manner; follow an outgoing, personable, professional
and businesslike style in dealing with others, representing the City in a positive manner; be comfortable in
working closely with an active Mayor and being readily accessible to all elected officials; be accessible and
responsive to the Mayor, City Council, staff and employees, serving as a resource toward assisting in the
effective administration of progress and delivery of services; provide prompt, thorough, and fully responsive
implementation and follow-through on Council policy decisions, action, and direction; promote a strong
service-oriented approach by Municipal employees, ensuring that citizen inquiries and requests are dealt
with expeditiously and in a friendly manner; be detail oriented and well organized in accomplishing
administrative duties and responsibilities; follow a management style which involves a "no surprises"
approach in providing all the facts, alternatives, and implications of proposed administrative or policy
considerations of concern to the Mayor and City Council; be a good listener, with a sincere empathy and a
desire to understand other persons' point of view and concerns; anticipate rather than just react to Municipal
problems, concerns and opportunities; be innovative and creative; be willing to commit a reasonable period
of time serving the City; have the maturity, self-confidence, and strength of professional convictions to
provide administrative insights, counsel, and leadership to elected officials; not be a "yes" person, but able
to firmly and diplomatically present professional views, concerns, and implications of proposed policy action,
while also being committed to carry out ultimate policy decisions in a timely, professional and impartial
manner; possess solid personnel management skills, including a record of sensitivity and fairness to all
employees.
C. Absence Or Disability: During the absence or disability for any reason of the administrator, the city council
may designate some properly qualified person to perform the duties of the position of the city administrator.
6/5/2019 Sterling Codifiers, Inc.
https://www.sterlingcodifiers.com/codebook/index.php?book_id=502 66/767
(Ord. 95-23-0, 6-28-1995)
1-6E-2: BOND REQUIREMENTS:
Before assuming his or her position, the city administrator shall qualify for and have the minimum mandated
bond required for his or her position pursuant to the Illinois Compiled Statutes. The cost of such bond shall be
paid in its entirety by the city. (Ord. 14-34-0, 9-10-2014)
1-6E-3: COMPENSATION:
The city administrator shall receive such compensation as shall be fixed from time to time by the city council, in
accordance with law. (Ord. 86-03-0, 2-12-1986)
1-6E-4: RESPONSIBILITIES AND DUTIES:
Except as otherwise required by law, the city administrator, to the extent not prohibited by law, shall have such
specific duties as are assigned to him or her from time to time by the mayor and city council including, but not
limited to, those duties and authorities specifically provided for herein as follows:
A. To observe, review and evaluate the work of department heads, except the chief of police.
B. When directed to do so by the mayor or city council, to coordinate city council functions with those of other
city agencies, such as the board of fire and police commissioners, and the plan commission-zoning board1,
or with other outside public agencies, such as fire protection and sanitary districts, public schools, park
districts, other municipalities, the county and the state, keeping the mayor and council informed of major
activities, problems and possible areas of concern.
C. To assist and coordinate, through subordinate administrators, the programs and activities of all departments
and divisions of the city government (except the police department); assist these offices in any
administrative matter and in the coordination of activities; recommend to the mayor and city council
measures and ordinances deemed necessary and expedient; keep the mayor and city council fully advised
as to any special financial needs of the city which come to his or her attention.
D. To prepare and submit to the mayor and city council an annual appropriation and appropriation message;
upon its adoption, to oversee the administration and execution of the appropriation.
E. To prepare and submit to the mayor and city council justifications for capital improvements; review funding
alternatives, analyze costs and prepare recommendations; meet with the city council to explain proposed
capital improvements.
F. To prepare and submit to the mayor and city council an annual report on the finances and administrative
activities of the city.
G. To prepare reports on any specific municipal activity as requested by the mayor or city council; respond to
citizen requests regarding city services.
6/5/2019 Sterling Codifiers, Inc.
https://www.sterlingcodifiers.com/codebook/index.php?book_id=502 67/767
H. Subject to the direction of mayor or council, to attend meetings of local, regional, state or other offices to
represent the interest of the city and to keep informed on matters of interest to the city.
I. To meet with developers, contractors, consultants, attorneys, and others who are involved in city business or
have an interest in the city's development.
J. To recommend the hiring, termination, suspension or other discipline of city employees; recommend to the
city council a standard schedule of pay for each office and position in the city service.
K. To prepare agendas and supporting information for city council meetings, and when directed to do so by the
mayor or council, for any other public meetings; attend all meetings of the city council unless excused.
L. To supervise the purchase of all materials, supplies, and equipment for which funds have been provided.
M. To conduct regular staff meetings.
N. To promote and maintain responsive community relations, subject to the approval of the mayor or city
council.
O. To authorize all purchase orders and contracts for services, supplies, materials or equipment, or for
contractual services, including printing and publication, and all work or other public improvement contracts
involving the expenditure of not more than two thousand dollars ($2,000.00); provided, however, no such
purchase order or contract shall be authorized without a prior unexpended and unencumbered appropriation
in sufficient amount for such purposes. (Ord. 95-23-0, 6-28-1995)
P. To administer discipline in the form of suspension, with or without pay, for a period of up to ten (10) working
days, to all city employees, except department heads and members of, or those employed within, the police
department. (Ord. 96-02-0, 1-10-1996)
Q. To serve ex officio as the HIPAA privacy officer pursuant to article J of this chapter. (Ord. 03-12-0, 3-12-
2003)
1-6E-5: CONFLICT OF INTEREST PROHIBITED:
The city administrator shall comply fully with the "conflict of interest" provisions set forth from time to time in the
Illinois municipal code2 and the Illinois corrupt practices act3 regardless of whether said statutory provisions are
made expressly applicable to the position of city administrator. The city administrator shall also not violate any
common law principles regarding conflict of interest for municipal officers, and he or she shall also not be
interested directly or indirectly in any matters requiring decisions or recommendations to be made by the city
and/or any of its committees or commissions, and specifically including zoning and other legislative decisions,
unless expressly exempted by law or by the city council. (Ord. 86-03-0, 2-12-1986)
1-6E-6: TEMPORARY ADDITIONAL AUTHORITY TO AUTHORIZE EXPENDITURES IN
CONNECTION WITH MAPLE CREST GOLF COURSE:
Notwithstanding anything in this chapter to the contrary, and particularly subsection 1-6E-4O of this article, the
city administrator shall have the authority to authorize purchase orders and contracts for services, supplies,
6/5/2019 Sterling Codifiers, Inc.
https://www.sterlingcodifiers.com/codebook/index.php?book_id=502 68/767
materials or equipment directly related to the improvement, renovation and construction of Maple Crest golf
course, and its appurtenant facilities, in an amount not to exceed four thousand dollars ($4,000.00) per order
and/or contract, and not to exceed an aggregate of eight thousand dollars ($8,000.00) per calendar month. This
authority shall be in addition to the administrator's authority to authorize purchase orders and contracts of not
more than two thousand dollars ($2,000.00) provided for in subsection 1-6E-4O of this article, and shall be in
effect from and after the effective date of this section to and including June 30, 1993. (Ord. 92-15-0, 4-8-1992)
ARTICLE F. ADMINISTRATIVE CLERK
1-6F-1: CREATION OF POSITION, EMPLOYMENT:
There is hereby created the position of Administrative Clerk within the administrative structure of the City of
Countryside.
The Administrative Clerk shall be chosen on the basis of ability and competence with special reference to
knowledge of office terminology and procedures; ability to take and transcribe notes; ability to follow complex
oral and written instructions; ability to meet officials and others with tact and diplomacy; ability to maintain
complex clerical records and prepare reports from such records; good judgment, tact and courtesy; ability to
acquire knowledge of City and departmental policies; and good physical condition. Knowledge of some or all of
the following equipment is preferred:
Telephone
Electric typewriter
Electric calculator
Copy machine
Computer terminal for data entry
Computer terminal word processor
Postage meter and envelope sealer
Intercom systems
Pager system
1-6F-2: COMPENSATION:
The Administrative Clerk shall receive such compensation as shall be fixed from time to time by the City
Council.
1-6F-3: RESPONSIBILITIES AND DUTIES:
The Administrative Clerk shall be under the direction of the City Clerk and City Administrator and shall perform
secretarial and administrative duties and related work, as required, for the City Clerk, City Administrator and
Public Works Director. He or she shall have frequent contact with the public and shall handle a variety of
administrative matters with a view toward conserving the time of the City Clerk, City Administrator and
department heads. The Administrative Clerk shall have such specific duties as are assigned to him or her
including, but not limited to, those duties specifically provided for herein as follows:
A. Take, transcribe and type dictation, make appointments for superiors and remind them of appointments and
other matters needing their attention;
B. Prepare memoranda, letters and other correspondence from brief notes;
6/5/2019 Sterling Codifiers, Inc.
https://www.sterlingcodifiers.com/codebook/index.php?book_id=502 69/767
C. Screen visitors, telephone calls and incoming mail, act as switchboard operator, direct telephone calls to
proper department personnel;
D. Gather and compile background data for various reports;
E. Serve as recording secretary for City Council meetings and meetings of various boards and commissions of
the City at such time(s) as the regular recorder for each is absent;
F. Aid the City Clerk in maintenance of the City's official records system including minute books, ordinance
books and City Municipal Code;
G. Maintain files and records in an orderly and efficient manner;
H. Register voters;
I. Maintain and care for copy machine, maintain inventory of all office supplies and forms and order same as
needed;
J. Issue purchase orders as needed;
K. Notify City Council and various City boards and commissions of meetings;
L. Submit advertisements and notices to newspapers for publication; and
M. Distribute mail. (Ord. 86-25-0, 6-25-86)
ARTICLE G. CODE ENFORCEMENT OFFICER
1-6G-1: CREATION OF POSITION:
There is hereby created the position of Code Enforcement Officer within the administrative structure of the City.
1-6G-2: QUALIFICATIONS:
The Code Enforcement Officer shall have had at least two (2) years' experience in construction and/or property
management and maintenance, and in environmental health education and training. He or she shall have the
ability to perform inspection work involving elimination of blight and/or substandard conditions in existing
housing and be well informed on structural stability and mechanical equipment related to health and safety. He
or she shall have the ability to recognize hazardous conditions and recommend the proper corrective action for
their abatement and the ability and sensitivity to deal with property owners, limitations, and problems to secure
compliance, the ability to write concise, narrative reports and give testimony at appeals hearings and court
actions, and the ability to meet with people and to be able to explain the City's purpose and goals of improving
the home and environment. He or she shall be fluent in reading and writing the English language, and have as
a minimal educational requirement a high school diploma.
6/5/2019 Sterling Codifiers, Inc.
https://www.sterlingcodifiers.com/codebook/index.php?book_id=502 70/767
1-6G-3: RESPONSIBILITIES AND AUTHORITY:
The Code Enforcement Officer shall be under the direction and supervision of the Building Commissioner, and
shall have the following responsibilities and authority:
A. He or she shall investigate all complaints of violations of the City's building, zoning and health codes and
regulations, and all other codes and regulations enforceable by the Building Commissioner and the Health
Officer; and further, he or she shall investigate any situation where he or she has probable cause to believe
such violation exists, or when directed to do so by the Building Commissioner.
B. To the extent mandated by the Building Commissioner, he or she shall make ordinarily or extraordinary
inspections of construction in progress as are from time to time necessary to insure that all applicable codes
and regulations are being complied with.
C. To the extent mandated by the Building Commissioner, he or she shall make ordinary or extraordinary
inspections of facilities within the City subject to health codes and/or regulations to assure that the same are
being complied with.
D. When violations of codes and/or regulations subject to the Code Enforcement Officer's jurisdiction come to
his or her attention, through investigation or otherwise, the officer shall have authority to take one or more of
the following actions: To issue warning tickets, warning letters, verbal warnings and written citations for
violations; perform follow-up inspections on previously issued warnings; meet with developers and
contractors to discuss ordinance violations and compliance; initiate long-range ordinance goals; sign
complaints for the prosecution of ordinance violations; and to take any other actions reasonably necessary
to insure or bring about compliance with city codes and regulations.
E. Subject to direction of the Building Commissioner, the Code Enforcement Officer shall, among other things,
document pertinent information concerning, and prepare reports regarding, inspections, investigations,
complaints received, violations and their dispositions; and cooperate with the City Prosecutor and City
Attorney by giving testimony and otherwise assisting in the prosecution of ordinance violations. Further,
activities of the Code Enforcement Officer, including inspections and investigations, shall be at the times,
places and in the manner prescribed by the Building Commissioner.
1-6G-4: COMPENSATION:
The Code Enforcement Officer shall be an employee of the City and receive such compensation as shall be
fixed from time to time by the City Council. (Ord. 88-12-0, 2-10-88)
ARTICLE H. DRUG AND ALCOHOL ABUSE POLICY

The drug and alcohol abuse policy ordinance of the City is of a general and permanent nature, is codified as
Title 1, Chapter 6 Article H, contains Sections 1-6H-1 through 1-6H-8 and shall hereby constitute Title 1,
Chapter 6 Article H, of this City Code, same being adopted by reference as fully as if set out at length herein.
Said regulations are published in pamphlet form, and the City Clerk shall keep two (2) copies thereof on file in
his office and available for public inspection. (Ord. 95-46-0, 12-13-1995)

ARTICLE I. COMMUNITY DEVELOPMENT OFFICER
1-6I-1: CREATION OF POSITION, EMPLOYMENT:
There is hereby created the position of the community development officer, an administrative position in the city.
A. Selection And Term Of Service: The community development officer shall be selected by and serve at the
pleasure of the city council and under such terms and conditions as the city council shall determine and as
are permitted by law.
B. Qualifications: The community development officer shall be chosen on the basis of executive, administrative
and academic qualifications with special reference to actual experience in and knowledge of accepted
practices in respect to the duties of that position as hereinafter set forth. The following factors and personal
traits have been identified by the city council as ideal attributes for the community development officer to
possess:
Achievement of a Bachelor's Degree in Planning, Public Administration or a related field is highly desirable;
three (3) to five (5) years demonstrable experience in the area of community development; municipal
experience in a metropolitan setting involving interaction in regional and intergovernmental affairs; a working
knowledge of local land use planning and zoning administration; have an orientation toward continuing
education and professional development of self; a desire and ability to keep up to date and abreast of
modern, innovative methods; exemplary high moral standards and personal ethics with a background of the
highest integrity; have a professional style which will establish early credibility with city officials, council,
staff, and the community at large; an open style and ability to deal with all in a forthright, straightforward,
thoughtful, and responsive manner; outgoing, personable, professional and businesslike style in dealing with
others and the ability to represent the city in a positive manner; be comfortable working closely with an
active mayor and be readily accessible to all elected officials. He or she must also be accessible and
responsive to the mayor, city council; provide prompt, thorough, and fully responsive implementation and
follow through on council policy decisions, action, and direction; be detail oriented and well organized in
accomplishing duties and responsibilities; follow a management style which involves a "no surprises"
approach in providing all the facts, alternatives, and implications of proposed administrative or policy
considerations of concern to the mayor and city council; be a good listener, with a sincere empathy and a
desire to understand other persons' points of view and concerns; anticipate rather than just react to
problems, concerns and opportunities; be innovative and creative; be willing to commit a reasonable period
of time serving the city; have the maturity, self-confidence, and strength of professional convictions to
provide administrative insights, counsel, and leadership to elected officials; not be a "yes" person, but able
to firmly and diplomatically present professional views, concerns, and implications of proposed policy action,
while also being committed to carry out ultimate policy decisions in a timely, professional and impartial
manner; possess solid personnel management skills.
C. Absence Or Disability: During the absence or disability for any reason of the community development officer,
the city council may designate some properly qualified person to perform the duties of the position of the
community development officer. (Ord. 02-19-0, 7-10-2002)
1-6I-2: COMPENSATION:
The community development officer shall receive such compensation as shall be fixed from time to time by the
city council, in accordance with law. (Ord. 02-19-0, 7-10-2002)
6/5/2019 Sterling Codifiers, Inc.
https://www.sterlingcodifiers.com/codebook/index.php?book_id=502 72/767
1-6I-3: RESPONSIBILITIES AND DUTIES:
A. Duties: Except as otherwise required by law, the community development officer, to the extent not prohibited
by law, shall have such specific duties as are assigned to him or her from time to time by the mayor and city
council and the city administrator including, but not limited to, those duties and authorities specifically
provided for herein as follows:
Under general direction from the city administrator, the community development officer shall plan and direct
economic development activities; be primarily responsible for marketing and promoting the city to attract
new businesses; actively support retention and expansion of existing businesses; developing short and long
range plans for city economic development; prepare and manage the departmental budget.
The community development officer shall also prepare reports on any specific municipal activity as
requested by the mayor or city council or city administrator and respond to citizen requests regarding
community development. Subject to the direction of mayor, the city council or the city administrator, the
community development officer may attend meetings of local, regional, state or other offices to represent the
interest of the city to keep informed on matters of interest to the city. The community development officer
may also meet with developers, contractors, consultants, attorneys, and others who are involved in city
business or have an interest in the city's development.
The community development officer will promote and maintain responsive community relations, subject to
the approval of the mayor or city council.
B. Physical Demand: The physical demands described herein are representative of those that must be met by
an employee to successfully perform the essential functions of this job. Reasonable accommodations may
be made to enable individuals with disabilities to perform the essential functions.
Work is performed mostly in office settings. Some outdoor work is required in the inspection of various land
use developments and construction sites. Due to varying topographic conditions encountered in
Countryside, such as construction sites, some inspections may involve rugged terrain. Hand eye
coordination is necessary to operate computers and various pieces of office equipment.
While performing the duties of this job, the employee is frequently required to talk or hear; sit; use hands to
finger, handle, feel or operate objects, tools, or controls; and reach with hands and arms. The employee is
occasionally required to stand or walk.
The employee must occasionally lift and/or move up to twenty five (25) pounds. Specific vision abilities
required by this job include close vision, distance vision, peripheral vision, depth perception and the ability to
adjust focus. (Ord. 02-19-0, 7-10-2002)
1-6I-4: CONFLICT OF INTEREST PROHIBITED:
The community development officer shall comply fully with the "conflict of interest" provisions set forth from time
to time in the Illinois municipal code and the Illinois corrupt practices act regardless of whether said statutory
provisions are made expressly applicable to the position of community development officer. The community
development officer shall also not violate any common law principles regarding conflict of interest for municipal
officers, and he or she shall also not be interested directly or indirectly in any matters requiring decisions or
recommendations to be made by the city and/or any of its committees or commissions, and specifically
including zoning and other legislative decisions, unless expressly exempted by law or by the city council. (Ord.
02-19-0, 7-10-2002)
ARTICLE J. HIPAA PRIVACY OFFICER
6/5/2019 Sterling Codifiers, Inc.
https://www.sterlingcodifiers.com/codebook/index.php?book_id=502 73/767
1-6J-1: CREATION OF POSITION AND DESIGNATION:
There is hereby created the position of health insurance portability and accountability act (HIPAA) privacy
officer within the administrative structure of the city of Countryside, and the city administrator shall ex officio
hold that position. (Ord. 03-12-0, 3-12-2003)
1-6J-2: QUALIFICATIONS:
The HIPAA privacy officer shall have the following qualifications: He or she shall be the duly appointed and
acting city administrator for the city of Countryside and shall be and remain acquainted with the relevant privacy
laws, access to and release of information control technologies and techniques for releasing, accessing,
exchanging and transferring information, all in accordance with applicable HIPAA standards. He or she shall
also be and remain current with and able to apply principles of health insurance maintenance program and
project management. (Ord. 03-12-0, 3-12-2003)
1-6J-3: RESPONSIBILITIES AND AUTHORITIES:
The HIPAA privacy officer will have the following responsibilities and authorities:
A. Provide development guidance and assist in the identification, implementation, and maintenance of the city's
information privacy policies and procedures in coordination with the city's management and administration,
the privacy oversight committee, if one is created, and legal counsel.
B. Work with the city's administration to establish a privacy oversight committee within the city's administration.
C. Serve in a leadership role for the privacy oversight committee's activities.
D. Perform initial and periodic information privacy risk assessments and conduct related ongoing compliance
monitoring activities in coordination with any other compliance and operational assessment functions of the
city.
E. Work with legal counsel and management, all departments, and committees to ensure the city has and
maintains appropriate privacy and confidentiality consent, authorization forms, and information notices and
materials reflecting current legal practices and requirements.
F. Oversee, direct, deliver, or ensure delivery of initial privacy training and orientation to all city officials,
employees and other appropriate third parties.
G. Participate in the development, implementation, and ongoing compliance monitoring of all
intergovernmental, business, and other agreements, to ensure all privacy concerns, requirements, and
responsibilities are addressed.
H. Establish with the administration a mechanism to track access to protected health information, within the
purview of the city's administration and as required by law and to allow qualified individuals to review or
receive a report on such activity.
6/5/2019 Sterling Codifiers, Inc.
https://www.sterlingcodifiers.com/codebook/index.php?book_id=502 74/767
I. Work cooperatively with the health insurance maintenance (HIM) director, if one is designated, and other
applicable city personnel or units in overseeing patient rights to inspect, amend, and restrict access to
protected health information when appropriate.
J. Establish and administer a process for receiving, documenting, tracking, investigating, and taking action on
all complaints concerning the city's privacy policies and procedures in coordination and collaboration with
other similar functions and, when necessary, legal counsel.
K. Ensure compliance with privacy practices and consistent application of sanctions for failure to comply with
privacy policies for all individuals in the city's work force, extended work force, and for all business
associates, in cooperation with the administration and legal counsel as applicable.
L. Initiate, facilitate and promote activities to foster information privacy awareness within the city administration
and related entities.
M. Serve as a member of, or liaison to, the city's privacy committee, should one be created.
N. Review all system related information security plans throughout the city's administration to ensure alignment
between security and privacy practices.
O. Work with all city personnel involved with any aspect of release of protected health information, to ensure full
coordination and cooperation under the city's policies and procedures and legal requirements.
P. Maintain current knowledge of applicable federal and state privacy laws and accreditation standards, and
monitor advancements in information privacy technologies to ensure their adaptation and compliance.
Q. Serve as information privacy consultant to the city for all officials, personnel, departments and other
appropriate entities.
R. Cooperate with the office of civil rights, other legal entities, and city officials in any compliance reviews or
investigations.
S. Work with the city administration, legal counsel, and other related parties to represent the city's information
privacy interests with external parties (state or local government bodies) who undertake to adopt or amend
privacy legislation, regulations, or standards. (Ord. 03-12-0, 3-12-2003)
ARTICLE K. BUDGET AND FINANCE DIRECTOR
1-6K-1: CREATION OF POSITION:
There is hereby created the position of budget and finance director, an administrative position in the city. (Ord.
05-28-0, 8-10-2005)
1-6K-2: SELECTION AND TERM OF SERVICE:
6/5/2019 Sterling Codifiers, Inc.
https://www.sterlingcodifiers.com/codebook/index.php?book_id=502 75/767
The budget and finance director shall be selected by and serve at the pleasure of the city council and under
such terms and conditions as the city council shall determine and as are permitted by law. (Ord. 05-28-0, 8-10-
2005)
1-6K-3: JOB SUMMARY:
Under the direction of the city treasurer and city administrator, the position of finance director provides
administrative and supervisory direction for the planning and supporting of the city's financial activities,
including investing, debt management, capital planning, budgeting and purchasing. The finance director assists
the city administrator in defining the strategic direction of the city in relation to the needs of the community and
the mission of the city of Countryside. (Ord. 05-28-0, 8-10-2005)
1-6K-4: DUTIES AND RESPONSIBILITIES:
The duties and responsibilities described below are indicative of what the position may be asked to perform;
other duties may be assigned. The job description is to be incorporated into any municipal ordinances created
for the position. Reasonable accommodations may be made to enable individuals with disabilities to perform
the essential functions.
A. Strategic:
1. Develop and communicate short and long term goals for the department.
2. Direct the operation of the budget through budget planning, purchasing, negotiating contract services,
capital improvements, etc.
3. Establish, within city policy, appropriate service and staffing levels; monitor and evaluate the efficiency
and effectiveness of service delivery methods and procedures; allocate resources accordingly.
4. Direct the operations of the department through the development of policies, procedures, department
guidelines, rules, etc.
5. Support administration by providing reliable and accurate reports for municipal operations and planning.
6. Make formal presentation on city financial activities and provide staff support to assigned boards and
commissions. (Ord. 05-28-0, 8-10-2005)
B. Administrative:
1. Oversee and participate in the development and administration of the city's budget. The budget and
finance director shall be authorized to exercise the duties and powers as granted to the city treasurer.
(Ord. 06-21-0, 6-14-2006)
2. Oversee and participate in the development and administration of the finance department budget;
approve the forecast of funds needed for staffing, equipment, materials, and supplies; approve
expenditures and implement budgetary adjustments as appropriate and necessary.
3. Assist with the presentation of the budget to appropriate city officials and the council.
4. Monitor the daily cash activity of the city; supervise all collection activities; ensure proper methods,
techniques and procedures are observed by city personnel.
5. Ensure budgetary constraints are monitored and observed; compile statements of current operating and
capital outlay expenditures for use in preparing budget estimates.
6/5/2019 Sterling Codifiers, Inc.
https://www.sterlingcodifiers.com/codebook/index.php?book_id=502 76/767
6. Direct the preparation of financial statements, cost reports, statements of receipts and expenditures at
regular intervals.
7. Transfer city funds between appropriate accounts and ensure adequate funds.
8. Work with the city's auditors in preparing and presenting financial audit worksheets, guarantees, etc.
C. Payroll/Human Resources:
1. Direct the payroll functions ensuring that data is updated, pay is correct and in accordance with city policy
and union contracts.
2. Ensure that all payroll records are tracked and prepared according to accounting practices.
3. Direct the preparation of all year-end reports, W-2s, etc.
4. Coordinate replies for requests of information by the public, other staff, accountants, etc.
5. Prepare recurring and special reports and analyses as requested by departments, mayor or council.
6. Coordinate proper payment of the Illinois municipal retirement fund (IMRF), including calculating the city's
share, submission of payments, and completion of required reports.
7. Assist the city administrator in the procurement, implementation, and maintenance of the city's insurance
programs - health, dental, life, etc.
8. Function as the city liaison for benefits with employees and authorized agents.
9. Initiate and process unemployment claims.
10. Ensure that new employees are orientated regarding payroll and benefits of the city.
D. Investments:
1. Supervise the investment of city funds; make recommendations and monitor investment choices.
2. Work with the appropriate agencies to investigate and recommend investment instruments to the mayor
and council.
3. Monitor city investments to ensure proper and timely renewals or transfers, and assure maximization of
earnings.
E. Clerical:
1. Develop annual treasurer's report for publication.
2. Maintain accurate and up to date personnel information within the department.
3. Prepare reports for the city council and other agencies as appropriate.
4. Prepare checks for bill payments approved by the city council.
5. Prepare quarterly reports for federal and state taxes, grants, and other agencies.
6. Maintain and update fixed assets records.
F. Public Relations:
6/5/2019 Sterling Codifiers, Inc.
https://www.sterlingcodifiers.com/codebook/index.php?book_id=502 77/767
1. Assist citizens and city personnel with requests for service.
2. Handle departmental complaints and inquiries.
3. Represent the finance department to other city departments, elected officials and outside agencies;
coordinate finance department activities with those of other departments and outside agencies and
organizations.
4. Respond to and resolve difficult and sensitive citizen inquiries and complaints.
G. Supervision:
1. Ensure that employees understand how work is related to the city's mission.
2. Assist in the hiring of personnel.
3. Work with employees to set job expectations and monitor productivity.
4. Stay informed regarding employee's progress and performance and provide feedback.
5. Complete employee evaluation instruments and assist in employee development.
6. Identify employee performance issues and implement performance improvement measures.
H. Professional Development:
1. Attend and participate in professional group meetings; stay abreast of new trends and innovations in the
field of finance program administration. (Ord. 05-28-0, 8-10-2005)
1-6K-5: QUALIFICATION REQUIREMENTS:
To perform this job successfully, an individual must be able to perform each duty satisfactorily. The
requirements listed below are representative of the knowledge, skill and/or ability required at the time of hire or
for continuation of employment:
A. Education And Experience:
1. Bachelor's degree in business, accounting, economics or equivalent major.
2. Master's degree in business preferred.
3. Certified public accountant.
4. A minimum of three (3) years in finance or accounting for municipal government.
5. A minimum of five (5) years of progressively responsible supervisory experience.
6. A minimum of three (3) years' advanced knowledge of word processing and spreadsheets.
B. Skills And Abilities:
1. Ability to cooperate with staff, elected officials, and the public.
2. Ability to maintain a professional manner when dealing with the public.
3. Ability to use office equipment such as copy machines, typewriters, computers, fax machines, etc.
6/5/2019 Sterling Codifiers, Inc.
https://www.sterlingcodifiers.com/codebook/index.php?book_id=502 78/767
C. Language Skills:
1. Ability to communicate effectively with other members of the staff, councils, supervisor, and the public.
2. Ability to communicate effectively in both written and verbal form.
D. Mathematical Skills:
1. Ability to perform advanced mathematical calculations, primarily in spreadsheets.
2. Ability to perform statistical analysis of data and make recommendations.
E. Reasoning Skills:
1. Ability to organize time and resources.
2. Ability to define problems and deal with a variety of situations.
3. Ability to think quickly, maintain self-control, and adapt to stressful situations.
4. Ability to use good judgment and effectively solve problems.
5. Ability to plan work and establish priorities.
F. Physical/Work Environment: The physical demands and work environment described are representative of
those that must be met by an employee to successfully perform the essential functions of this job.
1. Physical Environment:
a. The duties of this job may include physical activities such as reaching, standing, walking, extended
sitting, fingering, grasping, talking, hearing, listening, seeing/observing, and performing repetitive
motions.
b. Specific vision abilities required by this job include close, distance, and peripheral vision; depth
perception, and the ability to adjust focus.
c. This job is performed in an office environment.
2. Work Environment: The work environment may include some of the following:
a. Time pressure (frequent rush jobs, urgent deadlines, etc.).
b. Working under distractions (telephone calls, distractions, disturbances). (Ord. 05-28-0, 8-10-2005)
ARTICLE L. CITY ATTORNEY
1-6L-1: ESTABLISHED OFFICE, APPOINTMENT:
Heretofore there has been created the office of the city attorney, an executive office of the city. The city attorney
has been and shall continue to be appointed by the mayor with the advice and consent of the city council and
shall enjoy all of the emoluments of the office whether appointed and holding office as an independent
contractor or as an employee. During his term, the city attorney shall receive such compensation as may be
fixed by contract from time to time. He shall have direct communication with the city council and its members
6/5/2019 Sterling Codifiers, Inc.
https://www.sterlingcodifiers.com/codebook/index.php?book_id=502 79/767
individually as well as with the other city officials. The city attorney may be removed from office by the mayor
with the advice and consent of the city council. (Ord. 11-56-0, 9-14-2011)
1-6L-2: DUTIES:
The city attorney shall continue to be responsible for all legal matters pertaining to the city. Upon request by the
mayor or city council, he shall render any given legal opinion in writing. Examples of the duties of the city
attorney follow:
A. The city attorney shall prosecute, as the city prosecutor, or cause to be prosecuted violations of any of the
provisions of this code or other ordinances of the city, including complaints of zoning and housing violations
and shall advise and assist all city officials or employees on questions of law involved in filing complaints,
making arrest and preparing for prosecutions. He shall prosecute or defend, as the case may be,
administrative law actions and any and all suits or actions at law or in equity to which the city may be a
party, or in which it may be interested, including those brought against or by any officer of the city in the
capacity of such person as an officer or on behalf of the city.
B. The city attorney shall be the legal advisor to the boards and commissioners of the city, prepare all
ordinances and resolutions, and render opinions on city bond issues. (Ord. 11-56-0, 9-14-2011)
Chapter 7
BIDDING AND CONTRACT PROCEDURES
1-7-1: COMPETITIVE BIDDING REQUIRED:
Any work or other public improvement which is not to be paid for in whole or in part by special assessment and
all purchases of, and contracts for supplies and services, shall, except as specifically provided herein, be based
whenever possible on competitive bids. (1970 Code §2-16.01, as amended)
1-7-2: FORMAL CONTRACT PROCEDURE:
All work or other public improvement which is not to be paid for in whole or in part by special assessment and
all purchases of, and contracts for supplies and services, except as otherwise provided herein, when the
estimated cost thereof shall exceed five thousand dollars ($5,000.00), shall be purchased by formal, written
contract from the lowest responsible bidder, after due notice inviting bids, unless competitive bidding is waived
by a vote of the city council. (Ord. 03-02-0, 1-8-2003)
1-7-3: NOTICE INVITING BIDS:
Notice inviting bids shall be published at least once in a newspaper with a general circulation within the city.
The newspaper notice required herein shall include a general description of the work to be performed or the
articles to be purchased, shall state where specifications may be secured, and the time and place for opening
bids. (1970 Code §§2-16.03, 2-16.04, as amended)
1-7-4: BULLETIN BOARD:
6/5/2019 Sterling Codifiers, Inc.
https://www.sterlingcodifiers.com/codebook/index.php?book_id=502 80/767
The city shall also advertise all pending work or purchases by posting a notice on the public bulletin board in
the city hall. (1970 Code §2-16.05, as amended)
1-7-5: BID DEPOSITS:
When deemed necessary by the city council, bid deposits shall be prescribed in the public notices inviting bids.
Unsuccessful bidders shall be entitled to return of their bid deposits upon the award of the contract by the city
council. A successful bidder shall forfeit any bid deposit required by the city council upon failure on his part to
enter into a contract within ten (10) days after the award, unless such period is extended by the city council.
(1970 Code §2-16.06, as amended; amd. 1986 Code)
1-7-6: BID OPENING PROCEDURE:
A. Sealed: Bids shall be submitted sealed to the city and shall be identified as bids on the envelope.
B. Opening: Bids shall be opened in public at the time and place stated in the public notices.
C. Tabulation: A tabulation of all bids received shall be made by the city council or by a city employee, in which
event a tabulation of the bids shall be furnished to the city council at its next regular meeting. (1970 Code
§2-16.07, as amended)
1-7-7: REJECTION OF BIDS:
A. Authority Of City: The city shall have the authority to reject all bids or parts of all bids when the public interest
will be served thereby.
B. Bidders In Default To City: The city shall not accept the bid of a contractor who is in default on the payment
of taxes, licenses or other monies due the city. (1970 Code §2-16.08, as amended)
1-7-8: AWARD OF CONTRACTS:
A. Authority In City: The city council shall have the authority to award contracts within the purview of this
chapter.
B. Lowest Responsible Bidder: Contracts shall be awarded to the lowest responsible bidder on the basis of the
bid that is in the best interest of the city to accept. In awarding the contract, in addition to price, the city
council shall consider:
1. The ability, capacity and skill of the bidder to perform the contract to provide the service required.
2. Whether the bidder can perform the contract or provide the service promptly, or within the time specified,
without delay or interference.
3. The character, integrity, reputation, judgment, experience and efficiency of the bidder.
4. The quality of performance of previous contracts or services.
6/5/2019 Sterling Codifiers, Inc.
https://www.sterlingcodifiers.com/codebook/index.php?book_id=502 81/767
5. The previous and existing compliance by the bidder with laws and ordinances relating to the contract or
service.
6. The sufficiency of the financial resources and ability of the bidder to perform the contract or provide the
service.
7. The quality, availability and adaptability of the supplies or contractual services to the particular use
required.
8. The ability of the bidder to provide future maintenance and service for the use of the subject of the
contract.
9. The number and scope of conditions attached to the bid.
10. Whether the bidder has a place of business in the city. (1970 Code §2-16.09, as amended)
C. Performance Bonds: The city council shall have the authority to require a performance bond, before entering
into a contract, in such amount as it shall find reasonably necessary to protect the best interests of the city.
If any such bond is posted in cash, it shall be subject to the unclaimed bond forfeiture provisions of chapter
9 of this title. (Ord. 92-29-0, 10-14-1992)
1-7-9: OPEN MARKET PROCEDURE:
All work and purchases of supplies and services of less than the estimated value of five thousand dollars
($5,000.00) shall be made in the open market, without newspaper advertisement and without observing the
procedure prescribed by this chapter for the award of formal contracts. (1970 Code §2-16.10, as amended;
amd. 1986 Code)
1-7-10: PROFESSIONAL SERVICES; EXEMPT FROM BIDDING REQUIREMENTS:
All contracts for professional services, including, but not limited to, attorneys, engineers, real estate appraisers,
architects and city planners, may be entered into by the city without observing the bidding procedures
prescribed by this chapter for the award of formal contracts. (1970 Code §2-16.11, as amended)
1-7-11: EMERGENCY PURCHASES:
In case of an apparent emergency which requires immediate work or purchase of supplies or services, the city
council shall be empowered to secure by open market procedure as herein set forth, at the lowest obtainable
price, any work, supplies or services regardless of the amount of the expenditure. (1970 Code §2-16.12, as
amended)
1-7-12: COOPERATIVE PURCHASING:
The city shall have the authority to join with other units of government in cooperative purchasing plans when the
best interests of the city would be served thereby. (1970 Code §2-16.13, as amended)
1-7-13: LIMITATIONS ON CONSTRUCTION CONTRACTS:
A. Except as hereinafter provided, all change orders to construction contracts originally awarded by the city
council must receive approval from the city council. Bid specifications of all construction contracts shall
6/5/2019 Sterling Codifiers, Inc.
https://www.sterlingcodifiers.com/codebook/index.php?book_id=502 82/767
indicate the same. However, any change order that: 1) will not affect the contract price; 2) will lower the
contract price; or 3) will not increase the contract price by an amount in excess of ten thousand dollars
($10,000.00), shall be received and approved by the city administrator. (Ord. 03-21-0, 6-25-2003)
B. No claim whatsoever will be allowed to the contractor for changes, extra work, or material not included in the
contractor's original bid, or for a greater amount of money than the contract states is to be paid, for any
reason, including, but not limited to, subsurface or latent physical conditions, or unknown physical conditions
at the site, unless the change in, or addition to the work, and/or changes in the amount of money to be paid
to the contractor is first ordered in writing by the city engineer, and the additional price paid is agreed to in
writing by the city engineer and contractor and approved by the city council.
C. The contractor is responsible for making a careful examination of the site of the proposed work, the bid
documents, specifications, general conditions, plans, special provisions and contract forms before
submitting his bid. The contractor is responsible for fully informing himself as to the quality and quantity of
materials required and the character of the work to be performed. The contractor shall further make
investigation of the site prior to submitting his bid.
D. The provisions of this section shall apply in lieu of the provisions of the Illinois statutes 30 Illinois Compiled
Statutes 557/10 and 557/20. This portion of this code shall be reflected in all contracts made by the city
under which the public construction act would be applicable. (Ord. 00-28-0, 9-13-2000)
Chapter 8
CORPORATE SEAL
1-8-1: DESIGN:
The Corporate Seal of the City shall be the seal hitherto established and used as the City Seal, namely, a
circular disk with the words City of Countryside, Cook County, Ill. on the outer edge and in the interior the words
Corporate Seal. (1970 Code §1-1.08)
1-8-2: USE AND CUSTODY:
The Corporate Seal of the City shall be and remain in the custody of the City Clerk and his successor in office1,
to be used by him in all cases provided for by any provisions of this Code or other ordinance of the City or the
laws of the State, and in all such other cases whereby the laws and customs of any state or nation the use of
the Corporate Seal of the City becomes necessary. (1970 Code §1.1.09)
Chapter 9
UNCLAIMED BONDS
1-9-1: DEFINITION - FORFEITURE:
If any bond required under any section of this Municipal Code to insure performance, indemnity or fealty, except
bonds of City officials or employees, shall be in cash, and remains unclaimed by the party entitled to its return
for a period of six (6) months after notice is given pursuant to Section 1-9-2 hereof, it shall be forfeit to, and
become the property of, the City. (Ord. 92-29-0, 10-14-92)
6/5/2019 Sterling Codifiers, Inc.
https://www.sterlingcodifiers.com/codebook/index.php?book_id=502 83/767
1-9-2: NOTICE:
When the purpose for which any bond described in Section 1-9-1 above has become accomplished, and it is no
longer necessary, in the opinion of the appropriate City authority, that such bond be retained, the City Clerk's
office shall be so notified and forthwith give notice to the party entitled to the return of such bond that it may be
redeemed. Such notice shall be in writing and delivered in person, or by certified mail return receipt requested,
to that party's last known address. If, after a good faith attempt, delivery in person or by mail is unsuccessful,
such notice shall be published at least once in a newspaper of general circulation within the city, village or
township of that party's last known address. (Ord. 92-29-0, 10-14-92)
Chapter 10
MILEAGE REIMBURSEMENT
1-10-1: REIMBURSEMENT FOR MILEAGE TRAVELED:
Any elected official, officer, employee, agent, servant, or other person, firm or corporation, entitled to be paid
reimbursement by the City for mileage traveled, shall, in the absence of a prior agreement to the contrary (an
agreement entered into before such travel is undertaken) receive such reimbursement at a rate per mile equal
to that which is accepted by the Internal Revenue Service of the United States of America for tax purposes on
the date or dates such travel is made. (Ord. 94-06-0, 3-23-94)
Chapter 11
TUITION ASSISTANCE PROGRAM
1-11-1: PURPOSES:
The Tuition Assistance Program (TAP) is expected to enhance employee performance and skills; however, it
does not guarantee continued employment, advancement, different job assignments, or pay increases. (Ord.
95-32-0, 8-23-95)
1-11-2: ELIGIBILITY:
The TAP applies to active regular full-time employees. To maintain eligibility, employees must be on the City's
active payroll through completion of each course. (Ord. 95-32-0, 8-23-95)
1-11-3: ELIGIBILITY REQUIREMENTS:
A. Course Eligibility: For a course to qualify under the TAP, a course or degree must be pursued through a
regionally accredited institution, and must meet the following conditions. It must:
1. Broaden academic knowledge;
2. Enhance career opportunities, but not prepare the employee for a new profession (e.g., law, real estate,
social work, counseling, paralegal), or professional license (e.g., CPA);
6/5/2019 Sterling Codifiers, Inc.
https://www.sterlingcodifiers.com/codebook/index.php?book_id=502 84/767
3. Earn college credits; or
4. May qualify if it is:
a. Required to obtain an approved degree (e.g., physical education courses, one required for graduation
and at least fifty percent (50%) of degree courses requirements have been completed);
b. Required for admission to an approved degree program even if no credit is awarded (e.g., remedial or
refresher courses);
c. An elective applied to an approved degree except for skilled based courses (e.g., commercial computer
software, such as Word Perfect or Lotus) or, courses related to games, hobbies, or leisure activities;
d. Required for a second degree at the same level as the first if the second degree is:
(1) Related to the employees job or relevant to the City's business;
(2) Needed for a higher degree in a different discipline;
e. It is taken through a high school or other qualified educational institution and leads to a grammar school
certificate or a high school diploma.
B. Prohibited During Work Hours: A course or degree must not be pursued during the employee's standard
work hours at the City.
C. Reimbursement Agreement: As a condition to an employee's participation in the Tuition Assistance Program,
and in consideration therefor, he or she shall execute an agreement, in the form made a part hereof as
Appendix I, adopted herein as set out at length, whereby it is agreed that if such employee leaves City
employment voluntarily or due to disciplinary reasons within three (3) years from the date he or she has
completed, or otherwise ceased attending, the course of study for which the tuition assistance was provided
by the City, he or she will reimburse the City a sum of money equal to the full amount of tuition assistance
provided multiplied by that percentage of said three (3) year period remaining at the time employment
ceased.
D. Costs Allowed: The following is a list of the allowed and disallowed expenses:
Allowed Expenses Disallowed Expenses
Tuition Admission tests
Registration, nonresident laboratory,
library, mandatory student health fees,
and all mandatory recurring fees (e.g.,
building facilities fees)
Application fees
Course audit
Books
College Level Examination Program
(CLEP) or CLEP-type test fees if test
results in college credit
Equipment, insurance,
and late registration
fees
Evaluation of Life Experience Portfolio
if evaluation results in college credits
Meals/lodging
6/5/2019 Sterling Codifiers, Inc.
https://www.sterlingcodifiers.com/codebook/index.php?book_id=502 85/767
Continuous registration fee for up to
six (6) semesters beyond completion of
courses/programs while working on
thesis/dissertation
Parking
Postage
Test review classes
(e.g., SAT, GMAT,
CPA, Bar Exam)
Nonacademic activity
fees
Personal student
health insurance
Transportation
Tutoring
(Ord. 95-32-0, 8-23-95)
1-11-4: EMPLOYEE RESPONSIBILITIES:
A. The educational decisions should reflect current career plan goals.
B. It is recommended that the employee's career plans be periodically reviewed by his or her supervisors in
conjunction with all educational plans.
C. Questions concerning the appropriateness of a course or a degree should be directed to the employee's
supervisor.
D. TAP applicants must report any monies received from another agency or institution (e.g., scholarship,
fellowship, grant, Veterans' Educational Assistance) for TAP-covered tuition and allowed expenses. These
funds are deducted from TAP payments. Failure to report these funds is considered misconduct and may
result in loss of tuition assistance and disciplinary action up to and including termination.
E. Employees must also inform granting agencies or institutions of tuition assistance received from the City.
F. To be covered by the TAP, an employee must receive a minimum grade of "C-" (C minus) or equivalent for
each course. A grade of "pass" is acceptable for courses graded on a "pass/fail" basis.
Employees must submit an original grade report within sixty (60) days of course completion.
An incomplete grade ("I") is valid for one hundred twenty (120) days from the course completion date. All
that time, the supervisor assigns an "F" if a passing grade report is not received.
6/5/2019 Sterling Codifiers, Inc.
https://www.sterlingcodifiers.com/codebook/index.php?book_id=502 86/767
Further tuition assistance may be denied until an employee has demonstrated successful completion of the
course.
G. TAP participants are also responsible to:
1. Tell his or her supervisor of educational plans so the supervisor can budget funds.
2. Discuss career goals with the supervisor and link to educational goals.
3. Consult with the supervisor on course(s) or degree(s) relating to job or career plan.
4. Seek supervisory guidance to ensure educational activities will not negatively effect job performance.
5. Prepare TAP request completely and accurately and submit to supervisor for initial review and approval.
6. Submit a completed original request for final review and approval at least three (3) weeks before course
starts. Reimbursements or payment will not be made if the original application arrives after course finish
date.
7. Submit original, itemized documents showing payment of tuition and allowed expenses.
8. Submit an original grade report to the supervisor (within sixty calendar days after completing course).
Further, tuition assistance may be denied until an employee has demonstrated successful completion of
each course taken.
H. Employees should discuss educational plans with their supervisors before applying for tuition assistance.
(Ord. 95-32-0, 8-23-95)
1-11-5: REIMBURSEMENTS:
When tuition repayment is required, the employee should contact the City (preferably through his or her
supervisor) as soon as possible but not later than sixty (60) days after course completion to arrange
reimbursement.
Payment is made when original itemized expense statements from the school, or itemized bills and receipts
from the employee are provided to the City. (Ord. 95-32-0, 8-23-95)
1-11-6: TAX CONSIDERATIONS:
Tuition assistance is considered income when a course or degree is not directly job related and the total
nondirectly job-related annual tuition exceeds Federal, State, or local exclusion limits. As the tax laws are
changed, the students withholdings may vary. Most states follow Federal tax laws for tuition assistance. If the
tuition is taxable at the Federal level, the aggregate withholding is approximately thirty eight percent (38%) of
the total taxable tuition assistance. The employee's tax liability, however, may vary based upon personal
circumstances.
Tuition assistance is treated according to the tax laws in effect when the grades are processed and associated
course dollars are expended to the proper area.
Note: Employees should consult their personal tax advisor about tuition assistance taxability, since tax laws are
subject to change from time-to-time. (Ord. 95-32-0, 8-23-95)
1-11-7: SUPERVISOR'S RESPONSIBILITIES:
6/5/2019 Sterling Codifiers, Inc.
https://www.sterlingcodifiers.com/codebook/index.php?book_id=502 87/767
The employee's supervisor at the time of course enrollment has the responsibility to do the following:
A. Review selected course or degree for content and job/career relatedness.
B. Determine whether the number of credits of courses requested will negatively affect employee's job
performance.
C. Align employee's educational goals with current career plan (if appropriate).
D. Ensure TAP participants are aware of their obligations to:
1. Pay applicable taxes for course(s)/degree(s) that are not directly job-related;
2. Verify that the requested courses are scheduled during nonwork hours.
E. Ensure that requests are submitted to the Finance Committee for final review and approval within the
requested time frame.
Note: The supervisor should advise the employee to submit a copy of the applied for course(s) at least three
(3) weeks before a course(s) start(s). If late fees are assessed for a job-related reason (e.g., extended
business trip), send a letter of explanation to the supervisor.
F. Discuss TAP with new employees and TAP participation status with transferred employees.
G. Allocate funds for tuition when preparing or reviewing budgets, since tuition assistance is an organizational
expense. (Ord. 95-32-0, 8-23-95)
1-11-8: CONFLICTS WITH THE COLLECTIVE BARGAINING AGREEMENT:
If any provisions in this Chapter differ from the requirements of a collective bargaining agreement, the collective
bargaining agreement prevails for represented employees. (Ord. 95-32-0, 8-23-95)
Chapter 12
ADMINISTRATIVE ADJUDICATION OF CHARGES OF
MUNICIPAL CODE VIOLATIONS
1-12-1: CREATION:
Pursuant to authority of section 1-2.1-1 of the Illinois municipal code1 there is hereby created a system of
administrative adjudication of charges of municipal code violations for the city. (Ord. 98-20-0, 5-13-1998)
1-12-2: PURPOSE:
6/5/2019 Sterling Codifiers, Inc.
https://www.sterlingcodifiers.com/codebook/index.php?book_id=502 88/767
The purpose of the system of administrative adjudication of charges of municipal code violations is to provide a
procedure and facility by which charges of certain municipal code violations can be administratively adjudicated
by use of city personnel and facilities without initial resort to the circuit court. (Ord. 98-20-0, 5-13-1998)
1-12-3: JURISDICTION:
Those matters that shall be subject to administrative adjudication provided for hereby are charges of violation of
any ordinance of the city except: a) matters not within the statutory or home rule authority of the city; and b) any
offense under the Illinois vehicle code2 or a similar offense that is a traffic regulation governing the movement
of vehicles; and c) any reportable offense under section 6-204 of the Illinois vehicle code3. (Ord. 98-20-0, 5-13-
1998)
1-12-4: HEARING OFFICER APPOINTMENT:
Charges of municipal code violations may be heard and adjudicated by a hearing officer appointed by the
mayor with the consent of the city council at such compensation as may be from time to time established by the
city council. (Ord. 98-20-0, 5-13-1998)
1-12-5: HEARING OFFICER QUALIFICATIONS:
Any person appointed as hearing officer shall:
A. Be an attorney licensed to practice law in the state for not less than three (3) years.
B. Prior to conducting any administrative adjudications hearing hereinunder, have successfully completed a
formal training program which includes the following:
1. Instruction on rules of procedure of the administrative hearings to be conducted;
2. Orientation to each subject area of the code violations to be adjudicated;
3. Observation of administrative hearings; and
4. Participation in hypothetical cases, including ruling on evidence and issuing final orders. (Ord. 98-20-0, 5-
13-1998)
1-12-6: PROCEDURE:
All proceedings hereunder shall be commenced upon service of written notice of ordinance violation upon the
party alleged to have committed such violation and the following procedure shall be followed:
A. Preparation And Service: The notice shall be prepared and served by any persons authorized to exercise
city code enforcement authority by the City Council, the Chief of Police, the City Administrator, or the
Building Commissioner.
B. File Copy: A copy of such notice shall be filed with the hearing officer as soon as practicable at the place and
in the manner he or she shall from time to time direct.
6/5/2019 Sterling Codifiers, Inc.
https://www.sterlingcodifiers.com/codebook/index.php?book_id=502 89/767
C. Manner Of Service: Parties shall be served with notice in a manner reasonably calculated to give them
actual notice, including, as appropriate, personal service of notice upon a party or its employees or agents;
service by mail at a party's address; or notice that is posted upon the property where the alleged violation is
found when the party is the owner or manager of the property.
D. Hearing Notice: Parties shall be given notice of the adjudicatory hearing which includes the type and nature
of the Code violation to be adjudicated, the date and location of the adjudicatory hearing, the legal authority
and jurisdiction under which the hearing is to be held, and the penalties for failure to appear at the hearing.
E. Hearings: Parties shall be provided with an opportunity for a hearing during which they may be represented
by counsel, present witnesses, and cross-examine opposing witnesses. Parties may request the hearing
officer to issue subpoenas to direct the attendance and testimony of relevant witnesses and the production
of relevant documents. Hearings shall be scheduled with reasonable promptness, provided that for hearings
scheduled in all nonemergency situations, if requested by the respondent, the respondent shall have at least
fifteen (15) days after service of notice to prepare for the hearing. For purposes of this subsection,
"nonemergency situation" means any situation that does not reasonably constitute a threat to the public
interest, safety, or welfare. If service is provided by mail, the fifteen (15) day period shall begin to run on the
day that the notice is deposited in the mail.
F. Rules Of Evidence Shall Not Govern: The formal and technical rules of evidence do not apply in an
adjudicatory hearing provided for hereunder. Evidence may be admitted so long as it is of a type commonly
relied upon by reasonably prudent persons in the conduct of their affairs. Hearsay may be admitted if more
reliable evidence is not available, and if in the end the hearing officer's finding is supported by the kind of
evidence on which reasonable people are accustomed to rely in serious affairs.
G. Burden Of Proof: The burden shall be upon the City to prove by a preponderance of the evidence that the
alleged violation occurred.
H. Judicial Review: Any final decision by the hearing officer that a Code violation does or does not exist shall
constitute a final determination for purposes of judicial review and shall be subject to review under the
Illinois Administrative Review Law. (Ord. 98-20-0, 5-13-1998)
1-12-7: ENFORCEMENT OF JUDGMENT:
A. Any fine, other sanction, or costs imposed, or part of any fine, other sanction, or costs imposed, remaining
unpaid after the exhaustion of or the failure to exhaust judicial review procedures under the Illinois
Administrative Review Law are a debt due and owing the City and may be collected in accordance with
applicable law.
B. After expiration of the period in which judicial review under the Illinois Administrative Review Law may be
sought for a final determination of a Code violation, unless stayed by a court of competent jurisdiction, the
findings, decision, and order of the hearing officer may be enforced in the same manner as a judgment
entered by a court of competent jurisdiction.
C. In any case in which a respondent has failed to comply with a judgment ordering a respondent to correct a
Code violation or imposing any fine or other sanction as a result of a Code violation, any expenses incurred
by the City to enforce the judgment, including, but not limited to, attorney fees, court costs, and costs related
to property demolition or foreclosure, after they are fixed by a court of competent jurisdiction or a hearing
officer, shall be a debt due and owing the City and may be collected in accordance with applicable law. Prior
to any expenses being fixed by a hearing officer pursuant to this subsection, the City shall provide notice to
6/5/2019 Sterling Codifiers, Inc.
https://www.sterlingcodifiers.com/codebook/index.php?book_id=502 90/767
the respondent that states that the respondent shall appear at a hearing before the administrative hearing
officer to determine whether the respondent has failed to comply with the judgment. The notice shall set the
date for such a hearing, which shall not be less than seven (7) days from the date that notice is served. If
notice is served by mail, the seven (7) day period shall begin to run on the date that the notice was
deposited in the mail.
D. Upon being recorded in the manner required by article XII of the Code of Civil Procedure or by the Uniform
Commercial Code, a lien shall be imposed on the real estate or personal estate, or both, of the respondent
in the amount of any debt due and owing the city under this section. The lien may be enforced in the same
manner as a judgment lien pursuant to a judgment of a court of competent jurisdiction.
E. The hearing officer may set aside any judgment entered by default and set a new hearing date, upon a
petition filed within twenty one (21) days after the issuance of the order of default, if the hearing officer
determines that the petitioner's failure to appear at the hearing was for good cause or at any time if the
petitioner establishes that the city did not provide proper service of notice. If any judgment is set aside
pursuant to this subsection, the hearing officer shall have authority to enter an order extinguishing any lien
which has been recorded for any debt due and owing the city as a result of the vacated default judgment.
(Ord. 98-20-0, 5-13-1998)
1-12-8: ADDITIONAL PERSONNEL:
The city council may from time to time appoint or designate such other personnel as may be necessary to
properly effect the purpose of the system of administrative adjudication provided for hereby. (Ord. 98-20-0, 5-
13-1998)
1-12-9: DRIVER'S LICENSE SUSPENSION; NOTICE:
A notice of impending suspension of a person's driver's license shall be sent to any person determined to be
liable for the payment of any fine or penalty that remains due and owing on ten (10) or more vehicular standing
or parking regulation violations:
A. The notice shall state that the failure to pay the fine or penalty owing within forty five (45) days of the date of
notice will result in the city's notifying the secretary of state that the person is eligible for initiation of
suspension proceedings under 625 Illinois Compiled Statutes 5/6-306.5, incorporated herein by reference,
as it is amended from time to time.
B. The notice of impending driver's license suspension shall be sent by first class mail, postage prepaid, to the
address recorded with the secretary of state. (Ord. 00-10-0, 3-8-2000)
1-12-10: CHALLENGE OF CERTIFIED REPORT REGARDING SUSPENSION:
Any person may challenge the accuracy of a certified report sent to the secretary of state as provided in 625
Illinois Compiled Statutes 5/6-306.5.
A. Such a challenge shall be limited to the following grounds:
1. The person not having been the owner or lessee of the vehicle or vehicles receiving the ten (10) or more
standing, parking, or compliance violation notices on the date or dates such notices were issued.
6/5/2019 Sterling Codifiers, Inc.
https://www.sterlingcodifiers.com/codebook/index.php?book_id=502 91/767
2. The person having already paid the fine or penalty for the ten (10) or more violations indicated on the
certified report. (Ord. 00-10-0, 3-8-2000)
1-12-11: ADOPTION OF EDUCATION REQUIREMENT:
Pursuant to Illinois constitution, 1970, article VII, section 6 and its home rule authority, the city of Countryside
hereby adopts a mandatory education requirement for any ordinance violation enforced through its
administrative adjudication system. The mandatory education program shall consist of required hours of online
education related to the violation. It shall be imposed by the city's administrative adjudicator for any: a) photo
enforced red light ordinance violation; b) alcohol possession/consumption ordinance violation; c) cannabis
possession ordinance violation; d) bad check/deceptive practice ordinance violation; or any other ordinance
violation the city deems worthy of an education requirement in the future. (Ord. 09-01-0, 1-14-2009)
Chapter 13
ANTI-SEXUAL HARASSMENT POLICY
1-13-1: PURPOSE:
Recognizing the need to avoid the possibility of sexual harassment within the government of the City, and in the
rendering of City services, or the use of City facilities, the City Council has adopted the following Anti-Sexual
Harassment Policy as Chapter 13 of this Title. The Policy is designed to protect all persons employed by the
City or who receive services from the City or use City facilities from sexual harassment when so doing. The
Policy prohibits all forms of sexual harassment.
The protections in the Policy are enforced by the City Council acting ex officio as the City Commission on
Human Rights. The Commission is empowered to conciliate and conduct hearings on complaints of sexual
harassment and to order the implementation of measures for the prevention, alleviation, remediation, and
punishment of violations of the Policy. (Ord. 99-17-0, 4-14-1999)
1-13-2: DEFINITIONS:
Whenever used in this Chapter, the following words and terms shall have the meanings ascribed to them unless
otherwise defined herein:
CITY: The City of Countryside, a home rule unit of government, and includes its officers, employees, agents
and servants.
COMPLAINANT: A "person", as defined herein, who charges, complains of, or reports an alleged act or acts of
sexual harassment.
EMPLOYEE: Any individual whether paid or unpaid, engaged in employment for the City of Countryside.
EMPLOYER: The City of Countryside.
EMPLOYMENT: The performance of services for the City of Countryside:
A. For remuneration; or
B. As a volunteer; or
6/5/2019 Sterling Codifiers, Inc.
https://www.sterlingcodifiers.com/codebook/index.php?book_id=502 92/767
C. As a participant in a training or apprenticeship program.
PERSON: One or more individuals, partnerships, associations, or organizations; labor unions, joint
apprenticeship committees, or union labor associations, corporations; recipients of City funds; legal
representatives, trusts, trustees in bankruptcy, or receivers; state governments other than that of Illinois, or of
the United States.
RESPONDENT: A "person", as defined herein, against whom a complaint, charge or report of an act or acts of
sexual harassment is made.
SEXUAL ORIENTATION: The status or expression, whether actual or perceived, of heterosexuality,
homosexuality, or bisexuality. (Ord. 99-17-0, 4-14-1999)
This section has been affected by a recently passed ordinance, 18-2 - ANTI-SEXUAL HARASSMENT POLICY.
Go to new ordinance.
1-13-3: EMPLOYMENT:
A. Coverage: The prohibitions against sexual harassment contained in this section apply to employment that is
or would be in whole or in part by the City.
B. Prohibitions: The City shall not directly or indirectly permit or commit any act of "sexual harassment" as
defined in this section against any individual in hiring, classification, grading, recruitment, discharge,
discipline, compensation, selection for training and apprenticeship, or other term, privilege, or condition of
employment, on the basis of an individual's refusal to grant favors of a sexual nature. (Ord. 99-17-0, 4-14-
1999)
C. Sexual Harassment:
1. Neither any officer of the City, nor any employee thereof, nor any agent or servant thereof, (hereinafter
referred to collectively in this section as "employer") shall engage in sexual harassment. "Sexual
harassment" means any unwelcome sexual advance, request for sexual favors, and other verbal and
physical conduct of a sexual nature when: a) submission to such conduct is an explicit or implicit term or
condition of an individual's employment; or b) submission to or rejection of such conduct by an individual
is used as the basis for any employment decision affecting the individual; or c) such conduct has the
purpose or effect of substantially interfering with an individual's work performance or creating an
intimidating, hostile, or offensive working environment.
2. The City is responsible for acts of sexual harassment between coemployees in the workplace when,
through its agents or supervisory employees, it knew or in the exercise of ordinary care should have
known, of the conduct, unless it can show that it took immediate and appropriate corrective action. The
City may also be responsible for the actions of nonemployees, with respect to sexual harassment of
employees in the workplace, where through its agents or supervisory employees, it knew or in the
exercise of ordinary care should have known of the conduct and could have but failed to take immediate
and appropriate corrective action. (Ord. 99-17-0, 4-14-1999; amd. Ord. 18-01-0, 1-10-2018)
3. An employee experiencing what he or she believes to be sexual harassment must not assume that the
City is aware of the conduct. If there are no witnesses and the victim fails to notify a supervisor or other
responsible officer, the City will not be presumed to have knowledge of the harassment.
