4. Conduct which may constitute sexual harassment includes:
a. Verbal: Sexual innuendos, suggestive comments, insults, humor, and jokes about sex, anatomy or
gender-specific traits, sexual propositions, threats, repeated requests for dates, or statements about
6/5/2019 Sterling Codifiers, Inc.
https://www.sterlingcodifiers.com/codebook/index.php?book_id=502 93/767
other employees, even outside of their presence, of a sexual nature.
b. Non-verbal: Suggestive or insulting sounds (whistling), leering, obscene gestures, sexually suggestive
bodily gestures, "catcalls", "smacking" or "kissing" noises.
c. Visual: Posters, signs, pin-ups or slogans of a sexual nature, viewing pornographic material or
websites.
d. Physical: Touching, unwelcome hugging or kissing, pinching, brushing the body, any coerced sexual act
or actual assault.
e. Textual/electronic: "Sexting" (electronically sending messages with sexual content, including pictures
and video), the use of sexually explicit language, harassment, cyber stalking and threats via all forms of
electronic communication (e-mail, text/picture/video messages, intranet/on-line postings, blogs, instant
messages and social network websites like Facebook and Twitter).
5. The most severe and overt forms of sexual harassment are easier to determine. On the other end of the
spectrum, some sexual harassment is more subtle and depends, to some extent, on individual perception
and interpretation. The courts will assess sexual harassment by a standard of what would offend a
"reasonable person". (Ord. 18-01-0, 1-10-2018)
D. Police Department: All regular full-time, certified police officers, who are subject to disciplinary action by the
Fire and Police Commission, are specifically exempted from the provisions of this policy, such officers being
within the jurisdiction of the police regulations in section 4-1-17, "General Rules Of Conduct", of this Code
which provides for its own anti-sexual harassment policy including investigation, enforcement and discipline.
(Ord. 99-17-0, 4-14-1999)
This section has been affected by a recently passed ordinance, 18-2 - ANTI-SEXUAL HARASSMENT POLICY.
Go to new ordinance.
1-13-4: CITY FACILITIES, SERVICES, AND PROGRAMS:
A. Prohibition: The City shall not engage in sexual harassment in the provision or distribution of its facilities,
services, or programs.
B. Exception: The City Council acting ex officio as the City "Human Rights Commission", as defined in section
1-13-7 of this chapter may adopt rules specifying any exceptions to the prohibition contained in this section
based on bona fide considerations of public policy. (Ord. 99-17-0, 4-14-1999)
C. Sexual Harassment:
1. No officer, employees, agent or servant of the City shall engage in sexual harassment in the provision or
distribution of any City facilities, services, or programs. "Sexual harassment" means any unwelcome
sexual advance, request for sexual favors, and other verbal or physical conduct of a sexual nature when:
a) submission to such conduct is an explicit or implicit term or condition of an individual's use of City
facilities, or the provision of City services or programs; or b) submission to or rejection of such conduct by
an individual is used as the basis for any decision affecting the provision or allocation of City services or
programs, or the use of City facilities; or c) such conduct has the purpose or effect of substantially
interfering with an individual's access to City services, programs, or facilities, or the conduct creates an
intimidating, hostile, or offensive environment for the provision of City services or programs, or in the use
of City facilities. (Ord. 99-17-0, 4-14-1999; amd. Ord. 18-01-0, 1-10-2018)
2. An employee experiencing what he or she believes to be sexual harassment must not assume that the
City is aware of the conduct. If there are no witnesses and the victim fails to notify a supervisor or other
6/5/2019 Sterling Codifiers, Inc.
https://www.sterlingcodifiers.com/codebook/index.php?book_id=502 94/767
responsible officer, the City will not be presumed to have knowledge of the harassment.
3. Conduct which may constitute sexual harassment includes:
a. Verbal: Sexual innuendos, suggestive comments, insults, humor, and jokes about sex, anatomy or
gender-specific traits, sexual propositions, threats, repeated requests for dates, or statements about
other employees, even outside of their presence, of a sexual nature.
b. Non-verbal: Suggestive or insulting sounds (whistling), leering, obscene gestures, sexually suggestive
bodily gestures, "catcalls", "smacking" or "kissing" noises.
c. Visual: Posters, signs, pin-ups or slogans of a sexual nature, viewing pornographic material or
websites.
d. Physical: Touching, unwelcome hugging or kissing, pinching, brushing the body, any coerced sexual act
or actual assault.
e. Textual/electronic: "Sexting" (electronically sending messages with sexual content, including pictures
and video), the use of sexually explicit language, harassment, cyber stalking and threats via all forms of
electronic communication (e-mail, text/picture/video messages, intranet/on-line postings, blogs, instant
messages and social network websites like Facebook and Twitter).
4. The most severe and overt forms of sexual harassment are easier to determine. On the other end of the
spectrum, some sexual harassment is more subtle and depends, to some extent, on individual perception
and interpretation. The courts will assess sexual harassment by a standard of what would offend a
"reasonable person". (Ord. 18-01-0, 1-10-2018)
1-13-5: CONTRACTS:
A. Prohibition: No person who is a party to a contract with the City shall engage in sexual harassment against
any individual in the terms or conditions of employment, credit, public accommodations, housing, or
provision of facilities, services or programs. "Sexual harassment" has such meaning as is ascribed to it in
this chapter.
B. Contract Provisions: Any purchasing agent for the City, and any department heads, as authorized by the City
Council, shall include a provision in all City contracts that sets forth the City's policies with respect to sexual
harassment, as embodied in this chapter, and that requires every contractor to certify its compliance with
these policies and its agreement to abide by such policies as a part of the contractor's contractual
obligations.
All City contracts shall further provide that if any party to a contract with the City is found to have violated
any provision of this chapter, or furnished false or misleading information in any investigation, hearing, or
inquiry held pursuant to this chapter, that contract may be subject to a declaration of default and termination.
C. Exception: This section applies only to contracts executed after the effective date of this chapter. (Ord. 99-
17-0, 4-14-1999)
This section has been affected by a recently passed ordinance, 18-2 - ANTI-SEXUAL HARASSMENT POLICY.
Go to new ordinance.
1-13-6: ADDITIONAL VIOLATIONS:
6/5/2019 Sterling Codifiers, Inc.
https://www.sterlingcodifiers.com/codebook/index.php?book_id=502 95/767
A. Retaliation: No officer, employee, agent or servant of the City shall retaliate against any person because that
person in good faith has opposed that which he or she reasonably believed to be sexual harassment, or
other violation of this chapter, or has made a complaint, testified, assisted, or participated in an
investigation, proceeding, or hearing under this chapter. (Ord. 99-17-0, 4-14-1999)
No officer, employee, agent or servant of the City shall retaliate against any person who discloses or
threatens to disclose any violation of this chapter, provides information to any public body pursuant to this
chapter, or who assists or participates in any proceeding to enforce this chapter.
For the purposes of this chapter, retaliatory action means the reprimand, discharge, suspension,
demotion, denial of promotion or transfer, or change in the terms or conditions of employment of any City
employee that is taken in retaliation for a City employee's involvement in protected activity pursuant to this
chapter.
Similar to the prohibition against retaliation contained herein, the State Officials and Employees Ethics
Act1 provides whistleblower protection from retaliatory action such as reprimand, discharge, suspension,
demotion, or denial of promotion or transfer that occurs in retaliation for an employee who does any of the
following:
1. Discloses or threatens to disclose to a supervisor or to a public body an activity, policy, or practice of
any officer, member, State agency, or other State employee that the State employee reasonably
believes is in violation of a law, rule, or regulation,
2. Provides information to or testifies before any public body conducting an investigation, hearing, or
inquiry into any violation of a law, rule, or regulation by any officer, member, State agency or other
State employee, or
3. Assists or participates in a proceeding to enforce the provisions of the State Officials and Employees
Ethics Act.
Pursuant to the Whistleblower Act2, an employer may not retaliate against an employee who discloses
information in a court, an administrative hearing, or before a legislative commission or committee, or in
any other proceeding, where the employee has reasonable cause to believe that the information discloses
a violation of a State or Federal law, rule, or regulation. In addition, an employer may not retaliate against
an employee for disclosing information to a government or law enforcement agency, where the employee
has reasonable cause to believe that the information discloses a violation of a State or Federal law, rule,
or regulation3.
According to the Illinois Human Rights Act4, it is a civil rights violation for a person, or for two (2) or more
people to conspire, to retaliate against a person because he/she has opposed that which he/she
reasonably and in good faith believes to be sexual harassment in employment, because he/she has made
a charge, filed a complaint, testified, assisted, or participated in an investigation, proceeding, or hearing
under the Illinois Human Rights Act.
An employee who is suddenly transferred to a lower paying job or passed over for a promotion after filing
a complaint with IDHR or EEOC, may file a retaliation charge - due within one hundred eighty (180) days
(IDHR) or three hundred (300) days (EEOC) of the alleged retaliation. (Ord. 18-01-0, 1-10-2018)
B. Aiding And Abetting: No officer, employee, agent or servant of the City shall wilfully interfere with the
performance of a duty or the exercise of a power by the City Administrator, City Attorney, City Prosecutor or
City Council hereunder. (Ord. 99-17-0, 4-14-1999)
C. False Reporting: A false report is a report of sexual harassment made by an accuser using the sexual
harassment report to accomplish some end other than stopping sexual harassment or retaliation for
reporting sexual harassment. A false report is not a report made in good faith which cannot be proven.
6/5/2019 Sterling Codifiers, Inc.
https://www.sterlingcodifiers.com/codebook/index.php?book_id=502 96/767
Given the seriousness of the consequences for the accused, a false or frivolous report is a severe offense
that can itself result in disciplinary action. Any person who intentionally makes a false report alleging a
violation of any provision of this chapter shall be subject to discipline or discharge pursuant to applicable
City policies, employment agreements, procedures, employee handbooks and/or collective bargaining
agreements.
In addition, any person who intentionally makes a false report alleging a violation of any provision of the
State Officials and Employees Ethics Act to an Ethics Commission, an Inspector General, the State Police,
a State's Attorney, the Attorney General, or any other law enforcement official is guilty of a Class A
misdemeanor. An Ethics Commission may levy an administrative fine of up to five thousand dollars
($5,000.00) against any person who intentionally makes a false, frivolous or bad faith allegation. (Ord. 18-
01-0, 1-10-2018)
This section has been affected by a recently passed ordinance, 18-2 - ANTI-SEXUAL HARASSMENT POLICY.
Go to new ordinance.
1-13-7: ENFORCEMENT:
A. Human Rights Commission:
1. The Mayor and City Council shall act ex officio as the Human Rights Commission, except, however, if the
Mayor or any Alderman shall be a "complainant" or a "respondent" as defined herein, in a proceeding
brought to the commission, he or she is automatically recused from taking any part in such proceeding.
2. The commission shall be responsible for receiving and hearing charges of violations of this chapter, and
ordering remedies for violations found to have occurred. (Ord. 99-17-0, 4-14-1999)
B. Procedure:
1. Complaint Process:
a. Anyone who believes he or she has been the subject of "sexual harassment" as defined herein is
encouraged to immediately report such to his or her immediate supervisor, or to the Mayor, or to the
City Administrator, or to the City Attorney. All allegations, including anonymous reports, will be accepted
and investigated regardless of how the matter comes to the attention of the City. However, because of
the serious implications of sexual harassment charges and the difficulties associated with their
investigation and the questions of credibility involved, the claimant's willing cooperation is a vital
component of an effective inquiry and an appropriate outcome. (Ord. 99-17-0, 4-14-1999; amd. Ord. 18-
01-0, 1-10-2018)
b. Any person making such a report is further encouraged to provide as much information as possible,
such as: the name of the alleged perpetrator, the time and place of the alleged incident(s) and a
description of the act(s) complained of.
2. Investigation Process:
a. The Mayor, or the City Administrator, or the City Attorney, as designated by the Human Rights
Commission, shall immediately investigate the complaint and shall, among other things, as soon as
practicable, obtain a detailed written statement from the complainant and interview all witnesses,
including the alleged perpetrator.
b. As soon as practicable after the investigation is completed, the investigative agent shall report its
findings to the City Council, sitting ex officio as the City Human Rights Commission.
c. After receipt and consideration of the report, the commission shall decide whether a formal charge of
sexual harassment should be brought against the alleged perpetrator.
6/5/2019 Sterling Codifiers, Inc.
https://www.sterlingcodifiers.com/codebook/index.php?book_id=502 97/767
d. If the commission decides that the facts contained in the report are insufficient to support a formal
charge of sexual harassment, it shall dismiss the complaint and issue a written decision setting forth
findings upon which such dismissal is based.
e. If the commission decides that the facts contained in the report are sufficient to support a formal
charge, or charges, of sexual harassment, it shall so notify the assigned City Prosecutor who shall
prepare a formal charge(s) and cause the same to be served upon the respondent by the appropriate
means. The respondent shall have ten (10) days from the date of service to demand a hearing on said
charge(s). Such demand shall be delivered or mailed to the City Human Rights Commission care of the
Office of the City Clerk, 5550 East Avenue, Countryside, Illinois. Said ten (10) days shall be measured
from the date of service, but not counting the day of service.
f. If the respondent fails to respond or waives formal hearing, the commission may take appropriate action
including one or more of the following:
(1) It may attempt to settle or adjust any complaint by conciliation at any time that the complaint is
pending;
(2) It may order the respondent to cease the conduct complained of and to take steps to alleviate the
effect of the conduct complained of;
(3) It may hire, reinstate, or upgrade the complainant, with or without back pay, or provide such fringe
benefits as the complainant may have been denied;
(4) It may order the appropriate City personnel to extend to the complainant the full and equal
enjoyment of the goods, services, facilities, privileges, advantages, or accommodations of the
respondent;
(5) It may order respondent to file with the commission a report as to the manner of compliance;
(6) It may issue a formal reprimand to be placed in the respondent's employment file;
(7) It may order respondent to undergo mandatory counseling;
(8) It may order respondent suspended, with or without pay; or
(9) It may order termination of respondent's employment for cause.
3. Hearings:
a. If respondent demands a hearing, the commission shall notify the respondent that it will convene in a
prehearing conference to set a date and time for hearing, which shall be not more than ninety (90) days
after the commission determines there are grounds for a formal charge(s). The respondent may be
represented at said conference by legal counsel.
b. At the hearing on the charge(s), respondent may be represented by legal counsel, and the City may be
represented by the assigned City Prosecutor or other counsel of its choice. Either side may call
witnesses and present documentary evidence. The entire formal proceeding will be recorded by a
certified court reporter at the City's expense. At the hearing the following will apply:
(1) All testimony will be under oath;
(2) The commission may, upon its own determination, or upon request of any party, issue subpoenas for
the appearance of witnesses, the production of evidence, or both, in the course of investigations and
hearings. Subpoenas shall be issued where necessary for a full and complete hearing. A subpoena
shall be served in the same manner as subpoenas issued under the Rules of the Illinois Supreme
Court to compel the appearance of a deponent and shall be subject to the same witness and mileage
fees fixed by law for such subpoenas. The commission shall hear and determine objections to any
subpoenas and prescribe any other requirements for subpoenas;
6/5/2019 Sterling Codifiers, Inc.
https://www.sterlingcodifiers.com/codebook/index.php?book_id=502 98/767
(3) If any person refuses to comply with a commission subpoena, order, or decision, the commission
may seek judicial enforcement;
(4) The commission may adopt liberal rules for discovery so that the complainant and the respondent
may each obtain documents and other relevant information in the other's possession;
(5) The commission shall not disclose, other than to the parties or at the hearing on the charge(s), any
evidence obtained in the course of the investigation or conciliation unless otherwise required by law;
(6) The commission may dismiss a charge(s) or may enter an order of default against a party for failure
to cooperate with the commission.
c. At the conclusion of the hearing, the commission shall, within seven (7) business days, render its
decision, in writing, with findings in support thereof. Such decision may either dismiss the charge(s) as
not supported by the evidence or order one or more of the following:
(1) It may order the respondent to cease the conduct complained of and to take steps to alleviate the
effect of the conduct complained of;
(2) It may hire, reinstate, or upgrade the complainant, with or without back pay, or provide such fringe
benefits as the complainant may have been denied;
(3) It may order the appropriate City personnel to extend to the complainant the full and equal
enjoyment of the goods, services, facilities, privileges, advantages, or accommodations of the
respondent;
(4) It may order respondent to file with the commission a report as the manner of compliance;
(5) It may issue a formal reprimand to be placed in the respondent's employment file;
(6) It may order respondent to undergo mandatory counseling;
(7) It may order respondent suspended, with or without pay; or
(8) It may order termination of respondent's employment for cause. (Ord. 99-17-0, 4-14-1999)
(9) In addition to any and all other discipline that may be applicable pursuant to City policies,
employment agreements, procedures, employee handbooks and/or collective bargaining agreement,
any person who violates this chapter or the Prohibition On Sexual Harassment contained in 5 Illinois
Compiled Statutes 430/5-65, may be subject to a fine of up to five thousand dollars ($5,000.00) per
offense, applicable discipline or discharge by the City and any applicable fines and penalties
established pursuant to local ordinance, State law or Federal law. Each violation may constitute a
separate offense. Any discipline imposed by the City shall be separate and distinct from any penalty
imposed by an Ethics Commission and any fines or penalties imposed by a court of law or a State or
Federal agency. (Ord. 18-01-0, 1-10-2018)
d. Decisions of the commission must be approved by a majority of those commissioners who vote at a
meeting with a quorum. Decisions and orders of the commission are final and shall be served upon the
parties. The commission shall have no jurisdiction to review, reconsider or reverse or modify its
decisions and orders so made, but any such decisions and orders shall be subject to administrative
review under the Administrative Review Law of Illinois. (Ord. 99-17-0, 4-14-1999)
4. Additional Reporting Options: The purpose of this chapter is to establish prompt, thorough and effective
procedures for responding to every report and incident so that problems can be identified and remedied
by the City. However, all City employees have the right to contact the Illinois Department of Human Rights
(IDHR) or the Equal Employment Opportunity Commission (EEOC) for information regarding filing a
formal complaint with those entities. An IDHR complaint must be filed within one hundred eighty (180)
days of the alleged incident(s) unless it is a continuing offense. A complaint with the EEOC must be filed
within three hundred (300) days. (Ord. 18-01-0, 1-10-2018)
6/5/2019 Sterling Codifiers, Inc.
https://www.sterlingcodifiers.com/codebook/index.php?book_id=502 99/767
1-13-8: SEVERABILITY:
If any section, paragraph, sentence or clause of this chapter or the application thereof to any person is for any
reason deemed to be invalid or unconstitutional, such decision shall not affect any remaining portion, section, or
part thereof or application of the chapter to any other person. (Ord. 99-17-0, 4-14-1999)
Chapter 14
PROJECT ENGINEER
1-14-1: PROJECT ENGINEER:
A project engineer whose duties, qualifications and employment are hereinafter defined, shall not be an officer
or employee of the City. (Ord. 99-40-0, 8-25-1999)
1-14-2: QUALIFICATIONS:
Any project engineer employed hereunder shall be an independent Illinois licensed professional engineer. (Ord.
99-40-0, 8-25-1999)
1-14-3: EMPLOYMENT:
The Mayor, with the advice and consent of the City Council, may employ one or more project engineers, as they
deem necessary from time to time, and designate the projects for which they shall be assigned responsibility.
Compensation may be on an hourly basis, a flat fee for a specific assignment or project, or may be based upon
any other terms the parties may negotiate and agree upon. (Ord. 99-40-0, 8-25-1999)
1-14-4: STAFF:
Although a project engineer shall be an Illinois licensed professional engineer, he or she may use staff, agents
or assistants, as he or she determines appropriate, who are not licensed professional engineers. (Ord. 99-40-0,
8-25-1999)
1-14-5: DUTIES:
It shall be the duty of a project engineer in conjunction with the City Engineer to assure that all public
improvements required in any subdivision to be developed within the City are properly installed within such
subdivision in accordance with procedures set forth in Title 9, Chapter 4 of this Code. A project engineer shall
also carry out such other duties as the Mayor and Council may from time to time direct. (Ord. 99-40-0, 8-25-
1999)
Chapter 15
CITY INVESTMENT POLICY
6/5/2019 Sterling Codifiers, Inc.
https://www.sterlingcodifiers.com/codebook/index.php?book_id=502 100/767
1-15-1: POLICY:
It is the policy of the city to invest public funds in a manner which will provide the highest investment return with
the maximum security while meeting the daily cash flow demands of the city and conforming to all state and
local statutes governing the investment of public funds. (Ord. 99-46-0, 11-10-1999)
1-15-2: SCOPE:
The policy includes all funds governed by the city council. (Ord. 99-46-0, 11-10-1999)
1-15-3: PRUDENCE:
Investments shall be made with judgment and care, under circumstances then prevailing, which persons of
prudence, discretion and intelligence exercise in the management of their own affairs, not for speculation, but
for investment, considering the probable safety of their capital, as well as the probable income to be derived.
(Ord. 99-46-0, 11-10-1999)
1-15-4: OBJECTIVE:
The primary objective of this policy, in order of priority, shall be:
A. Legality; conformance with federal, state and other legal requirements;
B. Safety; preservation of capital and protection of investment principal;
C. Liquidity; maintenance of sufficient liquidity to meet operating requirements;
D. Yield; attainment of market rates of return.
Any portfolio will be reviewed by the treasurer on a monthly basis as to its effectiveness in meeting the city's
needs for safety, liquidity, rate of return, diversification and its general performance. (Ord. 00-39-0, 12-13-
2000)
1-15-5: DELEGATION OF AUTHORITY:
Management and administrative responsibility for the investment program is hereby delegated to the treasurer
who, under the delegation by the city council shall establish written procedures for the operation of the
investment program. (Ord. 99-46-0, 11-10-1999)
1-15-6: ETHICS AND CONFLICTS OF INTEREST:
1-15-6-1: CONSTRUCTION:
6/5/2019 Sterling Codifiers, Inc.
https://www.sterlingcodifiers.com/codebook/index.php?book_id=502 101/767
A. Where terms are not defined through the methods authorized by this section 1-15-6, such terms shall have
ordinarily accepted meanings such as the context implies.
B. The masculine gender includes the feminine and neuter, and the singular number shall include the plural
number. The word "shall" is mandatory, the word "may" is permissive. (Ord. 12-25-0, 3-28-2012)
1-15-6-2: DEFINITIONS:
Whenever in this section 1-15-6 the following words and phrases are used, they shall, for the purposes of this
section 1-15-6, have the meanings ascribed to them below, except when the context otherwise indicates:
BUSINESS ENTITY: Other than the city, any entity which invests capital, attention, time, labor and intelligence
for gain and profit for private benefit; including, but not limited to, any person, partnership, limited partnership,
joint venture, corporation, and/or trust as well as any entities owned, in whole or in part, by any of the foregoing.
CITY: The city of Countryside, Illinois.
CITY AFFILIATE: Any person elected to public office or any person appointed to a vacancy in an elective public
office of the city of Countryside.
CITY BUSINESS OR CITY TRANSACTION: Any work of the city government, including, but not limited to, the
casting of any vote; the issuance or participation in the issuance of any license, permit, certificate,
memorandum or stamp; the provision of public safety and/or public works; and/or the execution of any contract,
work order or any other document involved with the procurement of real or personal property and/or services by
or from the city.
FAMILY INTEREST: A wife or husband of a city affiliate who has an ownership or employment interest in a
contract, business, or transaction within the city.
FAMILY OR FAMILY MEMBER: One's husband or wife whether living together or not.
OWNERSHIP INTEREST: Any personal or family ownership, in whole or in part, of a business entity whether as
sole proprietor, partner, shareholder or joint venturer.
PROPRIETARY INFORMATION: The communication or reception of knowledge or intelligence, whether
conveyed to a city affiliate by mouth or in writing, obtained from instruction, investigation, study, or an exchange
of thoughts or ideas, relating to city business which is memorialized in any writing that is not a public document.
(Ord. 12-25-0, 3-28-2012)
1-15-6-3: PROHIBITED INTERESTS:
Except for the purchase of a city utility service and the payment of city taxes and/or filing fees, no city affiliate
shall have an ownership interest or family interest in any business entity entering into or which is engaged in
city business or a city transaction upon which such city affiliate may be called upon to act or vote; and, in
addition, no city affiliate shall:
A. Purchase in his own name or another's name any ownership interest in real property being sold for
delinquent taxes or assessments of the city or being sold by reason of any litigation or other claim brought
by or filed by the city; and
B. Have an ownership interest, directly or indirectly, in his own name or in the name of any business entity or
family member in any city business or a city transaction upon which such city affiliate may be called upon to
act or vote. (Ord. 12-25-0, 3-28-2012)
6/5/2019 Sterling Codifiers, Inc.
https://www.sterlingcodifiers.com/codebook/index.php?book_id=502 102/767
1-15-6-4: DISCLOSURE OF PROPRIETARY INFORMATION:
It shall be unlawful for any city affiliate to disclose, orally or in writing, proprietary information to any person, firm
or corporation that is not also a city affiliate. (Ord. 12-25-0, 3-28-2012)
1-15-6-5: PENALTY:
Whenever in this section 1-15-6, or in any ordinance of the city, any act or omission is prohibited and/or is made
or declared to be unlawful or a misdemeanor, the violation of any such provision of this section 1-15-6 shall be
a misdemeanor punishable, upon conviction, by a fine of not less than five hundred dollars ($500.00) nor more
than one thousand dollars ($1,000.00). Unless specifically provided otherwise, each day that any such violation
exists shall constitute a separate offense. (Ord. 12-25-0, 3-28-2012)
1-15-7: AUTHORIZED FINANCIAL DEALERS AND INSTITUTIONS:
Those financial institutions listed in the treasurer's monthly report shall constitute those financial institutions
authorized by the city council to provide investment services.
In addition, a list will also be maintained of approved security brokers/dealers selected by the city council. (Ord.
99-46-0, 11-10-1999)
1-15-8: AUTHORIZED AND SUITABLE INVESTMENTS:
Investments may be made in any type of security allowed for in Illinois statutes regarding the investment of
public funds.
Investments shall be made that reflect the cash flow needs of the fund type being invested. (Ord. 99-46-0, 11-
10-1999)
1-15-9: COLLATERALIZATION:
Funds on deposit (checking accounts, certificates of deposit, etc.) in excess of FDIC limits must be secured
pursuant to the city collateralization policy. (Ord. 99-46-0, 11-10-1999)
1-15-10: SAFEKEEPING AND CUSTODY:
All security transactions, including collateral for repurchase agreements, entered into by the city, shall be
conducted on a delivery versus payment (DVP) basis. Securities will be held by an independent third party
custodian designated by the treasurer and evidenced by safekeeping receipts and a written custodial
agreement. (Ord. 99-46-0, 11-10-1999)
1-15-11: DIVERSIFICATION:
The city of Countryside shall diversify its investments to the best of its ability based on the type of funds
invested and the cash flow needs of those funds. Diversification can be by type of investment such as
certificate of deposits, money markets, treasury bills and notes, number of institutions invested in, and length of
maturity. (Ord. 00-39-0, 12-13-2000)
6/5/2019 Sterling Codifiers, Inc.
https://www.sterlingcodifiers.com/codebook/index.php?book_id=502 103/767
1-15-12: MAXIMUM MATURITIES:
To the extent possible, the city of Countryside shall attempt to match its investments with anticipated cash flow
requirements. Unless matched to a specific cash flow, the city of Countryside will not directly invest in securities
maturing more than two (2) years from the date of purchase.
Reserve funds may be invested in securities exceeding two (2) years if the maturity of such investments is
made to coincide as nearly as practicable with the expected use of the funds.
The treasurer shall seek the approval of the city council prior to investing any funds with a maturity greater than
two (2) years from the date of deposit or purchase. (Ord. 00-39-0, 12-13-2000)
1-15-13: INTERNAL CONTROL:
The treasurer is responsible for establishing and maintaining an internal control structure designed to ensure
that the assets of the city are protected from loss, theft or misuse. The internal control structure shall be
designed to provide reasonable assurance that these objectives are met. The internal controls shall address the
following points:
A. Control of collusion.
B. Separation of transaction authority from accounting.
C. Custodial safekeeping.
D. Written confirmation of telephone transactions for investment and wire transfers. (Ord. 99-46-0, 11-10-1999)
1-15-14: PERFORMANCE STANDARDS:
Any investment portfolio will be managed in accordance with the parameters specified within the policy. Any
portfolio should obtain a comparable rate of return when compared to similarly situated investments during a
market/economic environment of stable interest rates. (Ord. 99-46-0, 11-10-1999)
1-15-15: REPORTING:
The treasurer shall prepare an investment report monthly. The report should be provided to the city council and
available to the public on request. An annual CAFR report will also be provided to the city council. (Ord. 99-46-
0, 11-10-1999)
1-15-16: MARKING TO MARKET:
A statement of the market value of the portfolio shall be issued to the city council quarterly. (Ord. 99-46-0, 11-
10-1999)
1-15-17: POLICY ADOPTION:
6/5/2019 Sterling Codifiers, Inc.
https://www.sterlingcodifiers.com/codebook/index.php?book_id=502 104/767
Any investment currently held at the time of adoption of the policy that does not meet the guidelines of the
policy shall be exempted from the requirements hereof. At maturity or liquidation, the proceeds shall be
reinvested only as provided in the policy.
The investment policy shall be adopted by the city council. The policy shall be reviewed on an annual basis by
the treasurer and any modifications made thereto must be approved by the city council. (Ord. 99-46-0, 11-10-
1999)
Chapter 16
ANNEXATION COSTS
1-16-1: ANNEXATION COSTS; OWNER RESPONSIBLE:
The owner of any territory annexed into the City shall bear all costs incurred by the City associated with the
annexation including, but not limited to, attorney fees, preparation of a plat of annexation and recording fees.
(Ord. 00-09-0, 2-3-2000)
Chapter 17
LOCALLY IMPOSED AND ADMINISTERED TAX RIGHTS AND
RESPONSIBILITY
1-17-1: SHORT TITLE:
This chapter shall be known as, and may be cited as, the LOCALLY IMPOSED AND ADMINISTERED TAX
RIGHTS AND RESPONSIBILITY ORDINANCE. (Ord. 00-40-0, 12-13-2000)
1-17-2: SCOPE:
The provisions of this chapter shall apply to the city's procedures in connection with all of the city's locally
imposed and administered taxes. (Ord. 00-40-0, 12-13-2000)
1-17-3: DEFINITIONS:
Certain words or terms herein shall have the meanings ascribed to them as follows:
ACT: The "Local Government Taxpayers' Bill of Rights Act".
CITY: The city of Countryside, county of Cook, state of Illinois.
CORPORATE AUTHORITIES: The city's mayor and city council.
LOCAL TAX ADMINISTRATOR: The city's treasurer is charged with the administration and collection of the
locally imposed and administered taxes, including staff, employees or agents to the extent they are authorized
by the local tax administrator to act in the local tax administrator's stead. The local tax administrator shall have
the authority to implement the terms of this chapter to give full effect to this chapter. The exercise of such
authority by the local tax administrator shall not be inconsistent with this chapter and the act.
6/5/2019 Sterling Codifiers, Inc.
https://www.sterlingcodifiers.com/codebook/index.php?book_id=502 105/767
LOCALLY IMPOSED AND ADMINISTERED TAX OR TAX: Each tax imposed by the city that is collected or
administered by the city and not an agency or department of the state. It does not include any taxes imposed
upon real property under the property tax code or fees collected by the city other than infrastructure
maintenance fees.
HEARING OFFICER: An administrative individual appointed by the mayor with the advice and consent of the
corporate authorities to conduct hearings and to issue final determinations regarding the collection of all locally
imposed and administered taxes.
NOTICE: Each audit notice, collection notice or other similar notice or communication in connection with each
of the city's locally imposed and administered taxes.
TAX ORDINANCE: Each ordinance adopted by the city that imposes any locally imposed and administered tax.
TAXPAYER: Any person required to pay any locally imposed and administered tax and generally includes the
person upon whom the legal incidence of such tax is placed and with respect to consumer taxes includes the
business or entity required to collect and pay the locally imposed and administered tax to the city. (Ord. 00-40-
0, 12-13-2000)
1-17-4: NOTICES:
Unless otherwise provided, whenever notice is required to be given, the notice is to be in writing mailed not less
than seven (7) calendar days prior to the day fixed for any applicable hearing, audit or other scheduled act of
the local tax administrator. The notice shall be sent by the local tax administrator as follows:
A. First class or express mail, or overnight mail, addressed to the persons concerned at the persons' last known
address, or
B. Personal service or delivery. (Ord. 00-40-0, 12-13-2000)
1-17-5: LATE PAYMENT:
Any notice, payment, remittance or other filing required to be made to the city pursuant to any tax ordinance
shall be considered late unless it is: a) physically received by the city on or before the due date, or b) received
in an envelope or other container displaying a valid, readable U.S. postmark dated on or before the due date,
properly addressed to the city, with adequate postage prepaid. (Ord. 00-40-0, 12-13-2000)
1-17-6: PAYMENT:
Any payment or remittance received for a tax period shall be applied in the following order: a) first to the tax due
for the applicable period; b) second to the interest due for the applicable period; and c) third to the penalty for
the applicable period. (Ord. 00-40-0, 12-13-2000)
1-17-7: CERTAIN CREDITS AND REFUNDS:
A. The city shall not refund or credit any taxes voluntarily paid without written protest at the time of payment in
the event that a locally imposed and administered tax is declared invalidly enacted or unconstitutional by a
6/5/2019 Sterling Codifiers, Inc.
https://www.sterlingcodifiers.com/codebook/index.php?book_id=502 106/767
court of competent jurisdiction. However, a taxpayer shall not be deemed to have paid the tax voluntarily if
the taxpayer lacked knowledge of the facts upon which to protest the taxes at the time of payment or if the
taxpayer paid the taxes under duress.
B. The statute of limitations on a claim for credit or refund shall be one year after the end of the calendar year in
which payment in error was made. The city shall not grant a credit or refund of locally imposed and
administered taxes, interest, or penalties to a person who has not paid the amounts directly to the city.
C. The procedure for claiming a credit or refund of locally imposed and administered taxes, interest or penalties
paid in error shall be as follows:
1. The taxpayer shall submit to the local tax administrator in writing a claim for credit or refund together with
a statement specifying:
a. The name of the locally imposed and administered tax subject to the claim;
b. The tax period for the locally imposed and administered tax subject to the claim;
c. The date of the tax payment subject to the claim and the canceled check or receipt for the payment;
d. The taxpayer's recalculation, accompanied by an amended or revised tax return, in connection with the
claim; and
e. A request for either a refund or a credit in connection with the claim to be applied to the amount of tax,
interest and penalties overpaid, and, as applicable, related interest on the amount overpaid; provided,
however, that there shall be no refund and only a credit given in the event the taxpayer owes any
monies to the city.
2. Within ten (10) days of the receipt by the local tax administrator of any claim for a refund or credit, the
local tax administrator shall either:
a. Grant the claim; or
b. Deny the claim, in whole or in part, together with a statement as to the reason for the denial or the
partial grant and denial.
3. In the event the local tax administrator grants, in whole or in part, a claim for refund or credit, the amount
of the grant for refund or credit shall bear interest at the rate of six percent (6%) per annum, based on a
year of three hundred sixty five (365) days and the number of days elapsed, from the date of the
overpayment to the date of mailing of a refund check or the grant of a credit. (Ord. 00-40-0, 12-13-2000)
1-17-8: AUDIT PROCEDURE:
Any request for proposed audit pursuant to any local administered tax shall comply with the notice requirements
of this chapter.
A. Each notice of audit shall contain the following information:
1. The tax;
2. The time period of the audit; and
3. A brief description of the books and records to be made available for the auditor.
6/5/2019 Sterling Codifiers, Inc.
https://www.sterlingcodifiers.com/codebook/index.php?book_id=502 107/767
B. Any audit shall be conducted during normal business hours and if the date and time selected by the local tax
administrator is not agreeable to the taxpayer, another date and time may be requested by the taxpayer
within thirty (30) days after the originally designated audit and during normal business hours.
C. The taxpayer may request an extension of time to have an audit conducted. The audit shall be conducted no
more than thirty (30) days from the date the notice is given, unless the taxpayer and the local tax
administrator agree to some other convenient time. In the event taxpayer is unable to comply with the audit
on the date in question, the taxpayer may request another date within the thirty (30) days, approved in
writing, that is convenient to the taxpayer and the local tax administrator.
D. Every taxpayer shall keep accurate books and records of the taxpayer's business or activities, including
original source documents and books of entry denoting the transactions which had given rise or may have
given rise to any tax liability, exemption or deduction. All books shall be kept in the English language and
shall be subject to and available for inspection by the city.
E. It is the duty and responsibility of every taxpayer to make available its books and records for inspection by
the city. If the taxpayer fails to provide the documents necessary for audit within the time provided, the local
tax administrator may issue a tax determination and assessment based on the tax administrator's
determination of the best estimate of the taxpayer's tax liability.
F. If an audit determines there has been an overpayment of a locally imposed and administered tax as a result
of the audit, written notice of the amount of overpayment shall be given to the taxpayer within thirty (30)
days of the city's determination of the amount of overpayment.
G. In the event a tax payment was submitted to the incorrect local governmental entity, the local tax
administrator shall notify the local governmental entity imposing such tax. (Ord. 00-40-0, 12-13-2000)
1-17-9: APPEAL:
A. The local tax administrator shall send written notice to a taxpayer upon the local tax administrator's issuance
of a protestable notice of tax due, a bill, a claim denial, or a notice of claim reduction regarding any tax. The
notice shall include the following information:
1. The reason for the assessment;
2. The amount of the tax liability proposed;
3. The procedure for appealing the assessment; and
4. The obligations of the city during the audit, appeal, refund and collection process.
B. A taxpayer who receives written notice from the local tax administrator of a determination of tax due or
assessment may file with the local tax administrator a written protest and petition for hearing, setting forth
the basis of the taxpayer's request for a hearing. The written protest and petition for hearing must be filed
with the local tax administrator within forty five (45) days of receipt of the written notice of the tax
determination and assessment.
C. If a timely written notice and petition for hearing is filed, the local tax administrator shall fix the time and place
for hearing and shall give written notice to the taxpayer. The hearing shall be scheduled for a date within
fourteen (14) days of receipt of the written protest and petition for hearing, unless the taxpayer requests a
later date convenient to all parties.
6/5/2019 Sterling Codifiers, Inc.
https://www.sterlingcodifiers.com/codebook/index.php?book_id=502 108/767
D. If a written protest and petition for hearing is not filed within the forty five (45) day period, the tax
determination, audit or assessment shall become a final bill due and owing without further notice.
E. Upon the showing of reasonable cause by the taxpayer and the full payment of the contested tax liability
along with interest accrued as of the due date of the tax, the local tax administrator may reopen or extend
the time for filing a written protest and petition for hearing. In no event shall the time for filing a written
protest and petition for hearing be reopened or extended for more than ninety (90) days after the expiration
of the forty five (45) day period. (Ord. 00-40-0, 12-13-2000)
1-17-10: HEARING:
A. Whenever a taxpayer or a tax collector has filed a timely written protest and petition for hearing under
section 1-17-9 of this chapter the local tax administrator shall conduct a hearing regarding any appeal. The
taxpayer may request that a hearing officer conduct the hearing rather than the local tax administrator.
B. No continuances shall be granted except in cases where a continuance is absolutely necessary to protect
the rights of the taxpayer. Lack of preparation shall not be grounds for a continuance. Any continuance
granted shall not exceed fourteen (14) days.
C. At the hearing the local tax administrator or hearing officer shall preside and shall hear testimony and accept
any evidence relevant to the tax determination, audit or assessment. The strict rules of evidence applicable
to judicial proceedings shall not apply.
D. At the conclusion of the hearing, the local tax administrator or hearing officer shall make a written
determination on the basis of the evidence presented at the hearing. The taxpayer or tax collector shall be
provided with a copy of the written decision. (Ord. 00-40-0, 12-13-2000)
1-17-11: INTEREST AND PENALTIES:
In the event a determination has been made that a tax is due and owing, through audit, assessment or other bill
sent, the tax must be paid within the time frame otherwise indicated.
A. Interest: The city hereby provides for the amount of interest to be assessed on a late payment,
underpayment, or nonpayment of the tax, to be six percent (6%) per annum, based on a year of three
hundred sixty five (365) days and the number of days elapsed.
B. Late Filing And Payment Penalties: If a tax return is not filed within the time and manner provided by the
controlling tax ordinance, a late filing penalty, of five percent (5%) of the amount of tax required to be shown
as due on a return shall be imposed; and a late payment penalty of five percent (5%) of the tax due shall be
imposed. If no return is filed within the time or manner provided by the controlling tax ordinance and prior to
the city issuing a notice of tax delinquency or notice of tax liability, then a failure to file penalty shall be
assessed equal to twenty five percent (25%) of the total tax due for the applicable reporting period for which
the return was required to be filed. A late filing or payment penalty shall not apply if a failure to file penalty is
imposed by the controlling ordinance. (Ord. 00-40-0, 12-13-2000)
1-17-12: ABATEMENT:
6/5/2019 Sterling Codifiers, Inc.
https://www.sterlingcodifiers.com/codebook/index.php?book_id=502 109/767
The local tax administrator shall have the authority to waive or abate any late filing penalty, late payment
penalty or failure to file penalty if the local tax administrator shall determine reasonable cause exists for delay or
failure to make a filing. (Ord. 00-40-0, 12-13-2000)
1-17-13: INSTALLMENT CONTRACTS:
The city may enter into an installment contract with the taxpayer for the payment of taxes under the controlling
tax ordinance. The local tax administrator may not cancel any installment contract so entered unless the
taxpayer fails to pay any amount due and owing. Upon written notice by the local tax administrator that the
payment is thirty (30) days delinquent, the taxpayer shall have fourteen (14) working days to cure any
delinquency. If the taxpayer fails to cure the delinquency within the fourteen (14) day period or fails to
demonstrate good faith in restructuring the installment contract with the local administrator, the installment
contract shall be canceled without further notice to the taxpayer. (Ord. 00-40-0, 12-13-2000)
1-17-14: STATUTE OF LIMITATIONS:
The city, through the local tax administrator, shall review all tax returns in a prompt and timely manner and
inform taxpayers of any amounts due and owing. The taxpayer shall have forty five (45) days after receiving
notice of the reviewed tax returns to make any request for refund or provide any tax still due and owing.
A. No determination of tax due and owing may be issued more than four (4) years after the end of the calendar
year for which the return for the applicable period was filed or for the calendar year in which the return for
the applicable period was due, whichever occurs later.
B. If any tax return is not filed or if during any four (4) year period for which a notice of tax determination or
assessment may be issued by the city, the tax paid was less than seventy five percent (75%) of the tax due,
the statute of limitations shall be six (6) years maximum after the end of the calendar year in which return for
the applicable period was due or end of the calendar year in which the return for the applicable period was
filed.
C. No statute of limitations shall apply if a fraudulent tax return was filed by the taxpayer. (Ord. 00-40-0, 12-13-
2000)
1-17-15: VOLUNTARY DISCLOSURE:
For any locally imposed and administered tax for which a taxpayer has not received a written notice of an audit,
investigation, or assessment from the local tax administrator, a taxpayer is entitled to file an application with the
local tax administrator for a voluntary disclosure of the tax due. A taxpayer filing a voluntary disclosure
application must agree to pay the amount of tax due, along with interest of one percent (1%) per month, for all
periods prior to the filing of the application but not more than four (4) years before the date of filing the
application. A taxpayer filing a valid voluntary disclosure application may not be liable for any additional tax,
interest, or penalty for any period before the date the application was filed. However, if the taxpayer incorrectly
determined and underpaid the amount of tax due, the taxpayer is liable for the underpaid tax along with
applicable interest on the underpaid tax, unless the underpayment was the result of fraud on the part of the
taxpayer, in which case the application shall be deemed invalid and void. The payment of tax and interest must
be made by no later than ninety (90) days after the filing of the voluntary disclosure application or the date
agreed to by the local tax administrator. However, any additional amounts owed as a result of an underpayment
of tax and interest previously paid under this section must be paid within ninety (90) days after a final
determination and the exhaustion of all appeals of the additional amount owed or the date agreed to by the
local tax administrator, whichever is longer. (Ord. 00-40-0, 12-13-2000)
6/5/2019 Sterling Codifiers, Inc.
https://www.sterlingcodifiers.com/codebook/index.php?book_id=502 110/767
1-17-16: PUBLICATION OF TAX ORDINANCES:
Any locally administered tax ordinance shall be published via normal or standard publishing requirements. The
posting of a tax ordinance on the internet shall satisfy the publication requirements. Copies of all tax ordinances
shall be made available to the public upon request at the city clerk's office. (Ord. 00-40-0, 12-13-2000)
1-17-17: INTERNAL REVIEW PROCEDURE:
The local tax administrator shall establish an internal review procedure regarding any liens filed against any
taxpayers for unpaid taxes. Upon a determination by the local tax administrator that the lien is valid, the lien
shall remain in full force and effect. If the lien is determined to be improper, the local tax administrator shall:
A. Timely remove the lien at the city's expense;
B. Correct the taxpayer's credit record; and
C. Correct any public disclosure of the improperly imposed lien. (Ord. 00-40-0, 12-13-2000)
1-17-18: CONFLICTING TAX PROVISIONS:
This chapter shall be liberally construed and administered to supplement all of the city's tax ordinances. To the
extent that any tax ordinance is in conflict with or inconsistent with this chapter, this chapter shall be controlling.
(Ord. 00-40-0, 12-13-2000)
Chapter 18
ETHICAL CONDUCT
1-18-1: STATE OFFICIALS AND EMPLOYEES ETHICS ACT:
A. The regulations of section 5-151 and article 102 of the state officials and employees ethics act, 5 Illinois
Compiled Statutes 430/1-1 et seq., (hereinafter referred to as the "act" in this section) are hereby adopted
by reference and made applicable to the officers and employees of the city of Countryside to the extent
required by 5 Illinois Compiled Statutes 430/70-5.
B. The solicitation or acceptance of gifts prohibited to be solicited or accepted under the act, by any officer or
any employee of the city of Countryside, is hereby prohibited.
C. The offering or making of gifts prohibited to be offered or made to an officer or employee of the city of
Countryside under the act, is hereby prohibited.
D. The participation in political activities prohibited under the act, by any officer or employee of the city of
Countryside, is hereby prohibited.
6/5/2019 Sterling Codifiers, Inc.
https://www.sterlingcodifiers.com/codebook/index.php?book_id=502 111/767
E. For purposes of this section, the terms "officer" and "employee" shall be defined as set forth in 5 Illinois
Compiled Statutes 430/70-5(c).
F. The penalties for violations of this section shall be the same as those penalties set forth in 5 Illinois Compiled
Statutes 430/50-5 for similar violations of the act.
G. This section does not repeal or otherwise amend or modify any existing ordinances or policies which
regulate the conduct of city of Countryside officers and employees. To the extent that any such existing
ordinances or policies are less restrictive than this section, however, the provisions of this section shall
prevail in accordance with the provisions of 5 Illinois Compiled Statutes 430/70-5(a).
H. Any amendment to the act that becomes effective after the effective date of this section shall be incorporated
into this section by reference and shall be applicable to the solicitation, acceptance, offering and making of
gifts and to prohibited political activities. However, any amendment that makes its provisions optional for
adoption by municipalities shall not be incorporated into this section by reference without formal action by
the corporate authorities of the city of Countryside.
I. If the Illinois supreme court declares the act unconstitutional in its entirety, then this section shall be repealed
as of the date that the Illinois supreme court's decision becomes final and not subject to any further appeals
or rehearings. This section shall be deemed repealed without further action by the corporate authorities of
the city of Countryside if the act is found unconstitutional by the Illinois supreme court.
J. If the Illinois supreme court declares part of the act unconstitutional but upholds the constitutionality of the
remainder of the act, or does not address the remainder of the act, then the remainder of the act as adopted
by this section shall remain in full force and effect; however, that part of this section relating to the part of the
act found unconstitutional shall be deemed repealed without further action by the corporate authorities of the
city of Countryside. (Ord. 04-21-0, 5-12-2004)
Chapter 19
COMMUNITY DEVELOPMENT DIRECTOR
1-19-1: CREATION OF OFFICE:
There is hereby created the position of community development director within the administrative structure of
the city of Countryside. (Ord. 05-18-0, 5-11-2005)
1-19-2: QUALIFICATIONS:
The community development director shall have the following qualifications:
A thorough competency and extensive knowledge in the field of community development. Extensive knowledge
of the regulations and ordinances associated with community development. Skill in preparing, and directing the
preparation of, comprehensive reports, presentations, budgets and correspondence. Skill in resolving conflicts
and in fostering compromise among conflicting groups. (Ord. 05-18-0, 5-11-2005)
1-19-3: EXPERIENCE AND TRAINING:
6/5/2019 Sterling Codifiers, Inc.
https://www.sterlingcodifiers.com/codebook/index.php?book_id=502 112/767
The community development director shall have completed a program in community development, urban
planning, geography, sociology, engineering, landscape architecture, or related fields, leading to a master's
degree from an accredited college or university approved by the city council. The director shall have five (5) to
eight (8) years of progressively responsible experience, including development of a long range comprehensive
plan and implementation of large scale development and development plans. If approved by the city council,
additional experience may substitute for some educational requirements. (Ord. 05-18-0, 5-11-2005)
1-19-4: ABILITIES:
Community development director shall have the ability to recognize and grasp community needs and develop
sound advance approaches to meeting those needs through the community development process. The director
shall have the ability to effectively plan, develop and maintain complex and detailed administrative and
technical programs and projects. He or she shall be able to communicate orally or in writing complex ideas and
information to a variety of sophisticated and unsophisticated audiences, and to organize, develop and maintain
a network of productive, harmonious relationships with community groups, officials, other city departments and
officials, and the general public. (Ord. 05-18-0, 5-11-2005)
1-19-5: PHYSICAL DEMANDS AND WORK ENVIRONMENT:
The physical demands and work environment characteristics prescribed herein are representative of those that
must be met or will be encountered by the director while successfully performing the essential functions of the
director's job. Reasonable accommodations may be made to enable individuals with disabilities to perform
these essential functions.
While performing the duties of the director's job, he or she shall be frequently required to sit and talk and hear.
The director must occasionally lift or move up to twenty five (25) pounds. Specific vision abilities required
include close vision and the ability to adjust and focus. Because the director will occasionally work in out of
doors weather conditions, he or she may be exposed to wet and humid conditions or airborne particles. (Ord.
05-18-0, 5-11-2005)
1-19-6: DUTIES AND AUTHORITIES:
A. Nature Of Work Involved: The community development director is a highly visible office. The director shall
advise the city administration, city council, and the plan commission-zoning board on a broad range of
economic and community development related issues. He or she shall be subject to supervision of the city
administrator. The director shall be responsible for organization and direction and department leadership
with regard to preparation and maintenance of a comprehensive plan and the meeting of community
development goals for the city in retaining and attracting businesses.
B. Oversight Authority: The community development director shall have complete supervisory authority over the
community development department and the building department, and all employees of the building
department, including, but not limited to, the building commissioner/zoning administrator, code enforcement
officer and department secretary; shall be under the supervision of, and report directly to, the community
development director.
C. Duties And Responsibilities: The community development director shall confer with and make
recommendations to the city administrator regarding economic and community development projects and
programs as are directed by the administrator. The director shall provide leadership, direction and technical
advice on complex projects and negotiations with landowners and developers concerning economical and
community development/redevelopment of the city. The director shall develop and maintain a
comprehensive inventory of available buildings and sites in the city for community development purposes;
6/5/2019 Sterling Codifiers, Inc.
https://www.sterlingcodifiers.com/codebook/index.php?book_id=502 113/767
prepare and maintain information on utilities, taxes, zoning, transportation, community services, financial
tools, etc.; respond to requests for information for development purposes. He or she shall serve as a liaison
between the city, chambers of commerce, merchants' associations, and other public, private or not for profit
groups interested in economic and community development.
The director shall make presentations before various groups, including the city council, plan commissionzoning
board and other committees and task forces at both on and off site public meetings, and shall
participate in community events. He or she shall direct the city's economic and community development and
building department functions, including managing the various operations and compiling the annual budgets
for those operations.
The director shall build and maintain respectful, positive working relationships with staff and with
supervisors, outside agencies and the public using principles of good customer service and proven methods
of conflict resolution, as needed. He or she shall maintain appropriate professional management conduct,
maintain appropriate confidentiality with regard to sensitive information and comply with and support city
policies and procedures. The director shall also perform all of his or her duties as assigned by the city
administrator. (Ord. 05-18-0, 5-11-2005)
Chapter 20
ELECTRONIC ATTENDANCE AT MEETINGS
1-20-1: RULES STATEMENT:
It is the decision of the city council of the city of Countryside that any member of the city council may attend any
open or closed meeting of the city of Countryside via electronic means (such as by telephone, video or internet
connection) provided that such attendance is in compliance with this chapter and any applicable laws. (Ord. 07-
28-0, 8-8-2007, eff. 8-8-2007)
1-20-2: PREREQUISITES:
A member of the city council may attend a meeting electronically if the member meets the following conditions:
A. The member should notify the city clerk at least eight (8) hours before the meeting, unless impractical, so
that necessary communications equipment can be arranged. Inability to make the necessary technical
arrangements will result in denial of a request for remote attendance.
B. The member must assert one of the following three (3) reasons why he or she is unable to physically attend
the meeting:
1. The member cannot attend because of personal illness or disability; or
2. The member cannot attend because of employment purposes or the business of the city; or
3. The member cannot attend because of a family or other emergency. (Ord. 07-28-0, 8-8-2007, eff. 8-8-
2007)
1-20-3: AUTHORIZATION TO PARTICIPATE:
A. The clerk, after receiving the electronic attendance request, shall inform the city council of the request for
electronic attendance.
6/5/2019 Sterling Codifiers, Inc.
https://www.sterlingcodifiers.com/codebook/index.php?book_id=502 114/767
B. After establishing that there is a quorum physically present at a meeting where a member of the city council
desires to attend electronically, the presiding officer shall state that: 1) a notice was received by a member
of the city council in accordance with this chapter, and 2) the member will be deemed authorized to attend
the meeting electronically unless a motion objecting to the member's electronic attendance is made,
seconded, and approved by two-thirds (2/3) of the members of the city council physically present at the
meeting. If no such motion is made and seconded or if any such motion fails to achieve the required vote by
the members of the city council physically present at the meeting, then the request by the member to attend
the meeting electronically shall be deemed approved by the city council and the presiding officer shall
declare the requesting member present. After such declaration by the presiding officer, the question of a
member's electronic attendance may not be reconsidered. (Ord. 07-28-0, 8-8-2007, eff. 8-8-2007)
1-20-4: ADEQUATE EQUIPMENT REQUIRED:
The member participating electronically and other members of the city council must be able to communicate
effectively, and members of the audience must be able to hear all communications at the meeting site. Before
allowing electronic attendance at any meeting, the clerk's office shall provide equipment adequate to
accomplish this objective at the meeting site. (Ord. 07-28-0, 8-8-2007, eff. 8-8-2007)
1-20-5: MINUTES:
Any member attending electronically shall be considered an off site attendee and counted as present
electronically for that meeting if the member is allowed to attend. The meeting minutes shall also reflect and
state specifically whether each member is physically present or present by electronic means. (Ord. 07-28-0, 8-
8-2007, eff. 8-8-2007)
1-20-6: RIGHTS OF REMOTE MEMBER:
A member permitted to attend electronically will be able to express his or her comments during the meeting and
participate in the same capacity as those members physically present, subject to all general meeting guidelines
and procedures previously adopted and adhered to. The member attending electronically shall be heard,
considered, and counted as to any vote taken. Accordingly, the name of any member attending electronically
shall be called during any vote taken, and his or her vote counted and recorded by the clerk and placed in the
minutes for the corresponding meeting. A member attending electronically may leave a meeting and return as
in the case of any member, provided the member attending electronically shall announce his or her leaving and
returning. (Ord. 07-28-0, 8-8-2007, eff. 8-8-2007)
1-20-7: APPLICABILITY:
This chapter shall apply to all committees, boards and commissions established by authority of the city of
Countryside. (Ord. 07-28-0, 8-8-2007, eff. 8-8-2007)
Chapter 21
FREEDOM OF INFORMATION ACT AND OPEN MEETINGS
ACT
1-21-1: FREEDOM OF INFORMATION ACT REGULATIONS:
6/5/2019 Sterling Codifiers, Inc.
https://www.sterlingcodifiers.com/codebook/index.php?book_id=502 115/767
A. Establishment: The deputy clerk shall be the freedom of information officer as required in section 3.5 of the
freedom of information act on and after January 1, 20101. In the absence or vacancy of the deputy clerk, the
city administrator shall be the freedom of information officer. In the temporary absence of both the deputy
clerk and the city administrator, the city administrator shall designate an employee of the city to act as the
freedom of information officer.
B. Designees: The deputy clerk may designate an individual or individuals to receive requests under the
freedom of information act. Such designation is subject to the approval of the city administrator.
C. Duties Of Freedom Of Information Officer: Except in instances when records are furnished immediately, the
freedom of information officer, or his/her designee, shall receive requests submitted to the city under the
freedom of information act, ensure that the city responds to requests in a timely fashion, and issue
responses under the freedom of information act. The freedom of information officer shall develop a list of
documents or categories of records that the city shall immediately disclose upon request. Upon receiving a
request for a public record, the freedom of information officer shall:
1. Note the date the city receives the written request;
2. Compute the day on which the period for response will expire and make a notation of that date on the
written request;
3. Maintain an electronic or paper copy of a written request, including all documents submitted with the
request until the request has been complied with or denied;
4. Create a file for the retention of the original request, a copy of the response, a record of written
communications with the requester, and a copy of other communications.
D. Denials And Exemptions: In issuing responses, the freedom of information officer shall consult with the city
attorney, city administrator and other appropriate city employees to determine whether items are exempt
from disclosure or whether exempt matter should be redacted as part of a response to a freedom of
information request. In all instances where the freedom of information act allows the "public body" to deny or
redact information which is exempt from disclosure, the freedom of information officer shall have the
authority to make such determinations upon his or her consultation with the city attorney and city
administrator as set forth above.
E. Training: The deputy clerk and the city administrator shall comply with the training requirements set forth in
the freedom of information act.
F. FOIA Fees: The freedom of information officer shall charge the following fees for copying documents:
First 50 pages No charge
Letter/legal, black and white copies for each page after
the first 50 pages
$0.15 per page
Certified copies $1.00 per document in addition to copy
charges
Large format, audiotapes, digital copies or color copies Actual cost to the city, excluding any
personnel costs
The freedom of information officer may waive or reduce the above fees upon a finding by the freedom of
6/5/2019 Sterling Codifiers, Inc.
https://www.sterlingcodifiers.com/codebook/index.php?book_id=502 116/767
information officer that the request is in the public interest as set forth in section 6 of the freedom of information
act. (Ord. 09-55-0, 12-9-2009)
1-21-2: OPEN MEETINGS ACT TRAINING:
A. Persons Designated To Receive Training: The mayor, all aldermen, city clerk, city administrator, deputy clerk
and zoning administrator are hereby designated to receive the training required under the open meetings
act. This designation shall apply to the city council as well as to all standing and ad hoc committees,
commissions or boards of the city ("subordinate public bodies") which may be considered a "public body"
under the open meetings act. The police pension board is not a committee or board of the city and,
therefore, is not a subordinate public body for purposes of this section. Subordinate public bodies need not
make additional designations.
B. Electronic Training: On or before June 30, 2010, or as may be extended by the Illinois public access
counselor, the above designated persons must successfully complete an electronic training curriculum,
developed and administered by the public access counselor, and thereafter must successfully complete an
annual training program.
C. Newly Elected/Appointed/Hired Persons: Whenever new individuals not currently holding the above offices
assume the above offices, those persons must successfully complete the electronic training curriculum
within thirty (30) days after assuming office. (Ord. 09-55-0, 12-9-2009)
Title 2
BOARDS AND COMMISSIONS
Chapter 1
BOARD OF FIRE AND POLICE COMMISSIONERS
2-1-1: CREATION AND TERMS:
There is hereby created a Board of Fire and Police Commissioners consisting of three (3) members who shall
be appointed by the Mayor with consent of the City Council. They shall serve for terms of three (3) years and
until their respective successors shall be appointed and qualified pursuant to the Illinois Municipal Code1. (1970
Code §2-10.01)
2-1-2: QUALIFICATIONS:
The members of the Board of Fire and Police Commissioners shall possess the qualifications set forth in 65
Illinois Compiled Statutes 5/10-2.1-3. (1970 Code §2-10.02)
2-1-3: COMPENSATION:
Members of the Board of Fire and Police Commissioners shall receive compensation for their services as
follows: for each regular and for each special meeting attended, the chairman shall receive fifty dollars ($50.00)
and each of the other commissioners shall receive forty dollars ($40.00). (Ord. 96-39-0, 8-28-1996)
6/5/2019 Sterling Codifiers, Inc.
https://www.sterlingcodifiers.com/codebook/index.php?book_id=502 117/767
2-1-4: POWERS AND DUTIES:
A. Appointments: The Board of Fire and Police Commissioners shall appoint all officers and members of the
Fire and Police Departments of the City, except the Chief of Police and the Chief of the Fire Department;
provided, that all appointments to each Department other than that of the lowest rank shall be from the rank
next below that to which the appointment shall be made, except in the respective appointments of the Chief
of Police and the Chief of the Fire Department, who shall be appointed by the Mayor with the consent of the
City Council; provided further, that such appointments of Chief of Police and Chief of the Fire Department
need not be from among the members of the Police and Fire Departments.
B. Hearings: The Board shall hold hearings on any charges brought against any policeman, except the Chief of
Police, and any full-time fireman, except the Chief of the Fire Department, as provided by statute. (1970
Code §2-10.05)
C. Reports: Annually, on or before May 1 of each year, the Board shall submit to the Mayor a report of its
activities, and of the rules in force and the practical effect thereof. (1970 Code §2-10.06)
D. Duties Prescribed By State Law: The Board of Fire and Police Commissioners, in accordance with the
applicable provisions of the statute, shall make such rules and make such appointments and removals, and
shall have such other and further powers and duties as are contained in 65 Illinois Compiled Statutes 5/10-
2.1-1 through 5/10-2.1-29. (1970 Code §2-10.03)
2-1-5: SECRETARY:
The Board of Fire and Police Commissioners may employ a secretary or may designate one of its own
members to act as such. The secretary shall keep the minutes of the Board's proceedings, shall be custodian of
all papers pertaining to the business of the Board, shall keep a record of all examinations held, and shall
perform such other duties as the Board shall prescribe. (1970 Code §2-10.04; 1986 Code)
Footnote 1: S.H.A. 65 ILCS 5/10-2.1-1 through 5/10-2.1-3.
Chapter 2
BOARD OF LOCAL IMPROVEMENTS
2-2-1: BOARD ESTABLISHED; COMPOSITION:
There is hereby established the Board of Local Improvements in and for the City, which shall consist of the
Mayor and all the members of the City Council.
A. President: The Mayor shall serve as the president of the Board of Local Improvements. (1970 Code §2-
11.01)
B. Secretary: The City Clerk shall be secretary of the Board of Local Improvements. He shall keep all records
pertaining to the activities of the Board, and shall perform such other duties as may be required of him by
the Board or by statute or ordinance. (1970 Code §2-11.04)
6/5/2019 Sterling Codifiers, Inc.
https://www.sterlingcodifiers.com/codebook/index.php?book_id=502 118/767
2-2-2: COMPENSATION:
The members of the Board of Local Improvements shall receive no compensation for their services as
members of such Board. (1970 Code §2-11.05)
2-2-3: ADOPTION OF STATE CODE:
Chapter 24, sections 9-2-1 to 9-2-144 of the Illinois Municipal Code are hereby adopted by reference; provided,
that section 9-2-138 is not adopted and, further provided, the provision of Section 2-2-6 of this Chapter shall
supersede the provisions of said section 9-2-138. (1970 Code §2-11.02, as amended)
2-2-4: RECORDS:
The Board of Local Improvements shall keep adequate records of all work undertaken by it, showing the work
undertaken, the work accomplished, the expenditures made, and the amount of money received. (1970 Code
§2-11.03)
2-2-5: LOCAL IMPROVEMENTS BY SPECIAL ASSESSMENT:
In making local improvements by special assessment, the Board of Local Improvements and the City Council
shall follow the procedures set forth in division 2, article 9 of chapter 24 of the Illinois Revised Statutes. Said
statute provisions are hereby adopted by the City by reference, not less than three (3) copies of such Act
having been on file in the office of the City Clerk for a period of fifteen (15) days prior to the adoption of this
Chapter. The Board of Local Improvements and the City Council shall have all the powers and duties set forth
in said statute incorporated herein by reference. (1970 Code §2-11.06, as amended)
2-2-6: SPECIAL ASSESSMENT REBATES:
A. If, after final settlement with the contractor for any improvement and after full payment of all vouchers or
bonds except those bonds and interest coupons not presented for payment, although called and for which
funds are available and reserved, there is any surplus remaining in the special assessment or special tax
above the specified payments and above the amount necessary for the payment of interest on those
vouchers or bonds, such surplus shall be applied to reimbursing the public benefit fund for any amounts
paid from such fund on account of the improvement.
B. If, after the public benefit fund has been reimbursed, a surplus still remains, the proper authorities of the
Municipality shall declare at once a rebate upon each lot, block, tract or parcel of land assessed, of its pro
rata proportion of that surplus. Such rebate shall be paid to the owner of record of each such lot, block, tract
