Chapter 3
AMUSEMENTS AND AMUSEMENT DEVICES
3-3-1: ALL PURPOSE SPECIAL EVENT LICENSE:
A. Intent: It is the intent of the all purpose special event license to permit the gathering of persons for a limited
period of time and to permit the sale and/or giving away of alcoholic liquor and food and other beverages at
a special event without the necessity of obtaining a separate license for each of those activities.
B. Definitions: For the purpose hereof, a "special event" is a gathering of persons sponsored by an individual or
individuals or an organization or organizations, or any combination thereof, to be held for a limited period of
time, with or without an admission charge, which is held on private property but open to the general public. It
shall not include a gathering taking place upon private property and not open to the general public. The
provisions of this chapter shall apply to all public shows, including, but not limited to, antique shows, craft
shows, baseball and other trading card shows, stamp and coin shows, fashion shows and flea markets; also
exhibitions, including, but not limited to, boxing and wrestling matches; also to theatricals, including, but not
limited to, movies and plays; also to circuses and other amusements held or presented within the City,
whether specifically licensed in another section of this chapter or not.
6/5/2019 Sterling Codifiers, Inc.
https://www.sterlingcodifiers.com/codebook/index.php?book_id=502 185/767
C. Permitted Activities:
1. If serving alcoholic liquor a Class C or Class CC liquor license shall be obtained in conjunction with the all
purpose special event license unless the location hosting the event will be serving alcoholic liquor and
such location holds a current and valid state and City liquor license. (Ord. 15-22-0, 4-22-2015)
2. If any activity, such as tattooing, body piercing or other legal activity shall be a part of the special event, it
will be required that both the applicant as well as the person/corporation performing such activity be
properly licensed by the State of Illinois as well as licensed by a local municipality. All documentation of
proper licensing and proof of insurance must be provided to the City prior to the event. (Ord. 17-17-0, 6-
14-2017)
D. Licensee: The all purpose special event license may be obtained by one (1) or more sponsors of the event
or any provider of food and/or beverages for the event, provided, however, that the application for such
license shall include the name, address and telephone number of at least one (1) sponsor of the event and
of each provider of food and/or beverages. (Ord. 15-22-0, 4-22-2015)
E. Security: No all purpose special event license shall be issued for any event or any gathering at which two
hundred (200) or more persons will be present, unless the licensee shall have first presented to the City
Clerk evidence that there will be on hand at such event or gathering not less than one (1) security person for
every two hundred (200) persons in attendance and if the event is serving or providing alcoholic beverages
then there shall be one (1) security person for every one hundred (100) persons in attendance. Such
security personnel shall be trained in crowd control and security and acceptable to the City Clerk. Such
evidence shall be in the form of a fully executed agreement between the licensee, or his agent, and the
agency or person who will provide such security personnel.
If any licensee fails to have the required number of security personnel present at any gathering as required
hereby, his or her license shall be deemed forfeited, and such licensee shall be subject to prosecution. Upon
the forfeiture of any such license, the Chief of Police, or any police officer acting under the authority of the
City Clerk or the Chief of Police may take appropriate action, including, but not limited to, arrest, citation of
the licensee and the arrest or citation of any person violating such order. (Ord. 16-19-0, 4-13-2016)
F. Applicable Laws: Notwithstanding the broad applicability of the all purpose special event license, each
provider of food, beverages and services thereunder shall be subject to all laws and regulations applicable
to such providers as if they were separately licensed for their respective activities. (Ord. 15-22-0, 4-22-2015)
G. Expiration: Any all purpose special event license will expire at two o'clock (2:00) A.M. on the day following
the date of licensed special event. In the event the special event license is for multiple days, the event shall
be open no later than two o'clock (2:00) A.M. the following day of any day the special event is open.
H. Charge: There shall be no charge for an all purpose special event license. (Ord. 16-19-0, 4-13-2016)
3-3-2: AMUSEMENT DEVICES:
3-3-2-1: DEFINITIONS:
AUTOMATIC AMUSEMENT DEVICES AND/OR ELECTRONIC GAMES: Any machines not requiring a Federal
gambling stamp which, upon the insertion of a coin, slug, token, plate or disc, may be operated by the public
generally for use as a game, entertainment or amusement, whether or not registering a score. It shall include,
but not be limited to, such devices as video games and any other form of electronic games played with
electrically operated devices upon a table or board having holes, pockets, cups or electrical contacts, electrical
6/5/2019 Sterling Codifiers, Inc.
https://www.sterlingcodifiers.com/codebook/index.php?book_id=502 186/767
impulse and/or cathode type games, and all games, operations or transactions similar thereto under whatever
name by which they may be indicated.
MANUALLY OPERATED AMUSEMENT DEVICES AND/OR GAMES: Any amusement device or game which is
not an automatic amusement device or electronic game, as herein defined, not requiring a Federal gambling
stamp, and which, whether or not activated upon the insertion of a coin, slug, token, plate or disc, may be
operated by the public generally for use as a game, entertainment or amusement, whether or not registering a
score. It shall include, but not be limited to, such things as pool tables, billiard tables, shuffleboard tables, and
any other form of table or board having holes, pockets or cups, and not electronically activated or actuated by
any electrical contacts, electrical impulses and/or cathode. For the purposes of this section 3-3-2, the term
"manually operated amusement device" shall include "jukebox".
NONVIDEO GAME: Any machine or other device which is not a "video game", as herein defined, not requiring
a Federal gambling stamp, and which, whether or not activated upon the insertion of a coin, slug, token, plate,
disc, or other object, may be operated by the public generally for use as a game, entertainment or amusement,
whether or not registering a score.
PERSON: Any person, firm, corporation, partnership or association which owns any such machine, device or
game; the person, firm, corporation or association in whose place of business any such machine, device or
game is placed for use by the public; and the person, firm, corporation or association having control over such
machine, device and/or game.
PREMISES: Any building, hall, auditorium or place where any manually operated amusement device or game,
or automatic amusement device and/or electronic game is to be used by the public.
SUPPLIER: Any person, firm, corporation, partnership or association which installs, places, sells, leases or
otherwise distributes any such machine, device and/or game.
VIDEO GAME: Any machine not requiring a Federal gambling stamp which, upon the insertion of a coin, slug,
token, plate, disc, or other object, may be operated by the public generally for use as a game, entertainment or
amusement, whether or not registering a score, and which utilizes a video screen to display the game being
played and which is commonly referred to as a "video game". (1970 Code §§8-2.11, 8-2.17, as amended; amd.
1986 Code; Ord. 91-27-0, 8-28-1991)
3-3-2-2: LICENSE REQUIRED:
A. Suppliers: No supplier shall place, keep, install, maintain, operate, sell, service, lease or otherwise distribute
any amusement device in any building or place within the City without first having obtained a license. (Ord.
91-27-0, 8-28-1991)
B. Individuals: No person shall own, place, keep, maintain, operate or permit any such amusement devices in
any building or place within the city for use by the public without there first having been obtained a license
for each such device, and such license will be issued only to those who operate a business within the city,
licensed by the city or state, and who will use such game and/or device as an appurtenant and subordinate
part of such primary business. (1970 Code §§8-2.12, 8-2.18, as amended; amd. Ord. 89-32-0, 7-26-1989)
C. Location And Number Of Licensed Video Games Limited: The location and the maximum number of video
games which will be licensed upon any one licensed premises shall be only as follows within a:
B-1 zoning district 4
B-2 zoning district 6
B-3 zoning district 8
M-1 zoning district 10
If the square footage of the licensed premises is greater than seven thousand (7,000) square feet, the
6/5/2019 Sterling Codifiers, Inc.
https://www.sterlingcodifiers.com/codebook/index.php?book_id=502 187/767
maximum number of video games per licensed premises in any of said zoning districts is ten (10).
Provided that within the M-1 district such games shall be operated and maintained as appurtenant to a duly
licensed recreational business or community facility which is the primary use at the licensed location. (Ord.
97-10-0, 5-14-1997)
3-3-2-3: FEES:
See section 3-1-13 of this title. (Ord. 00-38-0, 12-13-2000)
3-3-2-4: LICENSING CONDITIONS AND REQUIREMENTS:
A. Compliance With City Code: No license shall be issued for amusement devices defined in section 3-3-2-1 of
this chapter if the premises and primary license of the applicant do not fully comply with the requirements of
the city codes and ordinances.
B. Application For License: Any person desiring a license shall make application therefor through the office of
the city clerk. The application shall set forth the name and address of the applicant or, if a corporation,
partnership or association, the names of the principal officers or partners; and registered agent and
stockholders in the case of a corporation, and their addresses; name(s) and address(es) of the owner(s) of
the machine(s).
C. Investigation: The application shall be referred to the police chief for investigation and verification of the facts
stated therein. The chief of police shall determine whether the applicants, or if a partnership or corporation,
any stockholder or member of the partnership or any employee or manager, has been convicted of a
criminal offense in either the state or federal court. The police chief shall also determine whether the
applicant, or if a corporation or partnership, any stockholder, member, employee or manager has employed
coercive or illegal measures to promote the use of his machines or games. The police chief shall further
determine whether the applicant or its principals, employees or managers are persons of good moral
character.
D. Denial Of License, Appeal: If the police chief shall determine that the applicant, its stockholders, members,
employees or managers, or any of them, have in fact been so convicted or have engaged in such coercive
or illegal measures, or are not persons of good character and fitness, or are otherwise not entitled to such a
license, that said license shall not be issued. The applicant shall have the right to appeal to the city council;
provided however, that the appeal is made within thirty (30) days of the written denial of the mayor. The city
council may, after such hearing, sustain the mayor or order that a license be issued.
E. Revocation Of License: If the mayor shall determine at any time that any licensee is not in fact eligible by
reason of any facts which would have made him not eligible for the issuance of the original license, said
license may be revoked by the mayor after written notice to the licensee, which notice shall specify the
reason(s) for such action. The licensee shall then have ten (10) days in which to appeal to the city council.
At such hearing, the licensee and his attorney may present and submit evidence of witnesses in his
defense. The council may either affirm or overrule the mayor's revocation. Revocation shall be stayed while
any appeal is pending.
F. License Nontransferable: A license shall not be transferable from person to person, nor place to place and
shall be usable only at the place and by the licensee designated in the license.
6/5/2019 Sterling Codifiers, Inc.
https://www.sterlingcodifiers.com/codebook/index.php?book_id=502 188/767
G. Display Of License: Any license issued hereunder shall be conspicuously displayed on the premises of the
licensee.
H. Stock Transfer: If five percent (5%) of a business licensed hereunder is transferred in any manner during a
calendar year to another owner who is not listed as a stockholder on the last application for license, the
license shall terminate unless the licensee, within thirty (30) days, submits an updated application for license
which must comply with all provisions of this section.
I. Supplier Licenses Restricted: There will be no supplier's licenses issued at this time. (1970 Code §§8-2.12, 8-
2.18, as amended)
3-3-2-5: OPERATION AND MAINTENANCE OF AMUSEMENT DEVICES:
A. No gambling or individual wager on any amusement device defined in section 3-3-2-1 of this chapter shall be
permitted.
B. Maximum number of replays on an amusement device, at any one time, shall be:
2 when 1 person is playing
4 when 2 persons are playing
6 when 3 persons are playing
8 when 4 persons are playing
No device to remove replays shall be allowed in conjunction with amusement devices. No person shall buy
back replays.
C. No license issued hereunder shall permit the operation of any such game or device at any place or in any
manner which will disturb the peace and quiet of persons outside the licensed premises. (Ord. 91-27-0, 8-
28-1991)
3-3-3: BILLIARDS, POOL TABLES AND BOWLING ALLEYS:
A. License Required: No person shall operate, maintain or conduct, within the city, a billiard table, pool table or
a bowling alley, open to the public, without first having obtained a license as provided in chapter 1 of this
title. (Ord. 95-19-0, 6-14-1995)
B. Fee: See section 3-1-13 of this title. (Ord. 00-38-0, 12-13-2000)

billiard tables, or a combination thereof, in any single establishment within the following respective zoning
districts shall be as follows:
1. B-1 retail business district: two (2) tables.
2. B-2 limited service business district: three (3) tables.
3. B-3 service and wholesale business district: four (4) tables.
4. M-1 limited manufacturing district: five (5) tables.
6/5/2019 Sterling Codifiers, Inc.
https://www.sterlingcodifiers.com/codebook/index.php?book_id=502 189/767
If the square footage of the licensed premises is greater than seven thousand (7,000) square feet, the
maximum number of billiard and pool tables per licensed establishment in any business zoning district is
four (4) and in the M-1 district five (5). (Ord. 97-10-0, 5-14-1997)
D. Location Restrictions: No such pool table, billiard table, or combination thereof, as described in subsection A
of this section, shall be operated, maintained or used in any but the four (4) zoning districts set forth in
subsection C of this section, and further, their use shall be restricted as appurtenant uses to duly licensed
recreational businesses, community facilities, restaurants, and bowling alleys. (Ord. 95-19-0, 6-14-1995)
3-3-4: CIRCUSES AND CARNIVALS:
A. License Required: No person shall conduct or operate a circus or carnival in the city without first having
obtained a license therefor. Applications for such licenses shall be made to the city clerk and shall specify
the place in or on which the circus or carnival is conducted or open to the public. (1970 Code §8-2.25)
B. Fee: Fees for such licenses shall be two hundred dollars ($200.00) for each day during which the circus or
carnival is conducted or open to the public. (Ord. 99-53-0, 11-29-1999)
C. Cheating: It shall be unlawful for any person to cheat, shortchange or otherwise defraud any person
attending or about to attend a carnival or circus performance within the city. (1970 Code §8-2.27)
3-3-5: GOLFING ACTIVITIES:
A. License Required: It shall be unlawful to operate or conduct a golf driving range, miniature golf or putting
course without first having obtained a license therefor. (1970 Code §§8-2.28, 8-2.31)
B. Fees: See section 3-1-13 of this title.
1. However, if a miniature golf course or putting course is operated on the same premises with and in
connection with a golf driving range, only one license fee of three hundred dollars ($300.00) shall be
required for both the miniature golf course or putting course and the golf driving range. (Ord. 00-38-0, 12-
13-2000)
C. Hours: It is unlawful for any person to operate or open for business any golf driving range, miniature golf or
putting course in the city between the hours of eleven o'clock (11:00) P.M. and seven o'clock (7:00) A.M.
(1970 Code §§8-2.30, 8-2.33)
3-3-6: PRIVATE RECREATIONAL CLUBS:
A. Definition: For the purposes hereof, a "private club" is defined as any association, person, firm, corporation,
key club, racquet club, tennis club, handball club, pool club, golf club, locker club or any other kind of club or
association, excluding the general public from its premises or exercising control over any other place where
only members and guests of members, accompanied by a member, are admitted. (1970 Code §8-2.55)
B. License Required: Except as hereinafter provided, it shall be unlawful for any person or other legal entity to
conduct, operate or maintain a private club, or any activities thereof, upon any premises within the city,
without first having obtained a license therefor. The licensing requirements of this subsection shall not apply
to clubs which are primarily charitable, eleemosynary, educational, recreational, and which are not operated
6/5/2019 Sterling Codifiers, Inc.
https://www.sterlingcodifiers.com/codebook/index.php?book_id=502 190/767
for profit and which hold and maintain an income tax exempt status under the regulations and rulings of the
internal revenue service of the United States. However, such exempt private clubs shall be subject to all
other regulatory provisions hereof which apply to private clubs. (1970 Code §8-2.56)
C. Fee: See section 3-1-13 of this title. (Ord. 00-38-0, 12-13-2000)
D. Compliance With Other Laws: Each private club licensed hereunder which sells any goods or merchandise,
including, but not limited to, alcoholic liquor or beer, food, clothing or sports equipment shall secure a
separate appropriate license therefor. Further, each such private club shall comply with all other ordinances
of the city, including, but not limited to, those governing buildings1, zoning2, food handling3, liquor control4
and health regulations5. (1970 Code §8-2.58)
E. Entry And Inspection: The right of entry and inspection of any premises subject to the control of any private
club by any officer or agent of any department of the city with enforcement of the provisions hereof shall be
a condition on which every private club license shall be issued, and application for, and the acceptance of,
any license hereunder shall conclusively be deemed to be consent of the applicant and licensee to such
entry and inspection. (1970 Code §8-2.59)
F. Membership List: Each private club licensed hereunder shall keep an up-to-date list of all of its members and
officers showing the full name, address, date of application and acceptance into membership of each and, in
the case of officers, the term of office of each. A copy of such list shall be kept on the premises and subject
to inspection by the city at all times. (1970 Code §8-2.60)
G. Use Of Premises: No premises licensed for use of a private club shall be used for any purposes other than
that for which such license is issued, unless the licensee shall have first obtained an appropriate license
therefor. (1970 Code §8-2.61)
3-3-7: PUBLIC DANCES:
A. License Required: It shall be unlawful to operate or conduct a public dance in the city without first having
obtained a license therefor as is herein required pursuant to chapter 1 of this title. (1970 Code §8-2.34)
B. Fee: See section 3-1-13 of this title.
1. Public dances sponsored by charitable organizations or veterans' groups must obtain the required license
but no fee shall be charged. (Ord. 00-38-0, 12-13-2000)
C. Premises: It shall be unlawful to conduct a public dance in any hall or place which is not equipped with
sufficient and adequate exits. (1970 Code §8-2.36)
3-3-8: TEEN BARS:
A. Definitions: "Teen bars", also known as "juice bars", are those establishments providing an opportunity for
patrons of the age group sixteen (16) through twenty (20), inclusive, to socialize and partake of snacks
and/or other foods and beverages of a nonalcoholic nature.
B. Activities: Patrons shall be permitted to socialize while on the premises; however, no patron shall be
permitted to enter more than once during the hours of operation so that no off premises illegal activity may
6/5/2019 Sterling Codifiers, Inc.
https://www.sterlingcodifiers.com/codebook/index.php?book_id=502 191/767
be promoted. No patron shall be permitted to bring alcoholic liquors and/or illegal drugs onto the licensed
premises.
C. Age: Patrons must be at least sixteen (16) years of age and not more than twenty (20) years of age. The
licensee shall see that each patron shall present adequate and sufficient identification and proof of age
before being permitted to enter the licensed premises.
D. Location: Subject to proper zoning, teen bars may be conducted in establishments licensed to sell alcoholic
beverages conditioned on the following: During all hours of operation, all alcoholic beverages will be
secured behind locked cabinets or in other sufficiently secured containers, and all beer and ale taps and
dispensers will be located with any computerized dispensers disconnected. No alcoholic beverages shall be
within the sight of any patron.
E. Sale Of Beverages And Food: Soft drinks and other nonalcoholic beverages may be sold on the premises as
well as snacks and/or other foods.
F. Security: Each licensee shall be responsible for providing adequate security both on the interior and the
outside, including parking lot, of the licensed premises.
G. Hours: Teen bars may be operated between the hours of twelve o'clock (12:00) noon and ten o'clock (10:00)
P.M.
H. Other Applicable Regulations: Establishments licensed hereunder shall also be subject to all health and
sanitary regulations contained in chapter 4 of this title and applicable to restaurants, except that section 3-4-
6-3 of this title, providing for a license fee, shall not apply. (Ord. 88-23-0, 6-8-1988)
I. Fee: See section 3-1-13 of this title.
1. All teen bars shall be licensed in the same manner and using the same procedures as provided for
restaurants under sections 3-4-6-2 and 3-4-6-4 of this title. The city council shall have the right to approve
the issuance of such licenses for less than one year, on a trial basis, and any unused portion of an annual
license fee shall be refunded upon a prorated basis. (Ord. 00-38-0, 12-13-2000)
3-3-9: THEATERS:
A. License Required: It shall be unlawful to give, present or conduct any motion picture or theatrical for which
an admission fee is charged without having first secured a license therefor. (1970 Code §8-2.41)
B. Application For License: Application for such license shall be made in conformance with the general
provisions relating to such applications set forth in section 3-1-2 of this title and shall state, in addition to the
other information required, the place of the intended performance and the seating capacity thereof. (1970
Code §8-2.42)
C. Fees: See section 3-1-13 of this title. (Ord. 00-38-0, 12-13-2000)
D. Prohibited Acts Or Conditions: It shall be unlawful for any person to commit any of the following acts: (1970
Code §8-2.44)
6/5/2019 Sterling Codifiers, Inc.
https://www.sterlingcodifiers.com/codebook/index.php?book_id=502 192/767
1. Prohibited Pictures: To permit any person to offer or present any motion picture which has a tendency to
cause a riot or public disturbance of the peace, or obscene picture or performance. (1970 Code §8-2.44;
amd. Ord. 14-29-0, 8-27-2014)
2. Crowding, Order: To permit any person, excepting ushers or other theater employees, to remain standing
in a hall or room in which a motion picture or theatrical is presented during the time of such performance;
and to admit to any such hall more persons than can be accommodated by the seating arrangements of
the premises. (1970 Code §8-2.46)
3. Scenery: To use in any theater any scenery other than nonflammable scenery or such as shall have been
rendered nonflammable by the application of fire preventive coatings. (1970 Code §8-2.49)
4. Building Requirements: To present any public motion picture or theatrical in any building or structure
which does not contain the number of exits required by the ordinances of the city or by statutes
concerning buildings or places intended for such performances, or in premises which the electric wiring
does not fully comply with the ordinances. All places used for the exhibition of motion pictures or
theatricals must be kept adequately ventilated during the performance and for so long a time as the
audience remains therein. (1970 Code §8-2.50)
5. Exits: To obstruct or permit the obstruction of any aisle, corridor or exit leading from any room or
enclosure in which a motion picture performance or theatrical is being given or in which an audience for
such a performance is seated. (1970 Code §8-2.51)
Chapter 4
FOOD
3-4-1: GENERAL PROVISIONS:
3-4-1-1: DEFINITIONS:
CITY: The city of Countryside, Cook County, Illinois, and where the context requires, it shall also mean the city
of Countryside acting through one or more of its authorized officers, employees or agents.
CODE, CITY CODE AND CITY OF COUNTRYSIDE MUNICIPAL CODE: The city of Countryside municipal
code of 1986, as amended.
COMPLIMENTARY FOOD DEALER: Any person, or other entity operating a business, of any kind, which gives
away or otherwise makes available food to its customers at no charge. Complimentary food dealers shall be
subject to all of the provisions of this chapter which apply to the type of food being made available or the
manner in which it is made available.
FOOD: The term "food" as used in this chapter shall mean any nourishing substance taken into and absorbed
by human beings, or any substance taken as food, and shall be construed to include beverages.
FOOD DEALER: Any person or other entity operating a food service establishment or other establishment,
whether fixed or movable, where food or drink is kept, stored, manufactured, processed, prepared, displayed,
served or transported for purposes of sale, either at wholesale or retail.
FOOD SERVICE ESTABLISHMENT: Any business establishment dealing with the sale of food items.
HEALTH OFFICER: Any individual duly appointed and acting pursuant to section 1-6D-3 of this code, and/or
the Cook County department of public health or other similar agency carrying out the duties of health officer
6/5/2019 Sterling Codifiers, Inc.
https://www.sterlingcodifiers.com/codebook/index.php?book_id=502 193/767
pursuant to contract with the city.
LICENSE: A license issued pursuant to the provisions of this chapter, as amended.
PERSON: Any individual, partnership, corporation or other legal entity. (Ord. 87-31-0; amd. Ord. 94-04-0, 1-12-
1994; Ord. 04-45-0, 12-9-2004)
3-4-1-2: LICENSE REQUIRED, FEE:
A. Fee: See section 3-1-13 of this title.
B. License Required: Unless specifically licensed elsewhere in this chapter, it shall be unlawful for any food
dealer or complimentary food dealer to engage in or do business in the city without having first secured a
license therefor as required by this section. Applications for such licenses shall be made in compliance with
the general provisions of this code relating thereto1, and shall state the kind of food intended to be sold,
handled or processed.
C. Manufacturers Or Sellers Of Food: Any person licensed to manufacture or sell any of the foods for which a
license is required by the terms of this chapter may conduct, on the same premises and in connection with
the licensed business, any other business mentioned in this chapter without paying any additional fee
therefor; provided that the fee paid for the licensed business is at least as great in amount as the fee
required for the other business so conducted. But this section shall not be construed as to relieve any such
applicant from the regulatory requirements of such business. (Ord. 00-38-0, 12-13-2000)
3-4-1-3: APPLICATION FOR LICENSE:
All applications for a license to sell or otherwise dispense food or drink, but not including alcoholic beverages,
intended for human consumption shall be referred to the city code enforcement officer, who shall cause the
health officer to make an investigation of the premises to be used, and report to the city council the results of
such investigation, including findings thereof, recommending or advising against the issuance of the license.
Any application for a license for a food service establishment shall include the name, address and home phone
number of that establishment's certified food service sanitation manager or applicant required by section 3-4-1-
5 of this chapter. (Ord. 04-45-0, 12-9-2004)
3-4-1-4: HEALTH AND SANITATION REQUIREMENTS:
A. Food And Beverages: It shall be unlawful for any person to sell, offer to sell or keep for any purpose any food
or drink of any kind intended for human consumption which is spoiled, tainted, unwholesome or unfit for
human consumption; or which has been adulterated by any material harmful in any way or which does not
comply with state statutes governing the same. (1970 Code §§8-15.03, 8-15.04; amd. 1986 Code)
All tainted and unwholesome food intended for human consumption shall be condemned by the health
officer, and shall thereupon be seized by the health officer or any police officer and disposed of in
accordance with section 3-4-8-15 of this chapter. (Ord. 04-45-0, 12-9-2004)
B. Premises:
1. Sanitary Requirements: Premises used for the sale, manufacture or storage of food intended for human
consumption must be kept in a clean and sanitary condition. It shall be unlawful to permit any
accumulation of refuse or waste of any kind to remain therein for more than twenty four (24) hours, or to
6/5/2019 Sterling Codifiers, Inc.
https://www.sterlingcodifiers.com/codebook/index.php?book_id=502 194/767
permit any decaying matter or decaying animal or plant material to remain on such premises. (1970 Code
§8-15.05)
2. Flies And Vermin: Premises used for the storage, manufacture, preparation or sale of food intended for
human consumption shall be kept free from flies, vermin and rodents. (1970 Code §8-15.08)
C. Employees:
1. Cleanliness: All persons engaged in handling or coming in contact with food intended for sale or human
consumption shall keep themselves clean, both as to person and clothing.
2. Diseased Employees Prohibited: It shall be unlawful for any person who is afflicted with or a carrier of,
any infectious or contagious disease to handle or be engaged in the care or preparation of any such food;
or to permit any such person to be employed in or about any premises where food is stored,
manufactured, prepared or sold; or to deliver such food.
3. Chest X-Ray Required: Each employee must obtain an acceptable chest X-ray before beginning his
employment and annually thereafter, when continuing in the same work. Such X-ray must be from an
approved laboratory and accompanied by the laboratory's interpretation thereof. (1970 Code §8-15.09)
D. Footwear Required: It shall be unlawful for any person who is barefoot to enter upon any premises where
food is kept, stored, prepared, displayed or served for purposes of sale either at wholesale or retail; and it
shall be unlawful for the owner or operator of any such premises to permit such person to enter thereon.
(1970 Code §8-15.10-1, as amended)
3-4-1-5: CERTIFIED FOOD SERVICE SANITATION MANAGER:
Every food service establishment licensed under this chapter shall be under the operational supervision of a
certified food service sanitation manager in accordance with rules promulgated under the "food handling
regulation enforcement act" of Illinois. If any such establishment is temporarily without such a manager, it shall
have six (6) months from the termination of employment of its former manager to secure the services of
another. During said six (6) month period, licensee shall present proof that at least one of its employees or
officers has made application for certification as a certified food service sanitation manager. (Ord. 94-04-0, 1-
12-1994)
3-4-1-6: MONTHLY INSPECTION FOR PESTS:
A. The licensee of any premises licensed hereunder for the manufacture, storage or sale of food intended for
human consumption shall cause such premises to be inspected monthly for the presence of "pests", as
defined by the Illinois pesticide act, by a certified applicator, being a person certified under said Illinois
pesticide act to purchase, use, or supervise the use of pesticides which are classified for restricted use.
B. A written report, issued by such certified applicator, of the area or areas inspected and any treatment
performed, shall be available at the licensed premises for inspection by the city health officer on or before
the fifteenth of the month in which such inspection is made. (Ord. 95-11-0, 4-12-1995)
3-4-2: FOOD RELATED BUSINESS VEHICLES:
3-4-2-1: FOOD DELIVERY VEHICLES:
6/5/2019 Sterling Codifiers, Inc.
https://www.sterlingcodifiers.com/codebook/index.php?book_id=502 195/767
A. License Required: It shall be unlawful to use or permit the use of any vehicle for the storage or carrying of
any food intended for human consumption in the city for the purpose of delivery to any place in the city for
use or consumption or for resale in the city as part of any business transaction in connection with said food
unless a license for such vehicle is first secured and the provisions of this code are fully complied with.
(1970 Code §8-15.11)
B. Fee: See section 3-1-13 of this title. (Ord. 00-38-0, 12-13-2000)
C. Application For License: Application for such license shall be made to the city clerk, and shall state the
names of persons from whom such deliveries are made and the nature of the goods carried. The city clerk
shall issue such licenses, and shall give to the mayor a list of all such licenses issued. (1970 Code §8-
15.12)
D. Sanitation Requirements: All such vehicles shall be kept in a clean and sanitary condition and shall be
thoroughly cleaned each day they are so used. It shall be unlawful to permit any stale food, decaying matter,
or any other waste material or product to accumulate in or on any such vehicle while it is so used.
If unwrapped foodstuffs are transported in any such vehicles, such goods shall be carried in a portion or
compartment of the vehicle which is screened and protected against dust and insects. (1970 Code §8-15.13)
3-4-2-2: FOOD DISPENSING VEHICLES:
A. License Required: No person shall own or operate a motor vehicle on the streets or public places of the city
for the purpose of selling at retail, food products from such vehicle, without first having been issued a
license therefor by the city clerk.
B. Fee: See section 3-1-13 of this title.
C. Sanitary Requirements: The owner and operator of any vehicle licensed hereunder shall at all times keep the
vehicle and all machinery and other components therein contained in a clean and sanitary condition.
D. Background Check; Fingerprinting: It is required that any applicant for an ice cream truck food dispensing
license submit to a background check and be fingerprinted whether said applicant be an individual or a
partnership. Should the applicant be a corporation, the city clerk, within his or her discretion, may require the
following to complete a background check and be fingerprinted: the officers, manager or director thereof, or
any stockholder or stockholders owning in the aggregate of more than five percent (5%) of the capital stock
of said corporation.
All such fingerprinting shall be done by the city police department. Said fingerprints shall be submitted to the
appropriate state and/or federal agencies for processing as available. The cost of fifty dollars ($50.00) for
fingerprinting and background check shall be recoverable from the applicant. (Ord. 15-21-0, 4-22-2015)
3-4-3: ICE CREAM PARLORS:
A. Definition: For the purposes of this section, an "ice cream parlor" means any place where ice cream, any
drink or refreshment containing milk or cream, carbonated water, fruit juice or ices are sold for consumption
on the premises. (1970 Code §8-15.17)
6/5/2019 Sterling Codifiers, Inc.
https://www.sterlingcodifiers.com/codebook/index.php?book_id=502 196/767
B. License Required: It is unlawful for any person to conduct or operate an ice cream parlor in the city without
obtaining a license therefor. The application for the license shall be made to the city clerk and shall state the
matters specified in section 3-1-2 of this title. (1970 Code §8-15.18)
C. Fee: See section 3-1-13 of this title. (Ord. 00-38-0, 12-13-2000)
D. Requirements And Restrictions:
1. No ice cream containing more than fifty thousand (50,000) bacteria per cubic centimeter shall be sold or
offered for sale in the city.
2. Any ice cream which contains less than eight percent (8%) butterfat shall be sold in containers which
have on the outside thereof a label, plainly visible and readable, stating the contents thereof have less
than eight percent (8%) butterfat. (1970 Code §8-15.19)
3-4-4: MILK DEALERS:
A. License Required: It shall be unlawful to engage in the sale or distribution of milk or cream in the city without
having first obtained a license therefor. (1970 Code §8-15.21)
B. Fees: See section 3-1-13 of this title. (Ord. 00-38-0, 12-13-2000)
C. Application For License: Application for such license shall comply with the general regulations governing
such applications, as set out in section 3-1-2 of this title, and shall state, in addition to the other information
required, the source of supply of the milk to be sold, and the ownership of the cattle from whom the milk is
produced. (1970 Code §8-15.22)
D. Health And Sanitation Requirements:
1. Compliance With State Law Required: "Milk", as the term is used herein, shall mean the whole, fresh,
clean lacteal secretion obtained by the complete milking of one or more cows, excluding that obtained
within fifteen (15) days before and five (5) days after calving or such longer period as may be required to
render the milk practically colostrum free, and shall contain not less than three and one-quarter percent
(3.25%) of milk fat, and not less than eight and one-quarter percent (8.25%) of milk solids not fat. No milk
not conforming to this subsection shall be sold or offered for sale in the city.
All milk, milk products, buttermilk and cream shall conform to the standards fixed in the state dairy
statute2, and the sale or offering for sale of any milk or milk product not in conformity with this law is
prohibited. (1970 Code §8-15.24)
2. Deliveries To Quarantined Premises:
a. Milk may be delivered to quarantined premises, provided that there is no contact of any kind between
the inmates and contents of the quarantined premises and the delivery agent.
b. No milk receptacles shall be taken from such premises during the period of quarantine; and before
being taken away for use, such receptacles shall be thoroughly scalded and sterilized. (1970 Code §8-
15.25)
3. Vehicles: Every vehicle used for the delivery of milk or cream to the consumer shall have marked plainly
thereon the name and address of the producer of such milk. All such vehicles shall be kept in a clean and
sanitary manner and condition. (1970 Code §8-15.26)
6/5/2019 Sterling Codifiers, Inc.
https://www.sterlingcodifiers.com/codebook/index.php?book_id=502 197/767
E. Milk Or Milk Products From Other States, Prerequisites For Sale: Grade A raw milk and milk products, and
grade A pasteurized milk and milk products from outside the state shall not be sold in the state unless
produced and/or pasteurized under provisions which are substantially equivalent to the requirements of 410
Illinois Compiled Statutes, and which are enforced with equal effectiveness and determined by a milk
sanitation rating, reported by the state health authority of the state of origin. (1970 Code §8-15.28)
F. Inspection: The health officer shall conduct periodic inspections of all milk distribution plants, dairies, vehicles
and equipment used in the sale or distribution of milk as well as of the milk itself. Such inspection shall be
made every three (3) months or more often if the health officer deems necessary. The inspector may, in his
discretion, in lieu of inspections, accept the certificate of inspection of any other city having equal or more
rigid requirements than provided by this section. The licensee shall pay the cost of all bacteriological
inspections and tests necessary. (1970 Code §8-15.27)
3-4-5: REFRIGERATION LOCKER PLANTS:
A. Definition: "Food refrigeration locker plant" shall mean and include any establishment wherein compartments
are rented, leased or made available to any other than the owner of the establishment for the refrigerated
storage of food. (1970 Code §8-15.29)
B. License Required, Fee:
1. Required: It shall be unlawful for any person to operate or maintain a food refrigeration locker plant in the
city without first having secured a license therefor. (1970 Code §8-15.30; amd. 1986 Code; Ord. 99-53-0,
11-29-1999)
2. Fee: See section 3-1-13 of this title. (Ord. 00-38-0, 12-13-2000)
C. Application For License: The application for the license required by this section shall be made to the city
clerk and shall state the matters specified in section 3-1-2 of this title, as well as the number of units
maintained on the premises, the size of each unit and whether a unit is maintained in which will be stored
food belonging to various individuals in addition to the separate units rented to other than the owner of the
premises. (1970 Code §8-15.31)
D. Building Construction: No food refrigeration locker plant shall be operated or conducted in a building which is
not constructed in full compliance with the provisions of this code or any other ordinances of the city3, or in
any building other than one where the floors are so constructed as to bear a live load of one hundred (100)
pounds per square foot. (1970 Code §8-15.32)
E. Sanitation Requirements:
1. All premises used for the operation of a refrigeration locker plant shall be kept in a clean and sanitary
condition, shall be thoroughly cleaned of all refuse, dust and debris at least once in every twenty four (24)
hours; and all refuse and debris shall be removed from the premises at least once in every twenty four
(24) hours.
2. It is unlawful to store or keep in such plant unwholesome, spoiled, contaminated or adulterated food.
(1970 Code §8-15.33)
3-4-6: RESTAURANTS:
6/5/2019 Sterling Codifiers, Inc.
https://www.sterlingcodifiers.com/codebook/index.php?book_id=502 198/767
3-4-6-1: DEFINITIONS:
The following definitions shall apply in the interpretation and enforcement of this section:
ITINERANT RESTAURANT: One operating for a temporary period in connection with a fair, carnival, circus,
public exhibition or other similar gathering.
RESTAURANT: Any place that keeps for sale, sells and serves to the general public, for consumption on the
premises, any article of food or drink for human consumption. Restaurants, ordinaries, coffeehouses, ice cream
parlors, lunchrooms, tearooms, lunch stands, box lunch deliveries, luncheonettes, cafeterias and retail
drugstores serving counter lunches and drinks, lounges, caterers and industrial food servers dispensing food or
drinks to office personnel or employees of an industrial plant. (1970 Code §8-15.34; amd. 1986 Code)
3-4-6-2: LICENSE REQUIRED:
It shall be unlawful for any person to operate or maintain a restaurant or an itinerant restaurant in the city, which
does not possess a current unrevoked license for such business from the city. Only persons who comply with
the requirements of this section 3-4-6 shall be entitled to receive and retain such a license. The license required
hereunder shall be posted in a conspicuous place in that part of the restaurant to which the public has access.
(1970 Code §8-15.35; amd. Ord. 04-45-0, 12-9-2004)
3-4-6-3: FEES:
See section 3-1-13 of this title. (Ord. 00-38-0, 12-13-2000)
3-4-6-4: APPLICATION FOR LICENSE:
An application for a restaurant license shall be made in writing to the city clerk in such form as he shall require.
Each application shall state the name of the applicant, location of the premises and shall contain such further
information as may be required by the health officer in order to inform him fully as to the size and nature of the
place to be used for the purposes of the business and the conditions, equipment and facilities for conducting
the business therein, the health of persons to be employed, and the regulations and facilities provided for them.
The city clerk shall issue a restaurant license to such person who complies with the requirements of this section
3-4-6; provided, however, that no such license shall be issued by the city clerk unless the health officer has
certified that he has completed his inspection as required under the provisions of section 3-4-8-4 of this chapter,
and that the applicant has complied with all applicable provisions of this section 3-4-6 relating to health and
sanitation; and provided further, that no such license shall be issued by the city clerk unless the building
commissioner has certified that he has completed the inspection required to be made by him under the
provisions of section 3-4-8-4 of this chapter and that the applicant has complied with all provisions of the
building code4. (1970 Code §8-15.36; amd. Ord. 04-45-0, 12-9-2004)
3-4-6-5: RESERVED:
(Ord. 04-45-0, 12-9-2004)
3-4-6-6: HEALTH AND SANITATION REQUIREMENTS:
6/5/2019 Sterling Codifiers, Inc.
https://www.sterlingcodifiers.com/codebook/index.php?book_id=502 199/767
A. Unwholesome Food: No person shall offer for sale or keep for the purpose of selling or offering for sale, any
food of any kind intended for human consumption which is spoiled, tainted or is unwholesome and unfit for
human consumption for any reason. (1970 Code §8-15.39)
See section 3-4-8-15 of this chapter for enforcement procedure. (Ord. 04-45-0, 12-9-2004)
B. Employees: Every person connected with a restaurant or about to be employed therein, whose work brings
him in contact with the handling of food, drink, utensils or equipment shall first obtain a health certificate
from the health officer. Prior to issuing such certificate, the health officer shall examine and take a careful
morbidity history and blood test of such person. Such person shall also obtain an acceptable chest X-ray
before beginning employment and annually thereafter, when continuing in the same work. Such X-ray must
be from an approved laboratory and be accompanied by the laboratory's interpretation thereof. If such
examination of his history suggests that such person may be a carrier of or infected with the organisms of
typhoid or paratyphoid fever or any other communicable diseases likely to be transmitted through food, drink
or utensils, the health officer shall secure appropriate specimens of body discharges and cause them to be
examined in a laboratory approved by him or by the state health authorities for such examinations, and if the
results justify, such person shall be barred from such employment. If such person is free from infection, he
shall be entitled to a health certificate which shall be effective for a one year period; provided, however, that
such person shall furnish such information, submit to such physical examinations, and submit such
laboratory specimens as the health officer may require for the purpose of determining freedom from
infection. A fee of fifty cents ($0.50) shall be charged for each specimen submitted for examination. Blood
specimen tests shall be repeated every six (6) months thereafter.
No person who is afflicted with any disease in a communicable form, or is a carrier of such disease, shall
work in any restaurant, and no restaurant shall employ any such person suspected of being a carrier of such
disease. If the person in charge of any restaurant suspects that any employee has contracted any disease
in a communicable form, or has become a carrier of such disease in a communicable form, he shall notify
the health officer immediately. (1970 Code §8-15.40)
When suspicion arises as to the probability of transmission of infection from any restaurant employee, the
procedures set forth in section 3-4-8-18 of this chapter shall be followed.
C. Inspection: See sections 3-4-8-10 through 3-4-8-14 of this chapter. (Ord. 04-45-0, 12-9-2004)
D. Premises:
1. Toilet Facilities:
a. Every restaurant shall be provided with adequate and conveniently located toilet facilities for its
employees, conforming with the ordinances of the city.
b. In restaurants hereinafter constructed, toilet rooms shall not open directly into any room in which food,
drink or utensils are handled or stored.
c. The doors of all toilet rooms shall be self-closing.
d. Toilet rooms shall be kept in a clean condition, in good repair and well lighted and ventilated.
e. Hand washing signs shall be posted in each toilet room used by employees. (1970 Code §8-15.43)
2. Water Supply: Running water under pressure shall be easily accessible to all rooms in which food is
prepared or utensils are washed, and the water supply shall be adequate, and of a safe, sanitary quality.
(1970 Code §8-15.44)
3. Lavatory Facilities:
6/5/2019 Sterling Codifiers, Inc.
https://www.sterlingcodifiers.com/codebook/index.php?book_id=502 200/767
a. Adequate and convenient hand washing facilities shall be provided, including hot and cold running
water, soap, and approved sanitary towels.
b. The use of a common towel is prohibited.
c. No employee shall resume work after using the toilet room without first washing his hands. (1970 Code
§8-15.45)
4. Disposal Of Wastes: All wastes shall be properly disposed of, and all garbage and trash shall be kept in
suitable receptacles, in such manner as not to become a nuisance. (1970 Code §8-15.49)
5. Miscellaneous:
a. The premises of all restaurants shall be kept clean and free of litter or rubbish.
b. None of the operations connected with a restaurant shall be conducted in any room used as living or
sleeping quarters.
c. Adequate lockers or dressing rooms shall be provided for employees' clothing and shall be kept clean.
d. Soiled linens, coats and aprons shall be kept in containers provided for this purpose. (1970 Code §8-
15.53; amd. 1986 Code)
E. Utensils And Equipment:
1. Construction:
a. All multiuse utensils and all show and display cases or windows, counters, shelves, tables, refrigerating
equipment, sinks and other equipment or utensils used in connection with the operation of a restaurant
shall be so constructed as to be easily cleaned and shall be kept in good repair.
b. Utensils containing or plated with cadmium or lead shall not be used; provided, that solder containing
lead may be used for jointing. (1970 Code §8-15.46)
2. Cleaning And Bactericidal Treatment:
a. All equipment, including display cases or windows, counters, shelves, tables, refrigerators, stoves,
hoods, and sinks shall be kept clean and free from dust, dirt, insects and other contaminating material.
All cloths used by waiters, chefs and other employees shall be clean. Single service containers shall be
used only once.
b. All multiuse eating and drinking utensils shall be thoroughly cleaned and effectively subjected to an
approved bactericidal process after each usage. All multiuse utensils used in the preparation or serving
of food and drink shall be thoroughly cleaned and effectively subjected to an approved bactericidal
process immediately following the day's operation. Drying cloths, if used, shall be clean and used for no
other purpose.
c. No article, polish or other substance containing any cyanide preparation or other poisonous material
shall be used for the cleaning or polishing of utensils. (1970 Code §8-15.47)
3. Storage And Handling: After bactericidal treatment, utensils shall be stored in a clean, dry place protected
from flies, dust and other contamination, and shall be handled in such a manner as to prevent
contamination as far as practicable. Single service utensils shall be purchased only in sanitary containers,
and shall be stored therein in a clean, dry place until used, and shall be handled in a sanitary manner.
(1970 Code §8-15.48)
F. Care Of Food:
6/5/2019 Sterling Codifiers, Inc.
https://www.sterlingcodifiers.com/codebook/index.php?book_id=502 201/767
1. Refrigeration: All readily perishable food and drink shall be kept at or below fifty degrees Fahrenheit
(50°F) except when being prepared or served. Wastewater from refrigeration equipment shall be properly
disposed of.
2. Wholesomeness: All food and drink shall be clean, wholesome, free from spoilage, and so prepared as to
be safe for human consumption. All milk, fluid milk products, ice cream and other frozen desserts served
shall be from approved sources. Milk and fluid milk products shall be served in the individual original
containers in which they were received from the distributor or from a bulk container equipped with an
approved dispensing device; provided, that this requirement shall not apply to cream, which may be
served from the original bottle or from a dispenser approved for such service. All oysters, clams and
mussels shall be from approved sources, and if shucked, shall be kept until used in the containers in
which they were placed at the shucking plant. (1970 Code §8-15.51)
3. Storage, Display And Serving: All food and drink shall be so stored, displayed and served as to be
protected from dust, flies, vermin, depredation and pollution by rodents, unnecessary handling, droplet
infection, overhead leakage and other contamination. No animals or fowls shall be kept or allowed in any
room in which food or drink is prepared or stored. All means necessary for the elimination of flies, roaches
and rodents shall be used. (1970 Code §8-15.52)
3-4-6-7: DRIVE-IN/CARRYOUT RESTAURANTS:
A. Definitions: For the purposes of this section, the following terms, phrases and words shall have the meanings
given herein:
CARRYOUT RESTAURANT: Any establishment where food, frozen dessert and/or beverage is sold to
the consumer where parking is limited and the consumer must take such food, frozen dessert and/or
beverage to another location for consumption.
DRIVE-IN RESTAURANT: Any establishment where food, frozen dessert and/or beverage is sold to the
consumer, where motor vehicle parking space is provided and where such food, frozen dessert, and/or
beverage is intended to be consumed in the motor vehicle parked upon the premises or anywhere on the
premises outside of the building.
FEE: See section 3-1-13 of this title.
LICENSEE: A person having a city license in full force and effect issued for a drive-in restaurant.
PERSON: Any person, firm, partnership, association, corporation, company or organization of any kind.
WASTE MATERIAL: Paper cups, straw, napkins, garbage, beverages and all other waste matter intended
for disposal, which, if not placed in a proper receptacle, tends to create a public nuisance by rendering
property unclean, unsafe and unsightly. (1970 Code §8-15.58; amd. 1986 Code; Ord. 99-53-0, 11-29-1999;
Ord. 00-38-0, 12-13-2000)
B. Quiet And Good Order To Be Maintained: The licensee shall maintain quiet and good order upon the
premises of a drive-in or carryout restaurant and shall not permit disorderly or immoral conduct or loitering.
The licensee shall not cause or create any noise or other nuisance on the parking area of a drive-in
restaurant whereby the quiet and good order of the premises or of the neighborhood is disturbed. (1970
Code §8-15.59; amd. 1986 Code)
C. Noise And Other Disturbances By Patrons: No person on the premises of a drive-in or carryout restaurant
shall race the motor of any motor vehicle, needlessly bring to a sudden start or stop any motor vehicle, blow
any horn, or make or cause to be made any other loud or unseemly noise, nuisance or disturbance whereby
the quiet and good order of the premises or of the neighborhood is disturbed, nor shall the licensee permit
such conduct. (1970 Code §8-15.60; amd. 1986 Code)
6/5/2019 Sterling Codifiers, Inc.
https://www.sterlingcodifiers.com/codebook/index.php?book_id=502 202/767
D. Refuse Disposal:
1. Premises Free From Refuse: No person shall place, throw or deposit any waste material upon the outside
premises or parking area of a drive-in or carryout restaurant or on any street, alley or adjoining property or
in the vicinity of a drive-in or carryout restaurant, except in adequate receptacles provided for that
purpose, nor shall the licensee permit such conduct. (1970 Code §8-15.61; amd. 1986 Code)
2. Disposal Of Refuse By Licensee; Containers: The licensee shall, at least once in twenty four (24) hours,
dispose of waste materials which tend to create a public nuisance on the premises. The licensee shall
keep the premises whereon the restaurant is located, together with the parking area and that portion of
any street or alley adjoining the restaurant, free from waste material. The licensee shall provide the
restaurant with a sufficient number of adequate refuse containers. (1970 Code §8-15.62; amd. 1986
Code)
E. Intoxicating Liquors: No person on the premises of a drive-in or carryout restaurant, whether in or out of a
motor vehicle, shall drink, have in his possession or under his control, or offer to give to another to drink,
any beer, wine or intoxicating liquor, nor shall the licensee permit such conduct; provided, however, that this
provision shall not apply to any person when served inside the building by a drive-in or carryout restaurant
duly licensed to serve such beverages. (1970 Code §8-15.63; amd. 1986 Code)
F. Parking: No person shall enter the premises of a drive-in or carryout restaurant in a motor vehicle, park said
motor vehicle and then leave the premises other than in said motor vehicle without first obtaining the
consent of the owner of said premises. (1970 Code §8-15.64; amd. 1986 Code)
3-4-7: VENDING MACHINES:
A. License Required: No person shall operate or maintain in the city any automatic vending machine for the
sale of food, drink or cigarettes without first having obtained a license for each of such automatic vending
machines as provided in this section. Such license shall be renewed annually. (1970 Code §8-15.54)
B. Machine Defined: For the purposes hereof, each coin slot, the use of which will result in the purchase of a
certain item, including coins for operation thereof, from an individual dispensing mechanism, shall be
considered a separate machine and licensed individually, notwithstanding that it is located in a single unit
housing other coin slots utilized for dispensing other items. (Ord. 94-14-0, 4-27-1994)
C. Fees: See section 3-1-13 of this title.
1. The city may waive the required fee for any applicant that presents proof it possesses a current, valid
registration under "an act to regulate solicitation and collection of funds for charitable purposes, providing
for violations thereof, and making appropriation therefor"5 as amended from time to time.
The city clerk shall issue to the licensee a decal for each machine, which decal shall be posted in a
conspicuous place on the machine. (Ord. 00-38-0, 12-13-2000)
D. Application For License: Any person desiring to sell food, drink or cigarettes by means of automatic vending
machines shall make application for a license for that purpose to the city clerk, in which application shall be
set forth the full name of the applicant and the number of machines for which the applicant desires licenses.
(1970 Code §8-15.55)
E. Inspection And Analysis: It shall be the duty of the health officer and he is hereby authorized and empowered
to inspect and examine all food or drink being offered for sale by means of an automatic vending machine
6/5/2019 Sterling Codifiers, Inc.
https://www.sterlingcodifiers.com/codebook/index.php?book_id=502 203/767
for the purpose of ascertaining whether the laws of the state and of the city in relation to sales from the
vending machines are complied with, and that the food and drink so offered for sale have been kept fresh,
clean and wholesome. It shall be the duty of all persons operating the vending machines, upon demand of
the health officer, to furnish to him for his inspection samples of all such food and drink, which samples may
be analyzed by or under the direction of the health officer, and a record of such analysis shall be made and
kept in his office for the inspection of the public.
The health officer shall also inspect all locations where the machines are placed in order to ascertain that
the food and drink shall be free of contamination and in a wholesome condition. All machines shall be kept
within the enclosure of a substantial building, and the owners of the machines shall, on the request of the
health officer, furnish keys for the machines so that the contents of same may be inspected in company with
a representative that the owner of the machine may designate. (1970 Code §8-15.57)
3-4-8: ENFORCEMENT:
3-4-8-1: INTENT:
It is the intent of this section 3-4-8 to provide the mechanisms and procedures for enforcement of the regulatory
provisions of this chapter and related sections of this code. Wherever the provisions of any other section of this
chapter conflict with the provisions of this section 3-4-8, it is intended that the provisions of this section 3-4-8
shall govern. (Ord. 04-45-0, 12-9-2004)
3-4-8-2: STATUTES AND CODES:
In order to effectuate the intent hereof, section 5/1-3-1 et seq., of the Illinois municipal code6, as amended; the
1998 and all subsequent editions of, or amendments to, the Illinois department of public health's publication
currently titled, "Food Service Sanitation Code", that are on file with the secretary of state; and the 1992 and all
subsequent editions of, or amendments to, the Illinois department of public health's publication currently titled,
"Retail Food Store Sanitation Code", that are on file with the secretary of state, are incorporated in and made a
part hereof by reference.
The issuance of licenses shall be governed by sections 3-4-1-3, "Application For License"; 3-4-2-1, "Food
Delivery Vehicles"; 3-4-2-2, "Food Dispensing Vehicles"; 3-4-3, "Ice Cream Parlors"; 3-4-4, "Milk Dealers"; 3-4-
5, "Refrigeration Locker Plants"; 3-4-6, "Restaurants"; 3-4-6-7, "Drive-In/Carryout Restaurants"; 3-4-7, "Vending
Machines" of this chapter; suspension and revocation of licenses to operate retail food establishments; the
prohibiting of the sale of unsound or mislabeled food or drink; and the enforcement of this chapter shall be
regulated in accordance with this section 3-4-8. The inspection of food service establishments shall be
regulated in accordance with the 1998 and all subsequent editions of, or amendments to, the Illinois department
of public health's publication currently titled, "Food Service Sanitation Code" that are on file with the secretary of
state. The inspection of retail food stores shall be regulated in accordance with the 1992 and all subsequent
editions of, or amendments to, the Illinois department of public health's publication currently titled, "Retail Food
Store Sanitation Code", that are on file with the secretary of state.
Further, three (3) copies of each of the Illinois department of public health's publications currently titled, "Food
Service Sanitation Code", and "Retail Food Store Sanitation Code", shall be on file at the city clerk's office and
available to public inspection during normal business hours. (Ord. 04-45-0, 12-9-2004)
3-4-8-3: COMPLIANCE PROCEDURES; GENERAL:
No person shall operate a food establishment who does not have a valid license issued to them by the city of
Countryside. Only a person who complies with the requirements of this chapter shall be entitled to receive or
6/5/2019 Sterling Codifiers, Inc.
https://www.sterlingcodifiers.com/codebook/index.php?book_id=502 204/767
retain such a license. Licenses are not transferable. A valid license shall be posted in every food establishment.
(Ord. 04-45-0, 12-9-2004)
3-4-8-4: INSPECTION REQUIRED PRIOR TO ISSUANCE OF LICENSE:
A. Any person desiring to operate a food establishment shall make written application for a license in
accordance with the procedures provided elsewhere in this chapter for the particular type of license
required.
B. Prior to approval of an application for a license, the city and the Cook County department of public health
shall inspect the proposed food establishment to determine compliance with the requirements of this
chapter.
C. The city shall issue a license to the applicant if its inspection reveals that the proposed food establishment
complies with the requirements of this chapter. (Ord. 04-45-0, 12-9-2004)
3-4-8-5: SUSPENSION OF LICENSE:
A. Any license issued under this chapter may be temporarily suspended without warning, notice, or hearing
upon the violation by the holder of any of the terms of this chapter or if the establishment otherwise
constitutes a hazard to the public health. Suspension is effective upon service of the notice required by
section 3-4-8-7 of this chapter. When a license is suspended, food operations shall immediately cease.
Whenever a license is suspended, the holder of the license shall be afforded the opportunity for hearing
within twenty (20) days of receipt by the city of a request for hearing as provided for in subsection B of this
section.
B. Whenever a license is suspended, the holder of the license, the person in charge of the licensed premises,
or other agent of the license holder, shall be notified in writing that the license is, upon service of the notice,
immediately suspended and that an opportunity for hearing will be provided if a written request for hearing is
filed with the office of the city clerk by the holder of the license within ten (10) days of service of such notice.
If no written request for hearing is filed within that ten (10) day period, the suspension is sustained. The city
may end the suspension at any time if reasons for suspension no longer exist. (Ord. 04-45-0, 12-9-2004)
3-4-8-6: REVOCATION OF LICENSE:
A. The city may, after providing opportunity for hearing as provided for in subsection B of this section, revoke
the license for serious or repeated violations of any of the requirements of this code or for the interference
with the city or the Cook County department of public health in the performance of their duties hereunder.
B. Prior to revocation, the city shall notify, in writing, the holder of the license, the person in charge of the
licensed premises, or other agent of the license holder, of the specific reason(s) for which the license is to
be revoked and that the license shall be revoked at the end of the ten (10) days following service of such
notice unless a written request for hearing is filed with the office of the city clerk by the holder of the license
within such ten (10) day period. If no request for hearing is filed within that ten (10) day period, the
revocation of the license becomes final. (Ord. 04-45-0, 12-9-2004)
3-4-8-7: SERVICE OF NOTICES:
6/5/2019 Sterling Codifiers, Inc.
https://www.sterlingcodifiers.com/codebook/index.php?book_id=502 205/767
All notices provided for in this section 3-4-8 are properly served when delivered to the holder of the license, the
person in charge of any part of the business operated under such license, or other agent of the license holder,
or when sent by registered or certified mail, return receipt requested, to the last known address of the holder of
the license. In either case, the date of receipt shall be deemed the date of service. A copy of the notice, with
sworn proof of service, shall be filed in the office of the city clerk and maintained as part of the licensee's file.
(Ord. 04-45-0, 12-9-2004)
3-4-8-8: HEARINGS:
The hearings provided for in this section shall be conducted by the city's administrative adjudication hearing
officer at a time and place designated by him. All oral testimony given at such hearing shall be transcribed
verbatim or recorded, and the hearing officer shall make provision for copies of a complete transcript, including
testimony and exhibits admitted into evidence, to be made available to all interested parties upon request.
Within three (3) working days following conclusion of the hearing, the hearing officer shall make a final written
decision including findings based upon the complete hearing proceedings held before him and shall sustain,
modify, or rescind any notice or order considered in the hearing. A copy of the hearing officer's written decision
including findings shall be furnished to the holder of the license.
The hearing officer's decisions shall not be subject to review, reconsideration or appeal by him but shall be
subject to administrative review before the circuit court. (Ord. 04-45-0, 12-9-2004)
3-4-8-9: APPLICATION AFTER REVOCATION:
Whenever a revocation of a license has become final, the holder of the revoked license may make written
application for a new permit, license, or certificate. (Ord. 04-45-0, 12-9-2004)
3-4-8-10: INSPECTION FREQUENCY:
An inspection of a food establishment shall be performed at a frequency prescribed by the city. Additional
inspections of the food establishment shall be performed as often as necessary for the enforcement of this
chapter. (Ord. 04-45-0, 12-9-2004)
3-4-8-11: ACCESS:
Duly authorized representatives of the city or the Cook County department of public health, after proper
identification, shall be permitted to enter any food establishment at any reasonable time for the purpose of
making inspections to determine compliance with this chapter. Such representatives shall be permitted to
examine the records of the establishment to obtain information pertaining to food and supplies purchased,
received, or used. (Ord. 04-45-0, 12-9-2004)
3-4-8-12: REPORT OF INSPECTIONS:
Whenever an inspection of a food establishment is made, the findings shall be recorded on an inspection report
form substantially in accordance with that set forth in the appendix attached to ordinance 04-45-0, or as
otherwise prescribed by the city. The inspection form shall summarize the requirements of this chapter and
shall set forth a weighted point value for each requirement. Inspectional remarks should be written to reference,
by item number, the item violated and should state the correction to be made. The rating score of the
establishment shall be the total of the weighted point values for all violations, subtracted from one hundred
(100). A copy of the completed inspection report form shall be furnished to the person in charge of the
6/5/2019 Sterling Codifiers, Inc.
https://www.sterlingcodifiers.com/codebook/index.php?book_id=502 206/767
establishment at the conclusion of the inspection. The completed inspection report form is a public document
that shall be made available for public disclosure to any person who requests it according to law. (Ord. 04-45-0,
12-9-2004)
3-4-8-13: CORRECTION OF VIOLATIONS:
A. The completed inspection report form shall specify a reasonable period of time for the correction of the
violations found, and correction of the violations shall be accomplished within the period specified, in
accordance with the following provisions:
1. If an imminent health hazard exists, such as complete lack of refrigeration or sewage backup into the
establishment, the establishment shall immediately cease food operations. Operations shall not be
resumed until authorized by the Cook County department of public health.
2. All violations of four (4) or five (5) point weighted items shall be corrected as soon as possible, but in any
event, within ten (10) days following inspection. A follow up inspection to confirm correction may be
conducted at the discretion of the Cook County department of public health.
3. All one or two (2) point weighted items shall be corrected as soon as possible, but in any event, by the
time of the next routine inspection.
4. When the rating score of the establishment is less than sixty (60), the establishment shall initiate
corrective action on all identified violations within forty eight (48) hours. One or more reinspections may
be conducted at reasonable time intervals to assure correction.
5. In the case of temporary food establishments, all violations shall be corrected within twenty four (24)
hours. If violations are not corrected within twenty four (24) hours, the establishment shall immediately
cease food operations until authorized to resume by the Cook County department of public health.
B. The inspection report shall state that failure to comply with any time limits for corrections may result in
cessation of food operations. An opportunity for hearing on the inspection findings or the time limitations or
both will be provided if a written request is filed with the office of the city clerk within ten (10) days following
cessation of operations. If a request for hearing is received, a hearing shall be held within twenty (20) days
of receipt of the request following the same procedures as are set forth in section 3-4-8-8 of this chapter
insofar as those procedures are appropriate for such a hearing.
C. Whenever a food establishment is required under provisions of this section to cease operations, it shall not
resume operations until it is shown on reinspection that conditions responsible for the order to cease
operations no longer exist. Opportunity for reinspection shall be offered within a reasonable time. (Ord. 04-
45-0, 12-9-2004)
3-4-8-14: INSPECTION REPORT FORM:
See appendix attached to ordinance 04-45-0. (Ord. 04-45-0, 12-9-2004)
3-4-8-15: EXAMINATION AND CONDEMNATION OF FOOD:
Food may be examined or sampled by the Cook County department of public health as often as necessary for
enforcement of this chapter. The Cook County department of public health may, upon written notice to the
owner or person in charge of the licensed premises, specifying with particularity the reasons therefor, place a
hold order on any food which it believes is in violation of section 750.100, 750.110, 760.100, or 760.110 of the
Illinois department of public health's "Food Service Sanitation Code" or the "Retail Food Store Sanitation Code",
6/5/2019 Sterling Codifiers, Inc.
https://www.sterlingcodifiers.com/codebook/index.php?book_id=502 207/767
respectively, or any other section of this chapter. The Cook County department of public health shall tag, label,
or otherwise identify any food subject to the hold order. No food subject to a hold order shall be used, served, or
moved from the establishment. The Cook County department of public health shall permit storage of the food
under conditions specified in the hold order, unless storage is not possible without risk to the public health, in
which case immediate destruction shall be ordered and accomplished. The hold order shall state that a request
for hearing may be filed within ten (10) days and that if no hearing is requested the food shall be destroyed. If a
request for hearing is received, the hearing shall be held within twenty (20) days after receipt of the request
following the same procedures as are set forth in section 3-4-8-8 of this chapter insofar as those procedures
are appropriate for such a hearing. On the basis of evidence produced at that hearing, the hold order may be
vacated, or the owner or person in charge of the food may be directed by written order to denature or destroy
such food or to bring it into compliance with the provisions of this chapter. (Ord. 04-45-0, 12-9-2004)
3-4-8-16: SUBMISSION OF PLANS:
Whenever a food establishment is to be constructed or extensively remodeled and whenever an existing
structure is to be converted to use as a food establishment, properly prepared plans and specifications for such
construction, remodeling, or conversion shall be submitted to the city building department and the Cook County
department of public health for review and approval before construction, remodeling, or conversion is begun.
The plans and specifications shall indicate the proposed layout, arrangement, mechanical plans, and
construction materials of work areas, and the type and model of proposed fixed equipment and facilities. The
city building department and the Cook County department of public health shall approve the plans and
specifications if they meet the requirements of this chapter and other applicable codes and ordinances. No food
establishment shall be constructed, extensively remodeled, or converted except in accordance with plans and
specifications approved by the city building department and the Cook County department of public health. (Ord.
04-45-0, 12-9-2004)
3-4-8-17: PREOPERATIONAL INSPECTION:
Whenever plans and specifications are required by section 3-4-8-16 of this chapter to be submitted to the city
and the Cook County department of public health, the city and the Cook County department of public health
shall inspect the food establishment prior to the start of operations, to determine compliance with the approved
plans and specifications and with the requirements of this chapter and other applicable codes and ordinances.
(Ord. 04-45-0, 12-9-2004)
3-4-8-18: PROCEDURE WHEN INFECTION OF FOOD HANDLERS IS SUSPECTED:
When the Cook County department of public health has reasonable cause to suspect possible disease
transmission by an employee of a food establishment, it may secure a morbidity history of the suspected
employee or make any other investigation as indicated and shall take appropriate action. The Cook County
department of public health may require any or all of the following measures:
A. The immediate exclusion of the employee from employment in food establishments;
B. The immediate closing of the food establishment concerned until, in the opinion of the Cook County
department of public health, no further danger of disease outbreak exists;
