C. Restriction of the employee's services to some area of the establishment where there would be no danger of
transmitting disease;
6/5/2019 Sterling Codifiers, Inc.
https://www.sterlingcodifiers.com/codebook/index.php?book_id=502 208/767
D. Adequate medical and laboratory examination of the employee and of other employees and of his and their
bodily discharges. (Ord. 04-45-0, 12-9-2004)
3-4-8-19: REINSPECTION COSTS:
In the event a reinspection is deemed necessary by the inspector, the cost of any and all subsequent
reinspections shall be borne by the holder of the license. (Ord. 04-45-0, 12-9-2004)
3-4-8-20: CONDITIONAL LICENSE:
When structural, plumbing, electrical, ventilation, or similar such defects exist in an established food facility that
may require significant expenditures to correct, but are not considered to be imminent health hazards, a
conditional license may be granted at the discretion of the city. Under no circumstances will a conditional
license be issued for more than two (2) consecutive twelve (12) month periods. The purpose of the conditional
license or permit is to allow a reasonable period of time for correction of existing defects. (Ord. 04-45-0, 12-9-
2004)
3-4-8-21: PENALTIES:
Any person violating the provisions of this section 3-4-8 shall be fined not more than seven hundred fifty dollars
($750.00) for each offense, and a separate offense shall be deemed committed on each day during or on which
a violation continues. (Ord. 04-45-0, 12-9-2004)
3-4-8-22: INJUNCTIONS:
The city shall have the right to enjoin any person or establishment in the event violations occur on a continuing
basis. (Ord. 04-45-0, 12-9-2004)
Chapter 5
LIQUOR CONTROL
3-5-1: DEFINITIONS:
A. Except the definition of "alcoholic liquor", all words and phrases defined in the "liquor control act of 1934"1
are hereby incorporated and made a part of this chapter.
B. "Alcoholic liquor" includes alcohol, spirits, wine and beer, and every liquid or solid, patented or not,
containing alcohol, spirits, wine or beer, and capable of being consumed as a beverage by a human being.
The provisions of this act shall not apply to alcohol used in the manufacture of denatured alcohol produced
in accordance with acts of congress and regulations promulgated thereunder, nor to any liquid or solid
containing one-half of one percent (0.5%), or less of alcohol by volume, except that it shall include cooking
wine and sherry and any other form of cooking aid containing more than one-half of one percent (0.5%) of
alcohol by volume and now exempted from definition of "alcoholic liquor" under federal and state laws. (Ord.
94-32-0, 12-14-1994)
3-5-2: LIQUOR LICENSES REQUIRED:
6/5/2019 Sterling Codifiers, Inc.
https://www.sterlingcodifiers.com/codebook/index.php?book_id=502 209/767
A. City License: It shall be unlawful for any entity to sell or offer for sale at retail or to keep with the intention of
selling at retail, alcoholic liquor within the city without first having secured a license therefor. It shall further
be unlawful for any entity to permit consumption of alcoholic liquors in or upon any premises (private
residences and offices excepted) which such entity owns, leases, operates or otherwise controls without first
having obtained a license therefor, notwithstanding that such liquors are given away or brought upon the
premises by persons for their own use.
Each license, except class C license, shall terminate on January 31 next following its issuance and the fee
therefor shall be due and payable in full on or before February 1 of each year.
B. State License: It shall be unlawful for any entity to sell or offer for sale at retail or to keep with the intention of
selling at retail, alcoholic liquor within the city without also possessing a valid, current state liquor license
issued by the Illinois liquor control commission specifically permitting licensee to engage in the activity for
which licensee is licensed by the city. (Ord. 00-26-0, 7-26-2000)
C. Background Check; Fingerprinting: It is required that any applicant for a new city liquor license or a current
liquor license holder as the liquor commissioner deems necessary, submit to a background check and to be
fingerprinted whether said applicant be an individual or a partnership. Should the applicant be a corporation,
the commissioner may, within his or her discretion, require the following to complete a background check
and be fingerprinted:
The officers, manager or director thereof, or any stockholder or stockholders owning in the aggregate of
more than five percent (5%) of the capital stock of said corporation.
All such fingerprinting shall be done by the city police department. Said fingerprints shall be submitted to the
appropriate state and/or federal agencies for processing as available. The cost of fingerprinting and
background check shall be recoverable from the applicant. (Ord. 05-06-0, 2-23-2005)
3-5-3: APPLICATION FOR LICENSE:
Application for such license shall be made to the local liquor commissioner in writing, under oath, signed by the
applicant, if an individual, or by a duly authorized agent thereof if a club or corporation, and shall contain the
following information and statements:
A. The name, age and address of the applicant in the case of an individual; in the case of a copartnership, the
persons entitled to share in the profits thereof; and in the case of a corporation for profit or a club, the date
of incorporation, the objects for which it was organized, the names and addresses of the officers and
directors, and if a majority in interest of the stock of such corporation is owned by one person or his
nominees, the name and address of such person.
B. The citizenship of the applicant, his place of birth, and if a naturalized citizen, the time and place of his
naturalization.
C. The character of business of the applicant; and in case of a corporation, the objects for which it was formed.
D. The length of time that said applicant has been in business of that character, or in the case of a corporation,
the date on which its charter was issued.
E. The amount of goods, wares and merchandise on hand at the time application is made.
6/5/2019 Sterling Codifiers, Inc.
https://www.sterlingcodifiers.com/codebook/index.php?book_id=502 210/767
F. The location and description of the premises or place of business which is to be operated under such license.
G. A statement whether the applicant has made similar application for a similar other license on-premises other
than described in this application.
H. A statement that the applicant has never been convicted of a felony and is not disqualified to receive a
license by reason of any matter or thing contained in this Chapter, the laws of this State, or the ordinances
of the City.
I. Whether a previous license by any state or subdivision thereof, or by the Federal Government has been
revoked, and the reasons therefor.
J. The date of incorporation if an Illinois corporation, or the date of becoming qualified under the Illinois
Business Corporation Act2 to transmit business in Illinois if a foreign corporation.
K. A statement that the applicant will not violate any of the laws of the State of Illinois or of the United States, or
any ordinance of the City in the conduct of his place of business. (1970 Code §8-1.04)
L. In addition to all other requirements, any applicant for a liquor license which will permit consumption of
alcoholic liquor on the premises where it is sold and/or served, shall obtain and submit proof of, not less
than one million dollars ($1,000,000.00) combined single limit dramshop insurance, before a liquor license
may be issued.
Said insurance shall be noncancelable without thirty (30) days' prior notice to the City Liquor Control
Commissioner.
Failure to have and maintain such insurance in effect shall be cause for immediate closing of the licensed
premises pursuant to subsection 3-5-6E of this Chapter. (Ord. 90-41-0, 10-10-1990)
M. In the case of any application for renewal, proof that the applicant holds a current, valid State liquor license
issued by the Illinois Liquor Control Commission specifically permitting applicant to engage in the type of
activity for which applicant seeks a license hereunder. Such proof may be the original of such license,
submitted in person with the application for photocopying by the City Clerk's office, or may be in the form of
a photocopy submitted with the application. In the event applicant fails to produce such proof, but meets all
other requirements for renewal, applicant's license will be renewed, but automatically suspended and held
by the Liquor Control Commissioner until such time as the required proof is presented. (Ord. 00-26-0, 7-26-
2000)
3-5-4: RESTRICTION ON LICENSES:
No such license shall be issued to: (1970 Code §8-1.04)
A. In the case of license renewal only, any entity that does not possess a current, valid State liquor license, as
required in subsection 3-5-2B of this Chapter. (Ord. 00-26-0, 7-26-2000)
B. A person who is not of good character and reputation in the City of Countryside in which he resides.
6/5/2019 Sterling Codifiers, Inc.
https://www.sterlingcodifiers.com/codebook/index.php?book_id=502 211/767
C. A person who is not a citizen of the United States.
D. A person who has been convicted of a felony under Federal or State law.
E. A person who has been convicted of being the keeper or is keeping a house of ill fame.
F. A person who has been convicted of pandering or other crime or misdemeanor opposed to decency and
morality.
G. A person whose license issued under this chapter or state act has been revoked for cause.
H. A person who, at the time of application for renewal of any license issued hereunder, would not be eligible
for such license upon a first application.
I. A copartnership, unless all of the members of such copartnership shall be qualified to obtain a license.
J. A corporation, if any officer, manager or director thereof, or any stockholder or stockholders owning in the
aggregate more than five percent (5%) of the stock of such corporation, would not be eligible to receive a
license hereunder for any reason other than citizenship and residency within the city.
K. A corporation unless it is incorporated in Illinois, or unless it is a foreign corporation which is qualified under
the Illinois business corporation act, to transact business in Illinois.
L. A person whose place of business is conducted by a manager or agent unless said manager or agent
possesses the same qualifications required of the licensee.
M. A person who has been convicted of a violation of any federal or state law concerning the manufacture,
possession or sale of alcoholic liquor, subsequent to the passage of this chapter, or shall have forfeited his
bond to appear in court to answer charges for any such violation.
N. A person who does not beneficially own the premises for which a license is sought or does not have a lease
thereon for the full period for which the license is to be issued.
O. Any law enforcing public official, any mayor, alderman, or member of the city council; and no such official
shall be interested in any way, either directly or indirectly, in the manufacture, sale or distribution of alcoholic
liquor.
P. A person who is not a beneficial owner of the business to be operated by the licensee.
Q. A person who has been convicted two (2) or more times of a gambling offense as proscribed by 720 Illinois
Compiled Statutes, 5/28-1(a)(3) through (a)(10); provided, that any person convicted of a first offense shall
not be issued such license for a period of one year from the conviction. (1970 Code §8-1.04)
R. A person fails to present proof of dramshop insurance as required by subsection 3-5-3L of this chapter. (Ord.
90-41-0, 10-10-1990)
6/5/2019 Sterling Codifiers, Inc.
https://www.sterlingcodifiers.com/codebook/index.php?book_id=502 212/767
3-5-5: ISSUANCE OF LICENSE:
All applications for licenses shall be kept on file in the office of the local liquor commissioner, and the fees for all
licenses shall be paid to the city collector who shall certify to the local liquor commissioner the names and
addresses of all licensees paying fees to him together with the class of license for which payment is made, and
thereupon the said local liquor commissioner shall issue the license provided for in this chapter to all licensees
who have complied with all the requirements of this chapter. (1970 Code §8-1.05)
3-5-6: LOCAL LIQUOR COMMISSIONER AND POWERS:
The mayor shall be the local liquor commissioner for the city. He shall have, as such commissioner, the
following powers, functions and duties with respect to licenses, other than licenses to manufacturers, importing
distributors, distributors, nonbeverage users, railroads, airplanes and boats:
A. Grant, Suspend, Revoke Local License: Grant any liquor license issued hereunder, and revoke or suspend
any such license for violations of any provisions of the state of Illinois liquor control act, this code, or any
other applicable statutes, codes or ordinances, in accordance with law. In addition to any such revocation or
suspension, he may levy a fine on any licensee hereunder for any such violation. The fine imposed shall not
exceed one thousand dollars ($1,000.00) for the first violation within a twelve (12) month period, one
thousand five hundred dollars ($1,500.00) for a second violation within a twelve (12) month period, and two
thousand five hundred dollars ($2,500.00) for a third or subsequent violation within a twelve (12) month
period. Each day a violation continues shall constitute a separate violation. Not more than fifteen thousand
dollars ($15,000.00) in fines under this section may be imposed against any licensee during the period of his
license. (Ord. 01-01-0, 1-10-2001)
B. Inspection: To enter or to authorize any law enforcing officer to enter at any time upon any premises licensed
hereunder to determine whether any of the provisions of the State Liquor Control Act3, or any rules or
regulations adopted by him or by the State Commission have been or are being violated, and at such time to
examine said premises or said licensee in connection therewith.
C. Citizen Complaints: To receive complaint from any citizen within the City that any of the provisions of the
aforesaid Act, or any rules or regulations adopted pursuant thereto, have been or are being violated and to
act upon such complaints in the manner hereinbefore provided. (1970 Code §8-1.06; amd. 1986 Code)
D. Revocation/Suspension Of Liquor License:
1. Except as provided in subsection F of this section, the procedures of revocation or suspension of liquor
licenses shall be as determined from time to time under the provisions of the Dramshop Act4. (Ord. 00-26-
0, 7-26-2000)
2. A record of all hearing proceedings held by the Liquor Control Commissioner to consider the suspension,
revocation or issuance of any liquor license shall be taken and prepared by a certified Court Reporter.
3. In the event an appeal is taken from an order or action of the Liquor Control Commissioner, a record of
the proceedings taken and prepared by the certified Court Reporter shall be filed by the Liquor Control
Commissioner within five (5) days after notice of filing such appeal. The appeal shall be limited to a review
of the official record of the proceedings of such Liquor Control Commissioner. (1986 Code)
E. Community Welfare: If the Liquor Control Commissioner has reason to believe that any continued operation
of a particular licensed premises will immediately threaten the welfare of the community he may, upon
issuance of a written order stating the reason for such conclusion, which may include failure to maintain
6/5/2019 Sterling Codifiers, Inc.
https://www.sterlingcodifiers.com/codebook/index.php?book_id=502 213/767
dramshop insurance as required by this chapter, and without notice or hearing, order the licensed premises
closed until such threat ceases to exist, giving the licensee an opportunity to be heard during the period of
closing, except that if such licensee shall also be engaged in the conduct of another business or businesses
on the licensed premises, such order shall not be applicable to such other business or businesses, but
solely to licensee's sale of alcoholic liquors, beers and/or wines. (Ord. 90-41-0, 10-10-1990)
F. Valid License: If the Liquor Control Commissioner is advised either directly or through an officer, employee or
agent of the City, that any City liquor licensee has no current, valid State liquor license, as required in
subsection 3-5-2B of this chapter, and upon inquiry by the Commissioner or his agent, such licensee fails to
produce such a State liquor license, the Commissioner shall forthwith suspend licensee's City license
without hearing as provided for in subsection D of this section, and licensee shall immediately surrender the
same to the Commissioner or his agent. Such suspension shall remain in force until the licensee presents
proof to the Commissioner that he again possesses a valid, current State liquor license, at which time the
Commissioner shall revoke the suspension, and such City license shall be returned to the licensee, provided
it shall not have expired or for any other reason been suspended or revoked. It shall be unlawful for licensee
to engage in the sale or storage of alcoholic beverages permitted by such license, so long as such
suspension remains in effect. (Ord. 00-26-0, 7-26-2000)
This section has been affected by a recently passed ordinance, 19-02 - CLASS HH LIQUOR LICENSE. Go to
new ordinance.
3-5-7: LICENSE CLASSIFICATION, FEE, HOURS AND NUMBER:
Liquor licenses are hereby divided into the following classes: (1970 Code §8-1.07)
CLASS A
1. Class A license shall authorize the retail sale on the specified premises of alcoholic liquors in the original
package, not for consumption on the premises where sold. (Ord. 95-24-0, 6-28-1995)
2. Annual fee, $1,200.00. (Ord. 08-24-0, 5-14-2008)
3. No alcoholic liquor shall be sold, given away or offered for sale in, upon or about the specified premises
so licensed between the hours of 2:00 A.M. and 7:00 A.M. on weekdays and 2:00 A.M. and 10:00 A.M. on
Sundays except where Sunday falls on December 24 then between 2:00 A.M. and 9:00 A.M. (Ord. 17-41-
0, 12-13-2017)
4. There shall be no more than 1 Class A license outstanding. (Ord. 17-34-0, 10-25-2017)
CLASS AA
1. Class AA license shall authorize the retail sale on the specified premises of alcoholic liquors for
consumption on said premises and the retail sale of alcoholic liquors in the original package, not for
consumption on the premises where sold. (1970 Code §8-1.07)
2. Annual fee, $1,600.00. (Ord. 08-24-0, 5-14-2008)
3. No alcoholic liquor shall be sold, given away or offered for sale in, upon or about the specified premises
so licensed between the hours of 2:00 A.M. and 7:00 A.M. on weekdays and 2:00 A.M. and 10:00 A.M. on
Sundays. (1970 Code §8-1.07; amd. Ord. 97-20-0, 8-13-1997)
4. There shall be no more than 7 Class AA licenses outstanding. (Ord. 17-34-0, 10-25-2017)
CLASS B
6/5/2019 Sterling Codifiers, Inc.
https://www.sterlingcodifiers.com/codebook/index.php?book_id=502 214/767
1. Class B license shall authorize the retail sale of all alcoholic liquor in its original package, not for
consumption on the premises where sold. (1970 Code §8-1.07)
2. Annual fee, $1,200.00. (Ord. 08-24-0, 5-14-2008)
3. No alcoholic liquor shall be sold, given away or offered for sale in, upon or about the specified premises
so licensed between the hours of 2:00 A.M. and 7:00 A.M. on any day. (Ord. 15-48-0, 11-11-2015)
4. There shall be no more than 4 Class B licenses outstanding. (Ord. 17-14-0, 4-26-2017)
CLASS C
1. Class C license shall authorize the sale or giving away of alcoholic liquor, for consumption on the
premises where sold or given away at any "special event" defined as follows: A gathering of persons
sponsored by an individual or individuals or an organization or organizations, or any combination thereof,
to be held for a limited period of time, with or without an admission charge, which is held on private
property but open to the general public. It shall not include a gathering taking place upon private property
and not open to the general public.
2. Fee, $40.00 per day.
3. No alcoholic liquor shall be sold, given away or offered for sale in, upon or about the specified premises
so licensed between the hours of 2:00 A.M. and 7:00 A.M. on weekdays and 2:00 A.M. and 10:00 A.M. on
Sundays.
4. All Class C licenses shall expire 3 days after the date of issue.
5. Applications for Class C licenses shall be made as in the case of any other class of license, and said
license shall be governed by all of the provisions of this chapter.
6. Further, no Class C liquor license shall be issued for any event or any gathering at which 100 or more
persons will be present, unless the licensee shall have first presented to the Liquor Control Commissioner
evidence that there will be on hand at such event or gathering not less than 1 security person for every
100 persons in attendance. Such security personnel shall be trained in crowd control and security and
acceptable to the Liquor Control Commissioner. Such evidence shall be in the form of a fully executed
agreement between the licensee, or his agent, and the agency or person who will provide such security
personnel.
If any licensee fails to have the required number of security personnel present at any gathering as
required hereby, his or her license shall be deemed forfeited, and such licensee shall be subject to
prosecution for serving alcoholic liquor without a license as required by this chapter. Upon the forfeiture of
any such license, the Liquor Control Commissioner, the Chief of Police, or any police officer acting under
the authority of either may take appropriate action, including, but not limited to, arrest, citation of the
licensee, ordering the cessation of any further serving of alcoholic liquor, and the arrest or citation of any
person violating such order.
CLASS CC
1. Special event retailer's license (not for profit) shall permit the licensee to purchase alcoholic liquors from
an Illinois licensed distributor (unless the licensee purchases less than $500.00 of alcoholic liquors for the
special event, in which case the licensee may purchase the alcoholic liquors from a licensed retailer), and
shall allow the licensee to sell and offer for sale, at retail, alcoholic liquors for use or consumption, but not
for resale in any form, and only at the location and on the specific date(s) designated for the special event
on the license. An "event" can be defined as a single theme. A special event retailer's license must be
obtained for each single theme per location with a maximum duration of 15 days.
a. Eligibility: The special event retailer's license (not for profit) is to be used only for events conducted by
an educational, fraternal, political, civic, religious or not for profit organization.
6/5/2019 Sterling Codifiers, Inc.
https://www.sterlingcodifiers.com/codebook/index.php?book_id=502 215/767
b. Security: Further, no class CC liquor license shall be issued for any event or any gathering at which 100
or more persons will be present, unless the licensee shall have first presented to the liquor control
commissioner evidence that there will be on hand at such event or gathering not less than 1 security
person for every 100 persons in attendance. Such security personnel shall be trained in crowd control
and security and acceptable to the liquor control commissioner. Such evidence shall be in the form of a
fully executed agreement between the licensee, or his agent, and the agency or person who will provide
such security personnel.
If any licensee fails to have the required number of security personnel present at any gathering as
required hereby, his or her license shall be deemed forfeited, and such licensee shall be subject to
prosecution for serving alcoholic liquor without a license as required by this chapter. Upon the forfeiture
of any such license, the liquor control commissioner, the chief of police, or any police officer acting
under the authority of either may take appropriate action, including, but not limited to, arrest, citation of
the licensee, ordering the cessation of any further serving of alcoholic liquor, and the arrest or citation of
any person violating such order.
c. Private Party: A special event retailer's license is not required for a private party. A "private party" is an
event where attendance is by invitation only, the host controls access to the premises, and alcoholic
beverages are provided to invited guests at no charge.
2. Special event retailer's license fee, $25.00. (Ord. 15-22-0, 4-22-2015)
CLASS D
1. Class D license shall authorize the storage, distribution and retail sale of alcoholic liquor commonly
known as beer and wine only, in their original packages not for consumption on the premises where sold,
but where the beer and wine only is intended for delivery to or to be taken away by the consumer. (1970
Code §8-1.07)
2. Annual fee, $800.00. (Ord. 08-24-0, 5-14-2008)
3. No alcoholic liquor shall be sold, given away or offered for sale in, upon or about the specified premises
so licensed between the hours of 2:00 A.M. and 8:00 A.M. on weekdays and 2:00 A.M. and 8:00 A.M. on
Sundays. (1970 Code §8-1.07)
4. There shall be no class D licenses issued. (Ord. 14-17-0, 4-23-2014)
CLASS E
1. Description: Class E license shall authorize the retail sale on the specified premises of alcoholic liquor for
consumption on said premises and the retail sale of alcoholic liquor in the original package not for
consumption on the premises where sold, and any person holding a class E license shall have the
privilege of providing, upon the licensed premises, an orchestra of not more than 3 pieces and permitting
dancing by patrons therein; provided, however, that no such dancing by patrons shall be permitted unless
there is provided in the licensed premises a compact, clear and open area containing not less than 400
square feet for such dancing; and provided further, that no entertainers other than members of the
orchestra shall be engaged or permitted to perform therein.
2. Annual Fee: On or before January 1 of each year, each licensee shall pay a renewal fee equal to
$1,900.00. (Ord. 12-21-0, 3-14-2012)
3. Closing Hours: No alcoholic liquor shall be sold, given away or offered for sale in, upon or about the
specified premises so licensed between the following hours:
a. 2:00 A.M. and 8:00 A.M. on weekdays, with the exception of subsection 3c of this class;
b. 2:00 A.M. and 10:00 A.M. on Saturday and Sunday with the exception of subsection 3c of this class;
6/5/2019 Sterling Codifiers, Inc.
https://www.sterlingcodifiers.com/codebook/index.php?book_id=502 216/767
c. 3:00 A.M. and 8:00 A.M. on the following days: March 18, Thanksgiving, and January 1. (Ord. 13-17-0,
4-10-2013)
4. Restricted Number Of Licenses: There shall be no more than 7 class E licenses issued. (Ord. 15-55-0,
12-9-2015)
CLASS F
1. Class F license shall authorize the storage, distribution and retail sale of alcoholic liquor commonly known
as beer and ale solely for consumption at tables on the premises where sold, and such sales shall be
made only incidental to the sale of food for consumption on the licensed premises. (1970 Code §8-1.07)
2. Annual fee, $1,000.00. (Ord. 08-24-0, 5-14-2008)
3. No beer or ale shall be sold, given away or offered for sale in, upon or about the specified premises so
licensed between the hours of 1:00 A.M. and 11:00 A.M. on weekdays and 1:00 A.M. and 11:00 A.M. on
Sundays.
4. There shall be no class F licenses issued.
CLASS G
1. Class G license shall authorize the storage, distribution and retail sale, on the premises of motels with
100 or more rooms, of alcoholic liquor for consumption on said premises. The retail sale of alcoholic liquor
in the original package to occupants of the motel only shall also be authorized. (1970 Code §8-1.07)
2. Annual fee, $2,000.00. (Ord. 08-24-0, 5-14-2008)
3. No alcoholic liquor shall be sold, given away or offered for sale in, upon or about the specified premises

Sundays.
4. There shall be no class G licenses issued.
5. The holder of a class G license shall have the privilege of providing live music upon the licensed
premises.
CLASS H
1. Class H license shall authorize the sale of beer and wine solely for consumption at tables on the premises
where sold, and such sales shall be made only incidental to the sale of food for consumption on the

2. Annual fee, $1,200.00. (Ord. 13-02-0, 1-23-2013)

on Sundays. (1970 Code §8-1.07)
4. There shall be no more than 5 class H licenses outstanding. (Ord. 17-14-0, 4-26-2017)
CLASS HH
1. Class HH licenses shall authorize the retail sale, on the specified premises, of beer and wine only for
consumption on said premises, and the retail sale of beer and wine in the original package, not for
consumption on the premises where sold. (Ord. 94-08-0, 3-23-1994)

CLASS I

2. Annual fee, $1,600.00. (Ord. 08-24-0, 5-14-2008)
3. No alcoholic liquor shall be sold, given away or offered for sale in, upon or about the specified premises

4. There shall be no more than 5 class I licenses outstanding. (Ord. 17-14-0, 4-26-2017)
CLASS J, J-1 AND J-2
1. Class J, J-1 and J-2 licenses shall authorize the sale of alcoholic liquor in conjunction with the sale of
food only. A bar shall be permitted, but service at the bar can only be provided for customers who have
been or will be served a meal on the premises. Alcoholic liquor may be sold on the premises only during
that period when customers are offered a complete meal. (Ord. 93-01-0, 1-13-1993)
2. Annual fee for each, $1,600.00. (Ord. 08-24-0, 5-14-2008)
3. No alcoholic liquor shall be sold, given away or offered for sale in, upon or about the specified premises
operating under a class J license between the hours of 2:00 A.M. and 7:00 A.M. on weekdays and 2:00
A.M. and 10:00 A.M. on Sundays; under a class J-1 license, between the hours of 12:00 midnight and
7:00 A.M. on weekdays and 12:00 midnight and 10:00 A.M. on Sundays; and under a class J-2 license,
between the hours of 2:00 A.M. and 7:00 A.M. on weekdays and 2:00 A.M. and 10:00 A.M. on Sundays.
(Ord. 93-01-0, 1-13-1993; amd. Ord. 97-20-0, 8-13-1997)
4. There shall be no more than 1 class J license; no class J-1 licenses; and 4 class J-2 licenses issued.
(Ord. 15-55-0, 12-9-2015)
CLASS K
1. Class K licenses will permit the sale or offering for sale, at retail, of alcoholic liquor on such premises. A
"private club" is defined as an establishment to which only members and guests of members
accompanied by a member are admitted and eligible to be sold alcoholic liquor. Memberships must be
issued for a period of not less than 3 months and the sale of memberships for a period of less than 3
months will terminate a private club's eligibility for a class K license.
2. All sales, offering for sale and consumption of alcoholic liquor will be confined to a designated service bar
area, which area shall be serviced by at least 1 competent full time bartender who will be present at all
times during which alcoholic liquor is sold, offered for sale or consumed therein. No person under the age
of 21 shall have access to said designated service bar area during the hours alcoholic liquor is sold,
offered for sale or consumed therein. (1970 Code §8-1.07, as amended)
3. Annual fee, $1,000.00. (Ord. 08-24-0, 5-14-2008)
4. Except as hereinafter provided, no alcoholic liquor shall be sold, given away or offered for sale in, upon or
about the specified premises so licensed between the hours of 12:00 midnight and 4:00 P.M. on
6/5/2019 Sterling Codifiers, Inc.
https://www.sterlingcodifiers.com/codebook/index.php?book_id=502 218/767
weekdays and 1:00 A.M. and 12:00 noon on Saturdays and Sundays. Except, beer and wine may be sold
between the hours of 11:00 A.M. and 12:00 midnight on weekdays. (Ord. 87-50-0, 9-29-1987)
5. There shall be no more than 1 class K license issued. (Ord. 07-03-0, 1-10-2007)
CLASS L
1. Class L licenses will permit the sale or offering for sale, at retail, of premixed cocktails and of wine in cans
or glass containers, each container not to exceed 1 pint by volume of beverage sold. Such sales must be
incident to variety or gift shop operations in a hotel or motel for convenience of guests. No beverage or
food shall be sold for consumption upon the licensed premises (within the confines of the variety or gift
shop). (1970 Code §8-1.07, as amended)
2. Annual fee, $400.00. (Ord. 08-24-0, 5-14-2008)
3. There shall be no class L licenses issued. (1970 Code §8-1.07, as amended)
CLASS M
1. Class M licenses shall authorize the giving away of sample portions of alcoholic liquor for promotional and
advertising purposes, for consumption on the premises where given away, upon premises for which there
is in effect an existing and valid class A, B or D license. (Ord. 98-12-0, 2-25-1998)
2. The giving away of sample portions of alcoholic liquor under the authority of a class M liquor license shall
be confined to the types of beverages permitted to be sold or given away under the licensee's class B or
class D license and shall be permitted only during the hours alcoholic liquor may be sold or given away
under the licensee's class B or class D license. (1970 Code §8-1.07, as amended)
3. Fee, $200.00. (Ord. 08-24-0, 5-14-2008)
4. There shall be no more than 5 class M licenses issued. (Ord. 15-55-0, 12-9-2015)
CLASS N
1. Class N licenses shall authorize the maintenance and operation of a service bar. A service bar shall be
any area at which alcoholic beverages and/or nonalcoholic beverages are poured and/or mixed for
consumption by customers at tables or other locations within or upon the premises within or upon which
such service bar is located.
2. A service bar shall be permitted only upon premises for which another class of liquor license has, or will
be, issued pursuant to the provisions of this section authorizing the dispensing of alcoholic beverages for
consumption by customers at tables or other locations within or upon the premises. (Ord. 85-6-0, 2-13-
1985)
3. Annual fee, $200.00. (Ord. 08-24-0, 5-14-2008)
4. There shall be no more than 3 class N liquor licenses issued. (Ord. 12-62-0, 10-10-2012)
CLASS O
1. A class O license shall authorize the retail sale and the transporting, delivering and furnishing of alcoholic
liquor in its original package from the licensed premises, pursuant to previous order. For the purposes
hereof, "previous order" means an order placed by the customer not less than 12 hours prior to delivery.
(Ord. 06-23-0, 6-14-2006)
2. Annual fee, $600.00. (Ord. 14-04-0, 1-22-2014)

CLASS P
1. A class P license shall authorize the storage of alcoholic liquors for ultimate use in the conducting of
demonstrations and offering of samples for tasting at special events or in private homes and offices, and
the making available of such alcoholic liquors at such demonstrations or for the offering of samples; it
shall further authorize the solicitation and acceptance of orders for such alcoholic liquors and the delivery
of the same from the place of storage to the purchaser off the storage premises. It shall not, however,
authorize the display or sale of any product, including alcoholic liquors, at retail or wholesale on the
premises at which said alcoholic liquors are to be stored. Further, the fact that the licensee is authorized
to provide alcoholic liquor for demonstrations or tasting purposes shall not relieve the owner or operator of
any place of business, open to the general public, at which such demonstrations or tasting shall be held,
from the responsibility of securing the appropriate license therefor. (Ord. 87-04-0, 2-11-1987)
2. Annual fee, $1,600.00. (Ord. 08-24-0, 5-14-2008)

CLASS Q
1. A class Q license shall authorize the sale and/or giving away of all types of alcoholic liquors from a
service bar or service bars, for consumption at tables or other locations within or upon the licensed
premises, and in conjunction with the operation of a catering or banquet facility upon the same premises.
The holder of a class Q license shall have the privilege of providing or permitting upon the licensed
premises musical entertainment in the form of recordings, a band or an orchestra, and he may permit
dancing by patrons therein; provided, however, that no such dancing by patrons shall be permitted unless
there is provided in the licensed premises a compact, clear and open area, containing not less than 400
square feet for such dancing; and, provided further, that no entertainers other than members of the band
or orchestra shall be engaged or permitted to perform therein. (Ord. 87-18-0, 4-8-1987)
2. The annual fee for a class Q license shall be $1,900.00 and $200.00 for each service bar in excess of 1.
(Ord. 08-24-0, 5-14-2008)
3. The holder of a class Q license shall not be required to also hold a class N license for the operation of a
service bar or service bars upon the licensed premises.
4. No alcoholic liquor shall be sold, offered for sale, or given away in, upon or about the licensed premises
between the hours of 2:00 A.M. and 11:00 A.M. on any day. (Ord. 87-18-0, 4-8-1987)
5. There shall be no more than 3 class Q licenses issued. (Ord. 15-55-0, 12-9-2015)

1. A class R license shall authorize the sale and/or giving away of all types of alcoholic liquors from a bar or
bars or a service bar or service bars, for consumption at tables or other locations within or upon the
licensed premises, and in conjunction with the operation of a publicly owned golf course upon the same
premises. The holder of a class R license shall have the privilege of providing or permitting upon the
licensed premises musical entertainment in the form of recordings, a band or an orchestra, and he may
permit dancing by patrons therein; provided, however, that no such dancing by patrons shall be permitted
unless there is provided in the licensed premises a compact, clear and open area, containing not less
than 400 square feet for such dancing; and provided further, that no entertainers other than members of
the band or orchestra shall be engaged or permitted to perform therein. (Ord. 93-16-0, 4-28-1993)
2. The annual fee for a class R license shall be $1,900.00 and $200.00 for each service bar in excess of 1.
(Ord. 08-24-0, 5-14-2008)

CLASS U (BYOB)
1. Class U (BYOB) licenses shall authorize the consumption of beer and wine which has been brought onto
the premises of a business operating as a public accommodation as defined in section 11-42-10.1 of the
Illinois municipal code by a patron or patrons for their personal consumption while being served a meal in
said establishment;
2. The application fee for class U (BYOB) shall be $500.00. The annual license fee for a class U (BYOB)
license shall be $200.00;
3. Only beer and wine are allowed to be consumed on the premises of the holder of a class U (BYOB)
license;
4. The license holder is only allowed to provide glasses, ice and an ice holder for the patrons;
5. The license holder, its agents, and/or its employees may open, but shall be prohibited from serving,
pouring, and/or storing any wine or beer for its patrons;
6. It shall be unlawful for the license holder, its agents and/or its employees to permit any patron to leave the
licensed premises with open wine or beer, and the license holder shall require that patrons who leave with
such of their own beer and wine that has not been consumed to do so only in sealed or unopened
containers in compliance with Illinois law;
7. No consumption of wine or beer shall be permitted on the premises unless it is served as a complement
to the sale of food;
6/5/2019 Sterling Codifiers, Inc.
https://www.sterlingcodifiers.com/codebook/index.php?book_id=502 221/767
8. A certificate of insurance, reflecting coverage for general liability purposes in such minimum amounts as
the liquor commissioner may deem necessary from time to time, shall be presented to the city by the
applicant for a class U (BYOB) establishment and the city shall be named as an additional insured on the
license holder's insurance. The provisions of subsection 3-5-3L of this chapter shall be deemed satisfied
by this requirement. Further, the license holder shall agree in writing to save and hold harmless the city's
agents, employees, elected and appointed officials from any and all claims or causes of actions arising
out of the consumption of alcoholic liquor on the premises as a condition of the license;
9. The hours during which a class U (BYOB) license holder may permit consumption of beer and wine on its
premises shall conform identically to the hours of operation of the licensed business for which the BYOB
liquor license has been issued; (Ord. 09-35-0, 8-26-2009)
10. There shall be no more than 1 class U (BYOB) liquor license issued. (Ord. 12-62-0, 10-10-2012)
CLASS UU (BYOB)
1. Class UU (BYOB) licenses shall authorize the consumption of beer, wine and liquor which has been
brought onto the premises of a business operating as a public accommodation as defined in section 11-
42-10.1 of the Illinois municipal code by a patron or patrons as a complement to the purchase/sale and
consumption of tobacco products in said establishment.
2. The application fee for class UU (BYOB) shall be $500.00. The annual license fee for a class UU (BYOB)
license shall be $1,500.00.
3. The license holder is only allowed to provide glasses, ice and an ice holder for the patrons.
4. The license holder, its agents, and/or its employees may store wine, beer or liquor for its patrons.
5. It shall be unlawful for the license holder, its agents and/or its employees to permit any patron to leave the
licensed premises with open wine, beer or liquor, and the license holder shall require that patrons who
leave with such of their own beer and wine that has not been consumed to do so only in sealed or
unopened containers in compliance with Illinois law.
6. No consumption of wine, beer or liquor shall be permitted on the premises unless it is consumed as a
complement to the sale and consumption of tobacco products. Furthermore, no persons under the age of
21 shall be permitted in any areas designated a private or club VIP area.
7. A certificate of insurance, reflecting coverage for general liability purposes in such minimum amounts as
the liquor commissioner may deem necessary from time to time, shall be presented to the city by the
applicant for a class UU (BYOB) establishment and the city shall be named as an additional insured on
the license holder's insurance. The provisions of subsection 3-5-3L of this chapter shall be deemed
satisfied by this requirement. Further, the license holder shall agree in writing to save and hold harmless
the city's agents, employees elected and appointed officials from any and all claims or causes of actions
arising out of the consumption of alcoholic liquor on the premises as a condition of the license.
8. The hours during which a class UU (BYOB) license holder may permit consumption of beer, wine and
liquor on its premises shall conform identically to the hours of operation of the licensed business for which
the BYOB liquor license has been issued. (Ord. 10-05-0, 2-24-2010)
9. There shall be no more than 1 class UU (BYOB) license issued. (Ord. 10-11-0, 4-14-2010)
CLASS V
1. A class V license shall authorize licensee, who must also hold a first or second class winemaker's license
issued by the state of Illinois, to manufacture, sell and offer for sale at retail or consume in or on the
premises specified, the winemaker's wine.
2. Annual fee, $2,500.00. (Ord. 10-10-0, 3-24-2010)
6/5/2019 Sterling Codifiers, Inc.
https://www.sterlingcodifiers.com/codebook/index.php?book_id=502 222/767
3. There shall be 1 class V license issued. (Ord. 10-13-0, 4-14-2010)
CLASS W
1. Class W licenses will permit the giving away of alcoholic liquor as complimentary to a patron's purchase
of other goods and services.
2. Annual liquor license fee, $1,500.00.
3. There shall be no more than 1 Class W license issued.
4. A Class W license shall be subject to the following conditions and limitations:
a. Limited Individual Servings: The serving of wine or sparkling wine intended for consumption on the
licensed premises shall be limited to the consumption of individual servings of wine or sparkling wine as
part of a package of personal care services. No more than 2 servings of wine or sparkling wine (each
not to exceed 4 ounces) per customer shall be permitted on the licensed premises per calendar day.
b. Incidental To Business Operation: The serving of wine or sparkling wine for consumption on the
licensed premises shall be merely incidental to the primary business operation of the licensed premises
of a full service personal care services establishment, and the licensed premises shall not be advertised
or otherwise held out to be a drinking establishment. No beverage or food shall be sold for consumption
on the licensed premises (the confines of the salon).
c. Permitted Hours For Serving And/Or Consumption Of Wine And/Or Sparkling Wine: In no case shall the
serving, and/or consumption on the licensed premises of wine or sparkling wine take place outside of
the normal business hours of the licensed premises and, in any event, not outside of the hours for liquor
service as otherwise permitted by this chapter.
d. Leaving The Premises With An Open Container Prohibited: It shall be unlawful for the license holder, its
agents, and/or its employees to permit any patron to leave the licensed premises with open wine or
sparkling wine.
e. Live Entertainment Prohibited: No live entertainment of any nature shall be permitted on the licensed
premises.
f. No Signs: No sign or any other external indicia shall be permitted on the licensed premises or
surrounding property that indicates that alcoholic liquor is available for serving at the licensed premises.
g. Giving Away Wine And/Or Sparkling Wine: The giving away of wine or sparkling wine under the
authority of a Class W liquor license shall be subject to the requirements of this chapter and all other
liquor serving laws, including but not limited to BASSET training and maintaining dramshop insurance.
h. Certificate Of Insurance: A certificate of insurance, reflecting coverage for general liability purposes in
such minimum amounts as the Liquor Commissioner may deem necessary from time to time, shall be
presented to the City by the applicant for a Class W establishment and the City shall be named as an
additional insured on the license holder's insurance. The provisions of subsection 3-5-3L of this chapter
shall be deemed satisfied by this requirement. Further, the license holder shall agree in writing to save
and hold harmless the City's agents, employees elected and appointed officials from any and all claims
or causes of actions arising out of the consumption of alcoholic liquor on the premises as a condition of
the license. (Ord. 2018-13-0, 4-25-2018)
3-5-8: DISPLAY OF LICENSE:
Every licensee shall cause his license to be framed and hung in plain view in a conspicuous place on the
licensed premises. (1970 Code §8-1.15)
6/5/2019 Sterling Codifiers, Inc.
https://www.sterlingcodifiers.com/codebook/index.php?book_id=502 223/767
3-5-9: TRANSFER OF LICENSE:
A license shall be purely a personal privilege, good for not to exceed the period for which same is issued,
unless sooner revoked as in this chapter provided, and shall not constitute property, nor shall it be subject to
attachment, garnishment or execution, nor shall it be alienable or transferable, voluntarily or involuntarily, or
subject to being encumbered or hypothecated. Such license shall cease upon the death of the licensee and
shall not descend by the laws of testate or intestate devolution, provided that executors or administrators of the
estate of any deceased licensee, and the trustee of any insolvent or bankrupt licensee, when such estate
consists in part of alcoholic liquor, may continue the business of the sale or manufacture of alcoholic liquor
under the order of the appropriate court, and may exercise the privilege of the deceased, insolvent or bankrupt
licensee after the death of such decedent, or such insolvency or bankruptcy until the expiration of such license
but not longer than six (6) months after the death, bankruptcy or insolvency of such licensee.
Any licensee may renew his license at the expiration thereof, provided he is then qualified to receive a license
and the premises for which such renewal license is sought are suitable for such purpose; and, provided, further,
that the renewal privilege herein provided for shall not be construed as a vested right which shall in any case
prevent the city council from decreasing the number of licenses to be issued within its jurisdiction. (1970 Code
§8-1.08)
3-5-10: LICENSING OF PREMISES FOR WHICH LICENSE IS REVOKED:
When any license hereunder shall have been revoked for any cause, at the discretion of the local liquor control
commissioner, no license shall be granted to any person for the period of one year thereafter for the conduct of
the sale of alcoholic liquor in the premises described in such revoked license. (1970 Code §8-1.17)
3-5-11: CESSATION OF BUSINESS:
Any licensee who ceases to do business or closes his place of business for a period of more than thirty (30)
successive days shall be subject to having his license declared forfeited and lapsed by order of the local liquor
commissioner. (1970 Code §8-1.18)
3-5-12: CHANGE OF LOCATION:
Licenses issued hereunder apply only to the premises described in the application and in the license issued
thereon, and only one location shall be so described in each license. After a license has been granted for a
particular premises, the local liquor commissioner, upon proper showing, may endorse upon said license,
permission to abandon the premises therein described and remove therefrom to the premises approved by him
but in order to obtain such approval, the licensee shall file with the local liquor commissioner a request in writing
and a statement under oath which shall show that the premises to which removal is to be made comply in all
respects with the requirements of this chapter. The fee for such transfer shall be one hundred dollars ($100.00),
payable to the city collector upon application for change of location. (1970 Code §8-1.09)
3-5-13: LOCATION RESTRICTIONS:
No license shall be issued for the sale of any alcoholic liquors on any premises within one hundred feet (100')
of any church, school, hospital, home for aged or indigent persons, or for veterans, their wives or children or a
military or naval station. In determining the distance provided for in this section, the boundaries of the lot or
parcel of land upon which a church, school, hospital or home as herein defined, shall be construed as being the
point from which measurement shall be taken. (1970 Code §8-1.12)
6/5/2019 Sterling Codifiers, Inc.
https://www.sterlingcodifiers.com/codebook/index.php?book_id=502 224/767
3-5-14: PREMISES REQUIREMENTS:
A. Obstruction Of Interior: In premises upon which the sale of alcoholic liquor for consumption upon the
premises is licensed (other than as a restaurant, hotel or club), no screen, blind, curtain, partition, article or
thing shall be permitted in the windows or upon the doors of such licensed premises nor inside such
premises, which shall prevent a clear view into the interior of such licensed premises from the street, road or
sidewalk at all times, and no booth, screen, partition or other obstruction nor any arrangements of lights or
lighting shall be permitted in or about the interior of such licensed premises which shall prevent a full view of
the entire interior of such premises from the street, road or sidewalk; and said premises must be so located
that there shall be a full view of the entire interior of such premises from the street, road or sidewalk. All
rooms where liquor is sold for consumption upon the premises shall be continuously lighted during business
hours by natural light or artificial white light so that all parts of the interior of the premises shall be clearly
visible. In case the view into any such licensed premises required by the foregoing provision shall be wilfully
obscured by the licensee or by him wilfully suffered to be obscured or in any manner obstructed, then such
license shall be subject to revocation in the manner herein provided. In order to enforce the provisions of
this subsection, the local liquor commissioner shall have the right to require the filing with him of plans,
drawings and photographs showing the clearance of the view as above required. (1970 Code §8-1.13)
B. Health And Sanitation Requirements: It shall be the duty of every person licensed to carry on a business
under the provisions of this chapter to at all times keep the premises where such business is carried on
clean and in proper sanitary condition. All persons employed or working in any such premises shall be kept
clean and cleanly clothed. All utensils, appliances, vessels, receptacles, refrigerators, closets, rooms or
other places or things whatsoever which are used for the purpose of selling or offering for sale, such liquors
or of the storing or dispensing of the same, must at all times be kept in a clean, wholesome and sanitary
condition. (1970 Code §8-1.19)
C. Inspection: It shall be the duty of the health officer, and he is hereby authorized and empowered from time to
time, to inspect and examine the premises wherein any retail liquor business is carried on, for the purpose
of ascertaining whether or not all health ordinances of the city relative to the carrying on of such business
are being complied with at such premises. Such inspection shall be made at least once each and every
month during the time said licensee is engaged in such business. It shall be the duty of every person
licensed under the provisions of this chapter to permit such inspection to be made and to exhibit the
premises to such persons making such inspection. A record of such inspection shall be kept on file in the
office of the health officer, and in the office of the liquor commissioner.
The health officer shall report to the liquor control commissioner the name of a licensee who has violated
the provisions of any health ordinance of the city relating to the carrying on of the business named in the
license. (1970 Code §8-1.21; amd. 1986 Code)
3-5-15: EMPLOYMENT RESTRICTIONS:
A. Employment Of Persons Under Age: It shall be unlawful for any licensee or any officer, associate member,
representative, agent or employee of such licensee to engage or employ or permit any person under the
age of twenty one (21) years to tend the bar and to draw, pour, mix or sell any alcoholic liquor in any
licensed retail premises, except as provided in subsection 3-5-18E of this chapter.
All alcohol servers and "bouncers" (i.e., employees responsible for checking patrons' identification for entry
into a liquor licensed premises) in city of Countryside bars, restaurants, and banquet facilities shall complete
a four (4) hour beverage alcohol sellers/servers education and training (BASSET) prior to employment or
within one hundred twenty (120) days after being hired. Any person trained does not need to be retrained
until three (3) years after their previous certification date.
A BASSET certificate of completion belongs to the server or bouncer, and such may transfer to a different
employer, but shall not transfer to another server or bouncer. A copy of the certificate that a server or
6/5/2019 Sterling Codifiers, Inc.
https://www.sterlingcodifiers.com/codebook/index.php?book_id=502 225/767
bouncer has been trained must be available upon request by city, county or state law enforcement officials.
(Ord. 15-53-0, 12-9-2015)
B. Health Of Employees, Certificates: Every person in charge of such premises shall keep himself and his
employees in a clean condition and cleanly clothed, and no person who has tuberculosis, any venereal or
communicable skin disease, or who has any infectious or contagious disease shall engage in or be
employed in and about such business or such premises.
Every person employed in and about any premises licensed hereunder shall, as a condition to the issuance
of a license under this chapter, submit to the city health department, a certificate from a licensed physician
certifying that said person has no infectious, communicable or contagious disease of any kind whatsoever.
(1970 Code §8-1.21)
3-5-16: LICENSEE RESTRICTIONS:
A. Advertising: No person licensed to sell alcoholic liquors shall use the word "saloon" or "bar" in any sign or
advertisement. (1970 Code §8-1.14)
B. Sales To Certain Persons Prohibited: No licensee shall sell, give or deliver alcoholic liquor to any person
under the age of twenty one (21) years, or to any intoxicated person or any person known by him to be a
habitual drunkard, spendthrift or insane, feebleminded or distracted person. (1970 Code §§8-1.22, 8-1.26,
as amended)
C. Acts Of Agent Or Employee: Every act or omission of whatsoever nature constituting a violation of any of the
provisions of this chapter by any officer, director, manager or other agent or employee of any licensee, if
said act is committed or omission is made with the authorization, knowledge or approval of the licensee,
shall be deemed and held to be the act of such employer or licensee and said employer or licensee shall be
punishable in the same manner as if said act or omission had been done or omitted by him personally.
(1970 Code §8-1.23)
D. Soliciting Of Drinks: It shall be unlawful for any licensee, his manager, or other person in charge of any
licensed premises where alcoholic liquor is sold or offered for sale for consumption thereon to engage,
employ or permit any other patron or customer thereof to purchase alcoholic or nonalcoholic liquor for
herself, himself or any other person therein; provided, however, that nothing herein contained shall prohibit
any adult manageress or waitress who shall be regularly employed therein from accepting and serving the
order of a patron or customer in the regular course of her employment as such manageress or waitress.
(1970 Code §8-1.27)
E. Conduct Of Licensee:
1. Every licensee hereunder engaged in the sale of alcoholic beverages shall conduct his or her place of
business in a quiet, decent and respectable manner and shall eject therefrom or refuse to admit thereto all
persons rendering themselves objectionable or undesirable by reason of undue noise or other acts
disturbing the peace.
2. No licensee shall permit his patrons to perform any lewd, lascivious acts, or an act of obscenity.
3. Every licensee shall immediately report to the police any act by any person or patron causing undue
noise or disturbance, breach of peace, fighting, unusual conduct, or a person with an illegal firearm, knife,
bludgeon or deadly instrument.
4. Every licensee shall immediately report to the police a violation of any city ordinance, Illinois statute or
federal law occurring in the licensed premises, or outside the licensed premises, but adjacent thereto,
6/5/2019 Sterling Codifiers, Inc.
https://www.sterlingcodifiers.com/codebook/index.php?book_id=502 226/767
involving the conduct of his business or patrons. (Ord. 14-07-0, 2-12-2014)
This section has been affected by a recently passed ordinance, 19-02 - CLASS HH LIQUOR LICENSE. Go to
new ordinance.
3-5-17: ENTERTAINMENT PROHIBITED:
No live entertainment other than a pianist shall be permitted in any licensed premises and no dancing by
patrons shall be permitted in any licensed premises except as otherwise provided in this chapter. (1970 Code
§8-1.28)
3-5-18: MINORS:
A. Sale To Or Purchase By Prohibited:
1. It shall be unlawful for any person under the age of twenty one (21) years:
a. To purchase or obtain any alcoholic liquor in any tavern or other place in the city where alcoholic liquor
is sold.
b. To misrepresent his age for the purpose of purchasing or obtaining alcoholic liquor in any tavern or
other place in the city where alcoholic liquor is sold.
2. It shall be unlawful to sell, give or deliver alcoholic liquor to any person under the age of twenty one (21)
years, except in the performance of a religious ceremony or service.
3. For the purpose of this section, "sale" means any transfer, exchange or barter in any manner, or by any
means whatsoever, and includes all sales made by any person, whether principal, proprietor, agent,
servant or employee.
B. Warning Sign Required: In every tavern or other place in the city where alcoholic liquor is sold, there shall be
displayed at all times in a prominent place, a printed card which shall be supplied by the clerk and which
shall read substantially as follows:
WARNING TO PERSONS UNDER 21
You are subject to a fine up to $500.00 under the ordinances of the City of Countryside if you purchase
alcoholic liquor, or misrepresent your age for the purpose of purchasing or obtaining alcoholic liquor.
(1970 Code §8-1.24, as amended)
C. Minors On Premises: Except as hereinafter provided, it shall be unlawful for any holder of a retail liquor
dealer's license, or his agent or employee, to suffer or permit any person under the age of twenty one (21)
years to be or remain in any room or compartment adjoining, adjacent to or situated in the room or place
where such licensed premises is located. In addition to all other fines and penalties, the mayor may suspend
or revoke the retail liquor dealer's license for any violation of this subsection.
1. Provided, that this subsection shall not apply to any person under the age of twenty one (21) years who is
accompanied by his parent or guardian or to any licensed premises which derives its principal business
from the sale or service of other commodities than alcoholic liquor, provided persons under the age of
twenty one (21) years may be permitted on premises holding a class F license, but they shall not be
permitted in the room where beer or ale is sold unless accompanied by a parent or guardian.
6/5/2019 Sterling Codifiers, Inc.
https://www.sterlingcodifiers.com/codebook/index.php?book_id=502 227/767
2. Provided further, that this subsection shall not apply to any premises which is also licensed to operate as
a teen bar under section 3-3-8 of this title at such times as such licensed teen bar is in operation. (Ord.
88-23-0, 6-8-1988)
D. Parental Responsibility: It shall be unlawful for any parent or guardian to permit any person under the age of
twenty one (21) years of whom he may be the parent or guardian to violate any provisions of this section.
(1970 Code §8-1.24, as amended)
E. Employment: It shall be unlawful for any person under the age of twenty one (21) years to tend any bar, to
draw, pour or mix any alcoholic liquor in any licensed premises, or to sell any alcoholic liquor in any licensed
retail premises. However, it shall be lawful for an employee under twenty one (21) years of age to participate
in such a sale by serving such to patrons or customers, accepting money therefor or placing the item or
items sold in a box or bag for the customer; provided, however, that before payment for such merchandise is
received, the sale is first entered upon the cash register, or such other mechanical device used to record
sales, by an employee who is twenty one (21) years of age or older. (Ord. 13-46-0, 10-23-2013)
F. Purchases Or Acceptances Of Gift Of Liquor By Minor; Identification Card:
1. It shall be unlawful for any person to whom the sale, gift or delivery of alcoholic liquor is prohibited
because of age, to purchase or accept a gift of alcoholic liquor or to have alcoholic liquor in his
possession.
2. If a licensee or his agents or employees believes he has reason to believe that a sale or delivery of
alcoholic liquor is prohibited because of the nonage of the prospective recipient, he shall, before making
such sale or delivery, demand presentation of some form of positive identification containing proof of age,
issued by a public officer in the performance of his official duties.
3. No person shall transfer, alter or deface such an identification card; use the identification card of another;
carry or use a false or forged identification card; or obtain an identification card by means of false
information. No person shall purchase, accept delivery or have possession of alcoholic liquor in violation
of this subsection. (1970 Code §8-1.25)
3-5-19: EXTENDED HOURS FOR SALE WHEN CHRISTMAS EVE AND NEW YEAR'S EVE
FALL ON A SUNDAY:
When Christmas Eve and New Year's Eve fall on a Sunday, and it appears to the mayor and city council that it
would serve the public convenience to permit the retail sale of packaged goods alcoholic liquors, for off
premises consumption, to begin on either or both of such Sundays at an hour earlier than otherwise permitted,
they may do so as provided herein. Permits allowing earlier sales hours shall be subject to such reasonable
conditions and charges as the mayor and council may, from time to time, determine. The mayor and council
may, in their discretion, by motion grant such permits to all holders of licenses permitting the retail sale of
packaged goods liquors, or they may grant such permits on a case by case basis, giving consideration to the
need for such in any particular instance. (Ord. 89-41-0, 10-25-1989)
3-5-20: ABOLISHMENT OF THE FOUR O'CLOCK A.M. LIQUOR LICENSE:
There shall be no further creation or issuance of licenses permitting the sale or giving away of alcoholic
beverages within the city later than the hour of two o'clock (2:00) A.M. Further, all issued and currently
outstanding liquor licenses permitting the sale or giving away of alcoholic beverages after the hour of two
o'clock (2:00) A.M. will, as of February 1, 1998, become "2 A.M." licenses, permitting the sale or giving away of
alcoholic beverages no later than two o'clock (2:00) A.M. (Ord. 98-04-0, 1-14-1998)
6/5/2019 Sterling Codifiers, Inc.
https://www.sterlingcodifiers.com/codebook/index.php?book_id=502 228/767
3-5-21: PROHIBITED ACTS:
The following kinds of conduct on premises within the city of Countryside licensed to sell alcoholic liquor are
prohibited: any act or series of acts upon a human being, whether self-inflicted or inflicted by another, and
notwithstanding the consent of the person upon whom such act is inflicted, that is intended to cause a breaking
or puncturing of the skin and/or the drawing of blood and/or the fracturing and/or tearing of any part of that
person's anatomy, and whether or not inflicted directly by human hands or by means of another agency, either
living or mechanical for entertainment purposes as part of or in conjunction with any show, performance, or
exhibition. The utilization of any previously made punctures, holes, or devices imbedded within a human being's
anatomy for the purpose of hoisting, lifting, or suspending such a person for entertainment purposes as part of
or in conjunction with any show, performance, or exhibition. (Ord. 02-11-0, 3-28-2002)
3-5-22: VIDEO GAMING:
Premises licensed under this chapter that have been licensed as licensed video gaming locations by the Illinois
gaming board which were found to be in violation of the video gaming act5 shall also be subject to the penalties
provided for in this chapter and the Illinois liquor control act6. (Ord. 12-44-0, 8-22-2012)
Chapter 6
CHARITABLE GAMES
3-6-1: DEFINITIONS:
CHARITABLE GAME: Any game of bingo, any lottery or raffle, any pull-tab or jar game, or any other charitable
game to be conducted and operated under authority of a license issued by the Illinois Department of Revenue
pursuant to any of the Acts defined in this Section.
ILLINOIS BINGO LICENSING ACT: 230 ILCS 25/1 et seq.
ILLINOIS CHARITABLE GAMES ACT: 230 ILCS 30/1 et seq.
ILLINOIS PULL-TAB AND JAR GAME ACT: 230 ILCS 20/1.1 et seq.
RAFFLES ACT OF ILLINOIS: 230 ILCS 15/0.01 et seq. (Ord. 93-08-0, 1-27-1993)
3-6-2: LICENSE REQUIRED:
It shall be unlawful for any person to conduct, operate or take part in any charitable game within the City unless
such charitable game is conducted and operated pursuant to authority granted by a license issued hereunder.
Such a license shall authorize the licensee to conduct a charitable game, and is valid for only one such game.
(Ord. 93-08-0, 1-27-1993)
3-6-3: LICENSE FEE, WAIVER:
The fee for any license issued under this Chapter shall be fifty dollars ($50.00). However, any such fee may be
waived by the City Council. The City shall not be required to obtain any license or permit hereunder to conduct
a charitable game. However, any such charitable game shall be conducted in accordance with the purposes
and guidelines set forth herein. (Ord. 96-24-0, 5-22-1996)
6/5/2019 Sterling Codifiers, Inc.
https://www.sterlingcodifiers.com/codebook/index.php?book_id=502 229/767
3-6-4: APPLICATION FOR LICENSE:
Application for a license hereunder shall be upon a form which has been specifically approved by the City
Council. Such form shall be obtained from the office of the City Clerk, shall be filed with said office, and shall
include, among other things, the following:
A. The area within the City, the time period during which charitable game chances will be sold or issued, the
time of determination of the winning chances and the location at which winning chances will be determined.
B. A sworn statement attesting to the not-for-profit character of the prospective licensee organization, signed by
the presiding officer and the secretary of that organization. (Ord. 93-08-0, 1-27-1993)
C. Except for applications to conduct a raffle, a license issued for such charitable game by the Illinois
Department of Revenue pursuant to any of those Acts defined in Section 3-6-1 of this Chapter. (Ord. 97-26-
0, 10-22-1997)
D. All other information required on said form of application. (Ord. 93-08-0, 1-27-1993)
3-6-5: LIMITATIONS:
A. Prizes And Chances: Any charitable game conducted hereunder shall be subject to the limitations, from time
to time, imposed pursuant to any of the Acts defined in Section 3-6-1 of this Chapter.
B. Activities Restricted: Nothing in this Chapter shall be construed to authorize the conducting or operating of
any gambling scheme, enterprise, activity or device other than charitable games as provided for herein.
(Ord. 93-08-0, 1-27-1993)
3-6-6: CONDUCT OF CHARITABLE GAMES:
The conducting of charitable games shall be in accordance with any applicable provisions contained in those
Acts defined in Section 3-6-1 of this Chapter. (Ord. 93-08-0, 1-27-1993)
3-6-7: VIOLATION, PENALTY:
Violation of any provision of this Chapter is a Class C misdemeanor. (Ord. 93-08-0, 1-27-1993)
Chapter 7
PUBLIC TRANSPORTATION
ARTICLE A. TAXICABS
3-7A-1: DEFINITIONS:
6/5/2019 Sterling Codifiers, Inc.
https://www.sterlingcodifiers.com/codebook/index.php?book_id=502 230/767
Unless otherwise expressly stated or the context clearly indicates a different intention, the following terms shall,
for the purpose of this article, have the meanings indicated below:
RATE CARD: A card for display in each taxicab which contains the rates of fare then in effect.
TAXICAB: Any vehicle used for the carriage of persons for hire, except those vehicles commonly known as
buses, and those vehicles defined in this code as limousines.
TAXICAB OPERATOR: Any person, firm or corporation that operates one or more taxicabs upon the streets of
the city.
TAXIMETER: A mechanical instrument or device to which the charge for hire of a taxicab is mechanically
calculated for distance traveled and for waiting time and upon which such charge shall be indicated. (Ord. 06-
18-0, 5-24-2006)
3-7A-2: OPERATOR LICENSING REQUIREMENTS:
A. License Required, Fee:
1. Required: It shall be unlawful to operate or permit a taxicab to be operated as a vehicle for hire upon the
streets of the city without having first obtained a taxicab operator's license hereunder.
2. Fee: See section 3-1-13 of this title.
B. Application For License:
1. Upon the filing of an application with the office of the city clerk, the clerk shall submit the application to the
city council for council review and/or investigation.
2. If the city council finds from its review and/or investigation that further taxicab service is required in the
city by the public convenience and necessity and that the applicant is fit, willing and able to perform such
public transportation and to conform to the provisions of this article, then the city council shall direct the
clerk, upon compliance by the applicant with all provisions of this article, to issue a license to the
applicant. Otherwise the application shall be denied.
3. Upon approval of the application by the city council, direction of the city council, and the licensee's
compliance with all of the provisions of this article, the clerk shall issue a license stating the name and
address of the licensee, the number of vehicles authorized under said license and the date of issuance;
the clerk shall also provide the licensee with an appropriate copy of such license, or a decal evidencing
issuance of such license, for display upon or within each of the vehicles to be operated under the license.
C. Indemnity Bond Or Liability Insurance Required: No license shall be issued or continued in operation unless
the applicant has complied with all the provisions of this article and with all the provisions of the state law
requiring proof of financial responsibility of licensee's motor vehicles used for the transportation of
passengers for hire1. Before a license is issued, the applicant shall submit a certificate to the clerk from the
secretary of state of the state of Illinois for each motor vehicle to be operated or controlled by the applicant
evidencing proof of financial responsibility for each of said motor vehicles has been submitted to the
secretary of state.
D. Issuance And Duration Of License: Such license shall be in effect for the remainder of the calendar year. A
license for every calendar year thereafter shall be issued upon the payment of the fee as specified in section
3-1-13 of this title unless the license for the preceding year has been revoked or is currently under
suspension.
6/5/2019 Sterling Codifiers, Inc.
https://www.sterlingcodifiers.com/codebook/index.php?book_id=502 231/767
E. Display Of Driver's License: Every driver licensed under this article shall also post his or her driver's license
in such a place as to be in full view of all passengers while such driver is operating a taxicab.
F. Transfer Of License: No taxicab operator's license issued under this article may be sold, assigned,
mortgaged or otherwise transferred without the consent of the city council. (Ord. 06-18-0, 5-24-2006)
3-7A-3: VEHICLE EQUIPMENT, MAINTENANCE AND INSPECTION:
A. Examination Of Vehicles: Prior to the issuance of a taxicab operator's license and prior to the use and
operation of any vehicle under the provisions of this article, said vehicle may be thoroughly examined and
inspected by the city to assure its compliance with the provisions of this article and such reasonable rules
and regulations as may be prescribed by the city council. Such rules and regulations may be promulgated to
provide safe transportation and may specify such safety equipment and regulatory devices as the city
council shall deem necessary.
When such an inspection finds that a vehicle has met the standards established by the city council, and the
licensee has met all other requirements of this article, the clerk may issue a taxicab operator's license;
however, a vehicle's failure to meet such standards may constitute grounds for refusal to issue a license or
suspension or revocation of a license.
B. Sanitary Condition: Every vehicle operating under this article shall be kept in a clean and sanitary condition.
C. Inspection Of Vehicles Generally: The city also may inspect or cause to be inspected any taxicab, from time
to time, or on the complaint of any person, or as often as may be necessary. A vehicle's failure to meet
applicable standards may constitute grounds for suspension or revocation of a license. (Ord. 06-18-0, 5-24-
2006)
3-7A-4: DISPLAY OF TAXICAB FARES AND RECEIPTS:
A. Taximeter Required: All taxicabs operated under the authority of this article and not operating on a flat rate
basis shall be equipped with a taximeter fastened in front of the passengers, visible to them at all times;
and, after sundown, the face of the taximeter shall be illuminated. Said taximeter shall be operated
mechanically by a mechanism of standard design and construction, driven either from the transmission or
from one of the front wheels by a flexible and permanently attached driving mechanism. They shall be
sealed at all points and connections which, if manipulated, would affect their current reading and recording.
Each taximeter shall have thereon a flag to denote when the vehicle is employed and when it is not
employed; and it shall be the duty of the driver to throw the flag of such taximeter into a nonrecording
position at the termination of each trip. The said taximeters shall be subject to inspection, from time to time,
by the city. Any duly authorized agent of the city is hereby authorized, either on complaint of any person or
without such complaint, to inspect any meter and, upon discovery of any inaccuracy therein, to notify the
person operating said taxicab to cease operation. Thereupon said taxicab shall be kept off the streets of the
city until the taximeter is repaired and in the required working condition.
B. Display Of Rate Card: Every taxicab operated under this article shall have a rate card setting forth the
authorized rates of fare displayed in such a place as to be in view of all passengers.
C. Furnish Receipts: The driver of any taxicab shall, upon demand by the passenger, render to such passenger
a receipt for the amount charged, either by a mechanically printed receipt or by a specially prepared receipt
on which shall be the name of the owner, license number, amount of meter reading or charges and date of
transaction. (Ord. 06-18-0, 5-24-2006)
6/5/2019 Sterling Codifiers, Inc.
https://www.sterlingcodifiers.com/codebook/index.php?book_id=502 232/767
3-7A-5: SERVICE TO THE PUBLIC:
A. In General: All persons engaged in the taxicab business in the city operating under the provisions of this
article shall render an overall service to the public desiring to use taxicabs.
B. Additional Passengers: No taxi driver shall permit any other person to occupy or ride in his or her taxicab,
unless the person first employing the taxicab shall consent to the acceptance of the additional passenger.
(Ord. 06-18-0, 5-24-2006)
3-7A-6: MANIFESTS REQUIRED:
