Every driver shall maintain a daily manifest upon which are recorded all trips made each day, showing time and
place of origin, destination of each trip and amount of fare; and all such completed manifests shall be returned
to the owner by the driver at the conclusion of his tour of duty. The forms for each manifest shall be furnished to
the driver by the owner and shall be subject to review and approval by the city upon request. The licensee shall
retain and preserve all drivers' manifests in a safe place for at least two (2) years, and any such manifest shall
be made available to the city. (Ord. 06-18-0, 5-24-2006)
3-7A-7: DRIVER'S QUALIFICATIONS:
A. Driver's License Required: No person shall operate a taxicab in the city who is not properly licensed by the
state of Illinois.
B. Investigation Of Applicant: The city may conduct an investigation of each applicant for a taxicab driver's
license, and a report of such investigation and a copy of the traffic and police record of the applicant, if any,
may be attached to the application for consideration of the city council. (Ord. 06-18-0, 5-24-2006)
ARTICLE B. LIMOUSINE SERVICES
3-7B-1: DEFINITIONS:
Unless otherwise expressly stated or the context clearly indicates a different intention, the following terms shall,
for the purpose of this article, have the meanings indicated below:
LIMOUSINE: Any vehicle used for the carriage of persons for hire within the city to any point beyond the city
limits, except those vehicles commonly known as buses and taxicabs.
LIMOUSINE DRIVER: Any person who, either in the conduct of his own limousine service licensed hereunder
or as an employee of a limousine service licensed hereunder, drives a "limousine" as defined in this section.
LIMOUSINE SERVICE: Any person, firm, partnership, corporation or other legal entity which owns, operates or
otherwise controls limousines as defined herein, and maintains a place of business in the city. (1970 Code §8-
37.23, as amended)
3-7B-2: BUSINESS LICENSING REQUIREMENTS:
A. License Required, Fee:
6/5/2019 Sterling Codifiers, Inc.
https://www.sterlingcodifiers.com/codebook/index.php?book_id=502 233/767
1. Required: It shall be unlawful to operate a limousine service in the city without first having obtained a
license therefor. (1970 Code §§8-37.24, 8-37.28, as amended; amd. Ord. 99-53-0, 11-29-1999)
2. Fee: See section 3-1-13 of this title. (Ord. 00-38-0, 12-13-2000)
B. Application For License, Hearing And Notice:
1. Upon filing of an application for a limousine service license with the city clerk, the clerk shall submit the
same to the city council and the council shall fix a time and place for a public hearing thereon.
2. An application for a license for an individual shall be signed by that individual, an application for a
partnership shall be signed by each partner, and an application on behalf of a corporation shall be signed
by the president and secretary. In addition, each individual applicant; or in the case of a partnership, each
partner; and in the case of a corporation, the president and secretary; shall provide the police department
of the city with a full set of fingerprint impressions and a photograph, which impressions and photograph
shall be attached to the application.
3. Notice of such hearing shall be given to the applicant and to all to whom such licenses have been
previously issued. Notice of hearing shall also be given to the general public by publication in a
newspaper of general circulation in the city not less than fifteen (15) days prior to the hearing. Any
interested person may file a memorandum with the city clerk, or present written or oral comments at said
hearing, in support of or opposition to the issuance of the license applied for.
4. If the city council finds, from investigation and hearing, that further limousine service is not detrimental to
the public convenience and necessity and that the applicant is fit, willing and able to perform such public
transportation and to conform to the provisions of this article, then the city council shall direct the clerk,
upon compliance by the applicant with the provisions of this article, to issue a license stating the name
and address of the applicant, the number of vehicles authorized under said license and the date of
issuance; otherwise the application shall be denied. (1970 Code §8-37.26, as amended)
C. Restrictions Upon Issuance Of License: No limousine service license shall be issued to:
1. A person who is not of good character and reputation in the community in which he resides.
2. A person who has been convicted of a felony under federal or state law.
3. A person who has had any license issued under this article revoked for cause.
4. A person who, at the time of application for renewal of any license issued hereunder, would not be eligible
for such license upon a first application.
5. A copartnership, unless all of the members of such copartnership shall be qualified to obtain a license.
6. A corporation, if any officer, manager or director thereof, or any stockholder or stockholders owning in the
aggregate more than five percent (5%) of the stock of such corporation, would not be eligible to receive a
license hereunder.
7. A corporation, unless it is incorporated in Illinois, or unless it is a foreign corporation which is qualified
under the Illinois business corporation act, to transact business in Illinois.
8. A person who is not a beneficial owner of the business to be operated by the licensee. (1970 Code §8-
37.26, as amended)
D. Indemnity Bond Or Liability Insurance Required: No limousine service license shall be issued or continued in
operation unless the applicant has complied with all the provisions of this article and with all the provisions
of the state law requiring proof of financial responsibility of operators of motor vehicles used for the
transportation of passengers for hire1. Before a license is issued, the applicant shall submit a certificate to
6/5/2019 Sterling Codifiers, Inc.
https://www.sterlingcodifiers.com/codebook/index.php?book_id=502 234/767
the clerk from the secretary of state of the state of Illinois for each motor vehicle to be operated or controlled
by the applicant evidencing that proof of financial responsibility for each of said motor vehicles has been
submitted to the secretary of state. Any cash bond shall be subject to the unclaimed bond forfeiture
provisions of title 1, chapter 9 of this code. (Ord. 92-29-0, 10-14-1992)
E. Transfer Of License: No limousine service license may be sold, assigned, mortgaged or otherwise
transferred without the consent of the city council. (1970 Code §8-37.29, as amended)
3-7B-3: VEHICLE EQUIPMENT AND MAINTENANCE:
A. Licensing And Examination Of Vehicles:
1. Prior to the issuance of a limousine service license and prior to the use and operation of any vehicle
under the provisions of this article, said vehicle shall be thoroughly examined and inspected by the chief
of police or a member of the police department duly authorized by the chief of police and found to be in a
safe and clean condition.
2. When the chief of police finds that a vehicle has met the above requirements, he shall report the same to
the city council, and such report shall be made part of the application.
3. If the applicant fails to meet such requirements, he shall be notified by the chief of police, or his
authorized representative, as to any deficiencies. (1970 Code §8-37.30, as amended)
B. Inspection Of Vehicles Generally, Report: The chief of police shall maintain constant vigilance over all
limousines and see that they are kept in a condition of continued fitness for public use. To this end, the chief
of police shall inspect or cause to be inspected all limousines, prior to renewal of any limousine service
license or on the complaint of any person, or as often as may be necessary. At least once in each year the
chief of police shall make a written report of all such inspections to the city council. (1970 Code §8-37.32, as
amended)
C. Sanitary Condition: Every vehicle operating under this article shall be kept in a clean and sanitary condition.
(1970 Code §8-37.32, as amended)
3-7B-4: SERVICE TO THE PUBLIC:
A. Furnish Receipts: It shall be the responsibility of any holder of a limousine service license to see that the
driver of any limousine operated by such licensee shall, upon demand by any passenger, render to such
passenger a receipt for the amount charged, either by a mechanically printed receipt or by a specially
prepared receipt on which shall be the name of the licensee, license number or motor number, amount of
fare, and date of transaction. (1970 Code §8-37.33, as amended)
B. Additional Passengers: It shall be the responsibility of any holder of a limousine service license to see that
no driver of any limousine operated by such licensee shall permit any other person to occupy or ride in said
limousine, unless the person first employing the limousine shall consent to the acceptance of the additional
passenger. (1970 Code §8-37.34, as amended)
3-7B-5: MANIFESTS REQUIRED:
It shall be the responsibility of any holder of a limousine service license to see that every driver of a limousine
operated by such licensee shall maintain a daily manifest upon which are recorded all trips made each day,
6/5/2019 Sterling Codifiers, Inc.
https://www.sterlingcodifiers.com/codebook/index.php?book_id=502 235/767
showing time and place of origin and destination of each trip and amount of fare; and all such completed
manifests shall be returned to the owner by the driver at the conclusion of his tour of duty. The licensee shall
retain and preserve all driver's manifests in a safe place for at least two (2) years, and said manifest shall be
available to the police department. (1970 Code §8-37.35, as amended)
3-7B-6: LIMOUSINE DRIVER'S LICENSE:
A. License Required: No person shall act as a "limousine driver", as defined herein, and no holder of a
limousine service license shall permit any person to so act, unless such person shall have first obtained and
shall have then in force a limousine driver's license issued under the provisions of this article. (1970 Code
§8-37.36, as amended)
B. Qualifications Of Applicant: Each applicant for a driver's license must:
1. Be of the age of twenty one (21) years or over.
2. Be in good health with good eyesight, and not subject to any disease or infirmity of body or mind which
might render him unfit for the safe operation of a limousine.
3. Be able to read, write and speak the English language.
4. Be clean in dress and person and not be addicted to the use of drugs or intoxicating liquors.
5. Not have been convicted of a felony.
6. Be of good moral character.
7. Have a current motor vehicle operator's permit issued by the secretary of state of Illinois. (1970 Code §8-
37.37, as amended)
C. Examination Of Applicant, Current State Motor Vehicle Operator's Permit Required: Before any application is
finally passed upon by the city council, the applicant shall demonstrate that he has met the qualifications of
subsection B of this section. (1970 Code §8-37.38, as amended)
D. Police Investigation Of Applicant, Traffic And Police Record: The police department shall conduct an
investigation of each applicant for a limousine driver's license and a report of such investigation and a copy
of the traffic and police record of the applicant, if any, shall be attached to the application for the
consideration of the city council. (1970 Code §8-37.39, as amended)
E. Fingerprints And Photograph: The police shall take a complete set of fingerprint impressions and a
photograph of each applicant for a limousine driver's license which shall also be attached to the application.
(1970 Code §8-37.40, as amended)
F. Issuance And Duration Of License, Fees: See section 3-1-13 of this title. Each application shall be
accompanied by a fee. Upon approval of an application for a limousine driver's license by the city council,
the clerk shall issue a license to the applicant. Such license shall be in effect for the remainder of the
calendar year. A license for each calendar year thereafter shall be issued upon the payment of the fee
specified in section 3-1-13 of this title unless the license for the preceding year has been revoked. (Ord. 99-
53-0, 11-29-1999; amd. Ord. 00-38-0, 12-13-2000)
G. Display Of License: Every limousine driver licensed under this article shall post his driver's license in such a
place as to be in full view of all passengers while such driver is operating a limousine. (1970 Code §8-37.43,
6/5/2019 Sterling Codifiers, Inc.
https://www.sterlingcodifiers.com/codebook/index.php?book_id=502 236/767
as amended)
Chapter 8
MOBILE HOME PARKS1
3-8-1: DEFINITIONS:
Unless the context clearly requires otherwise, the words and phrases set forth in this Section shall have the
following meanings when used in this Chapter:
CLERK: The City Clerk of Countryside.
DEPENDENT MOBILE HOME: A mobile home which does not have toilet and bath or shower facilities. (1970
Code § 8-38.01)
IMMOBILIZED MOBILE HOME: Any structure resting on a permanent foundation with wheels, tongue and hitch
permanently removed. The following criteria are hereby established to complete immobilization of a mobile
home:
A. The home shall be placed upon a slab of reinforced concrete not less than six inches (6") thick or upon a
foundation which shall extend into the ground below the frost line so as to attach and become a part of the
real estate. Materials such as concrete, mortared concrete block or mortared brick extending into the
ground below the frost line shall satisfy the requirement for a permanent foundation.
B. As an alternate to A, piers may be used, extending into the ground below the frost line and sufficient in
number to properly support the mobile home.
C. All immobilized mobile homes shall be equipped with skirts on all sides extending from the base of the
unit to approximately ground level. (Ord. 85-56-0, 11-27-85)
INDEPENDENT MOBILE HOME: A mobile home with self-contained toilet and bath or shower facilities.
MOBILE HOME: Any vehicle or similar portable structure used or so constructed as to permit its being used as
a conveyance upon the public streets or highways and designed to permit the occupancy thereof as a dwelling
place for one or more persons, provided that any such structure resting in whole on a permanent foundation,
with wheels, tongue and hitch removed, shall not be construed as a "mobile home".
MOBILE HOME PARK: An area of land upon which two (2) or more occupied mobile homes are harbored,
either free of charge or for revenue purposes, and shall include any building, structure, tent, vehicle or
enclosure used or intended for use as a part of the equipment of such mobile home park.
MOBILE HOME SPACE OR SITE: Any portion of a mobile home park designed for the use or occupancy of one
mobile home.
SCHOOL DISTRICT: Any district created or operated under the provisions of the school code2. (1970 Code §8-
38.01)
3-8-2: LICENSES AND PERMITS REQUIRED:
A. License Required, Term: Except as provided in subsection B of this Section, no person shall establish,
maintain, conduct or operate a mobile home park after April 30, 1954, without first obtaining a license
therefor from the City Clerk. Such license shall expire at twelve o'clock (12:00) midnight on April 30 of each
6/5/2019 Sterling Codifiers, Inc.
https://www.sterlingcodifiers.com/codebook/index.php?book_id=502 237/767
year and the license shall be renewed from year to year upon payment of the annual license fee herein
provided. (1970 Code §8-38.02)
B. Recreational Areas Excepted: Except for the provisions of Section 3-8-10 of this Chapter which shall
continue to apply to the mobile home parks hereinafter described in this subsection, this Chapter shall not
apply to any mobile home park located in a recreational area of this State, the patrons of which have other
permanent residences and reside in mobile homes within the park only during recreational seasons. (1970
Code §8-38.03)
C. Construction Permit: No person shall construct a mobile home park without first obtaining a permit to do so.
D. Display Of Licenses And Permits: All permits to construct, all licenses to operate, and all permits to make
alterations therein shall be prominently displayed in the office of mobile home parks.
E. Licenses Transferable With Consent: All licenses issued under this Chapter shall be nontransferable without
the written consent of the licenser; provided however, that the licenser may not withhold such consent where
the provisions of this Chapter have been met. (1970 Code §8-38.08)
F. Installation Permit:
1. No person shall install a mobile home without first obtaining a permit to do so.
2. The permit fee shall be one hundred dollars ($100.00).
3. The Building Commissioner shall approve and issue all mobile home installation permits. (Ord. 00-01-0,
1-12-2000)
3-8-3: APPLICATION FOR PERMIT AND LICENSE:
In order to obtain a permit to construct or an original license to operate a mobile home park, the applicant shall
file with the City Clerk a written application setting forth:
A. The full name and address of the applicant, or names and addresses of the partners if the applicant is a
partnership, or the names and addresses of the officers if the applicant is a corporation, and the present or
last occupation of the applicant at the time of the filing of the application.
B. The location and legal description of the tract of land upon which it is proposed to operate and maintain a
mobile home park.
C. The proposed and existing facilities in the mobile home park for water supply, sewage, garbage and waste
disposal, fire protection, and for a sanitary community building, if required, which will include a description of
toilets, urinals, sinks, washbasins, slop sinks, showers and drains, and the proposed alterations therein and
the maintenance thereof.
D. The proposed method of lighting the structures and land upon which the mobile home park is to be located.
E. The calendar months of the year during which the applicant will operate said mobile home park.
6/5/2019 Sterling Codifiers, Inc.
https://www.sterlingcodifiers.com/codebook/index.php?book_id=502 238/767
F. The plot plans of the mobile home park, building plans and specifications for existing buildings and facilities,
and the plans and specifications for new buildings and facilities or the proposed alterations in existing
facilities, all as may be required by the rules and regulations of the Building Commissioner under the
provisions of this Chapter.
G. A statement of the firefighting facilities, public or private, which are available to the mobile home park.
An affidavit of the applicant as to the truth of the matters contained in the application shall be attached
thereto. Each application shall be accompanied by an application fee of twenty five dollars ($25.00). Each
application fee shall be paid to the Clerk by a separate certified check or United States money order in
amount of the application fee only and the application fee, once paid to the clerk, shall not be refunded.
(1970 Code §8-38.04)
3-8-4: ISSUANCE OF PERMIT OR LICENSE:
A. Upon receipt of an application for a permit to construct a mobile home park or an application for a license to
operate and maintain the same, the city clerk shall, if the park is or the proposed park will be in conformity
with this chapter and the rules and regulations adopted by the city pursuant thereto, issue a permit to
construct or an original license, as the case may be. If the application for a permit to construct or a license is
declined, the clerk shall give the reasons therefor in writing to the applicant; and if the objections can be
corrected, the applicant may amend his application and resubmit it for approval.
B. If a permit to construct a mobile home park has been issued, the applicant, upon completion thereof, shall
notify the clerk. The building commissioner or his deputies shall then inspect the mobile home park and, if
completed in accordance with the accepted application, the clerk shall issue a license.
C. No change in any sanitary facilities, methods of water supply, sewer, drainage, garbage or waste disposal,
and no change in the plot plan shall be made without first making a written application to the clerk and
receiving a written permit therefrom. Such application shall be made in the way and manner set forth under
title 8, chapter 1 of this code. No application fee shall be required to accompany an application for a permit
to alter a mobile home park where such alteration involves only a reduction in the number of mobile home
spaces to a number less than for which such mobile home park is currently licensed. Such change or
changes shall comply with such safety and sanitary code, building codes3, rules and regulations as are
applicable thereto.
D. Such a permit does not relieve the applicant from securing a building permit or from complying with any
ordinance applicable thereto. (1970 Code §8-38.05; amd. 1986 Code)
3-8-5: LICENSE FEE:
A. See section 3-1-13 of this title. (Ord. 00-38-0, 12-13-2000)
B. The licensee shall pay the clerk ten dollars ($10.00) for each additional mobile home space added to his
mobile home park under authority of a written permit to alter the park, as provided in section 3-8-4 of this
chapter, payment for the additional mobile home spaces to be made and a license therefor obtained before
any mobile homes are accommodated on the additional mobile home spaces. The clerk may issue a
supplemental license for such additional mobile home spaces, when they are to be occupied before the end
of the license year, for which year an annual license has been previously issued. Supplemental license fees
shall not be prorated. (Ord. 99-53-0, 11-29-1999)
6/5/2019 Sterling Codifiers, Inc.
https://www.sterlingcodifiers.com/codebook/index.php?book_id=502 239/767
C. Each license fee shall be paid to the clerk and any license fee or any part thereof, once paid to and accepted
by the clerk, shall not be refunded. (1970 Code §8-38.06; amd. 1986 Code)
3-8-6: FILES AND RECORDS KEPT BY CLERK:
A. Approved Licenses And Permits: When the clerk has approved an application for a permit to construct or
make alterations upon a mobile home park or the appurtenances thereto or a license to operate and
maintain the same, he shall retain the original and keep a file thereof, and one copy shall be returned to the
applicant or his agent.
B. Application Forms And Blanks: The clerk shall draft and supply all forms and blanks and specify the number
and detail necessary to obtain permits to construct or make alterations upon mobile home parks; and for a
license to operate and maintain such a park according to this chapter. (1970 Code §8-38.28)
C. Records: The clerk shall keep a record of all mobile home parks; said records to show the names and
addresses of such parks; names and addresses of the licensees; number of mobile home lots in each park;
source of water supply; system of sewage and garbage disposal; and any other information required hereby.
(1970 Code §8-38.29; amd. 1986 Code)
3-8-7: REVOCATION OF LICENSE:
Any license granted hereunder shall be subject to revocation or suspension by the City Council. However, the
City Clerk shall first serve or cause to be served upon the licensee a written notice in which shall be specified
the way or ways in which such licensee has failed to comply with this Chapter, or any rules or regulations
promulgated by the City pertaining thereto. Said notice shall require the licensee to remove or abate such
nuisance, insanitary or objectionable condition, specified in such notice, within five (5) days or within a longer
period of time as may be allowed by the Mayor. For the purposes of this Section, "objectionable condition" shall
include in its meaning a failure to comply with the provisions of Section 3-8-10 of this Chapter. If the licensee
fails to comply with the terms and conditions of said notice within the time specified or such extended periods of
time granted by the City Council, the City Council may revoke or suspend such license, subject to the
provisions set forth in Section 3-8-8 of this Chapter. (1970 Code §8-38.07; amd. 1986 Code)
3-8-8: APPEAL PROCEDURES:
A. Any person refused a permit to construct or alter a mobile home park or a license, or who has received a
notice that his license may be suspended or revoked, shall have the right to an appeal hearing before the
City Council. A written notice of a request for such a hearing shall be served upon the City Clerk within thirty
(30) days of such refusal of a permit to construct or alter or refusal of a license, or in case of possible
suspension or revocation, within the time specified for compliance. The Clerk shall give written notice of
such decision, by certified mail, to the park operator or the applicant, as the case may be, within five (5)
days of such refusal or of possible suspension or revocation. All such notices shall state the reason or
reasons therefor and shall set forth applicant's or licensee's appeal rights hereunder. The hearing shall be
conducted at City Hall by the City Council, or a duly qualified agent of the City designated in writing by the
City Council as a hearing officer to conduct the hearing.
B. The City Council or hearing officer may compel, by subpoenas or subpoena duces tecum, the attendance
and testimony of witnesses and the production of books and papers, and administer oaths to witnesses. The
Clerk shall give written notice of the time and place of hearing, by certified mail, to the park operator or
license applicant, as the case may be, at least five (5) days prior to such hearing.
6/5/2019 Sterling Codifiers, Inc.
https://www.sterlingcodifiers.com/codebook/index.php?book_id=502 240/767
C. The City Council or hearing officer shall permit the applicant or licensee to appear in person and to be
represented by counsel at the hearing, at which time the applicant or licensee shall be afforded an
opportunity to present all relevant matters in support of his application for license, renewal of license or in
resisting the revocation thereof.
D. In the event of the inability of any party, or the Clerk, to procure the attendance of witnesses to give
testimony or produce books and papers, such party or the Clerk may take the deposition of witnesses in
accordance with the provisions of the laws of this State. All testimony taken at a hearing shall be transcribed
by a certified court reporter and may be reduced to a written transcription on request of any party to the
appeal, and all such testimony and other evidence introduced at the hearing shall be a part of the record of
the hearing.
E. The City Council shall make findings of fact in such hearing, and the Council shall render its decision within
thirty (30) days after the termination of the hearing, unless additional time is required by it for a proper
disposition of the matter. When the hearing has been conducted by a hearing officer, the City Council shall
review the record before rendering a decision. It shall be the duty of the City Council to forward a copy of its
decision, by certified mail, to the park operator or applicant, as the case may be, within five (5) days of
rendition of such decision.
F. Technical errors in the proceeding before the City Council or hearing officer or their failure to observe the
technical rules of evidence shall not constitute grounds for the reversal of any administrative decision unless
it appears to the court that such error or failure materially affects the rights of any party and results in
substantial injustice to him.
G. All subpoenas issued by the City Council or hearing officer may be served by the City of Countryside Police
Department. The fees of witnesses for attendance and travel shall be the same as the fees for witnesses
before the circuit court and shall be paid by the party to such proceedings at whose request the subpoena is
issued. If such subpoena is issued at the request of the Clerk, the witness fee shall be paid as an
administrative expense.
H. In cases of refusal of a witness to attend or testify, or to produce books or papers concerning any matter
upon which he might be lawfully examined, the circuit court of the county wherein the hearing is held, or a
judge thereof, upon application of any party to the proceeding, may compel obedience by proceeding as for
contempt as in cases of a like refusal to obey a similar order of said court.
I. Receipt of a notice of appeal hereunder shall stay all further action by the City Clerk to suspend or revoke a
license hereunder. However, it shall in no way prohibit the City from making application to any court to
compel a licensee to comply with applicable codes or ordinances when an emergency affecting health,
safety or well being of City residents is deemed to exist. (1970 Code 88-38.37; 1986 Code)
3-8-9: RULES AND REGULATIONS FOR MOBILE HOME PARKS:
The following provisions shall be applicable to all mobile home parks licensed under the provisions of this
Chapter:
A. All streets and driveways in every mobile home park must be paved and maintained in accordance with City
Building Code requirements, and all streets and driveways shall have a minimum width of forty feet (40').
B. The management of every mobile home park shall assume full responsibility for maintaining in good repair
and condition all sanitary and safety appliances on the park, and shall promptly bring such action as is
6/5/2019 Sterling Codifiers, Inc.
https://www.sterlingcodifiers.com/codebook/index.php?book_id=502 241/767
necessary to prosecute or eject from the park any person who wilfully or maliciously damages such
appliances, or any person who fails to comply with the regulations of this Chapter. (1970 Code § 8-38.30;
1986 Code)
3-8-10: MOBILE HOMES TO DISPLAY CERTIFICATE OF TITLE:
In the event that any mobile home in such mobile home park shall not have displayed, in accordance with State
law4, a display certificate of title, the mobile home park shall, within forty eight (48) hours after said mobile
home enters said mobile home park or within forty eight (48) hours after any amendatory act shall become
effective, whichever shall be later, notify the Department of Revenue of that fact. For the purpose of determining
when, if ever, any such notification was sent to the Department of Revenue, by a mobile home park with
respect to any particular mobile home, it shall be a presumption that the notification was not sent more than
four (4) days prior to the time when it was received, if received, by the Department of Revenue. The owner of
any mobile home park which fails timely to give the Department of Revenue the notification required herein is
guilty of a misdemeanor and, upon conviction thereof, shall be fined one hundred dollars ($100.00) for each
such mobile home which is located in such mobile home park after the expiration of the forty eight (48) hours
hereinbefore referred to and prior to the time when the notification by the mobile home park is made to the
Department of Revenue.
Representatives of the Department of Revenue and all other law enforcement officers may enter any mobile
home park at any time for the purpose of determining which, if any, mobile homes located therein do not have
displayed the display certificate of title referred to hereinabove. (1970 Code § 8-38.32)
3-8-11: SCHOOL DISTRICT AUTHORITY:
The governing body of the school district in which such mobile home park is located, by and through its officers,
attendance officers and proper employees, may inspect and visit a mobile home park for the purposes of
examining the register with reference to children of school age for the purpose of enforcing attendance of
school children housed in the mobile home park. (1970 Code § 8-38.33; 1986 Code)
3-8-12: EXEMPT AREAS AND STRUCTURES:
Nothing in this Chapter shall be construed to include mobile home parks operated by the State or the Federal
government, or park land owned by either, and no trailer park operated for the use of recreational vehicles or
travel trailers, nor shall anything in this Chapter be construed to include mobile homes or trailers maintained by
any individual or company upon a construction site and used exclusively to house their office or persons
employed upon such site as watchmen for not more than ninety (90) days in any calendar year. However, any
mobile home or trailer shall meet sanitary and safety provisions of this Chapter, shall be inspected as herein
provided, shall pay or cause to be paid to the Clerk the respective application and license fees provided by this
Chapter and keep a register and make all reports, as herein required of a licensee. (1970 Code §§ 8-38.35, 8-
38.43; 1986 Code)
3-8-13: PARK OPERATION AND PREMISES REQUIREMENTS:
A. Operation; Compliance:
1. Park Operation: Each mobile home park licensed or to be constructed under the provisions of this
Chapter shall be operated and maintained in accordance with the requirements of this Section. (1970
Code § 8-38.09)
2. Mobile Home Standards: A mobile home park shall contain only mobile homes which comply with the
National Manufactured Home Construction and Safety Standards (Code of Federal Regulations, title 24,
6/5/2019 Sterling Codifiers, Inc.
https://www.sterlingcodifiers.com/codebook/index.php?book_id=502 242/767
part 3280, 4-1-85 edition as amended); and each mobile home within a mobile home park shall be
immobilized in strict compliance with the requirements set out for same in Section 3-8-1 hereof under
definition of "immobilized mobile home". (Ord. 85-56-0, 11-27-85)
B. Attendant Or Caretaker: Every mobile home park shall be in the charge of a responsible attendant or
caretaker whose duty it shall be to maintain the park, its facilities and equipment in a clean, orderly and
sanitary condition, and be answerable, with the licensee, for any violation of the provisions of this Chapter.
(1970 Code § 8-38.10)
C. Drainage: No mobile home park shall be so located that the drainage of the park area will endanger any
water supply. All such parks shall be well drained and shall be located in areas free from ponds, swamps
and similar places in which mosquitoes may breed. No waste water from mobile homes shall be deposited
on the surface of the ground. (1970 Code § 8-38.11)
D. Sites: Except as hereinafter provided, each mobile home shall be allotted a site of not less than two
thousand five hundred (2,500) square feet. No mobile home shall be parked closer than six feet (6') to the
side lot lines of a mobile home park, or closer than sixteen feet (16') to a public street, alley or building.
Each individual site shall abut or face on a driveway or roadway, which driveway or roadway shall have
unobstructed access to a public highway or alley. There shall be an open space of at least twelve feet (12')
adjacent to the side of every mobile home and at least ten feet (10') adjacent to the ends of every mobile
home.
Notwithstanding the foregoing, the following sites shall contain not less than one thousand seven hundred
forty (1,740) square feet: Lot 3 Elm, Lot 22 Elm, Lot 84 Country Club, Lot 85 Country Club and Lot 12 Oak,
all in Country Club Mobile Homes Park, 9800 Joliet Road. (Ord. 95-28-0, 8-8-95)
E. Water Supply: An adequate supply of water, of safe sanitary quality, approved by the City Council, shall be
furnished at each mobile home park. Where water from other sources than that supplied by the City is
proposed to be used, the source of such supply shall first be approved by the City Council. Each site shall
be provided with a cold water tap of at least four inches (4") above the ground. All exposed water lines shall
be completely covered with heat tape. (1970 Code § 8-38.13; 1986 Code)
F. Toilet And Bathing Facilities: Adequate toilet, lavatory and bathing facilities for occupants of dependent
mobile homes shall be provided in a community service building or buildings. Such building or buildings
shall be conveniently located, well constructed, have good natural and artificial lighting, adequate ventilation
and floors of concrete or similar impervious materials. Concrete curbings, extending at least six inches (6")
above the floor, shall be provided and the floor sloped to adequate drains. Walls and partitions shall be
constructed of impervious material where subject to splash. Such building shall be maintained at a
temperature of at least sixty eight degrees (68) Fahrenheit during the period from October 1 to May 1. (1970
Code § 8-38.14)
The City Council shall, by reasonable rules and regulations, specify the number of water closets, lavatories
and baths or showers required for service of dependent mobile home sites. (1970 Code § 8-38.18)
G. Service Building: The community service building shall be provided with toilet rooms for each sex, plainly
marked by appropriate signs, in which shall be installed water closets and lavatories adequate in number to
serve the reasonable needs of occupants of dependent mobile homes. Each water closet shall be placed in
a separate compartment, properly separated from other water closets, shall be not less than three feet (3')
wide and shall be enclosed with a proper partition. The community service building shall also be provided
with tub or shower bath compartments for both sexes, adequate in number to accommodate the reasonable
needs of occupants of dependent mobile homes. In combination with each bath or shower stall, there shall
be provided an individual dressing compartment not less than two and one-half feet by three feet (21/2' x 3')
in plan so arranged as to insure privacy. The floor of such compartment shall be waterproof and elevated
6/5/2019 Sterling Codifiers, Inc.
https://www.sterlingcodifiers.com/codebook/index.php?book_id=502 243/767
three inches (3") above the floor of the shower stall or a six inch (6") curbing provided, separating the
shower compartment from the dressing room. Mats, grids and walkways made of wood, cloth or other
absorbent materials will not be approved for use in bath sections of community service buildings. (1970
Code, § 8-38.15)
H. Laundry Rooms: No laundry trays shall be located in a toilet or bathroom. A laundry room or building
constructed as specified in subsection G above shall be provided containing laundry trays to accommodate
the patrons of the mobile home park. (1970 Code § 8-38.16)
I. Water Supply, Service Building: An adequate water supply shall be provided at all times for the operation of
all water closets in the service building, and an adequate supply of hot and cold water shall be provided at
all times in the service building for all bathing, washing, cleansing and laundry facilities. (1970 Code § 8-
38.17)
J. Sewage Disposal: All sewage and other water-carried wastes shall be disposed of into the City sewerage
system or such other sewerage system as may be approved by the City Council. (1970 Code § 8-38.19;
1986 Code)
K. Water Carriage System: Each mobile home site shall be provided with a sewer connection for the combined
liquid waste outlet or outlets of each mobile home, and trapped below the frost line. It shall be the duty of the
owner or operator of said mobile home park to provide an approved type of water and odor-tight connection
from the mobile home water drainage to the sewer connection, and it shall be the duty of said owner or
operator to make such connection and keep all occupied mobile homes connected to said sewer while
located in a mobile home park. Sewer connections in unoccupied mobile home sites shall be so closed that
they will emit no odors or cause a breeding place for flies. No water or waste shall be allowed to fall on the
ground from a mobile home. (1970 Code § 8-38.20; 1986 Code)
L. Garbage And Rubbish:
1. A sufficient number of adequate flyproof and watertight containers shall be supplied for the storage of
garbage.
2. Garbage containers shall be emptied at least every three (3) days and shall not be filled to overflowing, or
allowed to become foul smelling, or a breeding place for flies.
3. Garbage and rubbish shall be disposed of in a manner which creates neither a nuisance nor a menace to
health for all bathing, washing, cleansing and laundry facilities.(1970 Code § 8-38.21; 1986 Code)
M. Insect and Rodent Control: Adequate insect and rodent control measures shall be employed. All buildings
shall be fly and rodent proof and rodent harborages shall not be permitted to exist in the park. (1970 Code
§ 8-38.22)
N. Cooking and Eating Facilities: When community kitchens and dining rooms are provided, such facilities and
equipment as are supplied must be maintained in a sanitary condition and kept in good repair. (1970 Code
§ 8-38.23)
O. Electrical Outlets: Electrical outlets for each individual mobile home site shall be provided and the installation
shall be in compliance with all City of Countryside electrical codes and ordinances. No connected electric
extension cord shall lie on the ground or be suspended. (1970 Code § 8-38.24; 1986 Code)
6/5/2019 Sterling Codifiers, Inc.
https://www.sterlingcodifiers.com/codebook/index.php?book_id=502 244/767
P. Fire Protection: Fire extinguishers of a type approved by the State Fire Marshal for use at mobile home parks
shall be placed at locations within two hundred feet (200') of each individual mobile home site. Each fire
extinguisher shall be periodically examined and kept at all times in a condition for use. (1970 Code § 8-
38.25)
Q. Porches and Canopies: Temporary porches, canvas-roofed canopies and skirts shall be permitted for mobile
homes, and auxiliary rooms shall comply with City building regulations. (1970 Code § 8-38.26; 1986 Code)
R. Plumbing, Electrical and Heating: All buildings constructed or altered, all plumbing, and all electrical and
heating installations shall be in accordance with existing City of Countryside building ordinances and their
rules and regulations. (1970 Code § 8-38.27; 1986 Code)
3-8-14: ENFORCEMENT:
The Building Commissioner and the Health Officer, their deputies or authorized agents, or any member of the
Police Department shall enforce the provisions of this Chapter and the rules and regulations adopted pursuant
hereto affecting health, sanitation, water supply, sewage, garbage and waste disposal, and the Health Officer
shall personally inspect, at least once each year, each mobile home park and all the accommodations and
facilities therewith. Such officials or officers are hereby granted the power and authority to enter upon the
premises of such mobile home parks at any time for the purposes herein set forth. The City may issue rules and
regulations to carry out the provisions of this Chapter. (1970 Code § 8-38.37; 1986 Code)
3-8-15: CUSTODIAN'S OFFICE:
Each mobile home park shall be provided with a custodian's office where each mobile home entering such
mobile home park shall be assigned to a lot location, given a copy of the mobile home park rules, and
registered according to the prescribed form. Said registration shall include the name and address of every
occupant of said mobile home; the license number of all units; the state issuing such license; and a statement
indicating the exact location at which such mobile home was last parked, including the state, city, town or
village where such parking occurred. The licensee shall keep a registry of all children of school age occupying
mobile homes in the mobile home park. The abovementioned register shall be signed by an occupant of the
mobile home. Any person found guilty of furnishing misinformation for purposes of registration shall be fined not
less than fifty dollars ($50.00) nor more than five hundred dollars ($500.00). The registration records shall be
neatly and securely maintained, and no registration records shall be destroyed until six (6) years have elapsed
following the date of registration. The register shall be available at all times for inspection by law enforcement
officers. (1970 Code 88-38.31; 1986 Code)
3-8-16: LANDLORD AND TENANT REGULATIONS:
3-8-16-1: APPLICABILITY:
This Section 3-8-16 shall regulate and determine legal rights, remedies and obligations of the parties to any
lease of a mobile home or mobile home lot in a mobile home park containing five (5) or more mobile homes
within the City. Any lease, written or oral, shall be unenforceable insofar as any provision thereof conflicts with
any provision of this Section. (1970 Code § 8-38.39)
3-8-16-2: JURISDICTION:
Any person, whether or not a citizen or resident of the City, who owns, holds an ownership or beneficial interest
6/5/2019 Sterling Codifiers, Inc.
https://www.sterlingcodifiers.com/codebook/index.php?book_id=502 245/767
in, uses, manages or possesses real estate situated in the City, submits himself or his personal representative
to the jurisdiction of the courts of this State as to any action proceeding for the enforcement of an obligation
arising under this Section. (1970 Code § 8-38.40)
3-8-16-3: DEFINITIONS:
Unless otherwise expressly defined, all terms in this Section shall be construed to have their ordinarily accepted
meanings or such meanings as the context therein requires.
PARK OWNER: The owner of a mobile home park and any person authorized to exercise any aspect of the
management of the premises, including any person who directly or indirectly receives rents and has no
obligation to deliver the whole of such receipts to another person.
PERSON: Any legal entity, including but not limited to, an individual, firm, partnership, association, trust, joint
stock company, corporation or successor of any of the foregoing.
TENANT: Any person who occupies a mobile home rental unit for dwelling purposes or a lot on which he parks
a mobile home for an agreed upon consideration. (1970 Code § 8-38.41; 1986 Code)
3-8-16-4: REQUISITES FOR RENTAL OF MOBILE HOME OR LOT:
No person shall rent or offer for rent:
A. Any mobile home which does not conform to the sanitation, housing and health codes of the City.
B. Any lot in a mobile home which does not conform to relevant ordinances of the City. (1970 Code § 8-38.42)
3-8-16-5: LEASE AGREEMENTS:
A. Obligation of Park Owner to Offer Written Lease: No person shall offer a mobile home or lot for rent or sale in
a mobile home park without having first exhibited to the prospective tenant or purchaser a copy of the lease
applicable to the respective mobile home park.
1. The park owner shall be required to offer to each present and future tenant a written lease for a term of
not less than twelve (12) months, unless the parties agree to a different term subject to existing leases
which shall be continued pursuant to their terms.
2. All such leases being offered shall comply with the requirements of the Mobile Home Landlord and Tenant
Act of Illinois5. (1970 Code § 8-38.45)
B. Effect of Unsigned Lease: If the tenant shall fail to sign a written lease which has been signed and tendered
to him by the owner and shall further provide the owner with a rejection in writing of such offer, the tenant's
continuation of possession and payment of rent without reservation shall constitute an acceptance of the
lease with the same effect as if it had been signed by the tenant. (1970 Code § 8-38.45)
C. Renewal of Lease: Every lease of a mobile home or lot in a mobile home park shall contain an option which
automatically renews the lease; unless: (1) the tenant shall notify the owners thirty (30) days prior to the
expiration of the lease that he does not intend to renew the lease; or (2) the park owner shall notify the
tenant thirty (30) days prior to the expiration of the lease that the lease will not be renewed and specify in
6/5/2019 Sterling Codifiers, Inc.
https://www.sterlingcodifiers.com/codebook/index.php?book_id=502 246/767
writing the reasons, such as violations of park rules, health and safety codes or irregular or nonpayment of
rent. (1970 Code § 8-38.46)
D. Terms of Fees and Rents: The terms for payment of rent shall be clearly set forth and all charges for
services, ground or lot rent, unit rent, or any other charges shall be specifically itemized in the lease and in
all billings of the tenant by the park owner. The owner shall not change the rental terms nor increase the
cost of fees, except as provided herein. (1970 Code § 8-38.47)
E. Waiver of Provisions Void: Any provision of a lease whereby any provisions of this Section are waived is
declared void. (1970 Code § 8-38.48)
F. Provisions of Mobile Home Park Leases: Any lease hereafter executed or currently existing between an
owner and tenant in a mobile home park in the City shall also contain or shall be made to contain, the
following covenants binding the owner at all times during the term of the lease to:
1. Identify to each tenant prior to his occupancy the lot area for which he will be responsible.
2. Keep all exterior property areas not in the possession of a tenant, but part of the mobile home park
property, free from the species of weeds and plant growth which are generally noxious or detrimental to
the health of the tenants.
3. Maintain all electrical, plumbing, gas or other utilities provided by him in good working condition, with the
exception of emergencies, after which repairs must be completed within a reasonable period of time.
4. Maintain all subsurface water and sewage lines and connections in good working order.
5. Respect the privacy of the tenants and if only the lot is rented, agree not to enter the mobile home without
the permission of the homeowner, and if the mobile home is the property of the owner, to enter only after
due notice to the tenant, provided the park owner or his representative may enter without notice in
emergencies.
6. Maintain all roads within the mobile home park in good condition.
7. Include a statement of all services and facilities which are to be provided by the park owner for the tenant,
e.g. lawn maintenance, snow removal, garbage or solid waste disposal, recreation building, community
hall, swimming pool, golf course, laundromat, etc.
8. The full names and addresses of all individuals in whom all or part of the legal or equitable title to the
mobile home park is vested, or the name and address of the owner's designated agent.
9. Provide a custodian's office and furnish each tenant with the name, address and telephone number of the
custodian and designated office. (1970 Code § 8-38.49)
G. Lease Prohibitions: No lease hereafter executed or currently existing between a park owner and tenant in a
mobile home park in this State shall contain any provision:
1. Permitting the park owner to charge a penalty fee for late payment of rent without allowing a tenant a
minimum of three (3) days beyond the date the rent is due in which to remit such payment.
2. Permitting the park owner to charge an amount in excess of one month's rent as a security deposit.
3. Requiring the tenant to pay any fees not specified in the lease. (1970 Code § 8-38.50)
3-8-16-6: TENANT'S DUTIES:
6/5/2019 Sterling Codifiers, Inc.
https://www.sterlingcodifiers.com/codebook/index.php?book_id=502 247/767
The tenant shall agree at all times during the tenancy to:
A. Keep the mobile home unit, if he rents such, or the exterior premises if he rents a lot, in a clean and sanitary
condition, free of garbage and rubbish.
B. Refrain from the storage of any inoperable motor vehicle.
C. Refrain from washing any vehicles except at an area designated by park management.
D. Refrain from performing any major repairs of motor vehicles at any time.
E. Refrain from the storage of any icebox, stove, building material, furniture or similar items on the exterior
premises.
F. Keep the supplied basic facilities, including plumbing fixtures, cooking and refrigeration equipment and
electrical fixtures in a leased mobile home unit in a clean and sanitary condition and be responsible for the
exercise of reasonable care in their proper use and operation.
G. Not deliberately or negligently destroy, deface, damage, impair or remove any part of the premises or
knowingly permit any person to do so.
H. Conduct himself and require other persons on the premises with his consent to conduct themselves in a
manner that will not affect or disturb his neighbors' peaceful enjoyment of the premises.
I. Abide by all the rules or regulations concerning the use, occupation and maintenance of the premises.
J. Abide by any reasonable rules for guest parking which are clearly stated. (1970 Code § 8-38.51)
3-8-16-7: RULES AND REGULATIONS OF PARK:
Rules and regulations promulgated and adopted by the park owner are enforceable against a tenant only if:
A. A copy of all rules and regulations was delivered by the park owner to the tenant prior to his signing the
lease.
B. The purpose of such rules and regulations is to promote the convenience, safety and welfare of the tenants,
preserve park property from damage or to fairly distribute park services and facilities to the tenants.
C. They are reasonably related to the purpose for which adopted.
D. They apply to all tenants in a fair manner.
6/5/2019 Sterling Codifiers, Inc.
https://www.sterlingcodifiers.com/codebook/index.php?book_id=502 248/767
E. They are sufficiently explicit in prohibition, direction or limitation of the tenant's conduct to fairly inform him of
what he must or must not do to comply.
F. They are not for the purpose of evading the obligation of the park owners.
A rule or regulation adopted during the term of a lease is enforceable against the tenant only if thirty (30) days'
written notice of its adoption is given the tenant and such rule or regulation is not in violation of the terms and
conditions of the lease. (1970 Code § 8-38.52)
3-8-16-8: GROUNDS FOR EVICTION:
A. Statutory Grounds: A park owner may terminate the lease and evict a tenant for any one or more of the
following acts:
Nonpayment of rent due.
Failure to comply with the park rules.
Failure to comply with local ordinances and State laws regulating mobile homes. (1970 Code § 8-38.53)
B. Improper Grounds: The following conduct by a tenant shall not constitute grounds for eviction or termination
of the lease, nor shall a judgment for possession of the premises be entered against a tenant:
1. As a reprisal for the tenant's effort to secure or enforce any rights under the lease or the laws of the City,
the State of Illinois, or its governmental subdivisions, or of the United States.
2. As a reprisal for the tenant's good faith complaint to a governmental authority of the park owner's alleged
violation of any health or safety law, regulation, code or ordinance, or State law or regulation which has as
its objective the regulation of premises used for dwelling purposes.
3. As a reprisal for the tenant's being an organizer or member of, or involved in any activities relative to a
homeowner's association. (1970 Code 88-38.54)
3-8-16-9: NOTICE REQUIRED BY LAW:
The following notice shall be printed verbatim in a clear and conspicuous manner in each lease or rental
agreement of a mobile home or lot:
IMPORTANT NOTICE REQUIRED BY LAW
The rules set forth below govern the terms of your lease of occupancy arrangement with this mobile home park.
The law requires all of these rules and regulations to be fair and reasonable, and if not, such rules and
regulations cannot be enforced against you.
You may continue to reside in the park as long as you pay your rent and abide by the rules and regulations of
the park. You may only be evicted for nonpayment of rent, violation of laws, or for violation of the rules and
regulations of the park and the terms of the lease.
If this park requires you to deal exclusively with a certain fuel dealer or other merchant for goods or services in
connection with the use or occupancy of your mobile home or on your mobile home lot, the price you pay for
such goods or services may not be more than the prevailing price in this locality for similar goods and services.
You may not be evicted for reporting any violations of law or health and building codes to boards of health,
6/5/2019 Sterling Codifiers, Inc.
https://www.sterlingcodifiers.com/codebook/index.php?book_id=502 249/767
building commissioners, the department of the Attorney General or any other appropriate government agency.
(1970 Code § 8-38.55)
3-8-16-10: SECURITY DEPOSIT:
If the lease requires the tenant to provide any deposit with the park owner for the term of the lease, or any part
thereof, said deposit shall be considered a security deposit. Security deposits shall be returned in full to the
tenant, provided that the tenant has paid all rent due in full for the term of the lease and has caused no actual
damage to the premises.
The park owner shall furnish the tenant, within fifteen (15) days after termination or expiration of the lease, an
itemized list of the damages incurred upon the premises and the estimated cost for the repair of each item. The
tenant's failure to object to the itemized list within fifteen (15) days shall constitute an agreement upon the
amount of damages specified therein. The park owner's failure to furnish such itemized list of damages shall
constitute an agreement that no damages have been incurred upon the premises and the entire security
deposit shall become immediately due and owing to the tenant.
The tenant's failure to furnish the park owner a forwarding address shall excuse the park owner from furnishing
the list required by this Section. (1970 Code § 8-38.56)
3-8-16-11: PURCHASE OF GOODS AND SERVICES:
A. No park owner shall restrict a tenant in his choice of a seller of fuel, furnishings, accessories or goods or
services connected with a mobile home unless such restriction is necessary to protect the health or safety of
the park residents. The park owner may determine by rule or regulation the style or quality of exterior
equipment to be purchased by the tenant from a vendor of the tenant's choosing. Provided, that no park
owner shall be required to permit service vehicles in the park in such numbers and with such frequency that
a danger is created for pedestrian traffic in the park.
B. No park owner shall require, as a condition of tenancy or continued tenancy, for a tenant to purchase fuel oil
or bottled gas from any particular fuel oil or bottled gas dealer or distributor. Provided, that this subsection
shall not apply to a park owner who provides a centralized distribution system for fuel oil or bottled gas, or
both, for residents therein. No park owner providing a centralized distribution system shall charge residents
more than a reasonable retail price. (1970 Code § 8-38.57)
3-8-16-12: ACCEPTANCE OF GIFTS OR GRATUITY PROHIBITED:
A. Any park owner who, directly or indirectly, receives, collects or accepts from any person any donation,
gratuity, bonus or gift, in addition to lawful charges, upon the representation that compliance with the
request or demand will facilitate, influence or procure an advantage in entering into an agreement, either
oral or written, for the lease or rental of real property, or contract of sale of a mobile home, or any park
owner or his representative who refuses to enter into such lease or contract of sale unless he received,
directly or indirectly, a donation, gratuity, bonus or gift, or any park owner or his representative who directly
or indirectly aids, abets, requests or authorizes any other person to violate any provision of this subsection,
commits a violation of this Section.
B. Any person who pays such donation, gratuity, bonus or gift may recover twice its value, together with costs
of the action, against any such person in violation of this Section. (1970 Code § 8-38.58)
3-8-16-13: REMEDIES:
6/5/2019 Sterling Codifiers, Inc.
https://www.sterlingcodifiers.com/codebook/index.php?book_id=502 250/767
A. Tenants: If the park owner fails to substantially comply with any code, statute, ordinance or regulation
governing the operation of the mobile home park or the maintenance of the premises, the tenant may, on
written notice to the park owner, terminate the lease and vacate the premises at any time during the first
thirty (30) days of occupancy. After the expiration of said thirty (30) days, the tenant may terminate the lease
only if he has remained in possession in reliance upon the park owner's promise, to correct all or any part of
the condition which would justify termination by the tenant under this Section.
Any condition which deprives the tenant of substantial benefit and enjoyment which the park owner shall fail
to remedy within thirty (30) days after having received notice in writing of such condition, shall constitute
grounds for the tenant to terminate the lease and vacate the premises. No such notice shall be required
where the condition renders the mobile home uninhabitable or poses an imminent threat to the health,
welfare and safety of any occupant.
If such condition was proximately caused by the wilful or negligent act or omission of the park owner, the
tenant may recover any damages sustained as a result of the condition including, but not limited to,
reasonable expenditures necessary to obtain adequate substitute housing while the mobile home is
uninhabitable.
The tenant may sue to enforce all provisions of this Section 3-8-16, and the court may award damages or
grant any injunctive or other relief. (1970 Code § 8-38.59)
B. Park Owner: A park owner may, any time rent is overdue, notify the tenant in writing that unless payment is
made within the time specified in the notice, not less than five (5) days after receipt thereof, the lease will be
terminated. If the tenant remains in default, the park owner may institute legal action for recovery of
possession, rent due and any damages.
If the tenant breaches any provision of the lease or rules and regulations of the mobile home park, the park
owner shall notify the tenant in writing of his breach. Such notice shall specify the violation and advise the
tenant that if the violation shall continue for more than twenty four (24) hours after receipt of such notice, the
park owner may terminate the lease. (1970 Code § 8-38.60)
3-8-16-14: TERMINATION OF LEASE:
If a tenant shall remain in possession of the premises after the expiration of his lease without having notified the
park owner of his acceptance or rejection of a renewal of the lease and without the park owner's consent, the
tenant shall pay to the park owner a sum, not to exceed twice the monthly rental under the previous lease,
computed and prorated daily for each day he shall remain in possession. (1970 Code § 8-38.61)
3-8-16-15: SALE OF MOBILE HOMES:
A. The park owner shall be enjoined and restrained from prohibiting, limiting, restricting, obstructing or in any
manner interfering with the freedom of any mobile home owner to:
1. Sell his mobile home to a purchaser of his choice, provided that the park owner shall be allowed to
promulgate any general qualifications or lawful restrictions on park residents which limit or define the
admission of entrants to the park. The purchaser, prior to closing, must obtain a written and signed lease.
2. Employ or secure the services of an independent salesperson in connection with the sale of said mobile
home, provided that said salesperson collects and remits all governmental taxes.
B. The park owner is prohibited from imposing any fee, charge or commission for the sale of a mobile home,
provided that if a mobile home owner requests the park owner or his agent to assist in securing a purchaser
6/5/2019 Sterling Codifiers, Inc.
https://www.sterlingcodifiers.com/codebook/index.php?book_id=502 251/767
for his mobile home, a commission may be accepted for such service subject only to the following
conditions:
1. That the exact amount of commission or fee shall be a percentage of the actual sales price of the mobile
home, and
2. That the maximum percentage figure for the services in the resale of the mobile home by the park owner
or his agent shall be set forth in writing prior to the sale. (1970 Code § 8-38.62)
3-8-16-16: MEETINGS OF TENANTS:
Meetings by tenants relating to mobile home living shall not be subject to prohibition by the park owner if such
meetings are held at reasonable hours and when facilities are available and not otherwise in use. (1970 Code
§ 8-38.63)
3-8-16-17: STATE ACT CONCURRENT:
Nothing in this Section 3-8-16 is meant to supersede the provisions of the Mobile Home Landlord and Tenant
Act of Illinois6, but shall apply concurrently therewith so that both shall be in effect within the City. (1970 Code
§ 8-38.64)
3-8-16-18: CITY ENFORCEMENT:
The City Council, in its discretion, may direct either the City Prosecutor or the City Attorney to prosecute
violations of, or bring necessary legal action to enforce, the provisions of this Section 3-8-16. (1970 Code § 8-
38.65)
3-8-17: PENALTY:
Any person who violates any provisions of this Chapter shall, unless otherwise provided, be fined not less than
fifty dollars ($50.00) nor more than five hundred dollars ($500.00), and each day's violation shall constitute a
separate offense. (1970 Code § 8-38.34; 1986 Code)
Chapter 9
FIREARMS DEALERS LICENSING; WEAPONS
3-9-1: DEFINITIONS:
As used in this chapter the following terms shall have the following meanings:
CITY CLERK: The clerk of the city of Countryside, Illinois.
ENGAGED IN THE BUSINESS: Has the same meaning as in 18 USC section 921(a)(21).
FIREARM: Has the same meaning as used in 430 Illinois Compiled Statutes 65/1.1.
FIREARMS DEALER: Any person licensed by the federal bureau of alcohol, tobacco and firearms as a "dealer"
pursuant to section 923(a)(3)(B) or section 923(a)(3)(C) of title 18 of the United States Code and possessing a
6/5/2019 Sterling Codifiers, Inc.
https://www.sterlingcodifiers.com/codebook/index.php?book_id=502 252/767
"type 01" federal license; and excluding any person licensed solely as a "collector" pursuant to section 923(b) of
title 18 of the United States Code and possessing only a "type 03" federal license.
GUN SHOW OR EVENT: Any bona fide show or exhibition conducted for a temporary, fixed time period not
exceeding three (3) days at a temporary location and sponsored by a national, state or local organization or any
affiliate of any such organization devoted to the collection, competitive use or other sporting use of firearms.
MAYOR: The mayor of the city of Countryside, Illinois.
PERSON: Any individual, public or private corporation, partnership, firm, society, or unincorporated association.
PUBLIC PARK: Any land or buildings set apart for public recreation and owned by any unit of government and
any land owned by the forest preserve district of Cook County.
SCHOOL: Any public or private elementary or secondary school, or community college. (Ord. 95-02-0, 1-11-
1995)
3-9-2: LICENSE AND PERMIT REQUIRED:
A. Any person licensed as a firearms dealer pursuant to federal law at premises located within the city shall
apply for and obtain a city firearms dealer's license pursuant hereto by March 15, 1995. A city firearms
dealer's license shall be required in addition to any other license required by law. Possession of a valid
federal firearms dealer's license shall be deemed proof of being engaged in an activity requiring a federal
firearms dealer's license and thus requiring a city firearms dealer's license.
B. Any person who sponsors a gun show or event within the city shall first obtain a permit for such show or
event. Application for a permit must be made no later than thirty (30) days prior to the date the show or
event is to take place. No permit shall be issued unless the show or event has also been recognized by the
Illinois department of state police. No more than four (4) permits shall be issued for the same location during
any six (6) month period.
C. Any person who becomes a federally licensed firearms dealer after the effective date hereof, and is required
hereunder to obtain a city firearms dealer's license, shall apply for such license within forty five (45) days of
receipt of the federal firearms dealer's license.
D. Any person licensed under federal law at more than one location within the city must obtain a city license for
each individual location. A separate application and license fee is required for each location.
E. No license issued hereunder shall be transferable or assignable to any other person or any other location,
except as provided in subsection 3-9-5D of this chapter. (Ord. 95-02-0, 1-11-1995)
3-9-3: LICENSE AND PERMIT ADMINISTRATION:
A. The city clerk shall administer the licensing of firearms dealers and the permitting of gun shows and events,
but the city council shall approve or deny all applications for licenses or permits and revoke existing licenses
and permits pursuant hereto.
1. The city council may promulgate reasonable rules, definitions and regulations necessary to carry out the
duties imposed hereunder, including, but not limited to, developing reasonable procedures consistent with
existing practices of licensing persons engaged in the business of dealing in firearms, and including
seeking the assistance of the city chief of police and the sheriff of Cook County as necessary to conduct
investigations or inspections in connection with this chapter.
6/5/2019 Sterling Codifiers, Inc.
https://www.sterlingcodifiers.com/codebook/index.php?book_id=502 253/767
2. Any rules or regulations promulgated hereunder shall be filed in the office of the city clerk and shall be
made available for public inspection. Copies shall be made available upon request and payment of a
reasonable fee as determined by the city council to cover the cost of providing the copy. (Ord. 95-02-0, 1-
11-1995)
3-9-4: LICENSE AND PERMIT FEE:
See section 3-1-13 of this title. (Ord. 00-38-0, 12-13-2000)
3-9-5: LICENSE AND PERMIT APPLICATION; ISSUANCE:
A. Application Requirements: All applications for a license or permit hereunder shall be made in writing to the
city clerk on a form provided for that purpose. In addition to any other information required by the city
council, each application for a license or permit shall contain:
1. The applicant's full name, residence and the address and telephone number where the person is
engaged in the business of dealing in firearms;
2. If the applicant is a corporation, the corporate name, business and principal place of business of the
applicant; the date and state of incorporation; and the names and residence addresses of the corporate
officers and its registered agent;
3. If the applicant is a partnership, the name and business address and telephone number of the principal
office or place of business; the names, addresses and telephone numbers of all partners; the name,
address and telephone number of a person authorized to receive notices issued pursuant hereto.
B. Additional Federal Requirements: The city council will not issue a firearms dealer's license to any person
who fails to provide proof of a valid federal firearms dealer's license and a valid firearm owner's identification
card issued by the state.
C. Not Issued In School And Public Park Areas: The city council will not issue a firearms dealer's license to any
person who is engaged in the business of dealing in firearms or any other activity requiring a federal
firearms dealer's license, or indicates an intention to do so, within 0.5 mile of the grounds of a school or
public park, measured from the property lines of the respective properties.
D. Grandfather Clause: The restriction on location contained in subsection C of this section shall not apply until
July 1, 1996, to any person who on the effective date hereof is engaged in the business of dealing in
firearms within 0.5 mile of the grounds of a school or public park, measured from the property lines of the
respective properties.
E. Posting Of License: Any license issued hereunder shall be posted and kept available on the premises
covered by the license or permit for inspection by the city police or code enforcement officer. All sales and
other business records relating to the activity for which a federal firearms dealer's license is required shall
also be made available for inspection upon the request of the Police or Code Enforcement Officer. (Ord. 95-
02-0, 1-11-95)
3-9-6: LICENSE DENIED OR REVOKED:
A. The City Council may deny an application for a license if the applicant fails to provide the information
required by, or is otherwise not in compliance with, any provisions hereof or any applicable rules or
6/5/2019 Sterling Codifiers, Inc.
https://www.sterlingcodifiers.com/codebook/index.php?book_id=502 254/767
regulations. Any person seeking to appeal the denial may do so by filing a written request for a hearing with
the office of the City Clerk. Such request must be filed within thirty (30) days of the denial, and a hearing
must be held within thirty (30) days of receipt of the request. The hearing shall be conducted in accordance
with the procedures provided herein.
B. The Mayor may revoke or suspend the license of any person who violates any provision hereof or rules or
regulations adopted pursuant hereto. Before any such revocation or suspension is imposed, the licensee
shall be notified by mail of the specific violation and the date for a hearing on the matter, to occur not fewer
than seven (7) days and not more than fourteen (14) days after the mailing of the notice. The hearing shall
be conducted in accordance with the procedures provided herein. (Ord. 95-02-0, 1-11-95)
3-9-7: HEARING PROCEDURES:
A. If a person wishes to appeal the decision of the Council to deny or the Mayor to revoke or suspend a license,
the Mayor shall appoint a hearing officer who shall conduct the hearing. The hearing officer is authorized to
conduct hearings concerning any matter covered by this Chapter and may determine factual and legal
matters raised by the parties to the hearing. However, neither the Mayor nor the hearing officer shall hear or
decide any claim that the City Council did not have the authority to enact this Code provision.
B. The hearing officer may:
1. Examine any books, papers, records or memoranda bearing upon the business or activities of the
licensee;
2. Request the Circuit Court to issue subpoenas requiring the attendance of any person having personal
knowledge of any contested issue;
3. Request the Circuit Court to issue subpoenas duces tecum for the production of books, records, papers
or memoranda;
4. Administer oaths;
5. Take testimony;
6. Make rulings as to the admissibility of evidence; and
7. Take any other action as may be required for the expeditious conduct of the hearing.
C. The hearing officer is not bound by the technical rules of evidence. No informality in any proceeding or in the
manner of taking testimony or receiving evidence shall invalidate any order, decision, ruling or
recommendation of the hearing officer or final decision of the Mayor.
D. The City's books, papers, records and memoranda or parts thereof may be proved in any hearing or legal
proceeding by the original documents or by reproduced copy under the certificate of the City Clerk. Without
further proof, the original documents or reproduced copy shall be admissible into evidence.
E. If the Circuit Court issues a subpoena duces tecum, the following rules shall apply:
1. Service shall be made as provided by the Illinois Civil Practice Law, 735 Illinois Compiled Statutes 5/2-
201 et seq.;
2. Fees of witnesses for attendance and travel shall be the same as the fees of witnesses before the Circuit
Court of Cook County and shall be paid after the witness is excused from further attendance;
6/5/2019 Sterling Codifiers, Inc.
https://www.sterlingcodifiers.com/codebook/index.php?book_id=502 255/767
F. Any party to a hearing may apply to any judge of the Circuit Court of this State for enforcement of any
subpoena or subpoena duces tecum issued by the hearing officer holding a hearing authorized by this
Chapter.
G. At any hearing held under this Chapter, the Council's initial decision to deny or the Mayor's initial decision to
revoke or suspend a license shall be prima facie correct and the person contesting the decision shall have
the burden of proving with books, records and other documentary evidence that it is incorrect.
H. At the conclusion of the hearing, the hearing officer shall make a recommendation to the council or mayor,
as the case may be. The council or mayor shall adopt, reject or modify the recommendation based on a
review of the record within thirty (30) days of receiving the hearing officer's recommendation, and shall issue
a final decision. The mayor shall give written notification to the licensee of the council's or mayor's decision
and the reasons for such decision.
I. A person seeking judicial review of the council's or mayor's final decision shall bear the cost of certification. If
the protesting party prevails on appeal, the city shall reimburse that party for the cost of certification.
J. Items constituting the record may include notices and demands; the initial decision; the written protest and
petition for hearing; all relevant pleadings, briefs and memoranda of law; evidence admitted at the hearing;
the transcribed testimony given at the hearing; the recommendation of the hearing officer; and the final
decision of the council or the mayor. (Ord. 95-02-0, 1-11-1995)
3-9-8: ASSAULT WEAPONS BAN:
A. Definitions: The following words, terms and phrases, when used in this chapter, shall have the meanings
ascribed to them in this section, except where the context clearly indicates a different meaning:
ANTIQUE FIREARM: 1. Any firearm (including any firearm with a matchlock, flintlock, percussion cap, or
similar type of ignition system) manufactured in or before 1898; and
2. Any replica of any firearm described in subsection 1 of this definition if such replica is not designed or
redesigned for using rimfire or conventional centerfire fixed ammunition, or uses rimfire or
conventional centerfire fixed ammunition which is no longer manufactured in the United States and
which is not readily available in the ordinary channels of commercial trade.
ASSAULT WEAPON: 1. A semiautomatic rifle that has the capacity to accept a large capacity magazine
detachable or otherwise and one or more of the following:
a. Only a pistol grip without a stock attached;
b. Any feature capable of functioning as a protruding grip that can be held by the nontrigger hand;
c. A folding, telescoping or thumbhole stock;
d. A shroud attached to the barrel, or that partially or completely encircles the barrel, allowing the
bearer to hold the firearm with the nontrigger hand without being burned, but excluding a slide that
6/5/2019 Sterling Codifiers, Inc.
https://www.sterlingcodifiers.com/codebook/index.php?book_id=502 256/767
encloses the barrel; or
e. A muzzle brake or muzzle compensator.
2. A semiautomatic pistol or any semiautomatic rifle that has a fixed magazine, that has the capacity to
