may become unsafe or where any noisome, dangerous or unwholesome trade is carried on or which is
being used contrary to the zoning ordinances of the city, all nuisances and other matters affecting the
safety and convenience of the public, or in the interest of the city, and shall report the same to his
commanding officer. Where conditions are discovered which are immediately dangerous to life and limb,
he shall notify the desk officer at once, and do all in his power to remedy the condition and remove the
hazard. (1970 Code §3-1-8.9)
9. Reports: When at the station, at the time of roll call, he shall make a written report of all complaints
made to him directly, and which have not been previously reported to the department, and to which he
has given attention, and of all other information during the twenty four (24) hours preceding roll call which
requires a written report. (1970 Code §3-1-8.10)
10. Report Absence: He shall not leave his post except for some police or personal necessity. If required to
absent himself from his post, he shall enter in the memorandum book as soon as possible the
circumstances of said absence, the time of departure and return. He shall notify his commanding officer
and make an inspection of his post to ascertain if any crime or depredation has been committed during his
6/5/2019 Sterling Codifiers, Inc.
https://www.sterlingcodifiers.com/codebook/index.php?book_id=502 305/767
absence. At no time shall he leave from within the limits of the city, except by permission of his
commanding officer. (1970 Code §3-1-8.11)
C. Selection And Authority As Corporals:
1. The designation of corporals will be made by the chief of police with the advice of the lieutenants and
sergeants. Such designation, established for internal control only, will be made exclusive of any existing
civil service lists and it is not intended nor shall it be concluded that such designation constitutes
promotion or creation of a rank within the police department nor that it is a usurpation of the powers or
authority vested in the board of fire and police commissioners by state statutes.
2. Patrolmen designated as corporals by the chief of police will serve in that capacity at the discretion and
pleasure of the chief of police and are subject to removal from that capacity without recourse.
3. Corporals shall function in the temporary capacity of sergeants in the absence of the sergeant and
lieutenant, or as ordered by the sergeant, lieutenant, or chief of police. All personnel are subject to
disciplinary action for the failure to carry out the lawful orders of the corporal when acting in this capacity.
4. One corporal shall be assigned to each shift.
5. Corporals will be identified by the wearing of silver colored collar devices of two (2) chevrons which shall
be worn on both long and short sleeve uniform shirts in the same manner as the sergeants chevrons are
worn. It shall be considered part of the official uniform of the designated officers.
6. Any officer designated by the chief of police as a corporal, shall consider such designation as an
opportunity to gain experience in a limited supervisory capacity. Designated officers will exercise every
opportunity to learn and will discuss problems and procedures with their sergeant and lieutenant in order
to increase their efficiency and effectiveness through the sharing of experience.
7. When both the lieutenant and sergeant are present for duty, they shall assign the corporal to any patrol
function they feel necessary for the best utilization of personnel. Unless otherwise stated by the lieutenant
or the sergeant, when neither of them is present at the scene of a call, the corporal shall be considered
the senior officer present for purposes of control. (Ord. 87-42-0, 7-22-1987)
4-1-7: RADIO OPERATOR - DESK OFFICER:
A. Position Created: There is hereby created the position of radio operator - desk officer who shall be a civilian
employee of the city, subject to the personnel policies contained in title 1, chapter 6, article A of this code.
Such employee is not, and shall not be considered for any purposes, a police officer or a member of the
police department notwithstanding use of the term "desk officer" and the fact that he or she shall be subject
to direction and supervision by the police chief and other police command personnel and certain rules and
regulations of the police department. All persons employed as radio operator - desk officers on the effective
date hereof shall immediately be classified as radio operator - desk officers and subject hereto.
B. Employment: The radio operator - desk officer shall be employed by the city council, upon such terms and
conditions as the council from time to time determines, from candidates submitted by the chief of police. The
securing, testing and selecting of a qualified candidate or candidates, whose name or names shall then be
submitted to the city council for employment, shall be done by or at the direction of the chief of police.
C. Duties And Responsibilities: The radio operator - desk officer shall operate the department radio and
switchboard, and receive, transmit and record calls as necessary; he or she shall check periodically all
prisoners and see that they are fed and exercised, and his or her duties, except in case of emergency, shall
be confined to the police station. The radio operator - desk officer shall also perform the duties of records
officer, as set forth in this code, when there is no records officer. The radio operator - desk officer shall be
responsible to the chief of police, or his designated command personnel, and shall be subject to the rules,
6/5/2019 Sterling Codifiers, Inc.
https://www.sterlingcodifiers.com/codebook/index.php?book_id=502 306/767
regulations, policies and general orders of the police department, insofar as they may be applicable to that
position. (Ord. 90-48-0, 12-19-1990)
4-1-8: ADMINISTRATIVE ASSISTANT:
A. Position Created: There is hereby created the position of administrative assistant officer who shall be a
civilian employee of the city, subject to the personnel policies contained in title 1, chapter 6, article A of this
code. Such employee is not, and shall not be considered for any purposes, a police officer or a member of
the police department notwithstanding use of the term "administrative assistant" and the fact that he or she
shall be subject to direction and supervision by the police chief and other police command personnel and
certain rules and regulations of the police department. All persons employed as administrative assistant on
the effective date hereof shall immediately be classified as administrative assistant and subject hereto.
B. Employment: The administrative assistant officer shall be employed by the city council, upon such terms and
conditions as the council from time to time determines, from candidates submitted by the chief of police. The
securing, testing and selecting of a qualified candidate or candidates, whose name or names shall then be
submitted to the city council for employment, shall be done by or at the direction of the chief of police.
C. Duties And Responsibilities: The administrative assistant officer shall assist the chief of police or deputy
chief in their administrative duties and, except in case of emergency, shall be confined to the police station.
The administrative assistant officer shall be responsible to the chief of police, or his designated command
personnel, and shall be subject to the rules, regulations, policies and general orders of the police
department, insofar as they may be applicable to that position. (Ord. 04-07-0, 2-11-2004)
4-1-9: RECORDS OFFICER:
The records officer shall have the following duties:
A. Generally: He shall be responsible for the photographing, fingerprinting, describing and otherwise recording
by other appropriate methods, of known offenders and suspects brought into the station, and for the proper
filing and keeping of all records of personal identification and information concerning known offenders and
suspects called to his attention. For this purpose, he shall supervise the activities of the department
photographer. (1970 Code §3-1-10.1)
B. Disposition Of Cases: He shall cause the accurate and complete posting to the appropriate criminal history
sheets filed in his division of the record of final disposition of all cases in the criminal court. (1970 Code §3-
1-10.2)
C. Photographs Issued: He shall keep a record of all photographs issued, showing the name of the original of
the photograph, to whom and upon whose order issued, date of delivery, return thereof, and if not returned,
the reasons therefor. Photographs shall be furnished to the state's attorney as may be required in cases in
the criminal court. The records of habitual criminals shall be given particular attention when such records
are admissible in evidence. (1970 Code §3-1-10.3)
D. Fingerprints At Scene Of Crime; Preservation Of Evidence: He shall cause latent fingerprints to be
photographed, plats and diagrams made, dead bodies fingerprinted and shall perform such other duties as
are required in connection with the preservation and recording of evidence at the scene of a crime. Copies
of fingerprints, criminal histories, and other personal identification of criminals shall be sent to the federal
bureau of investigation, Washington, D.C. and to the state bureau of identification, Springfield, Illinois.
6/5/2019 Sterling Codifiers, Inc.
https://www.sterlingcodifiers.com/codebook/index.php?book_id=502 307/767
Wherever possible, strict cooperation will be given to the Chicago bureau of identification. (1970 Code §3-1-
10.4)
E. Destroying Records: No photographs or records of the department shall be destroyed without the written
order of the chief of police. (1970 Code §3-1-10.5)
F. Grave Crimes: When circumstances require it, he shall personally visit the scene of crimes of unusual
character or great magnitude, and acquaint himself with the location and conditions in order that he may
better direct their investigation. He shall enforce the provisions of subsection D of this section regarding the
preservation of evidence, and shall cause verbatim statements to be taken of principal witnesses and
persons suspected or involved in serious crimes. (1970 Code §3-1-10.6)
G. Correspondence: He shall be responsible for the proper attention to all correspondence referred to him.
(1970 Code §3-1-10.7)
H. Reports: When requested by the chief of police, he shall prepare and submit such tabulations, statistical
presentations, charts, graphs and analyses as may be required. (1970 Code §3-1-10.12)
I. Records Division:
1. Management: The records division shall be managed by the chief of police. (1970 Code §3-1-10.8)
2. Keep Records: The records division will provide for the systematic filing and ready reproduction, when
required, of records, compilations and other information applicable to the prevention, repression and
detection of crime. (1970 Code §3-1-10.9)
3. Complaints Of Crimes: The records division shall maintain and keep complete and accurate files of all
complaints of crime known to the department, crimes declared unfounded following investigation, crimes
cleared by arrest, persons charged with commission of crimes, persons found guilty of lesser offenses,
and persons released by the department because no formal charges were brought against them, with
such classification as will enable the compilation of a monthly and annual report of offenses and persons
charged, according to the standards of the uniform crime reporting program of the federal bureau of
investigation. (1970 Code §3-1-10.10)
4. Information Requests: The officer in charge of the records division shall inquire into all requests for
information coming from sources other than official law enforcing agencies, judicial, penal or other
agencies, and shall satisfy himself that such information is not intended for use detrimental to the rights of
any individual, group or corporation. No information is to be given out without the consent of the
commanding officer. (1970 Code §3-1-10.11)
4-1-10: PLAINCLOTHESMEN:
A plainclothes patrolman shall have the following duties:
A. Roll Call Report: He shall report at roll call when going on duty unless otherwise instructed by competent
authority, and shall remain out during his tour of duty, except when the nature of his work requires his
presence in the station. At the completion of his tour of duty, he shall report at the station unless otherwise
ordered. (1970 Code §3-1-6.1)
B. Investigations:
6/5/2019 Sterling Codifiers, Inc.
https://www.sterlingcodifiers.com/codebook/index.php?book_id=502 308/767
1. Report: When assigned to a case, he shall report to his commanding officer, as required, such information
as may be secured. He shall keep a memorandum book in which he shall legibly record the details of all
cases investigated by him. These notes shall be retained in a designated file in the department. (1970
Code §3-1-6.2)
2. Supplementary Duties: He shall follow up all cases assigned to him. He shall interview complaints without
delay, and carefully ascertain the full facts and pertinent information concerning each case, and obtain an
accurate and complete description of property reported lost or stolen, and persons wanted. Unless the
case has been officially closed, he shall consult with the complainant from time to time concerning the
status of the case, especially with the view of discovering new information. (1970 Code §3-1-6.3)
3. Discretion: He shall be careful in his inquiries not to endanger unnecessarily the reputation of any person
who may be the subject of his investigation. (1970 Code §3-1-6.4)
4-1-11: COMMANDING OFFICERS:
Commanding officers shall have the following duties:
A. Subordinates To Be Sustained: Commanding officers:
1. Shall sustain their subordinates when they have acted within the scope of their authority.
2. Shall not censure, ridicule or discipline subordinates in the presence of other members of the police
department.
3. When it becomes necessary to criticize or discipline a subordinate, they shall notify said subordinate to
report at their offices.
4. Shall not be tyrannical in their conduct or use abusive or profane language to subordinates.
5. Shall be firm, kind and just, always being mindful that their duties are to enforce the law and not to punish
violators.
In all cases of insubordination, it shall be mandatory of the superior officer to immediately file a detailed
report with the chief of police. Failure of a superior officer to comply with this rule shall be considered
gross neglect of duty. (1970 Code §3-1-16.1)
B. Deaths: In case of death of members of the police department, commanding officers shall submit to the chief
of police a written report stating the time, place, date and cause of death and all circumstances connected
therewith listing names and addresses of all witnesses. (1970 Code §3-1-16.2)
C. Accountability: They shall be held accountable for the care and condition of all fixed and movable property
under their control and for the economical use of supplies. Waste shall not be tolerated. (1970 Code §3-1-
16.3)
4-1-12: TEMPORARY POLICEMEN:
A. Appointment And Qualifications: As provided by chapter 24, section 10-2.1-16 of the board of fire and police
commissioners act, up to ten (10) temporary policemen may be appointed by the board of fire and police
commissioners for a period of sixty (60) days in accordance with the statute. No single temporary policeman
can be appointed more than twice during any calendar year.
6/5/2019 Sterling Codifiers, Inc.
https://www.sterlingcodifiers.com/codebook/index.php?book_id=502 309/767
Such temporary policemen shall meet the standards of the board of fire and police commissioners for
original appointees, except that no written examination is required. (1970 Code §3-1-12.1)
B. Active Duty: Temporary policemen:
1. Shall serve on active duty when requested by the chief of police, through the board of fire and police
commissioners, whenever there are vacancies in the department or in time of emergency, and shall
receive such compensation as the city council shall prescribe. (1970 Code §3-1-12.2)
2. May be relieved of active duty by the board of fire and police commissioners, through the chief of police,
in the event their services are not required. (1970 Code §3-1-12.3)
4-1-13: RADIO EQUIPPED AUTOMOBILES:
A. Duties Of Department Members Generally: A member of the department assigned to patrol duty in an
automobile shall operate such machine in a careful manner and in such manner as will enable him to
observe any conditions or occurrences which may require his attention. He shall adhere to the system of
patrol prescribed for foot patrolmen, and all rules and regulations prescribed for the same when appropriate,
and not in conflict with the specific rules applying to officers assigned to automobile patrol.
A vehicle shall not be left running while unattended; nor shall the keys be left in the vehicle; and all officers
shall wear headgear at all times, when not riding in or driving a squad car. (1970 Code §3-1-9.1)
B. Radio Alarm, Action On: When a broadcast is received, the officer of a radio equipped automobile shall
immediately respond. He shall notify the desk officer of action taken as soon as possible, and make all
written reports as required. (1970 Code §3-1-9.2)
C. Radio Out Of Order: When a radio set in any department vehicle is out of order, the officer shall immediately
notify the desk officer, and also call him every thirty (30) minutes by telephone until proper radio service is
restored. (1970 Code §3-1-9.3)
D. Automobile Safeguards: When a radio equipped patrol automobile is standing idle, but is in service and
available for calls (if 2 man car), one officer of the squad shall always remain in the car to receive and act
upon any alarm that may be broadcast, unless urgent police business necessitates its abandonment. If it is
a one man car, the officer shall notify the desk officer of his location and remove the ignition key. If weapons
are left in the automobile, proper safety security precautions shall be taken. (1970 Code §3-1-9.4)
E. Reporting Damage: Whenever any damage occurs to a department vehicle or its equipment, or if the same
is involved in an accident, the patrol officer shall make an immediate detailed report to his commanding
officer. When such damage is due to the negligence of the officer, he shall be responsible for the same. He
shall immediately report to the commanding officer all needed repairs and maintenance requirements of the
machine assigned to him. The officers of a vehicle shall be held responsible for damage to said vehicle and
its equipment when entrusted to their care when such damage is clearly discoverable by the routine
inspection required at the beginning of the tour of duty. Commanding officers shall cause an inspection to be
made at regular intervals, and keep a record of said inspection. (1970 Code §3-1-9.5)
F. Passengers Authorized: Officers assigned to duty in any department vehicle shall not permit persons other
than authorized members of the department, or temporarily appointed police patrolmen to ride in said
vehicle, except such persons as are required to be conveyed in the performance of duty. Use for personal
purposes is prohibited. (1970 Code §3-1-9.6)
6/5/2019 Sterling Codifiers, Inc.
https://www.sterlingcodifiers.com/codebook/index.php?book_id=502 310/767
G. Transporting Sick Or Injured Persons: A sick or injured person, when conveyed by department vehicle, shall
be taken to the nearest available first aid station or hospital, and action taken should be reported to the
commanding officer. (1970 Code §3-1-9.7)
4-1-14: POLICE PENSION FUND:
The provisions of "an act to provide for the setting apart, formation and disbursement of a police pension fund
in cities and villages and incorporated towns having a population of not more than 200,000 inhabitants4"
approved June 14, 1909, as amended, are hereby adopted by the city. Three (3) copies of said act are on file in
the office of the city clerk and available for public use, inspection and examination. (1970 Code §3-2.1, as
amended)
4-1-15: POLICE PERSONNEL BENEFITS:
Police personnel benefits such as vacation accrual, holidays, personal leave days, sick leave, maternity leave,
and emergency leave, are governed by the police collective bargaining agreement from time to time in effect
between the city and the bargaining agent. (Ord. 03-28-0, 8-27-2003)
4-1-16: HEALTH INSURANCE COVERAGE FOR RETIRED OFFICERS:
A. The city will provide coverage for a retired officer, other than a desk officer, after twenty (20) years' or more
service at age fifty five (55) or older, at fifty percent (50%) of the premium.
B. If an officer, other than a desk officer, has twenty (20) years' service and retires before he reaches fifty five
(55) years of age, he has the option of keeping his coverage. The city will carry him on its plan, and the
retiree will reimburse the city for his premiums.
C. Desk officers shall be covered by insurance and retirement benefits provided through the Illinois municipal
retirement fund. (1970 Code §3-1-13.7, as amended)
4-1-17: GENERAL RULES OF CONDUCT:
17.01
Interpretation: In the event any of the rules and regulations adopted herein by the mayor and city
council shall be in conflict with any statutes of the state of Illinois, the statutes of the state shall
govern, and such rules and regulations as may be in conflict are to be read and interpreted in
accordance with the state statutes. (1970 Code §3-1-14.1)
17.02
Knowledge Of Rules: Members of the police department shall acquaint themselves with all state
laws, city ordinances, rules and regulations of the board of fire and police commissioners and rules
of the chief of police pertaining to the police department, and shall strictly comply with same. (1970
Code §3-1-14.2)
17.03
Conduct: No member of the police department shall conduct himself in a manner unbecoming a
police officer or employee of the police department. All members of the department shall at all
times conduct themselves as gentlemen (and ladies) and shall be courteous in their conversation
and actions with citizens, and no member of the police department shall conduct himself in a
careless or malicious manner whereby a citizen is injured or damage caused to his property. No
police officer will associate with or keep company with a known criminal or ex-convict. (1970 Code
§3-1-14.3)
6/5/2019 Sterling Codifiers, Inc.
https://www.sterlingcodifiers.com/codebook/index.php?book_id=502 311/767
17.04
Obey Orders: All police officers shall promptly and speedily obey and execute all orders of a
superior officer, and strictly adhere to the chain of command whenever possible. (1970 Code §3-1-
14.4)
17.05
Obey Aides: All members of the department shall observe and enforce the order of an acting
superior officer in charge. (1970 Code §3-1-14.5)
17.06
Courtesy: Subordinates shall recognize the authority vested in superior officers and shall observe
such authority on all occasions. All members of the police department, when addressing one
another, shall use the full title and at no time shall use abbreviations. (1970 Code §3-1-14.6)
17.07
Police Officer Always On Duty: Members of the department shall be considered as being on duty at
all times. They shall be subject to special calls and special details upon the order of a superior
officer at any time of the day or night, whether on or off duty; provided, however, that certain hours
shall be designated as the working hours for each member of the department for the performance
of police duty. It shall be the duty of all members of the department to respond and perform police
duty at any time of the day or night, whether on or off duty, where he has the knowledge that an
emergency exists and his services are required, whether notified by a superior officer or not. (1970
Code §3-1-14.7)
17.08
Absence From Duty: When a policeman is absent from his regularly assigned duty, he shall, in all
cases, fill out the absentee report and file same with his commanding officer upon returning to duty.
If absence is due to illness, then a doctor's report, if required, shall be attached to the absentee
report. When disability prevents the absent person from making out his report, the chief of police
shall be responsible for the completion and filing of this report, stating in detail the reasons for the
inability of the absent person. Trading of days off shall not be permitted except upon the consent of
the chief of police. (1970 Code §3-1-14.8)
17.09
Unauthorized Absence: If no proper notification of absence is given and a member of the police
department is absent for five (5) successive calendar days, he shall be deemed to have resigned
and shall forfeit all of his rights and privileges as a member of the police department. At the
conclusion of the fifth day of absence, the chief of police shall notify the board of fire and police
commissioners in writing, and the board, after due consideration, shall notify the person involved
and he shall be dropped from the payroll of the city. (1970 Code §3-1-14.9)
17.10
Furlough, Requests: A furlough is an authorized absence from duty by a policeman without pay for
a period not exceeding thirty (30) days, for reasons of health and welfare to himself or his
immediate family. Requests for furlough shall be considered by the board of fire and police
commissioners upon receipt of a written request (3 copies) giving full details and properly approved
by the chief of police. A man on furlough shall not engage in any other employment, and shall
notify the chief of the police department for reassignment three (3) days before the expiration of his
furlough. If he shall fail to return to his duty at the expiration of his furlough, for five (5) consecutive
calendar days, he may be dropped from the department after due consideration by the board of fire
and police commissioners. (1970 Code §3-1-4.10)
17.11
Leaving Post: No member of the department shall leave his post without being regularly relieved or
without permission. (1970 Code §3-1-14.11)
17.12
Attention To Duty: All members of the department shall be attentive to their duties. (1970 Code §3-
1-14.12)
17.13
Negligence: No member of the police department shall neglect his duty or duties, or perform them
in an inefficient or careless manner, ever mindful that such carelessness or inefficient performance
of duty may cause serious results. (1970 Code §3-1-14.13)
17.14
Asleep While on Duty: No member of the police department shall sleep on duty, under any
conditions. (1970 Code §3-1-14.14)
17.15
False Report: No member of the police department shall make a false report, either verbal or
written. (1970 Code §3-1-14.15)
17.16
Drug or Alcohol Use: Members of the police department shall be subject to disciplinary procedure
for the excessive or habitual:
1. Use of drugs, such as:
Narcotics
6/5/2019 Sterling Codifiers, Inc.
https://www.sterlingcodifiers.com/codebook/index.php?book_id=502 312/767
Sedatives in excess
Antihistamines in excess
Stimulants, excessive or chronic use of Benzedrine or Dexedrine
2. Alcohol, chronic or excessive.
No member of the Department shall drink intoxicating beverages while on duty or immediately prior
to a regular tour of duty. (1970 Code §3-1-14.16; 1986 Code)
17.17
Driving of Police Motor Vehicle: No member of the Police Department shall drive any motor vehicle
in a careless, reckless or malicious manner. In case of an accident, he shall, as soon as possible,
make out a written report to the officer in charge of his shift, stating the nature of business at the
time of the accident, giving the date, time, place and cause; the names and addresses of all people
involved; the names and addresses of all witnesses; what disposition was made of the injured; and
what damage there was to his assigned vehicle or to any other property involved. In case the driver
of the police vehicle is unable to make out this report, then the officer in charge of the shift shall be
responsible for investigating and making out this report.
Commanding officers of the shift where a police accident takes place shall immediately put into
action a separate personal investigation and this written report shall be personally put before the
Chief of Police as soon as possible with all pertinent information thereof and what action was
taken. (1970 Code §3-1-14.17)
17.18
Residence and Telephone: All members of the Police Department shall notify the Chief of Police of
their address and telephone number. They shall notify the Chief of Police and the Board of Fire and
Police Commissioners of any change in their residence address or telephone number. All members
are required to have telephones.
17.19
Discipline: Members of the Department shall:
1. Not use course, profane or insolent language in their conversation with citizens or members of
the Department;
2. At all times be clean and neat in their appearance;
3. Be punctual;
4. Promptly comply with all the Rules and Regulations of the Police Department.
Superior officers shall be responsible for correcting improper conduct of their subordinates, for
instituting corrective and disciplinary action, and shall report all violations of the Rules and
Regulations of the Police Department to the Chief of Police in writing. (1970 Code §3-1-14.19)
17.20
Interference of Discipline: No member of the Police Department shall affiliate himself with a clique
or group of members of the Department, the result of which activity or whose purpose is to disturb
and interfere with the orderly procedure of Department business. (1970 Code §3-1-14.20)
17.21
Insubordination: Members of the Police Department shall not be insubordinate or disrespectful to a
superior officer. In all cases of insubordination, it shall be mandatory for the superior officer to
immediately file a written report with the Chief of the Police Department. All members of the Police
Department shall be subject to the orders of their superior officers and shall observe and comply
with the same. (1970 Code §3-1-14.21)
17.22
Criticizing: Members of the Police Department shall not discuss or criticize publicly, or in private,
the personal habits, religious beliefs, character or conduct, or the official actions of other members
of the Police Department. Constructive criticism is to be directed to the Chief of Police. (1970 Code
§3-1-14.22)
17.23
Enforcement of Laws:
1. Every member of the Police Department shall be charged with the enforcement within the City of
all laws, ordinances and Rules and Regulations of the Department. Every policeman shall have the
duty of taking cognizance of all known or suspected gambling houses or houses of ill fame or other
nuisances, and make every effort to eliminate such places and arrest the offenders. Police officers
shall keep themselves informed as to meetings and gatherings likely to attract large numbers of
persons and shall take steps necessary to provide police services for such assemblies.
2. The Police Department shall be responsible for suppression of riots and public disturbances.
3. The Police Department shall keep records of known criminals and law violators and keep such
persons under reasonable surveillance. Police officers shall not sit, lounge or loaf during their tour
6/5/2019 Sterling Codifiers, Inc.
https://www.sterlingcodifiers.com/codebook/index.php?book_id=502 313/767
of duty.
4. Police officers shall not conceal themselves except for some police purposes.
5. Each policeman shall have the duty to see that sidewalks and street corners in the City are not
obstructed by loitering. Whenever any person shall obstruct a sidewalk in the City, it shall be the
duty of the police officers to courteously request them to move on, and if they fail to do so, to prefer
charges under the applicable City ordinance.
6. Every police officer shall familiarize himself with the location and purpose of all street trafficcontrol
signals, and shall report any that have been misplaced or tampered with. Every police
officer shall be completely familiar with the City with particular reference to public buildings. (1970
Code §3-1-14.23; 1986 Code)
17.24
Daily Bulletin: All members of the Police Department shall carefully read the Duty Book daily, and
shall observe the instructions therein contained relating to the duties of their positions. Special
attention shall be given to the descriptions of criminals wanted and of missing persons and
property.
17.25
Name and Number: When requested to do so, a member of the Department shall give his name,
rank and official star number to the person requesting same. (1970 Code §8-1-14.25)
17.26
Loitering in Police Station: No persons other than those transacting police business shall be
permitted in or about the police station or building of the Police Department. Police officers shall
not lounge or appear to sleep in or about the police station or squad cars at any time, except in the
squad room or other proper place. (1970 Code §3-1-14.26)
17.27
Correspondence, Request: A copy of all correspondence or request may be made to the Board of
Fire and Police Commissioners by any member of the Police Department, and a copy sent to the
Chief of Police. The Chief may note his comments if he so desires. (1970 Code §3-1-14.27)
17.28
Leaving City: No members of the Police Department shall leave the City limits during duty hours,
except on official business. In all cases during time off in excess of twenty four (24) hours and
vacation periods, he shall notify his superior officer of such proposed absence and destination.
(1970 Code §3-1-14.28)
17.29
Use of Police Motor Vehicles for Personal Business: The use of police motor vehicles for personal
business is prohibited under any conditions. Police motor vehicles must be used strictly for police
business and no riders shall be permitted who are not in the performance of official police duties.
(1970 Code §3-1-14.29)
17.30
Rewards and Presents: No members of the Department:
1. May retain for his own benefit any reward or present tendered him for meritorious service
rendered by such member in the due discharge of his duty, without approval thereof of the City
Council.
2. Shall accept any fee, reward or gift of any kind from persons arrested or from any friend in his
behalf while he is in custody or after his release or discharge. Members of the Police Department
shall not accept presents or gifts from other members of the Police Department, groups, clubs,
associations, societies, citizens, lodges or political parties. (1970 Code §3-1-14.30)
17.31
Accept Awards: No member of the Police Department shall accept or receive any rewards or gifts
from any person, firm, corporation, association, society, lodge, political party or other body of
persons for service rendered or to be rendered as a member of the Police Department, except
regularly posted rewards, which shall in all cases be approved first by the City Council before their
acceptance. Should rewards or gifts come into the possession of a member of the Police
Department under conditions beyond the member's control, the Chief of Police shall be
immediately notified and he shall make such disposition as he shall see fit. (1970 Code §3-1-14.31;
1986 Code)
17.32
Bribes: No member of the Police Department shall accept bribes in any form of money, gifts or
other articles of apparent or actual value. (1970 Code §3-1-14.32)
17.33
Soliciting of Funds, Donations, Gifts, Etc.: No member of the Police Department shall solicit funds,
donations, gifts, etc., or cause any member's name to be used or authorize any organization or
person to solicit funds, donations or gifts in any member's behalf, for any purpose whatsoever,
without first getting the written approval of the Chief of Police. (1970 Code §3-1-14.33; 1986 Code)
6/5/2019 Sterling Codifiers, Inc.
https://www.sterlingcodifiers.com/codebook/index.php?book_id=502 314/767
17.34
Debts: Members of the Police Department shall honor all just obligations and indebtedness owed
by such members, and said member shall not incur or become liable for obligations which he, in
the reasonable course of events, could not contemplate meeting at maturity.
All correspondence regarding nonpayment of debts may be forwarded to the Board of Fire and
Police Commissioners in the discretion of the Chief of Police. (1970 Code §3-1-14.34)
17.35
Wage Assignment: No member of the Police Department shall sell or assign any wages to be
received from the Police Department. (1970 Code §3-1-14.35)
17.36
Altercations: Members of the Police Department shall refrain from physical altercations, except in
line of duty, and shall not maltreat any person or prisoner. (1970 Code §3-1-14.36)
17.37
Political Activity: No member of the Police Department shall be a delegate to or member of any
political party or party convention, and shall not take part in political campaigns or solicit
contributions, workers, or votes for any political party, club or association. No member of the Police
Department shall make a contribution to any political party, club or association or for any other
political purpose. (1970 Code §3-1-14.37)
17.38
Promotion: No officer or member of the Police Department shall, directly or indirectly, solicit the
support of any person or persons in order to effect his promotion. (1970 Code §3-1-14.38)
17.39
Game of Chance: Members of the Police Department shall not engage in any games of chance for
stakes or wagers, while on or off duty. (1970 Code §3-1-14.39)
17.40
Uniform:
1. Specifications: Each member of the Police Department shall be provided with a police uniform
made in accordance with specifications on file at headquarters. A uniform shall be subject to
inspection and approval by the commanding officer or other inspecting officer as designated by the
Chief of Police. City monetary allowances for purchase and replacement of equipment shall be
administered by and at the discretion of the Chief of Police. The Chief of Police shall from time to
time supply members of the Police Department with specifications and the requirements for
uniforms and other police equipment. Socks shall be solid black, unless otherwise specified by the
Chief of Police.
2. Time for Wearing Uniform: Police officers shall dress in full uniform, including hat, during their
tour of duty and when attending to police business, such as court hearings, trial board cases, etc.,
unless excused by the Chief of Police. Uniforms shall be worn in a clean, neat appearance at all
times. When attending court, if said officer is on duty, he shall wear his uniform; if he attends court
on his day off, he shall wear a suit and tie while attending court. (1970 Code §3-1-14.40)
17.41
Purchase of Uniform From Other Police Officer: Police officers shall not purchase or wear police
uniforms of other officers, without the approval of the Chief of Police. (1970 Code §3-1-14.41)
17.42
Official Police Department Weapons: A police officer shall provide himself or herself with an official
City Police Department weapon which may be either a Sig Sauer P26, 9 mm semi-automatic
weapon or a Glock 9 mm semi-automatic weapon. A police officer in uniform shall carry his or her
weapon forward of the outside trouser seam, in a holster on a belt. All weapons must be kept clean
and in perfect order at all times.
17.43
Weapons, Loss of: The loss of weapons by police officers shall immediately be reported, in writing,
to headquarters and to the Chief of Police, giving details of loss thereof. (Ord. 90-06-0, 3-14-90)
17.44
Stars, Wearing of, Loss: Police officers, when in uniform, shall wear their stars upon the left side of
the chest, on the outer garment of such uniforms. No shield or unauthorized badge shall be worn
on the uniform at any time. Officers shall not trade stars or cap devices with one another, either
permanently or temporarily. All members of the Department shall immediately report, in writing, to
the Chief of Police, giving full details, the loss of any star or shield, and the same procedure shall
be followed in the loss of police identification cards. (1970 Code §3-1-14.44)
17.45
Equipment: The equipment of a police officer shall consist of an official badge (star), cap shield,
identification card, identification name plate, whistle, loaded revolver, holster, and twelve (12)
rounds of extra ammunition, loose leaf report book and pencil. The foregoing equipment shall be
carried by a uniformed police officer during his tour of duty. All equipment issued to a police officer
shall remain the property of the City, and shall be taken up by a commanding officer in case a
police officer becomes separated from the Department. Commanding officers, in case of death of
6/5/2019 Sterling Codifiers, Inc.
https://www.sterlingcodifiers.com/codebook/index.php?book_id=502 315/767
members of the Police Department, shall take up all City property held by such deceased officer
and forward same to the Chief of Police. (1970 Code §3-1-14.45)
17.46
Giving Information Prohibited: A member of the Department will not give out any information
relating to police officers or police business without the approval of the Chief of Police. (1970 Code
§3-1-14.46)
17.47
Prohibited Communications: Except on express permission of the Chief of Police, no member of
the Department shall address any communication pertaining to police business to an official of the
City, any other department of the City, or other person or persons. This does not apply to written
communication addressed to the Board of Fire and Police Commissioners. (1970 Code §3-1-
14.47)
17.48
General Offenses: No member of the Police Department shall be guilty of any of the following
activities:
1. Immoral conduct;
2. Violation of any statute or ordinance;
3. Sleeping on duty;
4. Leaving post without being properly relieved;
5. Use of profane language;
6. Insubordination or disrespect to a superior officer;
7. Maltreatment of any person;
8. Falsifying any report;
9. Failure to wear and maintain a proper uniform and a neat and tidy appearance;
10. Soliciting any funds without proper permission of the Chief of Police;
11. Neglect to pay within a reasonable time a just indebtedness. (1970 Code §3-1-14.48)
17.49
Resignation: All members of the Police Department shall give fifteen (15) days' notice, in writing, to
the Chief of Police, with a copy to the Board of Fire and Police Commissioners, of their intention to
resign. Any member withdrawing from the Department, without proper notice to the Chief of Police,
shall be thereafter deemed disqualified to again become a member of the police force. (1970 Code
§3-1-14.49)
17.50
Care of City Property: Police officers shall exercise diligence in their use of City property and shall
not, through their carelessness, cause the loss of, or do damage to, any City property. (1970 Code
§3-1-14.51)
17.51
Civil Defense:
1. Every member of the Police Department shall give full cooperation and assistance to our Civilian
Defense Program, when requested by that Department and approved by a superior officer of the
Police Department.
2. Any member of the Police Department who, through neglect or any action, is guilty of being
uncooperative, shall be subject to the disciplinary procedure as defined in the Rules and
Regulations of the Board of Fire and Police Commissioners. (1970 Code §3-1-14.52)
17.52
Care of Vehicles: Police officers in charge of automobiles shall be responsible for keeping vehicles
in a neat and clean condition and fully supplied at all times with the required equipment, and if
same is not found in perfect condition, shall at once report to their commanding officer. They shall
make the required reports without delay. (1970 Code §3-1-14.53; 1986 Code)
17.53
Duties of Officers in Charge of Automobile and Crew: Police officers in charge of automobile crews
patrolling zones or districts shall be responsible for the proper performance of patrol duty, and the
senior regular police officer shall be in charge. (1970 Code §3-1-14.54)
17.54
Accidents: Whenever vehicles or other property is damaged, or persons are injured by police
vehicles, the police officer in charge shall designate a police officer to remain and render
assistance, ascertain the exact extent of the damage to property, the injury to persons, and submit
a full report of same to the commanding officer. The commanding officer shall make a thorough
investigation and file charges where police are at fault. (1970 Code §3-1-14.55; 1986 Code)
17.55 Duties of Drivers: Drivers shall be responsible for the proper working condition of police vehicles
6/5/2019 Sterling Codifiers, Inc.
https://www.sterlingcodifiers.com/codebook/index.php?book_id=502 316/767
during their tour of duty. Drivers shall respond to calls promptly and expediently as safety will
permit. They shall not drive faster than the legal speed limit, except in the immediate pursuit of
criminals or other cases of urgent necessity. They shall be governed by orders relating to the
proper care of police vehicles and submit the required reports.
A vehicle shall not be left running while unattended, nor shall the keys be left in the vehicle. (1970
Code §3-1-14.56)
17.56
Special Training: It shall be the duty of all members of the Police Department to fully cooperate and
submit themselves for further training as prescribed by their superior officers, such as first aid,
civilian defense programs and such other training that may be considered necessary. (1970 Code
§3-1-14.57)
17.57
Neglect of Duty: No member of the Police Department shall neglect any duty or fail to perform the
duties required of the Police Department in the Rules and Regulations contained herein. (1970
Code §3-1-14.58)
17.58
Radio Communications: Radio communications shall be used for official business only. Radio
conversation shall be in a direct, business-like manner. The use of disrespectful, slurring or profane
language is prohibited. (1970 Code §3-1-14.59)
17.59
Appear as a Witness: Members of the Police Department, subpoenaed or requested to appear for
the defense or in the prosecution of any court proceeding, shall immediately report to the Chief of
Police for appropriate action. (1970 Code §3-1-14.60)
17.60
Other Rules: In addition to the Rules and Regulations herein set forth, all laws of the State of
Illinois, ordinances of the City, Federal statutes, and Department Rules and Regulations pertaining
to and affecting police officers, and the general Rules of the Board of Fire and Police
Commissioners, shall be by this reference Rules and Regulations of the Police Department, and all
police officers shall be subject thereto. (1970 Code §3-1-14.61)
4-1-18: POWERS AND DUTIES:
A. General Duties and Authority:
1. It shall be the duty of all police officers to enforce all Federal and State laws and the ordinances of the
City, and to perform all duties imposed upon them by the laws of the United States of America, the State
of Illinois, ordinances of the City, Rules and Regulations of the Police Department and Rules and
Regulations of the Board of Fire and Police Commissioners of the City. (1970 Code §3-1-15.1)
2. Police officers governed by the Rules and Regulations of the Board of Fire and Police Commissioners
shall have such authority as may be granted them by the laws of the State of Illinois, ordinances of the
City and Federal statutes. (1970 Code §3-1-15.12)
B. Duties and Power to Arrest: All members of the Police Department, when on duty, shall devote their entire
time and attention to discharging the duties of a policeman according to the laws and ordinances of the City
and the Rules and Regulations of the Police Department. Police officers shall preserve the peace, order and
quiet and enforce the laws and ordinances throughout the City. (1970 Code §3-1-15.2)
C. Force, Exercise of Discretion: Police officers shall discharge their duties in a discreet and orderly manner. No
more force shall be used than is necessary to make arrests. (1970 Code §3-1-15.3)
D. Care and Booking of Prisoners:
1. Taking to Court: Police officers shall, without delay, book and arrange to take before a judge all persons
arrested by them, except where such persons are being held on orders of the Chief of Police or the
commanding officer for investigation. (1970 Code §3-1-15.4)
6/5/2019 Sterling Codifiers, Inc.
https://www.sterlingcodifiers.com/codebook/index.php?book_id=502 317/767
2. Notifying Friends: The desk clerk shall, when persons are booked and held, when requested, notify
prisoners' relatives or friends so that they may obtain bail. Under no circumstances shall police officers or
employees of the Police Department make any charge or accept any fee, money or reward for conveying
or sending messages of any nature. (1970 Code §3-1-15.5)
3. Females in Care of Matrons or Policewomen: Female prisoners shall, as soon as possible, be placed in
the care of matrons or policewomen and shall, while in custody of a policeman, be chaperoned by
matrons and policewomen. (1970 Code §3-1-15.6)
4. Searching Prisoners: Police officers shall, before placing persons in a cell, thoroughly search and take all
personal property from them and turn same over to the desk clerk, who shall give such prisoner a receipt
therefor. The arresting officer shall inventory the property taken from the prisoner in the presence of said
prisoner. Receipts shall not be given for concealed weapons or property alleged to have been stolen,
which may be used as evidence. It shall be the duty of the police officer making the search to request the
prisoner to sign said receipt. (1970 Code §3-1-15.8)
E. Juveniles: Children who come within the jurisdiction of the Juvenile Law5 and are under the age of twelve
(12) shall, under no circumstances, be placed in any cell, prison or other place of confinement. Such
children shall be brought to the attention of the Police Juvenile Office as quickly as possible, so that they
may be disposed of according to the provisions of said Juvenile Law. (1970 Code §3-1-15.7)
F. Recovered Property:
1. Not Held as Evidence: All recovered, lost or stolen property shall at once be inventoried on forms
provided for that purpose, and filed with the Chief of Police without delay, except when held as evidence.
(1970 Code §3-1-15.9)
2. Held as Evidence: Property held as evidence shall be inventoried, as required in the previous subsection,
and held at police headquarters until the case is disposed of in the courts. (1970 Code §3-1-15.10)
G. Warrants for Assault Upon Police Officers: Police officers shall not apply for warrants for assault upon
themselves without reporting the case to the Chief of Police. Police officers detailed to make warrants shall
not draw up complaints or warrants against police officers without first informing the Chief of Police. (1970
Code §3-1-15.11)
H. Fires:
1. Establish Fire Lines, Protect Recovered Property: Police officers in command at fires shall cause streets,
alleys and other places in the vicinity of such fires to be cleared of persons and obstructions. They shall
allow no one except firemen, reporters and officials to pass. A space inside of the fire lines shall be
reserved for the deposit of salvaged property, and police officers in command shall cause the property to
be properly protected. (1970 Code §3-1-15.13)
2. Ascertain if Incendiary: Police officers first arriving at a fire shall, if possible, in all cases, be particular to
ascertain the exact location where fires originate. If they believe fires to be incendiary, they shall at once
note in their memorandum book all information concerning the origin of the fire which would aid the
investigation thereof, and in the prosecution of persons responsible. (1970 Code §3-1-15.14)
I. Reporting Accidents, Stolen Automobiles:
1. When police officers are at the scene of an accident, or their attention is called to an accident, they shall,
after rendering first aid, apprehend the person responsible for the accident. Such officer shall obtain the
necessary information concerning said accident and make a full report to headquarters. (1970 Code §3-1-
15.15)
6/5/2019 Sterling Codifiers, Inc.
https://www.sterlingcodifiers.com/codebook/index.php?book_id=502 318/767
2. Police officers, when informed of the theft of an automobile, shall obtain full information in regard to same.
(1970 Code §3-1-15.16)
4-1-19: SECONDARY EMPLOYMENT:
A. Purpose: It is the purpose of this Section to:
1. Define secondary employment.
2. Delineate Department policy relating to secondary employment.
3. Outline procedures to be followed by members when requesting approval to engage in secondary
employment.
4. Enumerate general restrictions pertaining to secondary employment.
5. Provide information regarding expiration or cancellation of a member's permit to engage in secondary
employment.
6. Prescribe responsibilities of members and supervisory officers relating to secondary employment. (1970
Code §3-3.1)
B. Definition: "Secondary employment" shall mean the performance of any service which results in, or is
anticipated to result in, payment of money or goods; or participation and/or exercise of control in any
enterprise, public or private, which results in, or is anticipated to result in, profits of money, goods or
services. Financial investments in an enterprise which do not entail the performance of service are excluded
from this definition. (1970 Code §3-3.2)
C. Policy: Officers who wish to engage in secondary employment or business enterprise will recognize that their
primary professional responsibility is to the Police Department. Officers are subject to call at any time for
special assignments or emergencies; and are responsible for the thorough, efficient performance of their
official duties. Neither secondary employment nor business enterprise will be permitted to infringe on these
professional obligations.
1. Personnel performing services for a secondary employer shall provide this Department with a letter from
said employer stating:
a. Secondary employer is liable for workmen's compensation benefits while such employee is working for
said employer.
b. Secondary employer provides indemnity for said employee against damage suits, or other legal
expenses incurred as a result of duties.
c. The Police Department has first option on services of said employee.
2. A member of the Department will not exercise the authority of a Countryside police officer as a function of
secondary employment in a security capacity without the express written permission of the Chief of Police
and the Board of Fire and Police Commissioners. Employment must be within the City limits.
3. Members performing priority functions shall not wear any part of a Countryside police uniform, badge or
insignia while performing said duties.
4. Permission will be granted for secondary employment that does not exceed twenty (20) hours' work per
week.
6/5/2019 Sterling Codifiers, Inc.
https://www.sterlingcodifiers.com/codebook/index.php?book_id=502 319/767
5. All secondary employment must be cleared through the office of the Chief of Police and forwarded to the
Board of Fire and Police Commissioners for action. (1970 Code §3-3.3)
D. Procedures:
1. A member seeking approval to engage in secondary employment at any time, including during annual
and time-due furloughs, will complete a secondary employment request, filling out a form which shall be
provided by the Police Department.
a. The Department member will submit the secondary employment request to the Chief of Police at least
five (5) days prior to the requested effective date.
b. The requesting member will describe, in detail, the exact nature of employment in the "Remarks"
section of said request form. This will include the actual work location, work schedule, and the number
of hours per day and type of work.
c. If the request is to engage in secondary employment with more than one employer, complete
information relating to each secondary employment position will be entered on an individual request.
d. Whenever there is a change in the condition of any approved secondary employment, a new request
will be prepared to report such changes.
2. The Chief of Police will review the request, may consult with the member's immediate supervisor to
ascertain that the individual's work activity is satisfactory (a poor work record during a member's normal
duty assignment will result in disapproval of the request), will verify that the member is not disqualified by
any of the restrictions contained in this directive, and will indicate his approval or disapproval. A copy of
the request will be retained by the officer and the original will be forwarded through channels to the Board
of Fire and Police Commissioners for their approval. The decision of the Board of Fire and Police
Commissioners will be transmitted to the Chief, and the Chief will advise the member, in writing, of the
decision, and in the case of disapproval the reasons the request was disapproved.
3. In the event that an immediate "one day only" secondary employment arises, such as acting as a guard at
a church affair, social event or business affair, the member must submit a completed request form within
forty eight (48) hours of said event and it will be retained for a three (3) month period. All requests for
secondary employment must be submitted to the Chief of Police with a copy forwarded to the Board of
Fire and Police Commissioners. The Chief shall approve or disapprove all such requests. (1970 Code §3-
3.4; 1986 Code)
E. Restrictions: A request for secondary employment will be denied/revoked under any of the following
conditions:
1. Where there is an actual use of official police authority or services to solicit or conduct business for a fee.
2. When a member is classified as a probationary employee for one year.
3. When it appears from a member's medical absence record, or other evidence, that secondary
employment will impair the member's ability to carry out his assigned duties.
4. When the secondary employment would exceed twenty (20) hours per week. (This does not apply to
annual or time-due furlough periods.)
5. When the working conditions, hours of work, or location where the secondary employment is performed
tend to impair the member's efficiency or capabilities as an employee of the Department or interfere with
the member's response to emergency calls. A member should provide a sufficient amount of time
between secondary employment and the start of a tour of duty to allow for ample rest and relaxation (4
hours).
6/5/2019 Sterling Codifiers, Inc.
https://www.sterlingcodifiers.com/codebook/index.php?book_id=502 320/767
6. When the secondary employment would involve any connection whatsoever with any establishment
where the primary business is the sale of intoxicating liquor.
7. When the secondary employment would require the member to avail himself of official police equipment,
records, documents or files.
8. When the secondary employment would result at any time in a conflict of interest (e.g. conduct a defense
investigation for a litigant in a suit against the City Police Department).
9. When a member is on the medical roll for any reason (temporarily revoked until the member is restored to
duty), unless authorized by the Chief of Police and the Board of Fire and Police Commissioners. (1970
Code §3-3.5)
F. Expiration of Authorization and Renewal of Requests:
1. Permission to engage in secondary employment automatically expires after twelve (12) months, if it is not
renewed.
2. A request for renewal will be filed at least ten (10) days prior to the expiration date of the currently
approved request.
3. A request for renewal of secondary employment with more than one employer will include all information
pertaining to each secondary employment position on individual request forms. (1970 Code §3-3.6)
G. Cancellation:
1. The Chief of Police may cancel a member's permit to engage in secondary employment at any time for
good cause, a copy to be forwarded to the Board of Fire and Police Commissioners.
2. When secondary employment interferes with a member's ability to perform his duties, supervisory officers
shall request cancellation of the member's permit to engage in secondary employment. A written request,
setting forth reasons for requesting cancellation, will be forwarded to the Chief of Police and the Board of
Fire and Police Commissioners.
3. A member of the Department engaged in secondary employment with a company which is on strike could
become involved in a conflict of interest or labor dispute. Accordingly, secondary employment approval
will automatically be suspended during the term of the strike or when, by the nature of the secondary
employment, the member would be required to cross picket lines of an organization on strike.
H. Responsibilities:
1. Member:
a. A member will insure that an accurate description of his secondary employment is up-to-date at all
times. When the nature of the member's duties or business on his secondary employment changes, the
member will notify the Chief of Police by submitting a secondary employment request reporting such
changes. A copy is to be forwarded to the Board of Fire and Police Commissioners.
b. All members who desire to engage in secondary employment will recognize that their primary
responsibility is to the City Police Department. Members are subject to call at any time for emergencies,
special assignments or overtime duty. Secondary employment will not infringe on this obligation.
2. Supervisory Officers: Supervisory officers will continuously review the performance of their subordinates
who have authorization to engage in secondary employment to insure that such employment is not
interfering with the member's responsibilities or obligations to the Department. (1970 Code §3-3.8)
6/5/2019 Sterling Codifiers, Inc.
https://www.sterlingcodifiers.com/codebook/index.php?book_id=502 321/767
4-1-20: PENALTIES AND DISCIPLINARY MEASURES:
A. Penalties: Penalties may consist of the following:
1. Reprimand by the Chief of Police and Board of Fire and Police Commissioners.
2. Temporary suspension during the pendency of charges by the Board of Fire and Police Commissioners
for a period not to exceed thirty (30) days.
3. Suspension for not more than thirty (30) days after hearing duly required by law.
4. Discharge from the Police Department and service of the City, after hearing duly held as required by law.
(Whenever disciplinary action is taken against a member of the Department, such action will be posted on
the personal record).
5. The Chief of Police shall have the right to suspend a subordinate officer for a period not to exceed five (5)
days and shall file a copy of said order of suspension with the Board of Fire and Police Commissioners
the day said suspension is made, and the police officer so suspended shall have twenty four (24) hours
within which to appeal said suspension in writing from the time of receipt of notice of said suspension by
the Chief. The Board shall conduct a hearing on said suspension as in the case of charges having been
filed against said officer. (1970 Code §3-1-17.1)
B. Discipline: A commanding officer is required to report any violation to his immediate superior of the Rules
and Regulations by a member of his command. Civility, sobriety, neatness, punctuality, prompt obedience to
the orders and compliance with the Rules and Regulations is demanded of each member of the Department
whether on or off duty. A superior officer is responsible for bad conditions in his command. (1970 Code §3-
1-17.2)
C. Complaints by Subordinates: A subordinate having a complaint against another member of the Department
for a violation of a rule, or deeming himself aggrieved, shall make a statement thereof under oath, attaching
names of witnesses, and transmit same directly to the Chief of Police who shall take appropriate action.
(1970 Code §3-1-17.3)
D. Preferring and Contents of Charges: Any superior officer may prefer charges against a subordinate for any
one or more of the following offenses:
1. Any violation of these Rules and Regulations.
2. Any order of the Chief of Police or direct order of a superior officer, whether oral or written.
3. Any violation of law including a violation of an ordinance of the City, State statute or Federal statute.
Charges shall specify the rule violated, the general nature of such violation, and the names and
addresses of witnesses. The defendant shall be notified of the contents of charges and shall be requested
to submit a written statement in answer thereto. Charges, together with respondent's statement, if any,
shall be forwarded through official channels of the Board of Fire and Police Commissioners. (1970 Code
§3-1-17.4)
E. Proceedings Before The Fire And Police Commission: Proceedings before the fire and police commission
shall be in accordance with the Illinois municipal code6 and in accordance with the rules and regulations of
the board of fire and police commissioners. (1970 Code §3-1-17.5)
F. Return Of Property: Upon suspension of a member of the department, he shall promptly surrender such
department property in his possession as directed by the chief of police. Said property shall be retained by
6/5/2019 Sterling Codifiers, Inc.
https://www.sterlingcodifiers.com/codebook/index.php?book_id=502 322/767
the chief of police, and returned to the officer when relieved from suspension or restored to duty. (1970
Code §3-1-17.6)
4-1-21: DISPOSITION OF PROPERTY SEIZED UNDER "NARCOTICS PROFIT FORFEITURE
ACT":
A. Generally: All monies and property seized pursuant to the Illinois "narcotics profit forfeiture act" shall be held
and disposed of in accordance with said act and the U.S. "Attorney General's Guidelines On Seized And
Forfeited Property", to the extent that each applies.
B. Holding And Disposition Of Seized Monies: The city treasurer or his/her authorized agent shall establish and
maintain three (3) separate bank accounts. The accounts shall be designated as follows: "pending forfeiture
funds account", "state forfeiture funds account", and "federal forfeiture funds account". The "pending
forfeiture funds account" shall be used for the deposit of monies seized and subject to court order; funds in
that account shall be held therein pending order of court directing their disposition. Funds awarded to the
city pursuant to court order arising out of violation of state drug laws shall be deposited in the state forfeiture
funds account, and the "federal forfeiture funds account" shall be used for the deposit of funds awarded
pursuant to court order arising out of violation of federal drug laws.
C. General Purpose Of Expenditures From Drug Traffic Prevention Fund: Monies ordered paid over to the city
under the act or other antidrug enforcement laws and held in the drug traffic prevention fund account shall
be used solely for enforcement of laws governing narcotics activities.
D. Authorized Withdrawals:
1. Withdrawals from the pending forfeiture funds account, or the state forfeiture funds account, or the federal
forfeiture funds account, may be made only upon written check or other order signed by at least two (2) of
the following: the city treasurer, the city finance director, the mayor, the city administrator or the chief of
police.
2. The police department may maintain a reserve up to two thousand five hundred dollars ($2,500.00) in
cash for authorized use by the investigations division commander, the investigations supervisor and the
investigator. Authorized use shall be limited to expenditures directly related to a narcotics investigation
which cannot feasibly be paid by check such as informant fees and the purchase of narcotics. Said money
shall be kept in the department's safe with a transaction log in which a record of all collections and
withdrawals, including supporting documents shall be kept, and such record shall be forwarded to the
chief immediately after each transaction. Said monies shall be the responsibility of the investigations
division commander or such other person as is designated by the chief of police. These monies shall be
audited on a monthly basis, and the results forwarded to the city treasurer with a copy to the city
administrator on a form acceptable to the city treasurer. (Ord. 09-39-0, 9-23-2009)
4-1-22: DEPUTY CHIEF OF POLICE:
A. Qualifications And Status Of Rank: The deputy chief of police shall be appointed by the chief of police and
may be appointed from any rank of sworn full time officers of the city, and no one who is not a sworn full
time officer of the city may be so appointed. The deputy chief of police shall be an exempt rank immediately
below that of the chief of police. The deputy chief of police shall serve at the discretion of the chief of police,
and shall be suspended, removed or otherwise disciplined by the chief of police, and, if removed from the
position, shall revert to the rank held immediately prior to appointment to the deputy chief position. (Ord. 02-
04-0, 2-13-2002)
B. Compensation: The compensation of the deputy chief shall be, as from time to time, set by the city council.
6/5/2019 Sterling Codifiers, Inc.
https://www.sterlingcodifiers.com/codebook/index.php?book_id=502 323/767
C. Appointment And Eligibility: The chief of police shall have the authority to appoint the deputy chief. The
deputy chief shall be subject to the same resident requirements as applied from time to time to all other city
police officers.
D. Powers And Duties: The deputy chief shall have and perform the following powers and duties:
1. Shall be second in command within the Countryside police department, shall be in command of all police
activities while on duty, subject only to the orders of the chief of police and shall have such authority as
prescribed by the chief of police.
2. General oversight of services and activities of the patrol and support divisions of the department.
3. Direct supervision of the performance of the lieutenants and sergeants in order to guarantee efficient
performance of their managerial duties and assignments, ensure performance standards and cost
efficient assignment of personnel, as well as meeting general department goals and objectives in
providing professional services to the general community.
4. Assist in the development and annual oversight of department budget, meeting annual goals and
objectives in fiscal management and meeting five (5) year plan objectives.
5. Responsible for direct support of lieutenants in meeting department fiscal and service support goals.
6. Assist in identifying and making application for various departmental grants and ensure optimum
performance.
7. Responsible for maintaining efficient and fiscally responsible cross training management duties within the
sergeant and lieutenant ranks.
8. Provide a proactive planning and management approach in the continued support services provided to
the community of Countryside and in identifying the future law enforcement needs of constituents.
9. Perform any and all other duties assigned by the chief of police. (Ord. 01-11-0, 4-26-2001)
4-1-23: DRUG ENFORCEMENT OFFICER:
A. Qualifications And Status: The DEA officer is a specialty assignment to a task force. The DEA officer shall be
appointed and assigned by the chief of police and may be appointed/assigned from any sworn full time
officers within the police department. No person not so maintaining sworn officer status within the police
department may be appointed/assigned as a DEA officer. The DEA officer shall serve at the sole and
exclusive discretion of the chief of police. The DEA officer shall be subject to disciplinary action by the chief
of police. The removal from the appointment/assignment as DEA officer is not to be considered
"disciplinary" in nature in and of itself.
B. Appointment And Eligibility: The chief of police shall have the sole and exclusive authority to appoint/assign
the DEA officer.
C. Powers And Duties: The DEA officer shall have and perform the following powers and duties:
1. Duties and assignments as directed by the chief of police, maintaining primary responsibility for general
investigations directed by thereto.
2. Perform any and all other duties assigned by the chief of police. (Ord. 04-08-0, 3-26-2004)
6/5/2019 Sterling Codifiers, Inc.
https://www.sterlingcodifiers.com/codebook/index.php?book_id=502 324/767
Chapter 2
GENERAL OFFENSES
4-2-1: DEFINITIONS:
For the purposes of this chapter, the following words shall have the meanings given herein. When not
inconsistent with the context, words used in the present tense include the future, words in the plural number
include the singular number, and words in the singular number include the plural number. The word "shall" is
always mandatory and not merely directory.
CITY: The City of Countryside.
INTERTRACK WAGERING: A legal wager on the outcome of a simultaneously televised horserace taking place
at an Illinois racetrack or at a racetrack outside of Illinois.
PERSON: Any person, firm, partnership, association, corporation, company or organization of any kind.
PUBLIC PLACE: Any place where conduct may reasonably be expected to be viewed by others. (Ord. 10-28-0,
5-26-2010)
4-2-2: OFFENSES AGAINST CITY OFFICERS, AUTHORITY:
The following acts shall be prohibited:
A. Resisting Or Obstructing A Police Officer: To knowingly resist or obstruct the performance by one known to
the person to be a police officer, of any authorized act within his official capacity.
B. Interfering With Or Obstructing The Fire Department: To knowingly interfere with or obstruct the performance
by one known to the person to be a member of the Fire Department, of any authorized act within his official
capacity.
C. Impersonating An Officer: For any person, other than an official police officer of the City, to wear or carry the
uniform, apparel, badge, identification card or any other insignia of office like or similar to, or a colorable
imitation of that adopted and worn or carried by the official police officers of the City.
D. Escape From Confinement: It shall be unlawful for any person:
1. To offer or endeavor to assist any person in the custody of a police officer, a member of the police
department or a person duly empowered with police authority to escape or to attempt to escape from such
custody.
2. To make available to, present to, or place within the reach of, any person confined under authority of the
city, any tool, implement or other thing calculated to aid in the escape of such person so confined or any
other person confined under authority of the city.
3. To assist or aid, or attempt to assist or aid any person in the custody of or confined under the authority of
the city, to escape from jail, place of confinement or custody.
4. While a prisoner in the city jail, or in any other place where prisoners are confined, or otherwise in
custody of and confined by the city, to escape, attempt to escape or to assist others to escape or attempt
to escape from such custody or confinement. (Ord. 10-28-0, 5-26-2010)
6/5/2019 Sterling Codifiers, Inc.
https://www.sterlingcodifiers.com/codebook/index.php?book_id=502 325/767
4-2-3: OFFENSES AGAINST THE PERSON:
4-2-3-1: DISORDERLY CONDUCT:
A person commits disorderly conduct when he knowingly:
A. Uses force or violence disturbing the public peace without authority of law.
B. Does any act in such unreasonable manner as to alarm or disturb another and to provoke a breach of the
peace.
C. Assembles with one or more persons for the purpose of using force or violence to disturb the public peace.
D. Fails to obey a lawful order of dispersal by a person known by him to be a peace officer under circumstances
where three (3) or more persons are committing acts of disorderly conduct in the immediate vicinity, which
acts are likely to cause substantial harm or serious inconvenience, annoyance or alarm.
E. Remains in the public way in a manner that blocks customer access to a commercial establishment, after
being asked to clear the entrance by the person in charge of such establishment.
F. Enters upon the property of another and, for a lewd or unlawful purpose, deliberately looks into a dwelling on
the property through any window or other opening therein.
G. Transmits or causes to be transmitted a false police report to any public safety agency without the
reasonable grounds necessary to believe that transmitting such a report is necessary for the safety and
welfare of the public.
H. Calls the number "911" for the purpose of making or transmitting a false alarm or complaint and reporting
information when, at the time the call or transmission is made, the person knows there is no reasonable
ground for making the call or transmission and further knows that the call or transmission could result in the
emergency response of any public safety agency.
I. Transmits in any manner to any police officer, public officer or public employee a false alarm for fire or a
report to the effect that an offense has been committed, knowing at the time of such transmission that there
is no reasonable ground for believing that such fire exists or that such an offense has been committed. (Ord.
10-28-0, 5-26-2010)
4-2-3-2: ASSAULT OR BATTERY:
A. Assault: A person commits an assault when, without lawful authority, he engages in conduct which places
another in reasonable apprehension of receiving a battery.
B. Battery: A person commits battery if he intentionally or knowingly, without legal justification and by any
means: 1) causes bodily harm to an individual, or 2) makes physical contact of an insulting or provoking
nature with an individual. (Ord. 10-28-0, 5-26-2010)
6/5/2019 Sterling Codifiers, Inc.
https://www.sterlingcodifiers.com/codebook/index.php?book_id=502 326/767
4-2-3-3: DISTURBING LAWFUL ASSEMBLAGES:
It shall be unlawful for any person:
A. Religious Worship: To disturb any congregation or assembly for religious worship by making a noise or by
rude or indecent behavior, or profane discourse within such place of worship, or so near the same as to
disturb the order or solemnity of the meeting.
B. School Or Class: While on public or private grounds adjacent to any building in which a school or any class
thereof is in session, to wilfully make or assist in the making of any noise or diversion which disturbs or
tends to disturb the peace or good order of such school session or class thereof. (Ord. 10-28-0, 5-26-2010)
4-2-3-4: FIGHTING:
No person shall fight another person except in boxing exhibitions duly authorized and licensed under law. (Ord.
10-28-0, 5-26-2010)
4-2-3-5: RECKLESS CONDUCT:
A. No person shall recklessly cause bodily harm to or endanger the bodily safety of an individual by any means,
whether they otherwise are lawful or unlawful.
