Chapter 10
FAIR HOUSING
6-10-1: POLICY:
It is the policy of the city that all individuals shall have an equal opportunity to purchase, own, lease, and
occupy housing within the city without being discriminated against based on race, color, religion, sex, national
origin, ancestry, age, marital status, familial status, physical or mental handicap or disability, military status,
sexual orientation, parental status, retaliation, aiding/abetting, wilful interference or legal source of income. It is
also the policy of the city that members of those protected classes shall have the right to be free from
discriminatory practices when engaging in real estate transactions and seeking access to financial credit for
real estate transactions. The city's fair housing regulations shall be consistent with and, in some cases, more
stringent than the provisions of the fair housing act (42 USC section 3601 et seq., as amended) and the Illinois
human rights act. Both laws as used in this chapter shall be identified as the "fair housing act" and the "Illinois
human rights act" without citation to the statutes unless a specific citation is necessary.
Note: For state law authorizing city to prescribe fair housing practices and prohibit unfair housing practices, see
65 Illinois Compiled Statutes 5/11-11.1-1. (Ord. 11-35-0, 5-25-2011)
6-10-2: DEFINITIONS:
For the purposes of this chapter, the following words and phrases shall have the meanings respectively
ascribed to them by this section:
DWELLING: Any building, structure or portion thereof which is located within the city and which is occupied as,
or designed or intended for occupancy as, a residence by one or more families, including any vacant land which
is offered for sale, lease or rent for the construction or location thereon of any such building, structure or portion
thereof.
LENDING INSTITUTION: Any bank, insurance company, savings and loan association or other person
customarily engaged in the business of lending money for profit, and any person normally and customarily in
the business of obtaining, arranging or negotiating loans as agent or broker.
OFFER: Every attempt, by means of written or oral communications, to enter into a real estate transaction, and
every solicitation of an offer.
OWNER: Any person who holds legal or equitable title to, or owns any beneficial interest in, any real property,
or who holds legal or equitable title to shares of or any beneficial interest in any corporation, partnership or
unincorporated association which holds any such title or interest.
REAL ESTATE BROKER: Any person who customarily, as a business and for consideration, on behalf of
himself or others, sells or offers for sale, or buys or offers to buy, or negotiates the purchase or sale or
exchange of, real property, including dwellings, or leases or rents, or offers to lease or rent, real property, or
who negotiates the lease or rental thereof, or who employs any person to act as a real estate salesman to
perform any one or more of the foregoing acts.
REAL ESTATE SALESMAN: Any person licensed or required to be licensed as a real estate salesman in
accordance with the provisions of 225 Illinois Compiled Statutes or any acts supplementing, amending or
superseding such provisions.
6/5/2019 Sterling Codifiers, Inc.
https://www.sterlingcodifiers.com/codebook/index.php?book_id=502 419/767
REAL ESTATE TRANSACTION: The purchase, sale, exchange, lease or rental of any dwelling, and any legally
enforceable option or contract to do any of the foregoing, except the lease or rental of rooms in a dwelling
designed for single-family occupancy, provided the owner of such dwelling maintains such dwelling as his/her
principal place of residence. (Ord. 09-20-0, 5-13-2009)
6-10-3: DECLARATION OF POLICY:
It is the policy of the city to provide, within legal and constitutional limitations, for fair housing practices
throughout the city, with the intention that such practices will protect the interests of buyers and sellers, lessors
and lessees, landlords and tenants, in accordance with the provisions of this chapter. (Ord. 09-20-0, 5-13-2009)
6-10-4: PUBLIC OFFER TO SELL OR OFFER TO PARTICULAR PERSON TO SELL NOT
REQUIRED:
Nothing in this chapter shall require an owner of a dwelling to make a public offer or an offer to any particular
person or persons before selling, leasing or renting such dwelling. (Ord. 09-20-0, 5-13-2009)
6-10-5: OWNER MAY REFUSE TO ENTERTAIN OFFER WHILE OTHER OFFERS PENDING:
Nothing in this chapter shall be deemed to prohibit any owner from refusing to entertain offers for the purchase,
lease or rental of a dwelling, or to negotiate with respect thereto, on the ground that another offer or offers may
then be pending. (Ord. 09-20-0, 5-13-2009)
6-10-6: OWNER MAY GIVE NONDISCRIMINATORY PREFERENCE TO BUYERS, TENANTS,
ETC.:
Nothing in this chapter shall be deemed to prohibit any owner from giving preference to any prospective
purchaser, lessee or tenant for any reason other than race, color, religion or national origin of such prospective
purchaser, lessee or tenant or of any other person. (Ord. 09-20-0, 5-13-2009)
6-10-7: NEGOTIATIONS WITH PERSONS NOT NEGOTIATING FOR OWN ACCOUNT NOT
REQUIRED:
Nothing in this chapter shall require an owner to negotiate respecting a real estate transaction with any person
who does not reasonably appear to be negotiating the same in good faith for his/her own account. (Ord. 09-20-
0, 5-13-2009)
6-10-8: PROPERTY RIGHTS NEITHER CREATED NOR AFFECTED BY CHAPTER:
This chapter is not intended to create any interest in or lien or charge upon any real property or rights therein,
and neither the pendency of any complaint under this chapter nor the finding of the violation of any of the
provisions of this chapter shall invalidate, encumber, impair or affect in any manner any title to or interest in real
property which has otherwise been created, transferred or perfected in accordance with applicable law, or the
legal power of any person to enter into or consummate any real estate transaction which is otherwise in
accordance with the applicable law. (Ord. 09-20-0, 5-13-2009)
6/5/2019 Sterling Codifiers, Inc.
https://www.sterlingcodifiers.com/codebook/index.php?book_id=502 420/767
6-10-9: PENALTY FOR VIOLATION OF CHAPTER:
Any person convicted of a violation of any provision of this chapter shall be subject to a fine of not to exceed
seven hundred fifty dollars ($750.00) for each such violation; provided, that all actions of any one person with
respect to any one real estate transaction shall not be deemed to constitute more than one offense under this
chapter. (Ord. 09-20-0, 5-13-2009)
6-10-10: PROHIBITED ACTS OF BROKERS AND SALESMEN:
It shall be unlawful for any real estate broker or real estate salesman:
A. To make to any party to a real estate transaction any material misrepresentation with respect thereto.
B. To act on behalf of more than one party in any real estate transaction without the knowledge and consent of
all parties thereto.
C. To fail or refuse, within a reasonable time after request, to furnish to any party to a real estate transaction a
copy of any document signed by such party and in the possession of such broker or salesman. (Ord. 09-20-
0, 5-13-2009)
D. To fail or refuse, upon request, to permit any person to examine copies of any listing or descriptive materials
respecting any dwelling which has been publicly offered for sale, lease or rental because of the race, color,
religion, national origin, ancestry, age, sex, marital status, parental status, retaliation, aiding/abetting, wilful
interference or handicap of such person. (Ord. 11-35-0, 5-25-2011)
6-10-11: EMPLOYMENT OF SALESMEN HAVING TWO CONVICTIONS PROHIBITED:
It shall be unlawful for any real estate broker to employ or continue to employ any real estate salesman who is
found by a court of competent jurisdiction to have violated any of the provisions of section 6-10-10 or 6-10-13 of
this chapter more than twice in any period of six (6) consecutive months if such finding is sustained on appeal
or if no appeal is taken from such finding within the period of time permitted for such appeal. (Ord. 09-20-0, 5-
13-2009)
6-10-12: PROHIBITED ACTS OF OWNERS AND LESSEES:
It shall be unlawful for any owner or lessee to fail or refuse:
A. To sell a dwelling which is then being publicly offered for sale; or (Ord. 09-20-0, 5-13-2009)
B. To lease or rent a dwelling which is then being publicly offered for lease or rent, to a person who is ready,
willing and able to purchase, lease or rent the same, as the case may be, and who has made or who
tenders a bona fide offer therefor which is at least as favorable to such owner or lessee as the terms on
which such dwelling is then being publicly offered, or to fail or refuse to negotiate in good faith with any such
person for such sale, lease or rental, but only in each case if such failure or refusal is because of the race,
color, religion, national origin, ancestry, age, sex, marital status, parental status, retaliation, aiding/abetting,
wilful interference or handicap of such person. (Ord. 11-35-0, 5-25-2011)
6/5/2019 Sterling Codifiers, Inc.
https://www.sterlingcodifiers.com/codebook/index.php?book_id=502 421/767
6-10-13: PROHIBITED ACTS OF OWNERS, LESSEES, BROKERS AND SALESMEN:
It shall be unlawful for any owner, lessee, real estate broker or real estate salesman:
A. To refuse to extend to any person, because of the race, color, religion, national origin, ancestry, age, sex,
marital status, or handicap of such person, terms, conditions or privileges in connection with the sale,
leasing or rental of a dwelling, or in the provision of services or facilities in connection therewith, which are
substantially identical to the terms, conditions, privileges and provisions previously extended or offered to
any other person in connection with the sale, leasing or rental of such dwelling. (Ord. 09-20-0, 5-13-2009)
B. To publish or cause to be published any notice, statement or advertisement with respect to the sale, leasing
or rental of a dwelling which states any priority, preference, limitation or restriction based on the race, color,
religion, national origin, ancestry, age, sex, marital status, parental status, retaliation, aiding/abetting, wilful
interference or handicap of such person which is calculated to disclose an intention to make any such
priority, preference, limitation or restriction. (Ord. 11-35-0, 5-25-2011)
C. To misrepresent to any person, because of the race, color, religion, national origin, ancestry, age, sex,
marital status, or handicap of such person, that any particular dwelling is not being offered for sale, lease or
rental, or is not available for inspection for such purpose. (Ord. 09-20-0, 5-13-2009)
D. For profit, to induce or attempt to induce any person to sell, lease or rent any dwelling by means of written or
oral representations or misrepresentations regarding the residence or prospective residence within one
thousand five hundred feet (1,500') of such dwelling of, any person or persons of a stated race, color,
religion, national origin, ancestry, age, sex, marital status, parental status, retaliation, aiding/abetting, wilful
interference or handicap of such person.
E. To enter into any real estate brokerage or listing agreement which prohibits the sale, leasing or rental of a
dwelling to any person because of the race, color, religion, national origin, ancestry, age, sex, marital status,
parental status, retaliation, aiding/abetting, wilful interference or handicap of such person. (Ord. 11-35-0, 5-
25-2011)
6-10-14: PROHIBITED ACTS OF LENDING INSTITUTIONS:
It shall be unlawful for any lending institution to refuse to lend money or extend credit to any person, or to
refuse to negotiate with such person with respect to any such loan or extension of credit, because of the race,
color, religion, national origin, ancestry, age, sex, marital status, parental status, retaliation, aiding/abetting,
wilful interference or handicap of such person. (Ord. 11-35-0, 5-25-2011)
Chapter 11
ACTIVE TRANSPORTATION PLAN
6-11-1: ADOPTION:
A certain document titled the "Countryside Active Transportation Plan", three (3) copies of which are on file in
the office of the city clerk, city of Countryside, is hereby adopted in its entirety. (Ord. 12-12-0, 2-8-2012)

Title 7
PUBLIC WAYS AND PROPERTY
Chapter 1
EXCAVATIONS
7-1-1: PERMIT REQUIRED:
It shall be unlawful for any person, or other entity, unless specifically exempted herein, to tunnel or auger under
or to make any excavation in any street, alley, sidewalk or other public way under the jurisdiction of the city
without having obtained a permit therefor as required herein, or without complying with the provisions of this
chapter, or in violation of or variation from the terms of such permit. (1970 Code §§5-2.01, 5-2.04, as amended;
amd. 1986 Code)
7-1-2: APPLICATION FOR PERMIT:
A. Contents Of Permit: Application for such permit shall be made to the building department, and shall describe
the location of the intended excavation or tunnel, the size thereof, the purpose therefor, the date work is to
begin and the proposed completion date. The application shall also contain an agreement that the applicant
will comply with all ordinances relating to the work to be done. If approved by the building commissioner
such permit will be issued by the building department.
B. Time Limit: Each application for a permit shall state the length of time it is established will elapse from the
commencement of the work until the refill is made ready for the pavement to be put on by the city if the city
restores such surface pavement. It shall be unlawful to fail to comply with this time limitation unless
permission for an extension of time is granted by the city council.
C. Requirement Of Additional Applicants: In each case, application shall be made by not only the person
performing the excavating or tunneling, but also the person for whom the work is being performed. In such
case, the additional applicant will be subject to all of the provisions of this chapter and shall be copermittee
on any permit issued hereunder. Wherever the word "applicant" is used in this chapter, it shall apply to more
than one applicant, where appropriate. (Ord. 11-61-0, 10-12-2011)
7-1-3: ISSUANCE OF PERMIT, EXEMPTIONS:
A. Compliance Required: No permit shall be issued by the building commissioner except upon the applicant's
having met all requirements hereof. (Ord. 11-61-0, 10-12-2011)
B. Exemptions: The provisions of this chapter requiring the securing of permits shall not apply to the following:
the city of Countryside, its officers, agents and employees engaged in doing work for the city; persons or
other entities which are operating under a franchise or grant from the city, which franchise or grant provides
for the making of excavations or tunnels without securing a permit therefor; Commonwealth Edison
Company; Northern Illinois Gas Company; and Illinois Bell Telephone Company. (1970 Code §5-2.14, as
amended)
7-1-4: LIABILITY INSURANCE AND INDEMNIFICATION OF CITY:
6/5/2019 Sterling Codifiers, Inc.
https://www.sterlingcodifiers.com/codebook/index.php?book_id=502 423/767
No such permit shall be issued unless and until:
A. Applicant shall execute a written agreement indemnifying and holding harmless the city against all liability
arising out of the work to be done, on a form to be provided by the city.
B. Applicant shall secure and maintain public liability insurance in an amount of not less than one million dollars
($1,000,000.00) to protect the applicant against all risk of damage or injury (including death) to property or
persons, wherever located, in connection with the work to be performed.
C. All insurance policies shall be issued by a company or companies authorized to do business in Illinois. Each
policy shall contain an appropriate endorsement to save and hold harmless the city from any liability or
damage whatsoever. Certificates of insurance evidencing such insurance endorsement shall be filed with
the city clerk.
D. No change or cancellation in insurance shall be made without the consent of the city council. (1970 Code §5-
2.05, as amended)
7-1-5: BOND REQUIREMENTS:
A. Completion Bond: No permit shall be issued unless and until the applicant has posted with the city clerk a
bond, either in the form of a cash deposit or an irrevocable letter of credit, in the form prescribed by the city,
in an amount which may be required in any particular instance by the city council, but in no case less than
five hundred dollars ($500.00) if no pavement is involved, and seven thousand five hundred dollars
($7,500.00) if a paved area is involved. Such bond shall ensure the proper restoration of the ground and
proper laying of pavement, if any, and shall also ensure submission of an "as built plan" showing all
elevations if required by subsection 8-1-5B of this code. Said bond shall remain in effect until the project has
been properly completed, the "as built plan" has been submitted as required by subsection 8-1-5B of this
code, and the bond is released by order of the city council. (Ord. 05-37-0, 9-14-2005)
B. Default Or Release Of Performance Bond:
1. If the applicant shall have completed the restoration of the ground and laying of pavement, if any, on or
before the scheduled date of completion, and such completion shall meet all requirements of the city, the
city council shall direct the clerk to release said bond.
2. If the applicant fails to complete the project by the agreed upon completion date or fails to complete the
work in accordance with the applicable ordinances and reasonable requirements for the city, the building
commissioner shall so notify the applicant of such deficiencies, and shall advise the applicant that he has
thirty (30) days from the date of receipt of said notice to cure the same. If the deficiencies are not
remedied within said time, the building commissioner shall report the same to the city council which may,
by resolution, find the applicant in default and direct that the work be completed by the city and that the
applicant's bond, or any necessary portion thereof, be applied to the cost of completion.
3. Forfeiture of a bond shall not constitute a waiver of the city's right to collect from the applicant the amount
of a deficiency resulting from the actual cost of completion being in excess of the bond. The city shall
retain the right to use all legal and equitable remedies available to it for collection of such deficiency.
(1970 Code §5-2.07, as amended)
C. Deposit Of Cash Bonds:
1. All cash bonds will be held by the city treasurer.
6/5/2019 Sterling Codifiers, Inc.
https://www.sterlingcodifiers.com/codebook/index.php?book_id=502 424/767
2. In the event of a bond forfeiture, the bond proceeds will be first applied to payment of the cost of
completion, and as much thereof as is not needed to cover the cost of completion will be returned to the
applicant. (Ord. 06-19-0, 5-24-2006)
D. Unclaimed Bonds: Any bond posted with cash pursuant to this section, shall be subject to the unclaimed
bond forfeiture provisions of title 1, chapter 9 of this code. (Ord. 92-29-0, 10-14-1992)
7-1-6: EXCAVATION WORK REQUIREMENTS:
A. Barricades And Lights: Any person making or maintaining any excavation in any street or alley shall keep the
same adequately guarded by barricades and lights to protect persons and property from injury. (1970 Code
§5-2.08, as amended)
B. Manner Of Excavating:
1. It shall be unlawful to make any such excavation or tunnel in any way contrary to or at variance with the
terms of the permit therefor.
2. Proper bracing shall be maintained to prevent the collapse of adjoining ground; and in excavations the
excavation shall not have, anywhere below the surface, any portion which extends beyond the opening at
the surface.
3. No injury shall be done to any pipes, cables or conduits. The applicant shall notify the city department or
officer charged with the care thereof, of any such installations which are or may be endangered or
affected by such excavation or tunnel before such installations shall be disturbed.
4. No unnecessary damage or injury shall be done to any tree or shrub or the roots thereof. (1970 Code §5-
2.09, as amended)
C. Temporary Sidewalks: If any sidewalk is blocked by any such work, a temporary sidewalk shall be
constructed or provided which shall be safe for travel and convenient for users. (1970 Code §5-2.10)
D. Restoration, Resurfacing And Backfilling:
1. The person performing the excavating or tunneling shall restore the surface thereof to its original
condition if there is no pavement involved; or, where an opening has been made in a paved or improved
portion of a public way, the same shall be repaved and the surface relaid in compliance with all city
ordinances, and reasonable requirements, subject to supervision and final inspection by the building
commissioner, or his authorized agent.
2. All openings shall be properly backfilled and tamped down by a hydraulic or pneumatic tamping tool, not
to exceed four inches (4") of backfill at a time. All paved areas and areas extending up to three feet (3')
beyond noncurved pavement shall be backfilled with suitable granular backfill, sand, screenings, grade 14
stone, or the equivalent.
3. All bracing in any tunnel or excavation shall be left in the ground. (1970 Code §5-2.12)
E. Supervision And Final Inspection: The building commissioner, or his authorized agent shall, from time to
time, inspect all excavations and tunnels being made in or under any public way to ensure compliance with
the provisions of this chapter. Notice shall be given to the commissioner, or his agent, at least twenty four
(24) hours before the work of backfilling any such excavation or tunnel commences. Notice shall also be
given to the commissioner, or his agent, when work has been completed so that the final inspection can be
6/5/2019 Sterling Codifiers, Inc.
https://www.sterlingcodifiers.com/codebook/index.php?book_id=502 425/767
made. The building commissioner, or his agent, shall then report the results of such final inspection to the
city council on or before its next regular meeting. (Ord. 11-61-0, 10-12-2011)
7-1-7: EMERGENCY SITUATION:
A. If an individual believes that an emergency exists requiring immediate excavation or tunneling in a public
way, and it is impossible to make application for a permit as provided herein, such individual may cause
such work to commence; provided however, he makes a good faith effort to contact either the mayor, the
building commissioner or the chief of police to advise such official of the emergency situation and obtain that
official's consent to the commencement of work. If such official believes that an emergency exists requiring
such immediate work, he shall give his consent and is specifically relieved from any liability for such
decision made in good faith.
B. Such individual may cause excavating or tunneling work to begin but may be held civilly or criminally liable if
he acts contrary to the decision of the mayor, the building commissioner or the chief of police, or is unable to
show that he made a good faith effort to obtain the consent of one of the aforementioned officers.
C. If work is commenced under this section, the individual who caused such work to begin shall apply for a
permit hereunder as soon thereafter as the city hall is open to receive such application. (1970 Code §5-2.15,
as amended)
7-1-8: PENALTY:
Any person violating this chapter shall be punished according to section 1-4-1 of this code. (Ord. 11-61-0, 10-
12-2011)
Chapter 2
PRIVATE DRIVEWAYS
7-2-1: PERMIT REQUIRED, FEE:
A. Permit Required: No person shall hereafter build, construct, maintain or use any driveway leading from a
public street into abutting property or disturb the sidewalk or make an opening in any street or other public
property for the purpose of constructing or maintaining a driveway without first obtaining a permit so to do
from the building commissioner.
B. Issuance Of Permit, Nontransferability: No such permit shall be issued except as hereinafter provided, and
no such permit shall be transferred or assigned, nor shall any right or privilege thereunder be transferred or
assigned except as hereinafter provided. (Ord. 10-20-0, 4-28-2010)
7-2-2: APPLICATION FOR PERMIT:
Application for a permit for a driveway shall be made to the building commissioner and shall contain the name
and address of the person by whom such driveway is to be used or maintained and the proposed location and
dimensions of such driveway. Plans and specifications of such driveway shall be filed with the building
commissioner. (Ord. 10-20-0, 4-28-2010)
6/5/2019 Sterling Codifiers, Inc.
https://www.sterlingcodifiers.com/codebook/index.php?book_id=502 426/767
7-2-3: REVOCATION OF PERMIT:
Permits issued under this chapter shall contain conditions provided as follows:
A. Such permit may be revoked by the mayor and city council at any time without the consent of the grantee, in
which case the authority and privileges granted shall thereupon cease and terminate.
B. Upon the termination by revocation, expiration or otherwise of the authority, rights and privileges granted by
such permit, the driveway therein authorized shall be removed and the street space where the same shall
have been located shall be restored to its proper condition to the satisfaction of the building commissioner
so that the portion of the street space used for such driveway shall be safe for public use and in the same
condition as the remaining portion of such street and such sidewalk space, at the sole expense of the
grantee therein, without cost or expense of any kind whatsoever to the city.
C. In the event of the failure, neglect or refusal on the part of such grantee to remove and restore such
driveway when directed so to do, the city may proceed to remove and restore the same and charge the
expense thereof to such grantee. (Ord. 10-20-0, 4-28-2010)
7-2-4: INDEMNIFICATION OF CITY:
A. All applicants for a permit for a driveway leading from a public street into abutting property within the
commercial district or the industrial district shall indemnify and save harmless the city from all liability for
damages or expense resulting from or by reason of the granting of such permission or by reason of any act
or thing done by the applicant by virtue of the permission provided for herein.
B. Said applicants shall maintain the driveway, street and sidewalk, as the case may be, in such condition that
the driveway, street or sidewalk shall at all times be safe for public use and shall fully and completely protect
the city against any and all litigation growing out of the granting of such permit and the use of the street for
driveway purposes or anything done under such permit.
C. Applicants shall promptly vacate such driveway upon thirty (30) days' notice from the building commissioner
whenever, in the opinion of the building commissioner, it shall be necessary or advisable to have such
driveway space or any portion thereof vacated in order to provide for the use of such driveway space or any
portion thereof for a public purpose.
D. Upon termination by revocation, expiration or otherwise of the authority, rights and privileges granted by
such permit, applicant shall remove the driveway therein authorized and restore the street pavement,
curbing, parkway and sidewalk space, where the same shall have been located, to its proper condition to
the satisfaction of the building commissioner so that the portion of the street used for such driveway shall be
safe for public use and in the same condition as the remaining portion of such street, at the sole expense of
the grantee therein, without cost or expense of any kind whatsoever to the city. (Ord. 10-20-0, 4-28-2010)
7-2-5: DEPOSIT REQUIRED:
A. No person shall construct a driveway unless the applicant therefor has paid to the city a sum of money
sufficient in its judgment to defray the cost and expense of relaying any sewer, water pipe, street lighting
cable or conduit and the making of any necessary connections between the street pavement and sidewalk.
6/5/2019 Sterling Codifiers, Inc.
https://www.sterlingcodifiers.com/codebook/index.php?book_id=502 427/767
B. Every such applicant disturbing any street for the purpose of constructing a driveway shall, within ten (10)
days after so disturbing it, restore the same to such a condition as will meet the approval of the building
commissioner. When such street is so restored by such applicant, the sum so paid to the building
commissioner shall be refunded by him to such applicant. If such applicant shall fail to so restore the street
pavement or sidewalk or any sewer, water pipe, street lighting cable or conduit to the proper condition within
ten (10) days after the same is disturbed by him, then the building commissioner shall cause the same to be
restored in a manner to meet his approval, and the cost thereof shall be paid out of such sum. (Ord. 10-20-
0, 4-28-2010)
7-2-6: CONVEYANCE OF PREMISES BY PERMITTEE:
Any person to whom a permit shall have been granted under the terms of this chapter, or who has heretofore
given a bond to construct, maintain or use a driveway leading from a public street into abutting property and
who has conveyed his interest in the premises for which such permit is issued, may notify the building
commissioner in writing of such conveyance and furnish to the building commissioner in writing the name and
address of the purchaser thereof. Upon the giving of such notice in writing and furnishing the name and
address of such purchaser, such person may secure from the building commissioner a permit to discontinue the
use of such driveway and to restore the street pavement, sidewalk and parkway in front of such premises in a
manner similar to the adjoining street, sidewalk and parkway. Upon completion of such work to the satisfaction
of the building commissioner, all liability under the bond theretofore given by such person shall cease and
terminate, except as to acts happening or causes of action accruing prior to the removal of such driveway. If,
however, such purchaser shall pay the transfer fee hereinafter provided for and shall execute a new bond
conditioned as aforesaid, a renewal permit shall be issued to such purchaser covering the same driveway
space specified in the original permit, and it shall not be necessary for the person to whom the original permit
was issued to close up such driveway, but the filing of the bond and the securing of a new permit by the
purchaser shall act as a release of liability under the bond originally given in a like manner as if the use of such
driveway had been discontinued to the satisfaction of the building commissioner, except as to causes of action
accruing prior to the filing of such new bond. (Ord. 10-20-0, 4-28-2010)
7-2-7: PAVING OF DRIVEWAYS:
A. Paving Required:
1. Paving Of Driveways Required: From and after 1983, all private driveways constructed within the city
shall be paved in the manner provided in subsection B of this section. Thereafter, the construction of
private driveways with gravel, stone, dirt, clay or any material except as provided in subsection B of this
section is specifically prohibited and no permit shall be issued therefor.
2. Paving Of Parking Areas Required: From and after August 31, 1994, all private parking areas, being any
place upon private property used at any time for the parking of any type of motor vehicle or motor
vehicles, constructed within the city, shall be paved in the manner provided in subsection B of this section.
Thereafter, the construction of private parking areas with gravel, stone, dirt, clay or any material except as
provided in subsection B of this section is specifically prohibited and no permit shall be issued therefor.
B. Methods For Paving: From and after April 22, 2010, all private driveways constructed within the city shall be
paved as follows:
1. Concrete Driveways: All concrete driveways shall be constructed of six (6) bags per cubic yard concrete
mix, shall be of not less than four inches (4") thickness, and shall be poured over a compacted aggregate
base of not less than four inches (4") in thickness.
2. Approachway Aprons: All approachway aprons shall be constructed of six (6) bags per cubic yard
concrete mix, shall be not less than six inches (6") in thickness, and shall be poured over a compact
aggregate base of not less than two inches (2") in thickness.
6/5/2019 Sterling Codifiers, Inc.
https://www.sterlingcodifiers.com/codebook/index.php?book_id=502 428/767
3. Asphalt: All asphalt driveways shall be constructed of not less than two inch (2") minimum compacted
asphalt. For new driveways, said asphalt shall be poured on a compacted stone base of not less than six
inches (6") in thickness. Asphalt driveways constructed upon a bed where a driveway has previously
existed shall be poured upon a compacted granular base of not less than two inches (2") in thickness.
4. Asphalt Approachway Apron: All asphalt approachway aprons shall be constructed of not less than one
and one-half inch (11/2") minimum asphalt binder course with a minimum one and one-half inch (11/2")
asphalt top coat. For new driveways, said asphalt shall be poured on a compacted stone base of not less
than eight inches (8") in thickness. Asphalt driveways constructed upon a bed where a driveway has
previously existed shall be poured upon a compacted granular base of not less than two inches (2") in
thickness.
5. Brick, Etc., Driveways: All brick, concrete paver, concrete stone, paving block and brick paver driveways
shall be constructed of four inch (4") thick units over one and one-half inches (11/2") of fine sand over five
inches (5") of compacted crushed stone granular base (3/4 inch maximum size).
6. Replacement Of Curbs And Gutters: Wherever it is necessary to break out of the existing curb for the
purpose of constructing a driveway, the replacement curb and gutter shall be poured as one unit.
C. Curb Cuts Required: No parking area immediately adjacent to a street and which is accessible directly from
such street without first driving upon any part of an adjacent driveway, shall be constructed without there
being also provided a curb cut from said adjacent street to said parking area. In no case shall a parking area
be reached by driving over a curb.
D. Connection Of Parking Area With Driveway Or Street: No parking area shall be constructed which is not
abutting either an existing paved driveway or a street accessible through a curb cut as required by
subsection C of this section. In no case shall any parking area be reached by driving upon any unpaved
portion of property. (Ord. 10-20-0, 4-28-2010)
7-2-8: PAVING OF PARKWAYS:
It shall be unlawful to pave or place gravel on any portion of the parkways of streets in the city unless said
paving is for a private driveway, as set forth in this chapter. (Ord. 10-20-0, 4-28-2010)
7-2-9: DRIVEWAY AND SIDEWALK TO BE KEPT CLEAN1:
Any person maintaining a driveway leading from a public street into abutting property shall at all times keep
such driveway and sidewalk in connection therewith in good condition and repair and clear and free from all
snow, ice, dirt, filth or other obstructions or encumbrances. All snow which may accumulate on such driveway
shall be removed from the driveway and from the street abutting the premises for which such driveway is
maintained by and at the expense of the person to whom the permit is granted. (Ord. 10-20-0, 4-28-2010)
7-2-10: PROHIBITED ACTS:
A. Use Of Driveway Without Permit: If any person now using or maintaining a driveway leading from a public
street into abutting property shall fail to take out a permit for use as herein provided, then the building
commissioner shall proceed to remove such driveway and close the opening in the pavement in connection
therewith.
B. Prohibited Uses Of Driveway:
6/5/2019 Sterling Codifiers, Inc.
https://www.sterlingcodifiers.com/codebook/index.php?book_id=502 429/767
1. No vehicle parked in a private driveway shall extend beyond the curb line of the street or over the public
sidewalk.
2. Where a driveway is permitted at or near street intersections, where such streets have been established
as through streets, boulevards or stop intersections, no driveway shall be used by vehicles as a means to
avoid observance of the regulations that all vehicles must come to a complete stop before entering a
through street, boulevard or stop intersection.
3. No use shall be made of any driveway except in connection with the use of the abutting property. (Ord.
10-20-0, 4-28-2010)
Chapter 3
STREETS AND SIDEWALKS
7-3-1: ADVERTISING RESTRICTED ON PUBLIC WAYS:
A. Mechanical Devices: No person shall operate or cause to be operated upon any premises within the city, any
talking machine, radio, loudspeaker or other mechanical device for the purpose of advertising any goods,
wares or merchandise, or of attracting attention for any purpose in such a way as to disturb the peace and
good order of society, or disturb the peace of any person in the ordinary conduct of business. (1970 Code
§10-2.01)
B. Throwing Advertising Matter Or Samples: No person shall cast, throw or place or cause to be cast, thrown or
placed:
1. Any advertising matter or samples of merchandise from the streets or sidewalks of the city to or upon
private property. This subsection shall not apply to the delivery of daily newspapers or the delivery of
weekly, monthly or other publications of general circulation. (1970 Code §10-2.02)
2. In, upon or along any of the streets, alleys or public places of the city, any handbills, pamphlets, circulars
or other advertising matter or any samples of merchandise or medicinal preparations, for the purpose or
with the intent of advertising or making known in general or promiscuous manner, any business,
occupation, profession, medical treatment, medicine or any establishment or thing whatsoever. (1970
Code §10-2.03)
C. Affixing Advertisements To Certain Places: It shall be unlawful for any person to nail, paste, post or fasten in
any manner any handbill, sign, poster, advertisement or notice of any kind whatsoever, or cause the same to
be done:
1. On any curbstone, flagstone or any other portion or part of any sidewalk or street or upon any tree,
streetlight post, telegraph or electric light pole, hydrant, bridge, pier or upon any structure within the limits
of any street in the city except such notices as may be required by the laws of the state and the
ordinances of the city. (1970 Code §10-2.04)
2. Upon any private wall, window, tree, gate, fence, advertising board or sign, or upon any other private
structure or building unless such person is the owner, agent or lessee of such wall, window, fence, gate,
advertising board, sign or other private building or structure. (1970 Code §10-2.05)
D. Strings Of Lights: No strings of light bulbs designed to attract attention to any business or commercial
establishment shall be permitted in the city if said light bulbs are visible from any residential dwelling unit or
are visible from any street. This subsection does not prohibit the establishment of electric signs in
conformance with title 8, chapter 5 of this code. (1970 Code §10-2.06)
6/5/2019 Sterling Codifiers, Inc.
https://www.sterlingcodifiers.com/codebook/index.php?book_id=502 430/767
E. Advertising Signs Prohibited: No advertising sign, as defined in section 8-5-3 of this code, shall be permitted
upon any location within the city, and such signs are specifically prohibited. (1970 Code §10-2.07)
7-3-2: PUBLIC WAYS TO BE KEPT CLEAR OF SNOW AND ICE:
A. It is unlawful for any person or other entity engaged in or permitting the removal or plowing of snow and/or
ice from or upon any private property which is used for, or in conjunction with, any business, commercial or
manufacturing purpose to allow any portion of such snow and/or ice to remain upon any public sidewalk, the
paved surface of any public street, or any drive used for access to or from any public street; or further to pile
or allow to be piled any such snow and/or ice to a height or in a location which interferes with the line of
vision of any motorists' or pedestrians' view of oncoming traffic.
B. It shall be the responsibility of the owner of any private property upon which snow and/or ice is removed or
plowed, and the person or other entity removing or plowing such snow, and/or ice to comply with the
requirements of this section, and either or both shall be subject to prosecution for violation of this section
under subsection C of this section.
Further, it shall be the responsibility of any such owner or person or other entity removing or plowing snow,
and/or ice and each of their agents, servants and employees, to comply with, or cause the compliance with,
the requirements of this section, and any or all of them shall be subject to prosecution for violation of this
section under subsection C of this section. (Ord. 87-01-0, 1-28-1977)
C. Any person violating this section shall be punished according to section 1-4-1 of this code. (Ord. 11-61-0, 10-
12-2011)
In addition, the provisions of this section may be enforced by the city through its city administrator, or other
authorized agent, by injunction or temporary restraining order, or other legal remedy. The city shall further
have the right to seek civil damages for any violation of this section.
D. The provisions of this section shall not apply in any case where, because of the absence of a location to
which snow and/or ice can reasonably be removed, it is not possible, with reasonable effort, to comply
herewith. (Ord. 87-01-0, 1-28-1977)
7-3-3: ENCROACHMENTS UPON WILLOW SPRINGS ROAD PROHIBITED:
No person, firm, corporation or other entity shall install, place, maintain or construct any structure that
encroaches upon the state of Illinois right of way on Willow Springs Road within the corporate limits of the city.
(Ord. 87-15-0, 3-25-1987)
7-3-4: DISCHARGE OF SANITARY AND INDUSTRIAL WASTE INTO STORM SEWER OR
DRAINAGE FACILITY ON WILLOW SPRINGS ROAD PROHIBITED:
No person, firm, corporation or other entity shall discharge any sanitary waste or industrial wastewater into any
storm sewer or drainage facility constructed as part of the Willow Springs Road improvement, the limits of said
improvement being between the Fifth Avenue cutoff and 67th Street within the corporate limits of the city. (Ord.
87-16-0, 3-25-1987)
7-3-5: PERMANENT STRUCTURES IN PARKWAYS AND RIGHT OF WAY:
6/5/2019 Sterling Codifiers, Inc.
https://www.sterlingcodifiers.com/codebook/index.php?book_id=502 431/767
Structures of a permanent nature in parkways and rights of way are prohibited.
A. City Not Liable: The city is not liable for damage to illegal or nonconforming structures placed in a parkway or
right of way caused by damage from a snowplow or any other action by the city, its employees, or its
contractors.
B. Effective Date: As of January 1, 2008, illegal or nonconforming structures that are damaged more than fifty
percent (50%) of their replacement value, demolished, or removed shall not be rebuilt, repaired, or replaced
in any prohibited location or manner, regardless of the cause of damage, demolition or removal.
C. Definition: "Prohibited permanent structure" shall include, but not be limited to:
A structure in violation of any of the adopted codes or ordinances of the city of Countryside.
Any structure not specifically allowed or permitted by franchise, license or similar agreement with the city of
Countryside under the provisions of chapter 10 of this title.
Electrical wiring, piping, fixtures, or any electrical component other than required for connecting to the public
utility.
Signs, shelters, enclosures, monuments, bollards, piers, posts, columns, gates, towers, entry structures,
mailbox enclosures or other similar structures.
Underground lawn sprinkler system components.
Water, sewer, or gas piping, fixtures, or any other component other than required for connecting to a public
utility.
D. Permitted Structures:
Bollards, posts, piers, or other guard(s) utilized to prevent vehicles from leaving the street, as authorized by
the city council on a case by case basis, shall not be prohibited.
Cultivated trees, bushes, shrubs, or plants that do not encroach or interfere with the public right of way,
pedestrian, or vehicular traffic shall not be prohibited.
Landscaping features, details or components less than six inches (6") in height above the adjacent grade
shall not be prohibited.
One box for residential newspaper delivery, installed on a post or mounting mechanism that has been tested
in compliance with NCHRP report 350 shall not be prohibited.
One mailbox for U.S. postal service, installed on a post or mounting mechanism that has been tested in
compliance with NCHRP report 350 per mailing address shall not be prohibited.
Other similar structures as determined by the superintendent of public works or the building official. (Ord.
08-03-0, 1-23-2008)
Chapter 4
TREES ON CITY PROPERTY
6/5/2019 Sterling Codifiers, Inc.
https://www.sterlingcodifiers.com/codebook/index.php?book_id=502 432/767
7-4-1: PURPOSE AND INTENT:
A. Purpose: The purpose of this chapter is to provide for the proper establishment of new trees, the protection
and maintenance of existing trees and the timely removal of hazardous, infectious or diseased trees on
property lying between property lines on either side of any streets, highways, and public rights of way; and
on or in any easements, public parks or any other areas owned or under the jurisdiction of the city. In this
regard, the city council finds and declares that:
1. Trees enhance and preserve the air quality of the city through the filtering effect of trees on air pollutants;
2. Trees reduce noise within the city through the baffle and barrier effect of trees on the spread of noise;
3. Trees reduce topsoil erosion through the soil retention effect of tree roots;
4. Trees reduce energy consumption through the wind break and shade effects of trees;
5. Trees provide nesting areas for birds and other wildlife, which birds and other wildlife, in turn, assist in the
control of insects;
6. Trees reduce stormwater runoff and the costs associated therewith;
7. Trees replenish groundwater supplies; and
8. Trees protect and increase property values.
B. Intent: It is the intent of the city council that the terms of this chapter shall be construed so as to promote:
1. The planting, maintenance, restoration and survival of desirable trees, shrubs and other plants within the
city; and
2. The protection of community residents from personal injury and property damage, and the protection of
the city from property damage, caused or threatened by the improper planting, maintenance, or removal
of, or the failure to remove hazardous, infectious or diseased trees, shrubs, or other plants located within
the city. (Ord. 12-11-0, 2-8-2012)
7-4-2: DEFINITIONS:
As used within this chapter, the following terms shall apply unless the context clearly indicates or requires a
different meaning:
CITY PLANTING SPECIFICATIONS MANUAL ("PLANTING SPECIFICATIONS MANUAL"): A manual prepared
by the city's department of public works, which sets forth a plan for the care, preservation, pruning, planting,
replanting, removal or disposition of city trees, shrubs or other plants.
CITY SHRUBS AND OTHER PLANTS: All vegetation other than trees, woody or otherwise, except lawn grass
and flowers less than twenty four inches (24") in height, lying between property lines on either side of any
streets, highways, or public rights of way; or on or in any easements, public parks or any other areas owned or
under the jurisdiction of the city.
CITY TREES: Trees, bushes, and all other woody vegetation on land lying between property lines on either
side of any streets, highways, or public rights of way; and on or in any easements, public parks or any other
areas owned or under the jurisdiction of the city. (Ord. 12-11-0, 2-8-2012)
7-4-3: AUTHORITY TO CARE FOR CITY TREES, SHRUBS AND OTHER PLANTS:
6/5/2019 Sterling Codifiers, Inc.
https://www.sterlingcodifiers.com/codebook/index.php?book_id=502 433/767
A. The city and its authorized agents shall have the right, but not the obligation, to plant, prune, maintain and
remove city trees, shrubs and other plants as may be necessary to ensure public safety, preserve and
enhance the quality of vegetation, and beautify the city. For the same purposes, the city may prune or
remove all portions of any city tree, shrub or other plant or any tree, shrub or other plant on private property
that overhangs any property lying between property lines on either side of any streets, highways, or public
rights of way; or on or in any easements, public parks or any other areas owned or under the jurisdiction of
the city.
B. The city may cause to be removed as soon as practical any city tree, shrub or other plant that is infected,
diseased or dying, or that is hazardous in that it poses an irreconcilable threat to a utility or otherwise
threatens the public health, safety or general welfare. (Ord. 12-11-0, 2-8-2012)
7-4-4: PUBLIC WORKS DEPARTMENT; DUTIES AND RESPONSIBILITIES:
A. The public works department shall have the power to promulgate and enforce rules, regulations and
specifications concerning the planting, pruning, removal, spraying, maintenance and protection of city trees,
shrubs and other plants.
B. It shall be the responsibility of the public works department to study and investigate city trees, shrubs and
other plants, and to annually develop and/or update the city's "Planting Specifications Manual". (Ord. 12-11-
0, 2-8-2012)
7-4-5: INTERFERENCE WITH WORK ON CITY TREES, SHRUBS AND OTHER PLANTS:
It shall be unlawful for any person to prevent, delay or interfere with the city, or any of its agents, while they are
engaging in the planting, pruning, removing, spraying, maintaining or protecting any city trees, shrubs or other
plants, or trees on private property, as authorized in subsection 7-4-3A of this chapter. (Ord. 12-11-0, 2-8-2012)
7-4-6: DAMAGE TO CITY TREES, SHRUBS AND OTHER PLANTS:
A. It shall be unlawful for any person, other than an agent of the city, to cut; carve; break; climb upon; paint;
uproot; remove; attach a rope, wire, sign or any other contrivance to; or in any way injure or deface any city
tree, shrub or other plant.
B. Except as provided in this subsection, it shall be unlawful for any person to cause or allow the topping of any
city tree. "Tree topping" is defined as the severe cutting back of limbs to stubs larger than three inches (3")
in diameter within the tree's crown to such a degree so as to remove the normal canopy and disfigure the
tree. The city may permit the topping of a city tree under exceptional circumstances. City trees that are
severely damaged by storms or other causes, or certain city trees under utility wires or similar obstructions
where other pruning practices are impractical, may be exempted from this restriction upon the determination
of the public works superintendent. (Ord. 12-11-0, 2-8-2012)
7-4-7: VIOLATIONS; PENALTIES:
A. Any person who damages a city tree, shrub or other plant, as provided in section 7-4-6 of this chapter, shall
be held responsible for the costs of any required repairs, such as pruning or cabling, if the injured tree,
shrub or other plant will survive notwithstanding such injuries. In cases where a city tree, shrub or other
6/5/2019 Sterling Codifiers, Inc.
https://www.sterlingcodifiers.com/codebook/index.php?book_id=502 434/767
plant has been damaged beyond repair and cannot survive, the person responsible for such damage shall
reimburse the city for the cost of removal of the tree, shrub or other plant, and any stump.
B. In addition to any fines that may be assessed upon conviction of a violation of this chapter, as set forth in
subsection C of this section, the person responsible for damage to a city tree, shrub or other plant shall pay
to the city a sum equal to the value or partial value of the tree removed as a result of such damage. The
value or partial value of the tree lost shall be as determined by the city using the most current edition of the
"Guide For Plant Appraisal" prepared by the Council Of Tree And Landscape Appraisers, and edited,
published and copyrighted by the International Society Of Arboriculture. Various factors to be used in tree
value calculations for northern Illinois may be obtained from the most current edition of the "Species Ratings
And Appraisal Factors For Illinois" prepared by the Illinois Arborist Association.
C. In addition to any other fees or costs, any person who is convicted of a violation of this chapter shall be
subject to a fine as provided in section 1-4-1 of this code. (Ord. 12-11-0, 2-8-2012)
Chapter 5
CITY PARKS AND FLAGG CREEK GOLF COURSE
7-5-1: DEFINITIONS:
CITY PARK: Any parcel of land owned, maintained, leased or operated for recreational purposes by the city
including, but not limited to, those sites commonly known as Countryside Park, Ideal School Park, Brancato
Park, Hollands Park, City Park and Srjema-Michalek Park.
FLAGG CREEK GOLF COURSE: That certain golf course owned by the city and the Pleasant Dale park district
and situated between Joliet Road, Wolf Road, the Illinois Tollway and Willow Springs Road.
TOT LOT: Any city park or part thereof containing recreational equipment such as slides, swings or other
recreational equipment, set apart, designated and designed for use by children under the age of eleven (11)
years. (Ord. 87-47-0, 9-26-1987; amd. Ord. 93-06-0, 1-13-1993; Ord. 11-61-0, 10-12-2011)
7-5-2: HOURS:
A. Hours Of Operation; Parks: Each city park shall be open daily to the public during the hours of eight o'clock
(8:00) A.M. to ten o'clock (10:00) P.M. (Ord. 08-37-0, 7-23-2008)
B. Hours Of Operation; Flagg Creek Golf Course: Flagg Creek golf course shall be open upon such dates and
at such times as are from time to time determined by its administrative board and posted thereby. (Ord. 93-
06-0, 1-13-1993)
C. Closing Times; Parks: Each city park shall be closed daily from the hours of ten o'clock (10:00) P.M. to eight
o'clock (8:00) A.M. All kiddie or tot lots, skateboard and in-line skating lots are closed at dark. Any park, or
section thereof, may be declared closed to the public by the city council or any authorized agent thereof.
(Ord. 08-37-0, 7-23-2008)
D. Violation Of Closing Hours: It shall be unlawful for any person (other than city personnel conducting city
business therein, or, in the case of Ideal School, school district personnel conducting school business
therein), to occupy or be present in any city park, Flagg Creek golf course, or part thereof, during any hours
in which the park, the golf course, or any part thereof, is not open to the public. (Ord. 93-06-0, 1-13-1993)
6/5/2019 Sterling Codifiers, Inc.
https://www.sterlingcodifiers.com/codebook/index.php?book_id=502 435/767
7-5-3: REGULATIONS CONCERNING USE OF CITY PARKS:
A. Age Limit: It shall be unlawful for any person over the age of ten (10) years to occupy or be present in any tot
lot, unless that person is accompanying a person less than eleven (11) years of age and is responsible for
the well being of the person less than eleven (11) years of age who is using the tot lot.
B. Closing Time: All tot lots shall be closed to the public at dusk and it shall be unlawful for any person to enter
or remain in a tot lot after dusk where the closing time is posted.
C. Penalty: Violation of this section shall be punishable as provided by section 1-4-1 of this code. (Ord. 87-47-0,
9-26-1987)
D. Nonmotorized Wheeled Vehicles In Nonresidential Or Public Park Areas:
1. A person may not ride on or use any nonmotorized wheeled vehicle in a negligent manner on any public
street, alley, sidewalk, public way, or public park in the city of Countryside. For purposes of this section, a
person is guilty of negligent riding or using a nonmotorized wheeled vehicle if the person rides or uses the
nonmotorized wheeled vehicle in a careless or imprudent manner that endangers any property or the life,
safety or person of any individual. Any person using a nonmotorized wheeled vehicle on any public street,
alley, sidewalk, public way, or park shall wear proper protective equipment at all times.
2. For the purpose of this section, "nonmotorized wheeled vehicle" shall mean skateboards, in-line skates,
rollerblades, bicycles, unicycles and any other vehicle with one or more wheel(s) that is propelled by
human power. (Ord. 02-10-0, 3-12-2002)
E. Park Rules:
1. The city does not provide supervision of its facilities.
2. An adult must supervise children under the age of eight (8).
3. Park users/parents assume all risk and responsibility for any injury and should determine that all
conditions are safe.
4. Motorized recreation vehicles are not allowed beyond the parking lot.
5. Golf, fireworks, or other projectiles are prohibited.
6. Littering or dumping is prohibited.
7. Alcoholic beverages are prohibited.
8. Damaging or defacing public property is prohibited.
9. Planting of unauthorized trees or bushes is prohibited.
10. The city of Countryside is not responsible for lost or stolen property. (Ord. 08-37-0, 7-23-2008)
11. The use of bicycles, unicycles, in-line skates, scooters, roller skates, and skateboards on tennis or
basketball courts and gazebos is prohibited.
The use of bicycles, unicycles, scooters, and skateboards on the in-line hockey rink is prohibited. Only the
use of bicycles is permitted on the BMX track. (Ord. 13-61-0, 12-11-2013)
12. When using bicycles, unicycles, in-line skates, scooters, roller skates, and skateboards and other similar
recreational devices, a helmet and other proper protective equipment shall be worn at all times. This
6/5/2019 Sterling Codifiers, Inc.
https://www.sterlingcodifiers.com/codebook/index.php?book_id=502 436/767
includes helmet, wrist/band guards, kneepads, and elbow pads. Skateboards, in-line skates, and
equipment should be in good repair.
13. All animals and pets are prohibited in all parks.
14. Existing park property shall not be moved, relocated, or used for any public use other than its intended
original purpose. (Ord. 08-37-0, 7-23-2008)
15. Grills or open fires are prohibited. (Ord. 13-45-0, 10-9-2013)
16. No person shall use "cigarettes" or "tobacco products" as defined in section 6-9-2 of this code at any
time at any location upon any city park. (Ord. 14-37-0, 9-24-2014)
F. Skatepark Rules:
1. This facility is unsupervised.
2. Skating and in-line skating can be dangerous, causing serious injuries or death. Each person skates at
his/her own risk.
3. An adult must supervise children under the age of eight (8).
4. The city requires a helmet and proper protective equipment to be worn at all times. This includes helmet,
wrist/band guards, kneepads, and elbow pads. Skateboards, in-line skates, and equipment should be in
good repair.
5. Personally owned ramps, boxes, or other devices may not be brought into the park.
6. Inspect the premises before use to make sure it is safe and remove debris that could interfere with safe
use of this facility. (Ord. 08-37-0, 7-23-2008)
7. The use of scooters and unicycles are prohibited within the skatepark. (Ord. 13-61-0, 12-11-2013)
G. Tents:
1. Tents; Exemptions: No tent shall be erected, maintained, operated or used within a city park; provided,
however, that temporary tents may be erected for a period not exceeding two (2) days for religious,
educational or recreational purposes upon applying for and receiving a special event temporary structure
permit from the city building department.
No more than four (4) temporary tent permits shall be permitted within a twelve (12) month period, and a
period of at least seven (7) days shall be required between each permit period.
2. Safety Requirements: The design, construction, maintenance and use of temporary tents shall be
reasonably safe to persons and property and shall comply with the following standards:
a. Tent Tarpaulins: Tent tarpaulins and all decorative materials shall be treated to render the materials
flame resistant for the period for which the permit is granted, in accordance with the provisions of the
city building code and the fire prevention code.
b. Structural Supports: Tents shall be adequately guyed, supported and braced to withstand a wind
pressure of not less than twenty (20) pounds per square foot of projected area. Tent poles shall be
stayed with wire ropes; fiber rope shall be used only for mooring to stakes.
c. Exposed Flames: No gasoline, gas, charcoal or other heating or cooking device or other exposed flame
shall be allowed inside of the tent enclosure.
d. Parking: Parking shall be reviewed by the building department and shall be addressed by the applicant
resulting from the use prior to any approval of the special event temporary structure permit. (Ord. 13-
6/5/2019 Sterling Codifiers, Inc.
https://www.sterlingcodifiers.com/codebook/index.php?book_id=502 437/767
45-0, 10-9-2013)
7-5-4: HOURS DURING WHICH BASKETBALL COURT USE IS PERMITTED:
A. Hours Open: All basketball courts located in city parks shall be open for use between the hours of eight
o'clock (8:00) A.M. and ten o'clock (10:00) P.M. only.
B. Unlawful Use: It shall be unlawful for any person to use any basketball court within a city park at any time
except as provided in subsection A of this section.
C. Penalty: Violation of this section shall be punishable as provided by section 1-4-1 of this code. (Ord. 92-25-0,
7-22-1992)
7-5-5: REGULATIONS CONCERNING USE OF FLAGG CREEK GOLF COURSE:
A. Person Upon Golf Course: It shall be unlawful for any person (other than city, Pleasant Dale park district, or
golf course personnel conducting official business) to be upon any portion of the Flagg Creek Golf Course
premises any time said golf course is closed for the season or for any other reason.
B. Snowmobiles, Other Vehicles: The use of snowmobiles or any other vehicle not authorized by city, park
district, or golf course personnel acting in their official capacities is prohibited.
C. Penalty: Violation of this section shall be punishable as provided by section 1-4-1 of this code. (Ord. 93-06-0,
1-13-1993)
Chapter 6
WATERWORKS SYSTEM
7-6-1: WATER DEPARTMENT ESTABLISHED:
There is hereby established an executive department of the city to be known as the water department. The
mayor and city council are hereby authorized to appoint a superintendent of the water department, and all other
necessary employees, and said superintendent shall have the general management and control of the
waterworks system; subject, however, to the supervision of the mayor and city council. (1970 Code §6-1.01)
7-6-2: CONNECTION TO CITY WATER SUPPLY:
A. Connection Required: Commencing June 1, 1987, and except as specifically provided herein, the use of any
premises within the city which does not obtain its primary water supply from a public water supply system of
the city or other governmental agency is hereby declared to be a nuisance; every sink, water closet or
lavatory connected and used in any building not connected with such a water supply system is hereby
declared to be a nuisance, provided that this section shall be inapplicable to premises where connection
with the water supply system is not feasible. Such connection with the water supply system is hereby
declared to be feasible as to any premises abutting any street or other public way or water main right of way
in which any line of the water supply system exists.
6/5/2019 Sterling Codifiers, Inc.
https://www.sterlingcodifiers.com/codebook/index.php?book_id=502 438/767
B. Time For Connecting To System: Any premises for which connection to a public water supply system is
feasible as of November 1, 1986, shall be so connected on or before June 1, 1987. Any premises for which
connection becomes feasible after November 1, 1986, shall have one year from the date connection
becomes feasible to make such connection. (Ord. 91-09-0, 3-13-1991)
C. Application For Connection, Deposit: No water shall be turned on for use by the city on or in any premises
until an application therefor in writing has been made for that purpose and filed with the city clerk, stating the
purpose for which the water is to be used. The applicant shall deposit with his or her application the sum of
fifty dollars ($50.00) for residential use and seventy five dollars ($75.00) for a commercial use before any
water is turned on. Such deposit shall be held by the city as security for the payment for water used by the
applicant and may be so applied when any default is made in payment of a water bill. The owner of leased
premises shall be responsible to pay all unpaid balances on water bills of owner's tenants. (Ord. 96-44-0,
10-9-1996)
D. Schedule Of Charges: The following schedule of charges for connecting to water mains of the city is hereby
established: (Ord. 03-24-0, 8-27-2003)
1. Connection fees:
